column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/02/russia-and-the-west-compete-to-secure-safe-passage-for-ukraines-grain;2022-06-02;Russia and the west compete to secure safe passage for Ukraine’s grain;Analysis: both sides agree grain must reach world markets soon but each wants to decide how
In a game of diplomatic cat and mouse
column2: Russia and the west are coming up with similar if sometimes competing ideas for how Ukraine’s badly needed grain can be given safe passage through the Black Sea and on to the world markets. They are also competing to win the battle for world opinion if the plans collapse.

column1: Both sides are busy diplomatically across Africa and the Middle East trying to portray their adversary as the culprit for spiralling food and fertiliser prices. Russia and Ukraine export more than a quarter of the world’s wheat
column2: while Russia is the world’s top fertiliser exporter. The World Bank’s Fertiliser Price Index rose nearly 10% in the first quarter of 2022
column3: to an all-time high in nominal terms.

column1: Ukraine’s backlog of 20m tonnes of grain needs to be exported quickly to avoid a further explosion of food prices
column2: and also to preserve the next Ukrainian harvest that currently cannot be sent to already full storage facilities.

column1: That is not possible due to the Russian naval blockade of the Black Sea port of Odesa
column2: and Ukrainian floating mines planted to block the port from Russian attack. Russia
column3: in return for lifting the blockade
column4: wants any sanctions on its shipping and fertiliser products lifted. At issue is whether there is a deal to be done.

column1: In what is beginning to look like the main plan
column2: the Russian foreign minister
column3: Sergei Lavrov
column4: has agreed to meet the Turkish president
column5: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan
column6: but not until 8 June
column7: over proposals for Turkey to de-mine Odesa and then escort grain ships through to the Bosphorous along a naval corridor. Erdoğan spoke with Vladimir Putin about the proposal on Monday
column8: and according to the Turkish read-out
column9: Putin was willing to cooperate
column10: on conditions.

column1: Turkey
column2: through the 1936 Montreux convention
column3: is arbiter of sea traffic in and out of the Black Sea
column4: and justifies its refusal as a Nato member to impose sanctions on Russia by pointing to this unique role. The Turkish foreign minister
column5: Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu
column6: said on Tuesday that food security was the most important question: “We are focusing on this. We are planning to establish a centre in Istanbul to observe the corridor.”

column1: Within Europe
column2: the Italian prime minister
column3: Mario Draghi
column4: has taken the practical initiative
column5: discussing the issue first with Joe Biden a fortnight ago then last week holding talks with the Ukrainian president
column6: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column7: then Putin and then Zelenskiy again.

column1: The Ukrainians have said they are willing to see Odesa de-mined
column2: but conditions would have to be set on how the Russian navy would not use the clearance of mines as an opportunity for its warships to move closer to the port. Ukraine’s foreign minister
column3: Dmytro Kuleba
column4: said: “We must be very careful
column5: because a unilateral guarantee from the Kremlin is not enough. We need third countries to take responsibility for enforcing the agreement.”

column1: Italy and the UK have offered to undertake the de-mining operation
column2: something that could take a fortnight
column3: but Turkey may be Russia’s preferred choice to complete this perilous task.

column1: According to Draghi
column2: Putin has indicated that he would open access to Odesa provided valid checks could be made to ensure the grain ships were not carrying weapons for use by Ukraine. Unresolved issues also exist about the nationality of the ships escorting the convoy
column3: and their terms of engagement if threatened by Russia.

column1: According to Moscow
column2: Putin noted the “readiness of the Russian side” to facilitate the unhindered sea transit of goods in coordination with Turkish partners.

column1: But Russia also wants in return the lifting of western sanctions on Russian fertilisers
column2: something Draghi says is also being urged on the EU by Africa and warrants a second look.

column1: The US is also showing some flexibility. Its ambassador to the UN
column2: Linda Thomas-Greenfield
column3: said the US was prepared to give “comfort letters” to shipping and insurance companies to help facilitate exports of Russian grain and fertiliser.

column1: She insisted that Russian grain and fertiliser were not under US Treasury sanctions but that “companies are a little nervous and we’re prepared to give them comfort letters if that will help to encourage them”. She stressed this was not a bargain to get the Russian blockade of the port of Odesa lifted.
At the moment
column2: the UK and the EU may be heading in contradictory directions by coordinating a ban on insurance for ships carrying Russian oil anywhere in the world. Distinguishing insurance for grain as opposed to oil ships is feasible
column3: but could prove a complicating factor.

column1: One possibility is that Rebecca Grynspan
column2: a senior UN official – recently in Moscow for talks on the issue – could help negotiate a draft security council resolution backing the humanitarian corridor
column3: an idea backed by the French president
column4: Emmanuel Macron. One western official said: “It is unlikely even Russia could veto a resolution to feed the world simply because Russian demands on the lifting of sanctions had not been met.”

column2: but we have a duty to ask ourselves how we can help. How to accelerate
column3: to avoid arriving late.”

column1: However
column2: the UK
column3: Poland and Baltic states are sceptical that Putin will ever agree. Britain backed Lithuania’s proposal for a similar convoy plan
column4: but one that did not depend on Russian cooperation. It proposed a coalition of the willing – not a Nato force – to escort ships.

column3: or on barges down the Dnieper River to Romanian ports and finally via train to Poland. The option of taking grain by train through Belarus looks impossible due to Minsk’s demands for sanctions on potash to be lifted.

column1: At the main crossing point into Romania there is a 20km backlog of trucks waiting to be inspected. A queue of 100 barges were at the Dnieper River waiting to get to the Black Sea. Only seven vessels were being cleared a day.
Apart from the humanitarian necessity to avoid famine

column5: as real and imminent. As one Italian official put it: “We have two weeks left to sort this or we face something very grave.”"

Denmark has voted overwhelmingly to join the EU’s common defence policy
column2: becoming the last of the bloc’s members to sign up
column3: as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine continues to reshape Europe’s security landscape.

column1: The referendum on Wednesday
column2: in which voters backed the government’s proposal by 66.9% to 33.1%
column3: followed historic applications by Denmark’s previously non-aligned Nordic neighbours
column4: Finland and Sweden
column5: to join Nato last month.

column1: Denmark
column2: historically critical of the EU
column3: secured exemptions from joining the common security and defence policy (CSDP) and the euro in a 1993 referendum
column4: but the country’s prime minister
column5: Mette Frederiksen
column6: said it was time to change tack.

column1: “Tonight Denmark has sent a very important signal. To our allies in Europe and Nato
column2: and to Putin
column3: ” she told cheering supporters on Wednesday evening after the result was published.

column1: “We’re showing that when Putin invades a free country and threatens stability in Europe
column2: we others pull together.

column1: “Denmark now can partake in the European cooperation on defence and security. And for that I’m very
column2: very happy.”

column1: Frederiksen called the referendum barely two weeks after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
column2: after reaching an agreement with a majority of parties in the Danish parliament
column3: and pledged to increase defence spending to 2% of GDP
column4: in line with Nato membership requirements

column1: “Nato will of course remain our most important tool

column3: ” the ruling Social Democrats’ defence spokesperson
column4: Mogens Jensen
column5: said. Eleven of Denmark’s 14 parties
column6: representing more than three-quarters of seats in parliament
column7: had urged voters to drop the opt-out.

column1: “The world is changing
column2: and not in a good way. We need to stand together and strengthen the cooperation that strengthens our security
column3: ” said Jakob Ellemann-Jensen
column4: head of the opposition Liberal party.

column1: Participation in the EU’s defence policy will allow Denmark
column2: a founding Nato member
column3: to take part in joint EU military operations
column4: such as those in Bosnia
column5: Mali and Somalia
column6: and will allow Danish officials to stay in the room when EU colleagues discuss defence issues.

column1: EU leaders Ursula von der Leyen and Charles Michel welcomed the result.
Denmark’s decision was a “strong message of commitment to our common security”
column2: Von der Leyen tweeted
column3: saying Denmark and the European Union would benefit.

column1: “This decision will benefit Europe and make both the EU and the Danish people safer and stronger

column1: It would be seen largely as a symbolic win in Brussels

column1: Those opposed to abandoning the opt-out argued that the EU’s defence cooperation is hampered by excessive bureaucracy and inefficient decision-making

column2: if only they could get visas;"Home Office bureaucracy is depriving our economy of highly skilled workers
column3: write Nick Greenberg
column4: Shubham Agarwal
column5: Vathuthita Techataratip
column6: Jun Hatakeyama and Kate Halsted

column1: Under the Homes for Ukraine visa scheme
column2: we have seen many thousands of Britons put their hands up to host Ukrainians fleeing the carnage in their homeland. However
column3: the process to apply has been described by the Ukrainian ambassador to the UK
column4: Vadym Prystaiko
column5: as being “unnecessary
column6: long
column7: [and] bureaucratic”.

column1: The government should realise that there’s more to be gained than the warm fuzzy feeling of a global do-gooder if we prioritise the expedient assistance of as many Ukrainians as possible
column2: as soon as possible.

column1: The combination of EU workers in the UK heading back home post-Brexit
column2: combined with the necessary safety net support provided by the government in the pandemic
column3: has culminated in an unemployment rate of 3.7% in the first quarter of this year. This is the lowest it’s been since 1974
column4: and the first time that there have been fewer unemployed people than job vacancies.

column1: In other words
column2: UK businesses need employees now. And it turns out that there’s an able workforce ready to assist if they could get some help from the Home Office to simplify getting here. They are skilled workers too. In February this year
column3: Ukraine was home to 5
column4: 000 IT companies
column6: 000 developers
column7: 150 fintech companies
column8: five unicorn companies and startups that had secured $1.68bn (£1.35bn) of funding within the first 11 months of 2021. Before the war
column9: Ukraine was positioning itself as a hub for people adept in digital transformation and business innovation.

column1: Surely prioritising and simplifying the process of applying for a visa for people who are highly skilled and desperately in need of our assistance is therefore a no-brainer? Nick Greenberg

column3: Vathuthita Techataratip

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/01/ukraine-steel-boss-at-heart-of-mariupol-defence-says-economy-is-key-to-war-effort;2022-06-01;Boss of devastated Azovstal plant: ‘Steel is as key to Ukraine’s victory as soldiers’;"Yuriy Ryzhenkov’s Mariupol steelworks has been stopped
column2: but his company is leading Kyiv’s economic war against Russia

column1: The Azovstal steelworks in Mariupol has become one of the symbols of the brutality of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Soldiers held out for weeks in the warren of tunnels
column2: warehouses and cooling blast furnaces as they and hundreds of civilians sheltering with them were encircled and eventually forced to surrender.

column1: The site produced 40% of Ukraine’s entire steel output and was the key asset of the country’s biggest pre-war employer
column2: Metinvest. Now its owner has an important role to play in the parallel battle to sustain the economy via its other plants outside occupied territory
column3: according to its chief executive
column4: Yuriy Ryzhenkov.

column1: “The war effort is not only what you supply to the army
column2: but also how [the] economy functions
column3: ” the Metinvest boss says
column4: speaking via video link from a company office in Lviv in the west of Ukraine. “So the better the economy functions
column5: the better the country can fight a war. In our view
column6: in my personal view
column7: the people who are now at our steel mills are just as important to the victory of Ukraine as the soldiers on the frontline.”

column1: Ryzhenkov was in the capital
column2: Kyiv
column3: when he first heard Russian weaponry signalling the start of the invasion
column4: and was stunned that Vladimir Putin’s regime would launch open warfare. The company has since adjusted to operating in a warzone
column5: but at least 153 Metinvest employees have died in the fighting.

column1: Beyond keeping money flowing through the economy
column2: the metals and mining group is playing a direct role in the war effort
column3: delivering steel for 1
column4: 500 bulletproof vests a week to Ukraine’s armed forces
column5: and importing military equipment such as drones
column6: night-vision headsets and helmets.

column1: It is a remarkable shift for a company whose main shareholder – Ukraine’s richest man
column2: Rinat Akhmetov – was as recently as November cited by the president
column3: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column4: as a target to be recruited to back a possible coup attempt. Zelenskiy said Akhmetov was not involved in the plot
column5: and the oligarch said claims of moves to draw him in were “an absolute lie”.

column1: Akhmetov
column2: who has links to the UK including past property investments in London
column3: has remained hugely powerful under successive Ukraine administrations
column4: both pro- and anti-Moscow
column5: and has swung behind the current government
column6: saying his allegiance is only to Ukraine and that Russian soldiers should be punished
column7: adding that he would dedicate his wealth to rebuilding the country.

column1: Ryzhenkov says he is in regular contact with Akhmetov as well as the Kyiv government
column2: but insists the company is not involved with the “political issues” of its owner. “We’re working as a single team towards Ukrainian victory.”

column1: Before the war
column2: Azovstal employed 35
column3: 000 people
column4: producing 9.5m tonnes of steel a year – two-thirds of Metinvest’s output. That has all stopped. Given the scale of the human lives lost
column5: it can be jarring to talk about quotidian business matters. Ryzhenkov raises an eyebrow when asked what Metinvest’s output will be this year
column6: but responds that it will be down at least 60% compared with 2021.

column1: Yet there has been “help from the market” in the form of strong steel prices
column2: which have lessened the blow to the company’s finances
column3: which were in any case in relatively good shape before the February invasion began
column4: with cash balances high. Ryzhenkov says the company’s focus around Mariupol has now turned to providing temporary food and shelter for more than half of the workforce who have already left the city. Metinvest is running a “humanitarian hub” in the south-eastern city of Zaporizhzhia
column5: offering medics and psychological help for adults and children.

column1: Yet he estimates that 50
column2: 000 of its employees are still working in the country. Two more blast furnaces in Zaporizhzhia and the city of Kamianske to the north are working at about 50% and 60% capacity respectively
column3: with most products going to European markets or ports. Iron ore mining facilities in Ukraine are operating at around 35% to 40% capacity
column4: and a coking coalmine is at about 75%.

column1: Running a humanitarian operation alongside one of the country’s largest businesses during wartime is not something most chief executives face
column2: but Metinvest has had some preparation. It was forced to move its headquarters from Donetsk after Kremlin-backed separatists first invaded Ukraine’s east in 2014 and turn more towards European markets and non-Russian suppliers for fuel where possible. Then
column3: in the pandemic
column4: it implemented remote working for all eligible staff.

column1: The issue is getting the goods to customers. There has been “quite a significant slowdown in the flow of goods”
column2: Ryzhenkov says. Ukraine and EU governments could step in to provide subsidies for transport
column3: he suggests. The situation for food exports is of particular urgency
column4: not just for Ukrainians
column5: but for poorer consumers of imported wheat around the world.

column1: “It is a big concern
column2: ” he says. “Logistics is the key bottleneck right now for many Ukrainian businesses. The government is trying to restart the economy
column3: but without resolving these logistical difficulties
column4: it’s going to be very difficult. We are concerned about the speed at which these bottlenecks are being ‘debottlenecked’.” Reopening Black Sea ports at Mariupol and Odesa is “the key for economy restart”
column5: he adds.

column1: Efforts to increase exports via rail are complicated by the different railway gauges used in Ukraine and Poland
column2: so Metinvest has set up reloading centres in Poland and Slovakia to move products more quickly on to Europe-compatible trains. There is a limit to what can be taken by road
column3: and Ukraine is struggling with severe lack of fuel. Ryzhenkov says government efforts to cap prices have worsened the shortage instead.

column1: From the images of Azovstal’s destruction that filtered out – some of them truly extraordinary – it seems like there cannot be much of it left
column2: but the Metinvest boss cautions that the pictures could be “misleading”
column3: with many showing less important auxiliary units
column4: not the key blast furnaces.

column1: The brutality of the battle for Mariupol has contributed to international isolation of Russia. (Ryzhenkov praised Boris Johnson’s backing for Ukrainian victory
column2: saying the UK prime minister was sending a “very powerful message
column3: and we can hear it and feel it”.) Putin’s apparent aim was to control Ukraine
column4: but the invasion has prompted Metinvest and many other key parts of the economy to turn decisively away from Moscow.

column1: The company is even looking at options to produce more steel in the EU using Ukrainian commodities and Ryzhenkov hopes that Russian steel exports will be targeted by sanctions.
Links with Russia of any kind are off the cards for the “foreseeable future”
column2: he says
column3: and Metinvest will “absolutely not” operate from Russian-controlled territory. “Until [the] Russian regime changes
column4: I don’t see how that can be restored.”"

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jun/01/himars-what-are-the-advanced-rockets-us-is-sending-ukraine;2022-06-01;Himars: what are the advanced rockets US is sending Ukraine?;"High Mobility Artillery Rocket System can hit Russian targets up to 50 miles (80km) away
column2: helping to ‘even the playing field’

column1: Joe Biden has announced the US will send advanced missile systems to Ukraine. The new weapon is the Himars multiple launch rocket system
column2: or MLRS: a mobile unit that can simultaneously launch multiple precision-guided missiles.

column1: Both Ukraine and Russia already operate MLRS
column2: but Himars has superior range and precision.

column1: The M142 Himars system (High Mobility Artillery Rocket System) is a modernised
column2: lighter and more agile wheel-mounted version of the track-mounted M270 MLRS developed in the 1970s for US and allied forces.

column1: The Himars that Washington is providing to Ukraine will have a range of about 50 miles (80km)
column2: a US official told reporters.

column1: Himars units carry one preloaded pod of six 227mm guided missiles (the M270 carries two pods)
column2: or one large pod loaded with an Army Tactical Missile System (ATACMS) tactical missile. The US will not supply Ukraine with the ATACMS
column3: which has a range of 300km.

column1: With a small crew
column2: the Himars can remove a spent pod and load a fresh one in minutes
column3: without other vehicles helping. The crews will require some training.

column1: The US military already has Himars units in Europe; and Nato allies Poland and Romania have acquired the systems.
Himars will give Ukraine’s forces the ability to strike further behind Russian lines
column2: and at distances better protected from Russia’s own long-range weaponry.

column1: The GPS-guided missiles the Himars shoots have a range about double that of the M777 howitzers that the US recently supplied to Ukraine forces.
At roughly 80km it generally puts Himars out of range of Russia’s own artillery
column2: while placing the Russian batteries at risk.

column1: It also could threaten Russian supply depots
column2: amid western belief that the Russian forces suffer logistical problems.

column1: Some analysts have said Himars can be a “game-changer” in the war at a time when Ukraine forces appear to be struggling under Russian artillery fire.
But others say Himars will not suddenly turn the tables. “The Himars would even the playing field
column2: ” a senior US defence official said.

column1: The US president wrote in the New York Times that the advanced rockets will enable the Ukrainians “to more precisely strike key targets on the battlefield in Ukraine”.
Yet the US plans to limit the range of the missiles it gives Ukraine to avoid them being used to hit targets deep inside Russia.
“We are not going to send to Ukraine rocket systems that can strike into Russia
column2: ” Biden said.

column1: Since Russia invaded on 24 February
column2: the US has been sensitive about taking any action to support Kyiv that might provoke Moscow to take the war beyond Ukraine’s borders.

column1: That has included not overtly backing Ukraine strikes inside Russian territory. Several times Ukraine has used its own rockets
column2: drones and helicopters to hit nearby Russian targets in neighbouring Kursk and Belgorod oblasts.

column1: If the US provided ATACMS
column2: they would theoretically have the ability to strike major Russian urban centres and military bases
column3: including airfields from where attacks on Ukraine are launched.

column1: “[The] Ukrainians have given assurances they will not use these systems against Russian territory
column2: ” a US official said."

column2: if belated

By this point Russian troops had practically encircled the city and its port on the Bug River. They had seized Mykolaiv’s airport and were advancing from the north-east. “I was the last car in

column3: after he had failed in his original goal of toppling Kyiv’s government to return Ukraine to Russian influence and to demonstrate Moscow’s military invincibility.

column1: A member of the liberal pro-European Golos party
column2: he praised the UK
column3: US and Poland: “We love Boris Johnson. Britain is a country which has clearly stated its position. It stands by its values. It is not afraid of the Russia Federation. We have several British volunteers who are fighting with us. The whole civilised world is fighting Russia

column1: He was less enthusiastic about Germany and France. “Some of our partners are behaving very cautiously. It’s inexplicable. They are not calling out the enemy. We are fighting totalitarianism

column1: Mykolaiv’s inhabitants
column2: meanwhile
column3: have got used to thunderous booms
column4: which shake the city on an hourly basis. For more than a month there was no water after a pipeline was destroyed. Last week a supply for washing was finally reconnected. There is no drinking water. It is delivered to the city
column5: a major shipbuilding centre in USSR times
column6: in large plastic bottles. About 40% of its population have left.

column1: A humanitarian aid point has been set up in a crumbling 200-year-old theatre and concert hall once used by naval officers. There are supplies of clothes
column2: shoes and medicines. Residents fill in a form explaining what they need. Viktoria Veselovska
column3: a journalist working in a pop-up basement pharmacy
column4: said she had no mosquito repellant. “Insects are a big problem for our soldiers
column5: ” she said.

column1: Morale among those who have decided to remain in shell-battered Mykolaiv appears high. Olga Pidsosonna
column2: a volunteer and major in the port’s customs department
column3: described the war as “one very long bad day”. “Russia is trying to eat us. But it will break its teeth. We are a very strong nation. I’m proud to be Ukrainian and I’m proud of our army and our volunteers
column4: ” she said.

column1: In peacetime 10 cargo ships a day would leave Mykolaiv’s harbour
column2: she said. Most exported grain. Russia’s naval blockade of the Black Sea meant the port was inoperative. A Ukrainian victory should include Crimea
column3: “stolen by the Kremlin in 2014”
column4: Pidsosonna said
column5: adding: “I have relatives in Crimea. They want to be back with Ukraine. They can’t say this openly
column6: of course. They are afraid.”

column1: Few people in this city of half a million expected to find themselves living in an old-school war zone. One person not surprised by how 2022 turned out was Makar Kostiuk
column2: a student from Vladivostok. Kostiuk volunteered in the local office of the Russian opposition leader
column3: Alexei Navalny. He left the country for Ukraine before Navalny was arrested and jailed.

column1: “When the bombs started falling I was working on my second novel. The explosions made me type faster
column2: ” Kostiuk said. Shrapnel landed in his courtyard
column3: punching a hole in the glass on the stairwell. Kostiuk said he had not encountered any anti-Russian prejudice. But his bank cards had been blocked and he was likely to have to leave Ukraine in the summer when his residency permit ran out.

column1: Many shops on Mykolaiv’s main street
column2: Sobornaya
column3: were boarded up. Tinned music played from loudspeakers attached to maple trees. A few people were out shopping and a man in Lycra rode past on his mountain bike. A lot of destruction was visible. An airdropped bomb had flattened the Ingul hotel. In March the Russians fired a cruise missile at the regional administration building
column4: killing 12 and wounding 33.

column1: Nobody knows when the Ukrainian army will be able to take back Kherson
column2: which was overrun in the first days of the invasion. The Kremlin says the area now belongs to Russia. It recently prohibited residents from fleeing and has mined the road leading to Mykolaiv. Plans to hold a “referendum” on joining Moscow have been put on hold because of a lack of public support. “Ninety-nine per cent of the country does not want Russia
column3: ” the MP said.

column1: Kostenko gave the Guardian a souvenir: a jagged fragment from a Russian Kalibr warhead
column2: which he wrapped up carefully in kitchen roll. “Victory now depends on our international friends
column3: ” he said. “We have plenty of kalashnikovs and machine guns. If we get enough heavy arms Russia will not be able to go any further.” He stressed: “The west can change the outcome of this war.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/africa-warns-of-food-crisis-due-to-russian-blockade-of-ukraines-ports;2022-05-31;Africa warns of food crisis due to Russian blockade of Ukraine’s ports;"African Union chair calls on EU leaders to do all they can to release grain stocks amid ‘perfect storm’ for global supply chain
The African Union has warned EU leaders that Moscow’s blockade of Ukraine’s ports risks “a catastrophic scenario” of food shortages and price rises.
Senegal’s president
column2: Macky Sall
column3: who chairs the union
column4: said “the worst is perhaps ahead of us” if current global food supply trends continue.

column1: Speaking via video link to the 27 EU leaders meeting in Brussels
column2: Sall said African countries had been hit hard by the global food crisis
column3: because of their “strong dependence” on Russian and Ukrainian wheat. The situation was “worrying” for a continent that has 282 million people that did not get enough to eat
column4: he said.

column1: “In the immediate future
column2: we would like everything to be done to release available grain stocks and ensure transport and access to the market
column3: to avoid a catastrophic scenario of shortages and generalised high prices
column4: ” Sall said.

column1: Before the war
column2: African countries imported 44% of their wheat from Ukraine and Russia. Ukraine alone grew enough food for 400 million people.

column1: Russia’s blockade of Ukrainian ports is contributing to what analysts have called a “perfect storm” for global food supplies
column2: as farmers face rising oil and fertiliser costs and the lingering effect of coronavirus labour restrictions. Drought is also threatening to reduce wheat harvests in countries including France
column3: the US and India.

column1: Proposals to end the blockade have been made. The French president
column2: Emmanuel Macron
column3: said on Tuesday that he and the German chancellor had put to Vladimir Putin ending the blockade under the terms of a UN resolution. The Turkish foreign minister
column4: Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu
column5: said his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov will visit next week for talks to address among other things opening a Black Sea corridor for Ukrainian grain exports.

column1: The head of the UN World Food Programme
column2: David Beasley
column3: warned earlier this month that nearly 49 million people in 43 countries were on the edge of famine. “In many countries we are forced to make the heartbreaking decision to take food from hungry children to give it to starving children
column4: ” he said.

column1: Sall said the price of fertiliser was now three times higher than in 2021
column2: while cereal yields in Africa were forecast to be 20-50% lower this year.

column1: He also blamed EU sanctions on Russian banks for exacerbating the problem: “When the Swift system is disturbed
column2: this means that even if the products exist
column3: payment becomes more complicated
column4: even impossible.”

column1: The EU has cut some of Russia’s largest banks out of the Belgian-headquartered Swift interbank messaging system
column2: making it almost impossible to do business with them.

column1: The African Union leader said he supported proposals for the UN to coordinate efforts to release supplies from Ukrainian ports.
Lithuania has proposed that a naval “coalition of the willing” should lift the Black Sea blockade. Under the Lithuanian plan
column2: the UN would call on Russia to ensure safe passage for ships and Ukraine to remove mines from the port of Odesa
column3: a defensive measure to protect the strategic site.

column1: After the talks with Sall
column2: the president of the European Council
column3: Charles Michel
column4: tweeted: “Russia is using food as weapon of war. Destroying crops
column5: blocking tonnes of grain
column6: risking global famine. EU is sparing no efforts to free Ukraine’s exports over land and exploring alternative sea routes.”

column1: And in a press conference
column2: Michel said opening the Black Sea maritime route “should be the first priority … but we are not certain it will work”.

column1: The European Commission wants to get 20m tonnes of wheat out of Ukraine before the end of July
column2: half of the amount currently stuck in the country. But finding alternatives to sea transport is a huge logistical challenge
column3: as trucks and trains cannot take the same quantity of goods
column4: and face an average wait of 16 days to cross the EU border.

column1: The EU is attempting to help firms create alternative routes
column2: so-called “solidarity lanes”
column3: but senior EU officials have described this as a “gigantic” task. The EU transport commissioner
column4: Adina Vǎlean
column5: said earlier this month that “an astonishing 10
column6: 000 barges and almost 300 large ships are needed to carry 20m tonnes of grains” if it is to be exported via alternative EU ports.

column1: Some EU diplomats believe Russia wants to add fuel to the fire of a global food crisis
column2: with the aim of stoking a wave of migration from the Middle East and Africa that could destabilise European countries.

column1: Moscow has blamed the global food crisis on western sanctions. Lavrov
column2: said on Tuesday his country would guarantee “free export of Ukraine grain by ships that are now locked in Ukrainian ports” if Ukraine removed mines from its coastal waters.

column1: He said western countries had created “a flurry of artificial problems” by closing their ports to Russian vessels
column2: a sanction passed by the EU and the UK."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/ukraine-jails-two-russian-soldiers-shelling-villages;2022-05-31;Ukraine jails two Russian soldiers for shelling villages;"Each sentenced to over 11 years for ‘violating laws and customs of war’ after firing missiles at civilian areas
Two Russian soldiers have each been sentenced to more than 11 years in jail after a court in central Ukraine found them guilty of firing artillery at civilian areas.
The verdict after the trial in the Poltava region came one week after another court in the capital
column2: Kyiv
column3: gave a 21-year-old Russian soldier a life sentence – the country’s first judicial reckoning on Russia’s invasion.

column1: The servicemen convicted on Tuesday
column2: Alexander Bobikin and Alexander Ivanov
column3: were handed sentences of 11 years and six months under legislation against “violating the laws and customs of war”.

column1: They were found guilty of firing Grad missiles on two villages in the north-eastern Kharkiv region in the early days of the war. The Interfax news agency reported that both previously pleaded guilty.
It said their legal defence had requested a more lenient sentence
column2: claiming the soldiers had been following orders and acting under duress.

column1: The verdicts this month against Russian servicemen are expected to be the first in a wave of trials. Ukraine says it has already opened thousands of war crime investigations since the Russian president
column2: Vladimir Putin
column3: sent in his troops.

column1: Rights organisations have voiced hope that Ukraine’s trials of Russian soldiers will be impartial and transparent. After the conviction in Kyiv of 21-year-old Vadim Shishimarin
column2: the Kremlin said it had not received any information about his case while his trial was under way. Ukrainian lawyers representing the Russian servicemen say they have not been in contact with legal or military officials in Moscow.

column1: Ukraine has identified several thousand suspected war crimes in the eastern Donbas region where Russian forces are pressing their offensive
column2: Kyiv’s chief prosecutor separately said on Tuesday.

column1: “Of course we started a few thousand cases about what we see in Donbas
column2: ” the prosecutor general
column3: Iryna Venediktova
column4: told a news conference in The Hague as she met international counterparts.

column1: “If we speak about war crimes
column2: it’s about possible transfer of people; we started several cases about possible transfer of children
column3: adult people to different parts of the Russian Federation
column4: ” she said. “Then
column5: of course
column6: we can speak about torturing people
column7: killing civilians and destroying civilian infrastructure.”

column1: Ukrainian authorities did not have access to Russian-held areas of Donbas but they were interviewing evacuees and prisoners of war
column2: Venediktova told the press conference at the headquarters of the EU judicial agency
column3: Eurojust.

column1: In total
column2: Ukraine had identified 15
column3: 000 war crimes cases across the country since Russia’s invasion on 24 February
column4: she added.

column1: Ukraine had identified 600 suspects for the “anchor” crime of aggression
column2: including “high level of top military
column3: politicians and propaganda agents of Russian Federation”
column4: the prosecutor general said.

column1: Nearly 80 suspects had been identified for alleged war crimes that had actually taken place on Ukrainian soil
column2: she added."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/whats-next-for-ukraine-after-russias-donbas-offensive;2022-05-31;What’s next for Ukraine after Russia’s Donbas offensive?;"Analysis: Indiscriminate tactics of Russia’s grinding progress in east could characterise next phase of war
The recent Russian advances in the Donbas lead to an inevitable question: whether the indiscriminate tactics the Kremlin deployed there will be a template for future offensives.
With reports of large numbers of troops
column2: artillery and rocket launchers mustering across the border near the Russian city of Kursk – in an area that borders Ukraine’s Sumy province – it is an urgent issue.

column1: While much has been made of the painfully slow and grinding pace of Russia’s recent offensive in the Donbas
column2: the speed of territorial gains is not the only metric.

column1: The Russian tactics that have shaped the battle in the Donbas have also posed a brutal dilemma for Ukraine’s defenders – to hold their ground amid rapidly mounting casualties
column2: or withdraw and risk giving the attackers momentum.

column1: While other parts of the 300-mile frontline in Ukraine’s east lack some of the same vulnerabilities that existed around Sievierodonetsk – which sat in the midst of a Ukrainian salient that Russia exploited – in any future offensive the Kremlin is likely to offer Kyiv the same hard choices
column2: attempting to stretch its ability to respond.

column1: Perhaps the first and most pressing issue – if and when Russian forces fully take Sievierodonetsk – is whether they then attempt to cross the Siverskyi Donets River
column2: after disastrous attempts at crossing elsewhere were targeted by Ukrainian artillery with deadly effect.

column1: Whether or not Russian forces attempt to cross the Siverskyi Donets River – a natural barrier – at Sievierodonetsk or elsewhere within Ukraine
column2: Russian forces appear to be preparing for a fresh push farther north amid evidence that they are regrouping near the Ukrainian town of Izium to renew their stalled efforts against Slovyansk
column3: rebuilding a railway bridge near Kupyansk to facilitate the movement of troops and equipment to the area.

column1: What is more difficult to assess is the level of attrition inflicted on both sides
column2: and what impact that will have on further offensives and Ukraine’s ability to defend and counterattack.

column1: While the UK’s Ministry of Defence has made much of Russian losses throughout the war – most recently the mounting casualties among junior officers – Russian gains in the Donbas appear to tell a different story
column2: for now at least. Increasing anecdotal evidence suggests that Ukraine has suffered heavy casualties during recent fighting in the east
column3: largely from shrapnel
column4: and there are reports of equipment and supply issues.

column1: What may well be true is that despite evidence of fresh Russian preparations
column2: the difficulty of the fighting and heavy losses may limit Russia’s ambitions beyond controlling the Donbas
column3: the south and its key coastline.

column1: “After almost a hundred days of war
column2: ” Michael Clarke of the Royal United Services Institute wrote in the Times earlier this week
column3: “the Russian offensive in Ukraine is finally beginning to look more coherent
column4: if not yet strategically wise or sustainable.”

column1: Predicting a prolonged war
column2: however
column3: the former Australian general Mick Ryan disputed the notion that either Russia or Ukraine was close to exhaustion in a lengthy Twitter thread examining the current military position and likely trajectory.

column1: “In April and early May
column2: after Ukraine’s victory in the battle of Kyiv
column3: a degree of triumphalism crept into Ukraine war narratives. But as the Russians have shown recently
column4: by concentrating their forces on smaller regions of Ukraine
column5: they can generate tactical victories
column6: ” he said.

column1: “Neither belligerent has demonstrated the capacity to land a strategically decisive blow against the other. Despite the Ukrainians demonstrating superiority in global influence
column2: strategy and leadership
column3: the Russians keep generating the combat power to attack them in the east.

column1: “Despite the Russians and Ukrainians losing people and equipment in the hundreds (if not thousands)
column2: neither are exhausted nations. The Russians have reserves of manpower and equipment in storage. Ukraine has masses of military aid flowing across its borders.”

column1: In spite of continuing Russian shelling around Kharkiv and in the south around Kherson
column2: where two limited Ukrainian counteroffensives have stalled
column3: the Russian objective in both those areas – according to the Ukrainian general staff – is to consolidate defences and supply lines and to disrupt Ukrainian forces where they have managed to advance.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: however
column3: as the US-based thinktank the Institute for the Study of War suggests: “Russian advances remain limited and are unlikely to increase in pace in the near term
column4: particularly as Russian forces continue to prioritise assaults on Sievierodonetsk at the cost of other lines of effort.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/scorpions-say-they-changed-wind-of-change-lyrics-as-they-romanticised-russia;2022-05-31;Scorpions say they changed Wind of Change lyrics as song ‘romanticised Russia’;"German rockers’ most famous song now includes lyrics: ‘Now listen to my heart / It says Ukrainia’

The lead singer of the German hard rockers Scorpions has revealed he changed the lyrics of Wind of Change because he no longer wanted to “romanticise Russia” with his chart-topping perestroika power ballad
column2: after Putin’s war of aggression in Ukraine.

column1: “To sing Wind of Change as we have always sung it
column2: that’s not something I could imagine any more
column3: ” Klaus Meine told Die Zeit. “It simply isn’t right to romanticise Russia with lyrics like: ‘I follow the Moskva / Down to Gorky Park … Let your balalaika sing’”.

column1: Instead
column2: he said
column3: his band had decided to change the words to their most famous song during their ongoing US and European tour
column4: which opened in Las Vegas on 26 March
column5: a month after the start of the invasion.

column1: The revised lyrics
column2: projected on to a screen behind the band
column3: say: “Now listen to my heart / It says Ukrainia / Waiting for the wind to change.”

column1: Even though the song was released over a year after the fall of the Berlin Wall
column2: in December 1990
column3: it is widely remembered as the soundtrack to the era of economic and social changes in the former Soviet Union that heralded the end of the cold war.

column1: Scorpions performed Wind of Change at the Brandenburg Gate on the 10th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1999
column2: and it was voted song of the 20th century by viewers of the public broadcaster ZDF in 2005.

column1: Meine
column2: who wrote the music and lyrics for the hard rock band’s uncharacteristic ballad
column3: said he composed the words on 3 and 4 September 1989
column4: after Scorpions had performed at the Moscow Music Peace festival in mid-August.

column1: More recently
column2: Wind of Change was the subject of a playful eight-part podcast series in which the investigative journalist Patrick Radden Keefe tried to chase down a rumour that the anthem had in fact been written by the CIA
column3: without unearthing any substantial evidence for the theory. In his interview with Die Zeit
column4: Meine again denied that his most successful song had been written by US propaganda officers.

column1: Since the start of the war in Ukraine
column2: Germany’s political establishment has faced criticism that it has spent too long buying into the implicit premise of Scorpions’ chart-topper
column3: of a Russia ever ushered down a road of democratisation as it opened routes of trade and diplomatic exchange with the west. The threats an increasingly aggressive Kremlin continued to pose to the states that once made up its empire
column4: critics allege
column5: were overlooked in Berlin for decades.

column1: In his interview with Die Zeit
column2: Meine denied that his band
column3: too
column4: had overlooked Ukraine’s plight
column5: pointing out Scorpions had played concerts in Donetsk
column6: Kharkiv and Odesa.

column1: “But as a musician you hold on to the thought that people in wildly different countries
column2: some of whom may look on each other as enemies
column3: react to music in the same way. That was also the case in Ukraine and Russia.”

column1: Hailing from Hanover
column2: the state capital of Lower Saxony in north-west Germany
column3: the band used to be seen as part of the friendship circle of the Hanoverian ex-chancellor turned Russian gas lobbyist Gerhard Schröder
column4: whose fifth wedding party Meine attended in 2018.

column1: “I haven’t spoken with Gerhard Schröder for a while
column2: ” Meine told Die Zeit. “But his behaviour really is hard to understand.” The Social Democrat politician held on to his boardroom post with Rosneft for the first three months of the war before the Russian state-owned oil company announced his stepping down on 20 May.

column1: “If he now gives up this post on the supervisory board
column2: then that is a genuine step in the right direction after a long time
column3: ” Meine said."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/mass-civil-legal-action-to-seek-compensation-for-ukrainian-war-victims;2022-05-31;Mass civil legal action to seek compensation for Ukrainian war victims;"Exclusive: Lawyers to target assets of Russian state
column2: military contractors and affiliated business figures across globe

column1: A consortium of Ukrainian and international lawyers is preparing to launch a mass civil legal action against the Russian state
column2: as well as private military contractors and businesspeople backing the Russian war effort
column3: in an attempt to gain financial compensation for millions of Ukrainian victims of the war
column4: the Guardian can reveal.

column1: The team
column2: made up of hundreds of lawyers and several major law firms
column3: plans to bring “multiple actions in different jurisdictions against different targets”
column4: including the UK and the US
column5: said Jason McCue
column6: a London-based lawyer who is coordinating the initiative
column7: in an interview in Kyiv.

column1: The plan is to use UK and US judgments to seize Russian assets across the globe.
Targets are likely to include the Russian state and private military contractors such as the Wagner Group
column2: which is believed to have been active in Ukraine. But McCue said they would also include business figures linked to these contractors
column3: and to the Russian war effort more broadly. He believes that it will be possible to go after assets that have already been hit by sanctions as well as those that have not.

column1: The class action will be a private case
column2: independent of the Ukrainian state. But according to McCue
column3: they will need access to Ukraine’s evidence and intelligence.

column1: The Ukrainian MP and businessman Serhiy Taruta is supporting the initiative by facilitating meetings for the lawyers and investigators with Ukrainian officials.
Taruta
column2: who is from Mariupol and had investments in the city
column3: lost a large chunk of his business when Russia and its proxy forces took more than half of the Donbas region in 2014. This time he lost friends
column4: colleagues and a cousin as Russia destroyed Mariupol while attempting to occupy it.

column1: “Ukrainians have waited 20 years for the prosecution of [Pavlo] Lazarenko
column2: and now eight for MH17
column3: ” said Taruta
column4: referring to a case against Ukraine’s former prime minister who embezzled millions
column5: and to an ongoing case in The Hague over the downing of a Malaysian Airlines flight in 2014.

column1: “We need to develop a quicker mechanism [for compensation]
column2: ” said Taruta. “The normal routes are too slow.”

column1: Ukraine has already begun prosecuting captured Russian soldiers for war crimes in criminal cases
column2: and other war crime cases may later be tried in international courts. But claims for reparations for the war damage are trickier
column3: and McCue said part of the idea behind speedily launching the case was because reparations on a state-to-state level are rarely possible.

column1: “Often when it gets to the negotiations
column2: the issue of reparations is put to one side to focus on the sustainability of peace
column3: ” he said.

column1: According to Taruta
column2: individuals who have suffered the loss of a loved one or property or who have been injured will be the primary recipients of the compensation
column3: followed by state and local institutions
column4: and only then businesses. He estimated the total potential claim could be no less than $1tn (£793.9bn).

column1: A number of teams of investigators have come on board to help the team find assets of businesspeople they believe to be complicit in Russia’s war effort. They include Bellingcat
column2: which has been investigating the activities of the Wagner Group and other Russian private military contractors for some years.

column1: “We are closely monitoring the activity of Russia’s mercenary units in Ukraine
column2: ” said Christo Grozev
column3: Bellingcat’s executive director.

column1: “We believe that a deep dive into the [Wagner Group’s] chain of command and its links to official Russian authorities would not only help bring justice for the victims and their families
column2: but also will bring more public awareness and transparency on how Russia is conducting this war
column3: ” said Grozev.

column1: A key part of the case will involve pleading that Russia’s invasion is not just an aggressive war but also falls at least partially under the legal definition of terrorism
column2: which would make it easier to go after assets.

column1: “All the legal teams from different countries are satisfied that we have what we need
column2: ” said McCue. “It’s very solid.”

column1: McCue has extensive experience in similar cases on a smaller scale
column2: the first of which was won on behalf of victims of the 1998 Omagh bombing
column3: in which four men were found liable for the bombing and ordered to pay compensation to families of the victims.

column1: “The evidence was with the police but nobody was prosecuting because of the peace process
column2: ” said McCue
column3: who described how the families approached him. “So
column4: we did a civil action
column5: and we won
column6: and we managed to take houses off two of them.”

column1: The Ukraine case
column2: which is much bigger in scale
column3: is likely to operate on similar principles
column4: though it will be more focused on winning financial compensation for people who have suffered the loss of their loved ones
column5: property or businesses.

column1: “The Omagh case wasn’t about money
column2: it was about proving who did it. This case is about money
column3: ” said McCue.

column1: He conceded that there would be enormous work ahead to verify and rank cases and create a “victim hierarchy”
column2: and that targeted figures were likely to work hard to move or cover up their assets. However
column3: he said he believed the case had a good chance of succeeding.

column1: “What we know is that if we don’t do this
column2: people are less likely to get something. This increases the chances
column3: ” he said."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/mongolia-under-pressure-to-align-with-russia-and-china;2022-05-31;Mongolia under pressure to align with Russia and China;"Landlocked state is pursuing neutrality despite neighbours’ efforts to create triangle of anti-western cooperation
Mongolia
column2: a squeezed outpost of democracy in north-east Asia
column3: is under renewed pressure from its authoritarian neighbours
column4: Russia and China
column5: to shed its independence and form a triangle of anti-western cooperation in the wake of the war in Ukraine.

column1: The country is doggedly pursuing a path of neutrality
column2: coupled with a policy of economic diversification designed to keep its unique culture and still relatively recent independence alive
column3: according to Nomin Chinbat
column4: its culture secretary.

column1: A Soviet satellite state until 1990
column2: and heavily dependent on China as a market and conduit for its copper and coal exports
column3: Mongolia has to tread carefully. It is three times the size of France but has a population of only 3.5 million
column4: half of whom live in the capital
column5: Ulaanbaatar.

column1: So far it has dodged a definitive position on Ukraine by abstaining in major UN votes. However
column2: its governing Mongolian People’s party is attending briefings given by United Russia
column3: the biggest party in Russia – which has been interpreted in Russia as support for the war.

column1: Doubtless all this is a disappointment to Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column2: the Ukrainian president
column3: who spent four of his childhood years in the Mongolian town of Erdenet as the son of a Soviet mining specialist.

column1: Chinbat
column2: a graduate of the University of East Anglia
column3: is a model of diplomacy when she points out the term ambassador was invented in Mongolia. “Abstaining was a decision that our country had to make because of our geopolitical location
column4: ” she said. “We have had very healthy and manageable relationships with our two neighbours
column5: but we also have a third neighbour policy that allows us to develop a multi-pillar international relationships with other countries.

column1: “We have survived where we are
column2: and our sovereignty has been respected by our neighbours. But democracy is what will keep us developing further.”

column1: Chinbat
column2: who has been tasked with attracting foreign investment to her country – whether from film-makers
column3: industrialists or tourists – said there had been a generational shift among Mongolians
column4: over 60% of whom are under 35. The outlook of younger people
column5: she said
column6: is less defined by relations with the country’s neighbours and more by Mongolia’s own development.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: if there is a prolonged war Mongolia’s ultimate political orientation may once again be up for grabs
column3: especially if China and Russia genuinely form the long-discussed anti-western alliance
column4: making it harder for Mongolia to play its two powerful neighbours off one another.

column1: One path for the country is to form the third part of a Russian-Chinese triangle
column2: largely becoming a transport hub between the two superpowers
column3: and supplier of raw materials
column4: while the other option is to try to acknowledge the two countries’ economic importance
column5: while exploiting Mongolia’s own mineral resources to diversify the economy and modernise. The visit in May of the UK Asia minister
column6: Amanda Milling
column7: is a sign that Britain and the US will try to coax it along the latter course.

column1: Some claim Mongolia in reality has already chosen the Sino-Russian option
column2: since four days after the invasion it signed a memorandum of understanding to press ahead with the long-planned trans-Mongolian gas pipeline deal. This pipeline would increase Mongolia’s dependence on Russia by taking gas from Siberia’s Yamal fields and allowing Russia to transport gas originally destined for Europe to find a new market in China.

column1: As a landlocked country
column2: its vulnerability to China has been exposed by the prolonged Chinese border closures caused by Covid
column3: slowing a planned rise in Mongolian energy exports to Chinese ports due to be enabled by a network of new freight lines that will cut journey times by a third.

column1: Chinbat said the government had invested heavily in a wider economic policy of privatisation
column2: tourism
column3: climate and rural development policies
column4: which will allow it to diversify its economy over the next 20 years. The plan needs to succeed: in April
column5: young people took to the streets to protest against the impact of inflation on their lives.

column1: Once in charge of one of her country’s largest independent broadcasters
column2: Chinbat said Mongolia would not backslide from democracy. “We have free media and democracy. It is one of the beauties of Mongolia: that we have this ability to have so much different media
column3: from black and white to middle ground.”

column1: Chinbat acknowledged that Mongolia’s culture of ubiquitous citizen journalists operating in a society that is not particularly media literate could be frustrating
column2: but said: “Media should be challenging – that is what I fought for in my period in the media industry. Democracy and freedom of speech keeps our society lively and upright.”

column1: A bigger problem Chinbat identified was keeping younger people committed to the nomadic lifestyle
column2: when parents sometimes want to send their children to be educated in the city.

column1: Chinbat said that at the heart of the nomad mentality was a respect for nature
column2: a skill to survive in extreme weathers and a neighbourliness that means doors are left open in case herdsmen get lost. Mongolian politicians will require all that tact and resourcefulness in the years ahead."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/what-does-eu-partial-oil-ban-mean-for-russia-and-rest-of-europe;2022-05-31;What does EU’s partial oil ban mean for Russia and rest of Europe?;"Ban on seaborne oil aims to cut off funds for Kremlin war machine
column2: but some warn it could help Moscow in short term

column1: After nearly a month of wrangling
column2: the European Union has agreed to a partial ban on Russian oil
column3: with the aim of cutting off funding to the Kremlin’s war machine. According to the European Council president
column4: Charles Michel
column5: three-quarters of Russian oil imports will be immediately affected
column6: rising to 90% by the end of the year.

column1: The EU is banning seaborne oil immediately
column2: which covers about two-thirds of Russian imports to the EU. Oil transported through the critical Druzhba (“friendship”) pipeline will be exempt from the ban
column3: a key concession to Hungary
column4: which is heavily dependent on Russian oil.

column1: The EU is confident most Russian oil flows will cease by the end of the year
column2: because Germany and Poland
column3: countries on the northern branch of Druzhba
column4: have promised to forgo its supplies. Countries on the southern branch of the Soviet-era pipeline – Hungary
column5: Slovakia and the Czech Republic – will benefit from the temporary exemption.

column1: That is not clear. Ursula von der Leyen
column2: the European Commission president who has been driving sanctions policy
column3: promised the EU would discuss how to close the loophole “as soon as possible”. Hungary is seeking EU cash to retool its oil refineries that can only take Russian crude. Croatia also needs time to boost supplies to its northern neighbour through the Adria pipeline. EU leaders have avoided giving details on the end date of the exemption for central Europe.

column1: The EU is paying Russia about €1bn (£850m) a day for oil and gas
column2: an invaluable source of hard currency for the Kremlin in funding its war against Ukraine. A sharp cut in those financial flows deepens Russia’s economic problems in the long term. Some economists have warned
column3: however
column4: that it could have the perverse effect of helping Moscow in the short term
column5: as Russia benefits from high prices. The EU’s lengthy discussions have also given Russia time to find alternative buyers.

column1: Motorists and businesses will see higher prices at the pumps
column2: as the embargo feeds into higher oil prices. Governments will find it even harder to manage the already soaring cost of living. After the announcement of the EU oil embargo
column3: the price of a barrel of Brent crude hit $124.10 (£98.59)
column4: its highest level since March
column5: although it dropped back a little in later trading. Oil prices have already risen more than 55% this year and are at their highest levels since 2008.

column1: Before the EU had even agreed on the oil embargo
column2: some countries were already considering further sanctions against Russia’s biggest export: gas. Before the war

column4: Ukraine’s most outspoken allies in the EU
column5: Poland and the Baltic states
column6: think the EU should now put an end date on Russian gas. That step is far from assured and will be even harder than talks on the unfinished oil embargo."

column1: “Ukrainians don’t have to pay!” I am trying to buy three shawarmas in a market in Tbilisi
column2: Georgia
column3: but the street vendor emphatically refuses to take my money. I try to explain
column4: even though I was warned not to say this: “I am sorry
column5: I am not Ukrainian
column6: I am Russian.” The vendor looks at the Ukrainian flag pin on my lapel; he doesn’t believe me.

column1: Before 24 February
column2: I never thought about what it means to be Russian. Now it’s all I think about.

column1: I was born in Moscow and
column2: until recently
column3: lived there all my life. But “I am Russian” would literally be the last thing I would answer to the question
column4: “Who are you?” I am a father
column5: I am a creative executive at a film company
column6: a writer
column7: a journalist
column8: a podcaster
column9: a friend … a Russian? Well
column10: yes
column11: but it’s just the name on a passport that I have
column12: nothing else.

column1: I grew up in the 1990s and 2000s
column2: when people of my generation – or at least the people I knew – thought of themselves as citizens of the world. After my first year at university I hitchhiked across Europe. The only time I thought about my nationality was when I was had to apply for visas. I know
column3: however
column4: that this was ultimately down to privilege. Unlike my friends from Dagestan
column5: Buryatia
column6: Yakutia or North Osetia
column7: I could afford not to think about my Russian identity. With a Slavic face and a Slavic name
column8: I was not subject to the everyday chauvinism that saturates Russian society.

column1: I loved my country
column2: but I never waved a Russian flag at a demonstration or publicly expressed my patriotism – it was just not something that people like me did. We thought about patriotism in terms of politics – if you care for your country you try to make it better. So I tried. For over a decade I went to all the opposition rallies
column3: I protested against injustice. Like-minded people and I tried our best to make our country a better place. But I never fell for the patriotic mantras about how great Russia is or how great it used to be and should be again.

column1: Why should I be proud that the Soviet Union was the first country to launch a man into space? Yuri Gagarin or Sergei Korolev should be proud of that
column2: it was their achievement
column3: not mine. Why should I be proud that the Soviet Union won the great patriotic war? My grandfathers fought in it. The war broke them
column4: but they won: they should be proud of that. I know they were. These achievements were certainly never part of my identity in the same way that they are for the “Putin majority”
column5: my compatriots who build their sense of self on past victories to which they are associated only by an accident of birth.

column1: But now these questions do feel important to me. “I am Russian
column2: ” I repeat to the street vendor. “But you are with them?” he asks
column3: nodding in the direction of my companions. Maria Belkina and Kirill Zhivoi are the people who run Tbilisi Volunteers – a movement that has already helped thousands of Ukrainian refugees in Georgia. Yes
column4: I am with them. We had just finished buying a car full of supplies – food and hygiene products to be distributed among refugees in one of the Tbilisi Volunteers help centres. “I am with them – but I am Russian.”

column1: The day of the invasion – 24 February – is a day that will be forever seared into my memory. The enormity and the irrationality of the war was like a physical blow. In my carefully constructed social bubble
column2: there wasn’t a single person who supported the war. We felt like leaves
column3: scattered by a hurricane. We still feel like this.

column1: Some of us left Russia and some stayed. I left with the film director Kantemir Balagov. It was past midnight when we were sitting in the deserted food court of Istanbul airport
column2: waiting for our flight to Yerevan
column3: Armenia. Nursing a glass of water
column4: Kantemir asked me: do you think we should stop speaking in Russian? Do we have to be ashamed of our language? That is probably the only question to which I have an unequivocal answer: “No!”

column1: Let me try to explain. Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskiy both speak Russian
column2: but their languages could not be more different. Zelenskiy’s Russian is passionate
column3: emotional and vibrant – alive. The language of Russian propaganda is dead: a senseless pile-up of obscure bureaucratese. The great Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev made a powerful film
column4: Loveless
column5: about an absence of love in everyday Russian life. The Russian that Putin and his cronies speak reflects this – it is deliberately un-alive. So no
column6: we will never be ashamed of Russian: we speak a different language.

column1: It’s not quite the same with our passports. In the line to the border control in Istanbul
column2: I overheard a conversation between a Ukrainian mother and daughter. They were standing right behind me – they were trying to fly back home to Kyiv. They left for a holiday in Turkey before the war and now they were going back to a world in which their grandmother was hiding in a bomb shelter and their father and brother had joined the territorial defence forces. I listened to their conversation and felt an overpowering sense of shame. My Russian passport burned like hot coal in my pocket.

column1: I don’t think I will be able to read any of my favourite Russian books or watch Russian films or TV shows that I loved any time soon. They all have has the same ending now: 24 February and the robotic voice of President Putin announcing his “limited military operation”. Bucha
column2: Irpen
column3: Hostomel
column4: Mariupol … We will have to write new books and make new films. And
column5: step by step
column6: we will figure out what it means to be Russian now.

column1: Back in Tbilisi
column2: I finally convince the vendor to take my money. “You don’t support the war
column3: do you?” he asks me suspiciously. No
column4: of course I don’t. How can anyone support this bloody madness? But while I am very much against the war and against Putin
column5: I am Russian. For some reason
column6: it is important for me to say that. As I am about to leave
column7: he gives me an extra kebab for free.

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/31/tuesday-briefing-russian-tanks-ukraine;2022-05-31;Tuesday briefing: What Russia’s failing tanks tell us about how war is changing;"In today’s newsletter: Russian heavy armour is struggling to gain ground in Ukraine. Military expert Phillips O’Brien explains to Archie Bland why that matters – for this war and for future conflicts
Good morning. On Monday
column2: Russian troops began to advance into Sievierodonetsk
column3: the largest city in Donbas still held in Ukrainian hands. The city is important to the control of Luhansk
column4: one of two provinces in Donbas. If it falls
column5: that success – achieved at the cost of the city’s ruination and 1
column6: 500 civilian lives – will be viewed as grim vindication for Vladimir Putin’s decision to consolidate Russian forces in the region and bombard targets with artillery fire.

column1: There’s something else about the battle for Sievierodonetsk
column2: though: while Russian tanks are moving into the centre of the city
column3: they were not able to encircle it first. Cutting a city off from its supply lines to soften it up is brutally effective
column4: as the siege of Mariupol indicated. So why hasn’t that happened here?

column1: For today’s newsletter
column2: I spoke to Phillips O’Brien
column3: professor of strategic studies at the University of St Andrews
column4: about a compelling explanation that could have much bigger consequences: Russia may be running out of tanks. That’s after the headlines.

column1: Energy | The European Union agreed to an embargo on most Russian oil imports after late-night talks in Brussels. The sanctions
column2: hailed as a “remarkable achievement”
column3: will immediately impact 75% of Russian oil imports
column4: rising to 90% by the end of the year.

column1: Partygate | Momentum is building for a leadership challenge to Boris Johnson as soon as next week. As three more MPs called on Johnson to go
column2: rebels expressed anger at what they said was a lurch to the right after Partygate.

column1: Champions league final | Uefa commissioned an independent report into chaotic scenes outside the Stade de France on Saturday where some Liverpool fans were teargassed. France’s interior minister admitted access to the ground had been “disorganised” but blamed counterfeit tickets sold to English fans.

Justice | Police and prosecutors have been told to stop the mass collection of personal information from rape victims by the UK’s data watchdog. The information commissioner said police are going on unjustified “fishing expeditions” into complainants’ personal information.
Music | Glastonbury festival announced its full lineup for this summer
column2: with acts including Sam Fender
column3: Megan Thee Stallion and Foals among those added to the bill. Billie Eilish
column4: Paul McCartney and Kendrick Lamar had already been announced.

column1: Few assets of conventional warfare are more intimidating than the tank
column2: and when Russia attacked Ukraine
column3: its invasion force of around 1
column4: 500 (out of a total of about 2
column5: 800) was often judged to be among the most formidable in the world. Phillips O’Brien was never especially convinced by that analysis
column6: and given the accuracy of his earlier assessments of Russian might – in January
column7: he wrote that Russia “lacks the ability to mount sustained military operations and deploy a wide range of military forces at the same time” – it’s worth paying attention to his view of the current situation.

column1: So
column2: what should we expect next in Ukraine? O’Brien believes that Russian advances have largely stalled because the country’s forces are running very short of tanks
column3: and other armoured vehicles. It’s a view he laid out in a Twitter thread on Sunday
column4: and which built on a piece for the Atlantic last week
column5: based on evidence from the eastern Donbas region. I asked him how he reached that conclusion
column6: and what it might mean.

column1: What are tanks supposed to do?
Tanks are powerful
column2: well-armoured
column3: and move fast in open country. “They’re usually used to seize the land between cities quickly and surround an enemy
column4: ” O’Brien told me. “In Russian doctrine
column5: you have these battalion tactical groups which are supposed to have maybe 10 tanks alongside 30 armoured personnel carriers (APCs) carrying the infantry.”

column1: The theory – dating back to the second world war – is that tanks allow you to punch a hole in the enemy lines and cut forces or a strategic target like a city off from supplies
column2: softening them up before a final assault. All of that relies on effective air support to neuter the threat that enemy jets and drones pose to the progress of the armour on the ground.

column1: What’s happened in reality?
Nothing which Vladimir Putin will be pleased to hear about. “When I look at Donbas
column2: I don’t see the kind of breakthroughs which you would want to see in modern armoured warfare
column3: ” O’Brien said. “You want to get through the line and then exploit the situation by quickly encircling the enemy. What we’re seeing is that the Russians may make a hole in the line
column4: but then they are stopped.”

column1: He points to the failure to encircle Sieverodonetsk
column2: and declining numbers in Ukrainian claims of Russian tanks being destroyed. That could mean a change in Russian deployment or in Ukraine’s ability to attack them. But since at the same time the Russian machine has failed to break through after its artillery has softened the Ukrainian forces up
column3: it is more likely to indicate that there are simply fewer tanks in the fight in the first place.

column1: While exact measures of the scale of the damage to Russian armour are hard to come by
column2: Ukraine has claimed more than 1
column3: 300 Russian tanks have been destroyed. The lowest independent assessments are more than 700 destroyed or captured. The Pentagon
column4: which does not appear to have made unrealistically high estimates so far
column5: puts it at about 1
column6: 000 – a number which O’Brien thinks is “probably a safe bet”.

column1: “Those are vast losses
column2: ” O’Brien said. In its usually reliable defence intelligence update on Friday
column3: the UK Ministry of Defence said that Russia was now moving 50-year-old T-62 tanks out of storage for deployment. “These tanks are antiquated
column4: ” O’Brien said. “The Russians don’t have nearly the frontline armoured capability that they had.”

column1: Why has that happened?
The military doctrine that sees tanks as all-powerful is pretty out of date
column2: as you might expect given its second world war foundations. There are many examples of videos that appear to show Russian tanks being destroyed by handheld missiles
column3: some of which – like the British-manufactured Next-generation Light Anti-armour Weapon (NLAW) (pictured below held by a Ukrainian soldier shortly after destroying an armoured personnel carrier) – are designed to strike on top of the tank
column4: where its armour is weakest.

column1: Most importantly
column2: Russia has failed to secure the air superiority which is a prerequisite of effective tank warfare – instead finding that Ukrainian planes and drones continue to be able to stop Russian tanks in their tracks. “They’re far more vulnerable than they need to be
column3: ” said O’Brien. “They’re not flying air patrols
column4: or close air support. So they’re running into considerable defensive firepower.”

column1: How did Russia get itself into this position?
Because it overestimated its prospects of air superiority
column2: and underestimated the capacity of simple
column3: cheap anti-tank systems to stop it in its tracks. If
column4: as O’Brien has written
column5: “we are witnessing in Ukraine the final war of 20th-century militaries”
column6: we might be shocked that the Kremlin entered such a fight without a clear-eyed assessment of the likely risks – but “dictators on the whole have systems that tell them what they want to hear
column7: and Putin has clearly done that”.

column1: As for the failure of analysts worldwide to spot the same flaw: “A lot of people fell for what we could call ‘the American trap’: because the US military was able to do something
column2: people looked at other militaries
column3: and just view it as a scaled-down version of the US. And that is not the case here. The Russian military is an entirely more deficient beast. The US can overwhelm an enemy with complex air systems and defeat their air defences
column4: it still has the capacity to do these ‘break out’ operations. Russia just can’t.”

column1: What does it mean for the future of this war – and wars around the world?
It’s obviously favourable to Ukraine if the tanks are failing
column2: but as Russia’s grim progress in Sieverodonetsk indicates
column3: it doesn’t signal an end to the fight. “If they’re bringing out obsolete equipment they probably can’t keep going with their current approach for that much longer
column4: ” said O’Brien.

column1: “The problem the Ukrainians then have is: can they drive the Russians back? I wouldn’t be surprised if we have a summer of ranged warfare
column2: mostly – more attritional combat with both sides trying to destroy the other’s resources.” That’s why
column3: as the Guardian’s defence and security editor Dan Sabbagh wrote yesterday
column4: Ukraine has been pleading with its western allies for longer-range rocket systems.

column1: There is
column2: meanwhile
column3: a wider positive for those who fear Russia’s invasion signals a new era of military expansion around the world. “The one hopeful thing to come out of this is that this conflict demonstrates that going to war is really hard
column4: ” O’Brien said. “And it may be that militaries around the world look at it and realise that war is fraught with enormous new risks because of the power of cheaper forces. So maybe people will be less likely to take that risk in the future.”

column1: “He has several serious illnesses
