column3: ” Budanov told Ukrainian outlet Ukrainskaya Pravda. “But it’s not worth hoping that Putin will die tomorrow.” He also claimed that a coup “will eventually lead to the change of leadership of the Russian Federation. This process has already been launched.”

column1: A former Soviet spy has claimed that Putin has Parkinson’s disease
column2: while New Lines Magazine claimed to have obtained a recording of an oligarch saying Putin is “very ill with blood cancer”. Neither of the reports have been confirmed.

column1: One report from the Proekt investigative website said that Putin is believed to have thyroid cancer or another disease.
The report was based on leaked travel documents that showed that Putin had received regular visits from an oncologist and from two otolaryngologists
column2: whom the outlet said would often make a first diagnosis of a thyroid condition. The Kremlin has not confirmed any reports about Putin being sick
column3: saying that the Russian leader is in excellent health. Dmitri Peskov
column4: a Kremlin spokesman
column5: called it a “fabrication and untruth”.

column1: Rumours of Putin suffering from illness and injury have stretched back for more than two decades and are
column2: to a certain degree
column3: the fault of the Kremlin for closely guarding information about Putin’s health and whereabouts.

column1: Since taking power
column2: Putin has been portrayed as an active sportsman to contrast with the image of Boris Yeltsin as a heavy drinker whose poor health made him an even poorer leader.

column1: But Putin has disappeared for weeks at a time in the past
column2: amid reports of sporting injuries from ice hockey and judo. He recently told an interviewer that he had fallen off a horse early in his presidency as well.

column1: The Kremlin has regularly used pre-filmed reports
column2: often called “conserves”
column3: to make it appear that Putin is in meetings when he is in fact unaccounted for. One extended absence took place during the coronavirus outbreak
column4: when Putin claimed to be in Moscow while reports said he was in Sochi
column5: occasionally appearing in an identical office as if in Moscow.

column1: Since the beginning of the war
column2: some reports have focused specifically on Putin’s pained body language
column3: suggesting that he may have some back problems. A bulky frame has been explained alternatively as the president wearing a back corset or some kind of body armour when in public.

column1: Those rumours gained steam when Putin noticeably grimaced during a meeting with Shoigu in late April. Putin will turn 70 in October and the focus on his health is likely to continue as he ages. But Budanov said he believed that Putin “still has at least a few years left. Whether we like it or not
column2: that’s the truth.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/may/30/shameful-visa-delays-continue-for-ukrainian-refugees;2022-05-30;Shameful visa delays continue for Ukrainian refugees;"David Hoare and Doric Bossom on the difficulties they are encountering in bringing young Ukrainians into the country
We are having a similar experience to Paul Hanlon and Rebecca Shepherd regarding refugees from Ukraine (‘It doesn’t make sense’: Ukrainian teenager left in limbo by Home Office
column2: 29 May). We’re sponsoring a 17-year-old from Kyiv whose parents are unable to travel because of the need to care for his grandmother.

column1: He speaks good English
column2: and his mother has supplied a letter consenting to his travelling and staying with us
column3: yet the Home Office isn’t processing his application. Also
column4: local children’s services won’t do any checks as he’s not eligible for a visa as an unaccompanied minor. We are getting help from a solicitor
column5: but it shouldn’t be difficult to safeguard him and others. My partner is a magistrate and I have had a series of criminal record checks over the years for my roles working with vulnerable people. One can’t help but think it’s all part of the Tories’ hostile environment.David HoareLewes
column6: East Sussex

column1: Julia
column3: is a Ukrainian refugee from Odesa with a four-month-old baby daughter
column4: both sheltering in Spain. Her husband is serving in the Ukrainian navy. Julia has been offered a warm welcome here in Wiltshire
column5: but five weeks after applying for visas these have still not been granted. Instead
column6: the UK government required that her baby undergo biometric testing in Madrid
column7: an eight-hour round trip
column8: and now she has to wait until a hard-copy visa can be shipped to her.

column1: Even our MP does not have access to information to sustain her hopes. Julia and her daughter do not deserve to be treated in this way. The process is utterly shameful and shows the UK in a very poor light. Doric Bossom Pitton
column2: Wiltshire

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/30/russians-advance-largest-city-donbas-ukrainian-hands-sievierodonetsk;2022-05-30;Russians advance into largest city in Donbas still in Ukrainian hands;"Witnesses say tanks moving into Sievierodonetsk amid intense shelling and civilian casualties
Russian tanks and troops have begun advancing into Sievierodonetsk
column2: the largest city in Donbas still held by Ukraine
column3: bringing fighting street by street as the Kremlin’s forces continue to grind forwards in the east of the country.

column1: Witnesses said Russian tanks were advancing towards the centre of the city one blast at a time
column2: razing everything in their path that remains after intense shelling that Ukrainian authorities have said has led to conditions on the ground reminiscent of Mariupol.

column1: “Unfortunately we have disappointing news: the enemy is moving into the city
column2: ” the Luhansk regional governor
column3: Serhiy Gaidai
column4: told Ukrainian national television on Monday.

column1: The Russian army “use the same tactics over and over again. They shell for several hours – for three
column2: four
column3: five hours – in a row and then attack. Those who attack die. Then the shelling and attack follow again
column4: and so on until they break through somewhere.”

column1: The battle for Sievierodonetsk
column2: which lies on the eastern bank of the Siverskyi Donets River
column3: about 90 miles south of the Russian border
column4: is in the spotlight as Russia makes slow but solid gains in the industrial Donbas
column5: which comprises the self-proclaimed republics in Luhansk and Donetsk.

column1: Witnesses said the city was being bombed “200 times an hour” as Russian forces try to cut off reinforcement lines and surround its remaining Ukrainian defenders.
The city’s mayor
column2: Oleksandr Striuk
column3: confirmed in a telephone interview with the Associated Press that Russian troops had “advanced a few blocks towards the city centre”. He said Ukrainian forces were fighting to push the Russians out in street fighting and that the 12
column5: 000 civilians left in the city were sheltering in basements and bunkers to escape relentless bombardment.

column1: Local authorities estimated that 1
column2: 500 civilians had already died in Russian attacks on Sievierodonetsk
column3: including from a lack of medicines. Striuk said the city had “been completely ruined” and that the number of victims was “rising every hour
column4: but we are unable to count the dead and the wounded amid the street fighting”.

column1: Relentless Russian artillery barrages have destroyed critical infrastructure and damaged 90% of the buildings
column2: and power and communications have been largely cut to a city that was once home to 100
column3: 000 people.

column1: A French journalist was killed after an armoured humanitarian evacuation vehicle in which he was travelling was hit by shrapnel from a Russian shell in Sievierodonetsk. According to local authorities
column2: shrapnel pierced the vehicle’s armour
column3: killing Frédéric Leclerc-Imhoff as he travelled alongside civilians forced to flee Russian bombs. The evacuation was called off after the attack.

column1: Having failed to take the national capital
column2: Kyiv
column3: in the early phase of the war
column4: Russia is seeking to consolidate its grip on Donbas
column5: large parts of which are already controlled by Moscow-backed separatists. It has concentrated huge firepower on a small area – in contrast to the earlier phase of the conflict
column6: when its forces were often spread thinly – bludgeoning towns and cities with artillery and airstrikes.

column1: “They don’t care how many lives they will have to pay for this
column2: ” said Ukraine’s president
column3: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column4: in his latest national address
column5: referring to Russian forces in the region.

column1: Russia has also stepped up its efforts to take the neighbouring city of Lysychansk
column2: where
column3: according to Gaidai
column4: a Russian shell fell on a residential building over the weekend
column5: killing a child. The two cities sit on either side of the strategically important Siverskyi Donets River.

column1: According to Ukrainian officials
column2: Lysychansk is still under Ukrainian control
column3: while the main road into the two cities has been shelled
column4: but not blocked. The last remaining access and evacuation route
column5: leading south-west towards the town of Bakhmut
column6: remains under Ukrainian control.

column1: The Ukrainian defence ministry spokesman Oleksandr Motuzyanyk said Ukrainian troops were doing all they could to prevent Russian forces from completely encircling Sievierodonetsk
column2: which if it fell could help Moscow to consolidate its grip on the Donbas – large parts of which were controlled by Moscow-backed separatists before the 24 February invastion.

column1: “The liberation of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions
column2: recognised by the Russian Federation as independent states
column3: is an unconditional priority
column4: ” Sergei Lavrov
column5: the Russian foreign minister
column6: told the French TV channel TF1
column7: adding that other Ukrainian territories should decide their future on their own.

column1: Russian forces are also regrouping to resume their offensive further west in the direction of the Sloviansk region of eastern Ukraine
column2: Motuzyanyk said.

column1: “In Sloviansk
column2: the enemy is regrouping to resume attacks in the direction of Izyum-Barvinkove and Izyum-Sloviansk
column3: ” he told a briefing.

column1: In the south of the country
column2: the Russian-appointed mayor of occupied Melitopol said two civilians had been wounded by an explosion that she blamed on Ukraine. No one has claimed responsibility for the explosion
column3: which Halyna Danylchenko denounced as a “cynical terror attack by the Kyiv regime” in remarks broadcast by Russian state television.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the fate of the the last group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the smashed Azovstal steelworks in Mariupol
column3: who surrendered on 20 May
column4: hangs by a thread.

column1: According to Yuri Sirovatko
column2: a pro-Moscow separatist official and justice minister of the self-proclaimed Donetsk people’s republic (DNR) in eastern Ukraine
column3: the Ukrainian fighters may face the death penalty.

column1: “The court will make a decision about them
column2: ” Sirovatko was quoted as saying by the RIA Novosti news agency. “For such crimes we have the highest form of punishment in the DNR – the death penalty.

column1: “All the prisoners of war are on the territory of the DNR
column2: ” he said
column3: adding that there were about 2
column4: 300 soldiers from Azovstal among them."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/30/new-us-ambassador-ukraine-arrives-kyiv-symbolic-move-bridget-brink;2022-05-30;New US ambassador to Ukraine arrives in Kyiv in symbolic move;"Bridget Brink’s arrival confirmed on US embassy website
column2: as western diplomats slowly return to city

column1: The new US ambassador to Ukraine has arrived in Kyiv
column2: the Guardian understands
column3: a symbolic move after the US withdrew all diplomats from the country before the Russian invasion in February.

column1: A career diplomat who served as US ambassador to Slovakia until recently
column2: Bridget Brink was nominated by President Joe Biden in late April and confirmed unanimously by the US Senate on 18 May.

column1: Brink confirmed her arrival in Kyiv with a tweet noting that she had visited the foreign ministry to present her credentials. “Our first priority is to help Ukraine defend itself
column2: ” she wrote.

column1: The US embassy evacuated all family members and non-essential staff in January and moved operations to Lviv in western Ukraine in mid-February. Immediately before the Russian invasion
column2: the diplomats moved again
column3: to Rzeszów in Poland.

column1: At the time
column2: the Americans were criticised in some quarters for their departure
column3: with widespread scepticism inside Ukraine and in other European capitals over the apocalyptic warnings coming from US and British intelligence that Russia was preparing for full-scale war.

column1: In the end
column2: almost all western diplomats left Kyiv
column3: either before or immediately after Russia launched its invasion.

column1: Since the Russian army was pushed away from the region around Kyiv at the end of March
column2: small teams of diplomats have been slowly returning. The British ambassador arrived at the end of April. The US embassy restarted limited operations in Kyiv two weeks ago.

column1: The US secretary of state
column2: Antony Blinken
column3: called the reopening a “momentous step”
column4: in a statement after the American flag was raised at the embassy on 18 May. The skeleton US diplomatic presence that has returned to Kyiv is mainly locked down at the embassy
column5: a large compound in the suburbs.

column1: Last week
column2: the Wall Street Journal reported the Pentagon was considering deploying special forces operatives to guard the embassy.

column1: When Brink presents her credentials to Zelenskiy it will mark the first time the US has had a full-fledged ambassador to Ukraine in three years
column2: after the departure of Marie Yovanovitch in 2019
column3: who was recalled by Donald Trump and became embroiled in the scandal over Trump associates attempting to pressure Zelenskiy to investigate the activities of Biden’s son in Ukraine.

column1: During the buildup to Russia’s invasion
column2: the US embassy was headed by a chargé d’affaires
column3: Kristina Kvien."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/30/eu-forget-sanctions-russia-ukraine-food-energy-prices#comments;2022-05-30;The EU should forget about sanctions – they’re doing more harm than good;Far from compelling Russia to exit Ukraine
column2: they are causing great suffering worldwide as food and energy prices soar

column1: Six million households in Britain face the possibility of morning and evening blackouts this winter to maintain sanctions against Russia
column2: as do consumers across Europe. This is despite Europe pouring about $1bn a day into Russia to pay for the gas and oil it continues to consume. This seems crazy. Proposals by the EU to halt the payments are understandably being opposed by countries close to Russia and heavily dependent on its fossil fuels; Germany buys 12% of its oil and 35% of its gas from Russia
column3: figures that are much higher in Hungary.

column1: The EU in Brussels seems not to know what to do. A diplomatic compromise has been raised – exempting sanctions on imports via pipeline
column2: which would spare Hungary and Germany – but no practical plan has been agreed. The real reason is that arguments over the sanctions weapon have been reduced to macho rhetoric. They are supposed to induce a foreign regime to change some unacceptable policy. This rarely if ever happens
column3: and in Russia’s case it has blatantly failed. Apologists now claim that sanctions are merely a deterrent
column4: intended to work in the medium to long term. As war in Ukraine shifts into a different gear
column5: that term could be long indeed.

column1: Sanctions may have harmed Russia’s credit-worthiness
column2: but the 70% surge in world gas prices alone has supercharged its balance of payments. Its current account trade surplus
column3: according to its central bank
column4: is now over three times the pre-invasion level. At the same time
column5: sanctions are clearly hurting countries in western and central Europe who are imposing them.

column1: It is absurd to expect Hungary to starve itself of energy and
column2: as it says
column3: “nuclear bomb” its economy
column4: with no fixed objective or timetable in sight. Sanctions have an awful habit of being hard to dismantle. Worse is to come. Russia’s reaction to sanctions has been to threaten to cut off gas to Europe
column5: further driving up prices to its advantage. It is already blockading the Black Sea ports
column6: from which millions of tons of Ukrainian grain are normally shipped to the outside world. This blockade has seen cereal prices rise 48% on their 2019 base
column7: devastating markets
column8: particularly across Africa. This in turn has increased the value of Russia’s own massive grain exports. Russia has offered to lift the blockade if sanctions are lifted. Whether it means this is moot
column9: but the west cannot be blind to the unintended consequence of its sanctions war.

column1: Nato has been sensibly scrupulous in not escalating the war in Ukraine into a Europe-wide conflict. Sanctions know no such subtlety. Millions of innocent people across Europe and far from its shores will suffer as food and energy prices soar. Supply lines are disrupted. Trade links collapse. The victims are overwhelmingly the poor.

The objective – to compel Russia to withdraw its forces from Ukraine – has patently not been achieved. Military aid has been far more effective in that respect. But the harm done to the rest of Europe and the outside world is now glaring. The EU should stick to helping Ukraine’s war effort and withdraw economic sanctions against Russia. They are self-defeating and senselessly cruel.
Simon Jenkins is a Guardian columnist"

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/may/30/reflection-review-reflection-vidblysk-valentyn-vasyanovych-ukraine-donbas-war;2022-05-30;Reflection review – a shaken
column2: horrifying outcry for Ukraine – and statement of hope;"Ukrainian director Valentyn Vasyanovych’s enigmatic war drama
column3: set in Donbas
column4: is brutal in its depiction of conflict but also elusively redemptive

column1: Set at the start of the Donbas war in 2014
column2: Valentyn Vasyanovych’s fifth feature
column3: Reflection
column4: chimes horribly with the current mood
column5: grim and exacting as it is compared with previous
column6: more ironic films about the conflict such as Sergei Loznitza’s Donbass and Roman Bondarchuk’s Volcano. It is composed in largely static tableau shots
column7: many of them featuring windows
column8: windscreens and other partitions
column9: implying both the estranged unreality of the conflict taking place so close to civilised life
column10: as well as an elusive redemption sought by the film’s characters.

column1: The first window gets covered in multicoloured splatters at the paintballing birthday party of Polina (played by Nika Myslytska
column2: Vasyanovych’s daughter)
column3: child of Serhiy (Roman Lutskyi)
column4: a Ukrainian surgeon. It’s a playful allusion to nearby warfare
column5: which Serhiy discusses with Andriy (Andriy Rymaruk)
column6: the current partner of his ex-wife Olha (Nadia Levchenko). But when the two men head out to the frontline
column7: they run into a Russian checkpoint and are captured. Serhiy is tortured by fists and electrodes
column8: then forced to assist in the brutalisation of other Ukrainians – including Andriy – by checking their vital signs to see if they are still alive.

column1: These scenes
column2: which contain one of Reflection’s few bursts of camera movement as Serhiy is frogmarched into the bowels of the security outpost
column3: thrust us into a harrowing abyss. Serhiy contemplates suicide in his cell
column4: helps load corpses into an incinerator in the back of a truck marked “Russian humanitarian aid” and is finally forced into a terrible predicament regarding Andriy. Vasyanovych’s unwavering style is the cinematic equivalent of having your eyes prised open
column5: which gives his film the kind of unrelenting horror of Come and See.

column1: The tableau method arguably weighs Reflection down a little in its second half
column2: as Serhiy adjusts to civilian life
column3: but Vasyanovych lets some metaphysical light filter through. While Serhiy is reconnecting with his daughter
column4: a pigeon is killed as it flies into his apartment window; the ghostly smear it leaves behind
column5: like an imprint of a soul
column6: symbolises all at once the missing Andriy
column7: the difficulty of forgetting
column8: and a state of grace that may still exist in the world. Hauntingly enigmatic in its storytelling
column9: even with the highly controlled formalism
column10: Reflection is both a shaken outcry for Ukraine and subdued declaration that hope still lies beyond.

column1: Reflection is available on 2 June on the BFI Player."

column2: poll shows;"Annual global survey of attitudes to democracy finds many countries maintain positive views of Russia

column1: The sharp polarisation between mainly western liberal democracies and the rest of the world in perceptions of Russia has been laid bare in an annual global poll of attitudes towards democracy.
Within Europe
column2: 55% of those surveyed for the Alliance of Democracies said they were in favour of cutting economic ties with Russia due to Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine
column3: whereas in Asia there was a majority against
column4: and in Latin America opinion was evenly split.

column1: Negative views of Russia are largely confined to Europe and other liberal democracies. Positive views of Russia have been retained in China
column2: Indonesia
column3: Egypt
column4: Vietnam
column5: Algeria
column6: Morocco
column7: Malaysia
column8: Pakistan and Saudi Arabia.

column2: carried out after the invasion of Ukraine
column3: covers 52 highly populated countries in Asia
column4: Latin America
column5: the US and Europe.

column1: Majorities in a total of 20 countries thought economic ties with Russia should not be cut due to the war in Ukraine. They included Greece

column1: It was the Ukrainian president’s first official appearance outside the Kyiv area since the start of the war. “Kharkiv suffered terrible blows from the occupiers … One third of the Kharkiv region is still under occupation
column2: ” he said.

column1: Last Thursday
column2: Russian artillery pounded the city of Kharkiv for the first time in two weeks
column3: just as life in Ukraine’s second city was starting to return to normal after Moscow’s troops were pushed back from its outlying towns and villages. At least nine people have been killed and 17 injured in the attacks on the northern part of the city.

column1: Zelenskiy voiced hopes that his allies would provide much needed weapons and said he expected “good news” in the coming days.
A few days ago
column2: the US and its allies indicated that they would provide Ukraine with increasingly sophisticated weapons
column3: including the multiple-launch rocket systems for which Kyiv has been appealing. Ukraine said it has started receiving Harpoon anti-ship missiles from Denmark and US self-propelled howitzers.

column1: Presidential adviser Mykhailo Podolyak repeated a call for US-made long-range multiple-rocket launchers. US officials said such systems are actively being considered
column2: with a decision possible in the coming days.

column1: “It is hard to fight when you are attacked from 70km away and have nothing to fight back with
column2: ” Podolyak posted on Twitter. ”We need effective weapons.”

column1: In the meantime
column2: Zelenskiy said in a television interview that he believed Russia would agree to talks if Ukraine could recapture all the territory it has lost since the invasion.

column1: Zelenskiy ruled out the idea of using force to win back all the land Ukraine has lost to Russia since 2014
column2: which includes the southern peninsula of Crimea
column3: annexed by Moscow that year.

column1: “I do not believe that we can restore all of our territory by military means. If we decide to go that way
column2: we will lose hundreds of thousands of people
column3: ” he said.

column1: Associated Press and Reuters contributed to this report"
Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/29/putin-vladimir-kara-murza-wife-russian-politician;2022-05-29;Ukraine war is Putin’s death warrant
column2: says wife of jailed politician;"Vladimir Kara-Murza’s wife Evgenia says Russian president will fall over war in Ukraine

column1: Vladimir Kara-Murza’s wife Evgenia thinks he will have been like a “hurricane contained inside a bottle” since he was arrested on 11 April in Moscow and held in pre-trial detention over a speech he had made in Arizona criticising the war in Ukraine.
“He has so much energy
column2: so many ideas
column3: and initiatives
column4: that being contained within the four walls of a prison will be the hardest part for him
column5: ” said Evgenia
column6: who has not been allowed to speak to him.

column1: As a Russian politician
column2: campaigner and regime critic
column3: Vladimir Kara-Murza worked for 15 years alongside Boris Nemtsov
column4: another opposition leader
column5: who was killed in 2015.

column1: Sitting in a hotel near Westminster on the same day she met the Foreign Office minister James Cleverly
column2: Evgenia Kara-Murza warned the UK government that her husband
column3: a British citizen who has twice been allegedly poisoned by the Russian spy agency the FSB
column4: may have reason to fear for his own life.

column1: She had no criticism of her husband’s decision to repeatedly return to Russia
column2: even after the invasion of Ukraine
column3: saying: “He believed that as a Russian politician
column4: he cannot call on people to continue fighting if he himself is somewhere safe
column5: and he believes that he has to share the same risks
column6: the same challenges as the Russians who continue to oppose this war.

column1: “Basically
column2: by calling this war a war
column3: instead of the ‘special operation’ as the government wants it to be called
column4: by saying that
column5: a person can end up in prison for up to 15 years. On the basis of the charges laid so far Vladimir is now facing up to 10 years.”

column1: No court date has been yet set
column2: possibly because officials will press additional charges such as advocating personal sanctions against the regime
column3: she said.

column1: “Our family has been living like this for a long time
column2: ” said Kara-Murza
column3: who has three teenage children. “He was targeted by an FSB team that tried to kill him twice in 2015 and 2017.

column1: “Thanks to an amazing independent investigation by Bellingcat and Insider
column2: we now know the names and the faces of those people from the FSB
column3: who had followed him before the poisoning. Both times Vladimir was left in a coma with multiple organ failure. And I brought him back to the US. He recovered and then he went back to Russia.

column1: “The Russian authorities have chosen this new tactic of dealing with opposition figures
column2: especially well-known opposition figures like [Alexei] Navalny
column3: or my husband – they try to lock them away and hide them from the public eye and prevent them from continuing to work. It is because they’re so effective when they’re outside.”

column1: Kara-Murza said that since the war started Russia had switched from being an authoritarian regime to a totalitarian one. “There is not one independent media outlet left
column2: there is massive repression and propaganda pumped out on national TV … There is a new iron curtain around this country.”

column1: But she insisted dissent exists below the surface as people access news via virtual private networks or the Telegram messaging service. “I believe that Putin has not yet declared mobilisation because he knows how people will react to it. But a week or two ago
column2: they said that there have already been 11 conscription centres burned down across Russia.

column1: “So that’s how people protest – by saying: ‘We’re not going to go to your war.’ People get arrested for going out on the street with a copy of War and Peace. Others have been arrested for carrying ‘invisible anti-government slogans’. The police said they could see invisible things. It is that crazy.”
She pleaded for the west not to give up on the dissidents in Russia.
“I believe Putin has signed his own death warrant with this war
column2: ” she said
column3: “but he will fall the sooner we end these double standards: at the same time as countries support the Ukrainian people by sending weapons and providing humanitarian aid and imposing sanctions on the Russian economy
column4: they also give Putin billions for oil and gas
column5: which allows him to continue his aggression … this has to stop because honestly
column6: it is inexplicable.”

column1: Her husband’s arrest and her campaign to secure his release have required her to change her role. “The fact is
column2: I’ve never been a public figure. I’ve never been a public speaker
column3: so everything I’m doing today
column4: I’m learning it day by day.

column1: “All the people I’m meeting
column2: I heard of them
column3: of course
column4: from my husband’s work
column5: but I’ve met very few of them before. So everything is novel. Everything – speaking and being on stage
column6: speaking to journalists – is very new to me. It’s a rather glum joke
column7: but we do have this joke in the family
column8: that I only emerge when my husband gets poisoned or thrown in jail.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/29/ukraine-war-foreign-medics-volunteer-frontline;2022-05-29;‘This is Europe’s war’: the foreign volunteer medics on Ukraine frontline;"People who feel compelled to help are ferrying casualties from intense fighting in the east to hospitals
It was the photo of a young girl
column2: dying in a Mariupol hospital after Russian shelling
column3: that made up Martin Wyness’ mind. He had to go and help in Ukraine.

column1: Less than three months later
column2: he was in an ambulance racing to save the life of another little girl gravely injured by a Russian attack
column3: as more shells crashed down around them. They turned around and raced back the way they had came
column4: looking for another route to safety and medical care for the eight-year-old
column5: whose body was peppered with shrapnel.

column1: “They didn’t get her the first time so they had another go
column2: ” he said
column3: in his hospital base in Donbas region. “As if that little girl wasn’t vulnerable enough.”

column1: Wyness is part of a volunteer medical unit bridging the gap between Ukraine’s eastern frontline – which is experiencing the most intense fighting of the war – and major hospitals where war-injured soldiers and civilians can get long-term treatment for their wounds.
Medbat Pirogov volunteer hospital brings together dozens of Ukrainians
column2: including some who returned from abroad to serve
column3: and a handful of internationals who felt compelled to try to help out in a conflict thousands of miles from home.

column1: “I felt this wasn’t Ukraine’s war
column2: it was Europe’s war
column3: my war
column4: ” said Wyness. He has twice made the journey to Ukraine from his Southampton home. The first month of the war he spent in the basement of a Kyiv hospital
column5: patching up those injured in the battle for the city.

column1: After the Russians were defeated he returned home for a break
column2: but in early May returned to the new frontline near the almost-besieged town of Sievierodonetsk.

column1: Ukraine’s president
column2: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column3: said the battle in Donbas was so intense that up to 100 of the country’s soldiers were dying in combat each day.

column1: It is a gruelling artillery duel in which the enemy is often faceless and unseen
column2: appearing only in the form of shells
column3: rockets and missiles
column4: and visible through the terrible injuries they inflict on the bodies of civilians and soldiers alike.

column1: “Some days I think I’ve got to go
column2: it’s just too much
column3: ” Wyness said
column4: in an interview interrupted when shells started landing close to the base and the team had to race down to a basement bunker.

column1: Both the injuries and the constant threat of death are exhausting; the medics are targets for a military that has repeatedly bombed hospitals in Ukraine and in Syria
column2: killing doctors
column3: nurses and patients in defiance of international law.

column1: The medics are fundraising for armoured ambulances that would at least protect medics and patients from the worst of the shrapnel
column2: but the war has sent prices even for secondhand vehicles soaring. So for now the group race towards the frontline in ordinary vehicles that would be ripped to shreds if an artillery round landed too close.

column1: Jennifer spent $4
column3: 560) of her own money to travel from California and risk death daily to help out. She does not want her last name published because she told her mum she was only going to Poland to help refugees
column4: although she told her daughters – who are 17 and 23 – the truth.

column1: “The way I’ve raised them
column2: they understand that this is an important thing to do
column3: ” she said. “If you know something is wrong and you don’t say or do anything
column4: it’s doubly wrong.”

column1: Jennifer worked as a medic in Afghanistan
column2: on contract with the international mission
column3: so is used to conflict injuries and dangerous environments but the intensity and proximity of the fighting in Ukraine has still shocked her.

column1: “It’s more than I expected. Yesterday morning I was upstairs getting changed
column2: a rocket flew by and landed just close by. The first night we got here we were in the basement
column3: told to get ready to evacuate
column4: because they thought the Russians had breached [Ukrainian lines] and were coming.”

column1: She made up her mind to volunteer when she saw Zelenskiy appealing to the world for assistance in Ukraine’s struggle
column2: and began researching her options before contacting Gennadiy Druzenko
column3: the founder of Medbat. “It’s a struggle for freedom and they need help
column4: ” Jennifer said.

column1: Ukrainians have tried to deter foreigners who do not have military experience from trying to go to the frontlines but Martin and Jennifer have practical skills that are needed as the deaths and injuries mount among civilians and soldiers.
There are also Ukrainian medics in the team
column2: some returned from abroad
column3: others unable to get commissions in the oversubscribed military medical corps but determined to serve. Dmytro Rusnak drove back from Germany with a car full of medical aid.

column1: He had been getting ready for this moment for the best part of a decade. In 2014
column2: after Russia seized Crimea and Russian-backed proxy forces took control of parts of Donbas
column3: Rusnak changed his speciality from radiology to acute care.

column1: “I saw I had to prepare myself
column2: because at any moment it was possible that Russia could start a full war
column3: ” he said. When they did
column4: he paused only to put his contract on hold – his bosses were very understanding – and gather as much medical supplies as he could from friends and colleagues.

column1: His main worry when the shells start falling is not his own safety but the worry he is bringing his elderly parents. “Although they are proud
column2: it is very traumatic for them
column3: there are no parents who want to see their children’s funeral.”

column1: He is waiting to get his German medical qualifications certified so he can practise as a doctor in Ukraine
column2: so for now works with Wyness as an ambulance paramedic.

column1: “These years of education and preparation
column2: all these skills
column3: should be used
column4: ” he said. “I wanted to be an example
column5: you can say thousands of words
column6: make thousands of posts on social media
column7: but this means nothing … you have to act
column8: to do something.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/may/29/homes-for-ukraine-teenager-left-limbo-home-office;2022-05-29;‘It doesn’t make sense’: Ukrainian teenager left in limbo by Home Office;"Vlad Ksheminskyi
column3: is one of hundreds of teenagers still waiting for a Homes for Ukraine decision

column1: It has been two months since 16-year-old Vlad Ksheminskyi sent off the forms he hoped would trigger the start of a new life in Britain.
Vlad is one of hundreds of teenagers who applied to the Homes for Ukraine scheme having fled war without his parents. While the Home Office struggles to decide how to deal with cases like his
column2: they have been left in limbo for weeks – and even months – with no decision.

column1: “It is very difficult to be waiting
column2: knowing that my parents are one and a half thousand miles away and our destiny is still unknown
column3: ” Vlad said. “It’s very hard.”

column1: A keen student
column2: Vlad was preparing for school exams when areas around his home town of Krasyliv in western Ukraine came under intense bombing. His mum
column3: Marina
column4: was scared for his life but
column5: being unable to leave
column6: she rang her best friend
column7: Olesia Reviuk
column8: to ask if she could help her son escape.

column1: Reviuk
column3: recalled: “She was telling me that every day they could hear sirens and three or four times a day they would go down to the bomb shelter which was very cold
column4: with no water. It was impossible to sleep there at night with the sirens going off.”

column1: Reviuk did not hesitate. “I promised that I would take good care of Vlad
column2: ” she said. She arranged for him to join her and her two sons in Italy
column3: to where she had fled in February. Then
column4: with his parents’ blessing
column5: she became his legal guardian.

column1: The children spoke English and no Italian
column2: so Reviuk applied under the Homes for Ukraine scheme at the earliest opportunity.

column1: They were matched with Paul Hanlon
column2: a GP from Lancaster
column3: his wife
column4: Rebecca Shepherd
column5: an anatomy lecturer
column6: and their two young children. The British family quickly made ready two large spare bedrooms and a separate living room
column7: assuming the group would soon be arriving.

column1: Instead
column2: two months have gone by while Reviuk and the children wait in a cramped rented room in a flat in Modena
column3: Italy.

column1: Reviuk said: “Living in one bedroom with two teenage boys and one small child who wakes up at night and is also sometimes sick is very difficult for us.”
Hanlon
column3: said: “It’s so frustrating to think that they could have been enjoying the space and support on offer here
column4: but instead we’ve all been spending hundreds of hours battling with bureaucracy that seems to have been set up to deflect rather than to protect those fleeing this brutal conflict.”

column1: Hanlon is in touch with about 40 other sponsors in similar situations
column2: all despairing at the same impasse. “The government’s broad answer to most questions on the subject
column3: ‘because of safeguarding’
column4: is a cynical use of this term to avoid having to deal with the most vulnerable group affected by this war.”

column1: Given that Vlad is travelling with a legal guardian
column2: his case should be one of the straightforward ones. But it appears to have made no difference.

column1: “I do not understand the logic of safeguarding me because in my country there is a war and there is no worse security situation for me than staying there
column2: ” Vlad said. “It just doesn’t make sense to me what safeguarding issues the government could have
column3: when we have all the documents in place and Olesia is a family friend who has legal guardianship?”

column1: The Home Office has been sent a “letter before claim” over the families’ case
column2: threatening judicial review. Vlad’s lawyer
column3: Simon Robinson
column4: said: “The delay in even providing a decision while keeping the family in the dark demonstrates that the secretary of state has failed to make an adequate policy to meet the promises she has made. She is turning her back on some of the most vulnerable people fleeing the conflict
column5: children.”

column1: For Vlad
column2: the waiting means uncertainty over his education. He has only a week left to tell the Ukrainian authorities which country he will be in to take his exams remotely and is unsure what to put. He also wants to apply to university.

column1: Reviuk said: “The UK government is taking the future away from Vlad. He’s a very talented boy. He reads a lot
column2: he wants to study. And right now we just do not see the future.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/may/29/homes-for-ukraine-children-stuck-waiting-for-uk-visa-decision;2022-05-29;Over 500 Ukrainian children stuck waiting for UK visa decision;"Exclusive: sources say most have hosts ready under Homes for Ukraine scheme but have heard nothing
More than 500 Ukrainian children who fled the war without their parents are stuck waiting in limbo across Europe after applying to the Homes for Ukraine scheme
column2: sources working closely with the Home Office say.

column1: Most are teenagers who thought they would be eligible and have British families waiting to host them
column2: but have heard nothing from the Home Office.

column1: Many have been waiting for two months or more without an answer due to indecision about how to handle their cases.

Some are alone in Europe having left home thinking they would soon be joining a British family that is ready to welcome them. Others are with adult siblings or family friends who have been made legal guardians but still have no permission to come.
About 25 unaccompanied children were allowed into Britain during the first two weeks of the Homes For Ukraine scheme and ended up in care as a result
column2: sources say.

column1: Though the policy now says children cannot travel without their parents unless they are with a legal guardian
column2: the Home Office has not been offering a decision or solution to all those who applied before this was set out.

column1: Even teenagers travelling with adults who have been made legal guardians by their parents are among those caught up in the deadlock.
Stephen Kinnock
column2: the shadow immigration minister
column3: said: “I have only this week raised concerns in a letter to the immigration minister regarding the government’s policy on unaccompanied minors
column4: but this latest information reflects the potential scale of the problem.

column1: “We understand that the government needs to undertake comprehensive safeguarding checks but there is a particular question about why long delays are still happening in instances where a parent has already completed the relevant paperwork which grants permission for their child to be placed in the care of a relative.”
Earlier this month
column2: the Guardian told the story of Nazarii
column4: who was listening to war planes flying overhead in his village in western Ukraine while he waited for a decision from the Home Office. A teaching assistant and her family in Hampshire were ready to host him but he had heard nothing since submitting an application on 11 April.

column1: More than three weeks later
column2: he is still in Ukraine with no refusal or update. “The Home Office hasn’t given me any information. I don’t know what to do
column3: ” he said. “If it’s a refusal
column4: OK
column5: but without any information it’s impossible.”

column1: Beth Gardiner-Smith
column2: the chief executive of the child refugee charity Safe Passage
column3: said: “We know of far too many children who are currently stuck in limbo
column4: alone in Ukraine and neighbouring countries
column5: who are desperate to join their sponsors here in the UK. Unacceptably
column6: this is leaving lone children in dangerous and vulnerable positions
column7: at risk of exploitation.”

column1: Gardiner-Smith said the government should expand the Homes for Ukraine scheme to include unaccompanied children by working with local authorities and charities to ensure safeguarding.
Even those with British hosts ready to foster children have had no decision. Among these is severely autistic 16-year-old Timothy Tymoshenko
column2: who the Guardian reported is still waiting in Poland to be allowed to join a British foster carer.

column1: The situation is so critical that sources said it was the biggest point of concern at the latest weekly meeting of MPs’ offices with the Home Office.
Krish Kandiah
column2: the founder of the Sanctuary Foundation
column3: which is supporting British hosts in the Homes for Ukraine scheme
column4: said: “It is disturbing to hear that unaccompanied minors seeking to leave Ukraine for their own safety are waiting so long for visas when I know that there are foster carers like my own family and other appropriate hosts in the UK that are willing to care for them.”

column1: A government spokesperson said: “Due to safeguarding concerns
column2: unaccompanied minors are only eligible under the Homes for Ukraine scheme if they are reuniting with a parent or legal guardian in the UK.

column1: “The Ukrainian government has been clear that their preference is children should not be taken from Ukraine without their parents and that moving a child from their home region must be in their best interest.”"
Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/29/ukraine-donbas-donetsk-luhansk-fighting-putin-kharkiv-kyiv;2022-05-29;Fighting focuses on Donbas
column2: but Putin has not given up on Kharkiv – or Kyiv;"The outcome of Russia’s attacks on the Donetsk and Luhansk areas will determine the fate of the rest of Ukraine

column1: After three months of full-scale war against Ukraine
column2: in which ground troops invaded from several directions and missiles hit targets across the country
column3: right up to the western border with Poland
column4: the focus of the current phase of the conflict is back on the region where Russia has been fighting Ukraine for the past eight years: Donbas.

column1: Military analyst Michael Kofman wrote on Twitter last week: “The overall military balance in this war still trends in Ukraine’s favour
column2: given manpower availability and access to extensive Western military support … But the local balance in the Donbas during this phase is a different story.”

column1: How fully and how quickly Vladimir Putin attains his objectives in Donbas may dictate how and whether other parts of Ukraine come back into play. The level of losses sustained will also play a role.

Russia has abandoned attempts to encircle all Ukrainian forces in Donbas for the more modest goal of creating “cauldrons” – smaller encirclements cutting Ukrainians off from supplies and reinforcements.
Last week
column2: the focus was on the city of Sievierodonetsk
column3: where local governor Serhiy Haidai said Russia had committed 10
column4: 000 soldiers and an extra 2
column5: 500 pieces of equipment to attacking the city. There are reports that the Russians already control a hotel on the outskirts of the city
column6: after many days of ruthless bombardments.

column1: If Russia takes Sievierodonetsk
column2: it will control the entire Luhansk region
column3: and can increase its focus on parts of Donetsk it still does not control.

column1: “I don’t think the Russian offensive looks stalled
column2: and while sluggish
column3: there is no good way to predict when it will culminate
column4: ” wrote Kofman.

column1: There is no longer any doubt that Russia plans to fully annex parts of Ukraine
column2: as it did with Crimea in 2014. Then
column3: Moscow declined to do the same with the areas it controlled in east Ukraine
column4: preferring instead to prop up separatist administrations there. Now
column5: there is talk of rapid annexation of the parts of Kherson and Zaporizhzhia provinces that Russia took in the first days of the invasion.

column1: Unlike Mariupol
column2: which Russia conquered after bombing it to rubble – and possibly other cities in Donbas that Russia may soon capture – these territories were largely taken with no fighting
column3: so Russia has been able to focus on mopping up dissent and trying to take full control.

column1: The areas have seen an increased crackdown on pro-Ukrainian sentiment
column2: as well as reports that Russia is introducing the rouble and Moscow time zone
column3: announcements that teachers will be retrained in the Russian curriculum
column4: and a series of sinister videos of locals announcing on camera that they had been through “a course of denazification” and no longer support Ukraine.

column1: Formal annexation of this territory could have huge consequences for the prospect of a peace deal. Ukraine will not accept the loss of these areas
column2: but if it launches a counterattack
column3: Russia could claim Ukraine was attacking Russian territory.

column1: Life in the Ukrainian capital feels more normal by the week. The occasional air raid siren and men with guns on the streets are reminders of the war
column2: but cafe terraces are busy
column3: the opera has reopened and the curfew has been pushed back to 11pm. Since the Russians withdrew at the beginning of April
column4: there has been no artillery threat
column5: and no repeat of the booms from the suburbs that characterised the first weeks of the war.

column1: However
column2: Russian-language news outlet Meduza last week quoted Kremlin-linked sources claiming that Putin had not yet given up on Kyiv and may launch another assault once the battle for Donbas is over.

column1: As with Kyiv
column2: the Russians attempted to storm the country’s second city in the early days of the war and
column3: as in the capital
column4: they faced unexpectedly strong resistance
column5: were stalled on the outskirts and then pushed back into positions surrounding the city.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: Ukrainian forces have pushed the Russians back further but
column3: unlike with Kyiv
column4: the invaders are still within striking distance of the city. Last Thursday
column5: areas within the city limits were shelled for the first time in two weeks and nine civilians died
column6: according to local authorities.

column1: Military commanders say there is no sign of a new advance on Kharkiv
column2: but the Russians are digging firmly into the positions they still hold
column3: with no plans to retreat all the way to the border as they did elsewhere.

column1: “They are planning something
column2: ” said one commander based outside the city last week.

column1: “We may only find out what it is when it happens.”"

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/29/kherson-ukraine-diarists-escaped-city-russian-occupation;2022-05-29;‘We were lucky to escape’: Kherson diarists tell of their flight from Russians;"Their dispatches in the Observer revealed the reality of life in the occupied city. Now the two female journalists are safe in England but want to continue their work
After 48 days under Russian occupation
column2: they were so used to seeing enemy soldiers on every street corner that they thought the first Ukrainian checkpoint out of Kherson could be a trap. Arriving in a long column of cars
column3: filled mostly with women
column4: babies and pets
column5: Oksana Borisova and Alisa Poliakova (who are speaking under pseudonyms to protect their families still living in occupied territory)
column6: didn’t dare trust that they were safe.

column1: For weeks
column2: Russian soldiers had stalked them around the southern Ukrainian city in Z-marked vehicles
column3: destroyed their livelihoods
column4: imprisoned and tortured their friends and lobbed grenades at them at rallies. But after driving past seven Russian checkpoints over 10 hours to Mykolaiv – a journey that prewar would have taken an hour – and surviving a close encounter with a missile
column5: they had finally reached what appeared to be a Ukrainian soldier.

column1: “You understand that it should be our territory
column2: and you see the soldier
column3: but can’t distinguish the military signs on his uniform
column4: ” said Borisova
column5: now in the UK
column6: recalling their escape last month. “And you think: ‘Well
column7: Russian or Ukrainian?’”

column1: The confirmation she was looking for came when
column2: the car window lowered to the greeting “dobrogo dnia!” (Ukrainian for “Good day”). She could have hugged him
column3: she said. “Because now I believed that the Ukrainian army exists. Since 24 February we hadn’t seen our soldiers.”

column1: In a series of dispatches for the Observer at the start of the war
column2: the two female Ukrainian journalists bravely documented the horrors of life in occupied Kherson – from the city’s brave resistance to looming humanitarian disaster and burying the dead. But they also offered an insight into how
column3: despite it all
column4: residents fiercely continued to find glimmers of joy: a tale of young hospital interns getting married; drinking coffee at their favourite coffee shop under the roar of artillery strikes. There were scenes of dark humour too. In one dispatch
column5: they described how a queue of civilians laughed a group of empty-handed Russian soldiers out of the butcher’s shop because they were unimpressed with the quality of meat available.

column1: Despite growing numbers of people leaving
column2: the escalating danger – particularly for journalists – and dwindling supplies
column3: the old friends
column4: who are both in their 50s
column5: hadn’t planned to leave their home city.

column1: Despite writing anonymously
column2: they feared being identified by their reporting. One of their friends
column3: Oleh Baturin
column4: was detained and tortured for eight days and threatened with mutilation and death
column5: and Maxim Negrov
column6: the owner of the online newspaper Postfactum
column7: was arrested and detained. They also worried that if the city were liberated it could lead to further killings by Russian soldiers.

column1: But it was only when they were offered seats in friends’ cars that they made the decision to go. Borisova in a car with her daughter-in-law and a baby
column2: and Poliakova with a friend and her cat. Their husbands and sons remain in Kherson.

column1: “I made up my mind very quickly
column2: during half a day
column3: ” said Borisova. “Not because of me
column4: more for the sake of my daughter-in-law because my son begged me. Now with all these Bucha stories [of rape]
column5: he was very afraid. He said: ‘I will sleep well when you girls get out of Kherson.’” She added: “That chance was given to me and it was too foolish not to take it.”

column1: They left just in time. Just a few days ago
column2: an acquaintance was shot in the head and killed trying to escape. His family were not allowed to bury him. “Now I’m ready to pay any money for my son to leave
column3: ” said Borisova. “And I told him frankly: ‘Don’t bargain
column4: pay anything they want
column5: I will get money for you.’” Her mother
column6: who her husband has promised to take care of while she is away
column7: is dying with cancer.

column1: After reaching Mykolaiv
column2: they went to Odesa
column3: which
column4: initially at least
column5: felt like “a resort”. At a cafe
column6: they drank good coffee and ate fish
column7: revelling in the fact that they didn’t have to worry about being harassed by Russian soldiers. But when bombing started
column8: they realised it wasn’t safe there either.

column1: With the help of Christian volunteers
column2: they travelled for free by bus to Germany via Moldova
column3: where they stayed at a shelter for two nights
column4: before reaching Halle where they had been invited to Artist and the City
column5: a residency on the role of public spaces. Last week
column6: they arrived at Stansted under the Homes for Ukraine scheme after a London-based friend found them a host.

column1: After months of communicating online
column2: this is our first time meeting in person. Sat side by side on a sofa in the quiet Surrey suburbs
column3: Poliakova wearing a blue T-shirt and Borisova a hoodie that says “I speak fluent sarcasm” across it
column4: they seem remarkably calm and pragmatic on the surface – direct and quick to laugh and joke – but as they talk the heaviness of their deep pain seeps through.

column1: Although arriving in the UK was in some ways a relief
column2: they continue to suffer from the steady stream of debilitating updates from home via Telegram. “This news makes us anxious
column3: depressed
column4: we cry
column5: ” said Borisova. “We cry every day.”

column1: Before the war
column2: their lives in Kherson were busy and full. Borisova travelled throughout Europe
column3: writing about architecture and contemporary art
column4: and Poliakova reported on political and social issues. In the summer
column5: they spent holidays and weekends at the nearby seaside. Now
column6: however
column7: the shore has been mined by Russia.

column1: While it was not very prosperous and had fallen victim to corruption
column2: Kherson was “a cosy city and very warm”
column3: they said
column4: and had potential as a tourist attraction. They had a new mayor
column5: Ihor Kolykhaiev
column6: who they hoped would restore the city with new green zones and public spaces. But after the invasion of Ukraine and a battle for the city
column7: on 2 March Kherson became the first to fall. Kolykhaiev has since been replaced by a pro-Russian administration.

column1: After the Russians arrived
column2: they said
column3: the city was “cut off from the rest of the country immediately”. The television centre was quickly seized and the vast majority of residents did not have time to leave. “The next day we were absolutely sieged.”

column1: Living under occupation
column2: the issue of trust has become a life or death matter. “We stopped talking to anyone
column3: it’s a paranoia
column4: ” said Borisova. “You stop believing people.” To illustrate
column5: Poliakova cites the example of a former city manager who was such a convincing patriot with his “perfect Ukrainian”
column6: slogans and speeches but turned out to be a Russian collaborator.

column1: Although for weeks they continued to attend daily protests in the city’s Freedom Square
column2: a sense of escalating threat and distrust was palpable in their occupation diaries and in my communications with them. In one of their final Signal messages before they left
column3: Borisova expressed doubt they would stay alive.

column1: How did their feelings change under occupation? “From great
column2: great fear to some acceptance of reality to total despair
column3: because nothing helps you to accept it really
column4: ” said Borisova. She compares waking up under occupation to the film Groundhog Day. “It’s a nightmare and you feel like the day is repeating and repeating.”

column1: The streets were littered with explosives disguised as toys and they were watchful entering their homes. Each day
column2: from around 3pm
column3: the streets would empty out when soldiers started patrolling. People hid in their houses to avoid being shot. “Riding their vehicles around with their machine guns they could be drunk sometimes and just start firing. So it was quite dangerous wandering around in the evening
column4: ” said Borisova.

column1: While it was rare to see the Russians engaging in terrible acts in the morning
column2: they could be hungry and angry. “They were told in Russia that we would be happy to have them there. And they couldn’t understand
column3: it was a paradoxical thing for them
column4: that we were not waving flowers and Russian flags.”

column1: For weeks
column2: the Russian response to the daily protests was muted
column3: giving them the confidence to carry on. “It was a very surprising thing for me personally
column4: and for others I suppose
column5: that why they allowed protests so long
column6: ” said Borisova
column7: who now sees it as a tactic to paint them as “aggressive Nazis” rising up against “peaceful Russian soldiers”. But on 21 March
column8: the protesters were taken by complete surprise when they were met with grenades. The next day
column9: there was teargas and shooting and Borisova narrowly escaped with her life. Rally numbers dwindled and soon the protests stopped.

column1: “For the first time we saw lots of blood on the ground and we understood it was the end of peaceful rallies
column2: ” she said with sombre finality. “They showed us
column3: ‘OK people
column4: we’re fed up with it.’”

column1: Now
column2: they said
column3: life in Kherson is very tough. There are no jobs
column4: Russia has stolen their grain and people are being paid in food instead of money. Meanwhile
column5: the shops are full of expensive food from Moldova and regions of Russia that most couldn’t afford to buy
column6: even if they wanted to.

column1: “For people who stayed there
column2: nothing will help them except themselves
column3: ” said Poliakova. “So they start making gardens
column4: orchards near their houses to provide themselves with some food.”

column1: Sometimes medicines are smuggled in
column2: but it’s painfully insufficient.

column1: “So many countries of the world are ready to help us but it’s not very easy to squeeze between all these checkpoints
column2: ” said Borisova. “They’re numerous. And sometimes they’re in good mood
column3: sometimes they’re furious
column4: so it’s quite a roulette.”

column1: Trying to escape now can mean spending several days in battlefields surrounded by explosions. “We were lucky to escape within one day
column2: ” said Borisova. “But after the roadblocks are getting more and more numerous
column3: people spend two-three days. You’re very
column4: very scared. You are in the centre of the battle.” A ghost city would be bad for Russian propaganda
column5: she said
column6: but not everyone wants to leave. There are those who are prepared to cooperate and are informing on their neighbours.

column1: Although many of its residents speak Russian
column2: the journalists said there has been a sharp rejection of Russia since 2014
column3: when Moscow annexed nearby Crimea
column4: but Russian culture was not cancelled entirely. But now
column5: as she translates the eyewitness accounts of Ukrainian women and girls who have been killed and raped by Russian soldiers for a book about the war
column6: Borisova said she cannot tolerate anything Russian.

column1: “When you come through this terror and see these atrocities … I couldn’t bear it
column2: ” she said. “While translating
column3: I was just crying. I stopped for a while to comfort myself but it’s unbearable to read all of this.”

column1: Since arriving in the UK they have been received with warmth and kindness
column2: immediately bonding with their host over their shared love of Monty Python
column3: but it has also been overwhelming. Borisova is trying to see it as an adventure
column4: but Poliakova feels a strong pull back to Ukraine. They want to continue their journalistic work
column5: documenting Ukrainians’ experiences of the invasion and hope to write a book.

column1: “We are very conscious that our psychological conditions are very fragile. Not stable
column2: ” said Borisova. But she hopes that every day spent in the UK will help distract them from their grief. “This routine
column3: this desire to see another places
column4: meeting with other people will help us to cope and to overcome.”"

Military support can reduce over time and probably the economic support will become more important as the fighting gradually subsides.”"

In the sparkling azure waters of Antigua

column1: On the ninth day of Vladimir Putin’s war in Ukraine
column2: editor-in-chief Viktor Muchnik gathered the staff of TV2 for a meeting at their small newsroom in the Siberian city of Tomsk.

column1: New wartime laws meant the whole newsroom risked jailtime for reporting on the conflict
column2: Muchnik told them
column3: and TV2 had just been officially blocked by Russia’s communications watchdog
column4: along with many other independent media outlets.

column1: “All of us who wanted to change things for the better here
column2: at this moment we can feel we have failed
column3: ” said Muchnik
column4: reflecting bitterly on his three decades of work at one of Russia’s most resilient media outlets.

column1: The journalists drained glasses of wine
column2: and almost everybody cried. Then Muchnik signed resignation papers for the entire collective. A few days later
column3: he and his wife
column4: Viktoria
column5: who also worked for TV2 for more than a quarter of a century
column6: packed a couple of suitcases and flew out of Russia
column7: probably for ever.

column1: “One reason was professional: the thing you’ve been doing for so long has been killed. The other one was human. Neither of us wanted to be inside this space
column2: in this country which has launched a war
column3: and living among people who support this war
column4: ” said Muchnik
column5: in an interview in the Armenian capital Yerevan

column1: For years
column2: TV2 was an anomaly in the Russian media landscape
column3: an island of media freedom in the Siberian university town of Tomsk. From its chaotic yet idealistic beginnings as the Soviet Union collapsed
column4: through various gritty battles with authorities

column6: defiance and ultimately defeat

column1: The channel was the brainchild of Arkady Maiofis
column2: a reporter on Soviet television who wanted to create a place for free debate in 1991 as the Soviet Union was on its last legs. At the time
column3: Muchnik was a young history professor attracted by the idea of making political programmes; the first cameraman was a former policeman

column1: “Arkady was the only one who knew anything about television – the rest of us were straight off the street. We had one VHS camera
column2: and we made programmes and took them to the television tower. They put it out for us
column3: ” recalled Muchnik.

column1: For entertainment
column2: the channel showed American films: they located pirated cassettes at the market and broadcast them
column3: happily oblivious to copyright concerns.

column1: The channel came into its own in August 1991 during the coup from reactionary forces who wanted to restore hardline Soviet rule. As the central television stations went dark
column2: TV2 journalists got updates by calling friends in Moscow and broadcasting the latest news to viewers in Tomsk. Later
column3: TV2 sent a two-person crew to Moscow to film events. The journalists sent the tapes back with pilots flying to Tomsk.

column1: So it was that television viewers in the heart of Siberia got more relevant information than those watching at home in Moscow
column2: thousands of miles away.

column2: the channel’s journalists felt they were riding on a wave of freedom. Local politicians did not much like TV2
column3: but they felt obliged to come to the studio for interviews.

column1: But then

column4: I didn’t like his smile and his way of speaking
column5: ” said Muchnik.

column1: Gradually
column2: the space for free programming began to shrink. It did not help that the channel was purchased by the oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky
column3: who kept his promise not to interfere in editorial policy but left the authorities suspicious that the channel was his personal mouthpiece.

column1: By this time
column2: TV2 was a media holding with several radio stations and two television channels. A nine-story building to house the media group was under construction when Khodorkovsky was arrested in 2003 in a sign of Putin’s intention to make sure the oligarchs stayed out of politics.

column1: The channel survived Khodorkovsky’s arrest but the pressure on independent media outlets kept increasing. In 2007
column2: the channel received a series of unofficial warnings from Moscow.

column1: “It was made clear: if you want to attack the mayor
column2: that’s fine; if you want to attack the governor
column3: that’s just about OK
column4: but please don’t attack Putin
column5: ” said Muchnik.

column1: ”And how are you supposed to leave Putin out of it if you want to do journalism in our wonderful country? If you get into any problem
column2: before long you arrive at the Kremlin
column3: because that’s how the system is built
column4: ” he said.

column1: The channel continued to host opposition figures such as Boris Nemtsov and Alexei Navalny
column2: banned from the airwaves of most Russian television stations

column1: At the end of 2013

column3: and put out reports on the subsequent annexation of Crimea that had a very different flavour from those on state television.

column1: “Our reporting alienated us not only from the authorities but also part of our audience
column2: who started sending us abuse
column3: ” said Muchnik.

column1: A month later
column2: the channel was taken off the air
column3: due to supposed technical problems
column4: and at the end of 2014 it was formally closed down. TV2 went from a media holding with more than 250 employees to a website run by a team of 15 people. Authorities refused to register the website as a media outlet
column5: meaning they were banned from attending press conferences or requesting official commentary.

column1: Despite this
column2: TV2 continued to have impact beyond its modest means. During the Covid pandemic
column3: TV2 journalists received calls from doctors
column4: talking of a catastrophe that state television pretended didn’t exist. People sent footage of patients lying on the floor for a lack of beds.

column1: The site broke several Covid-related stories: a man who dressed up as a doctor to care for his grandmother and recorded the awful conditions in the hospital in the process
column2: and a family who were told their grandmother had died
column3: but when they opened the coffin found the body of a stranger.

column1: Working in these conditions was hard yet possible – but the invasion of Ukraine in February was a game-changer.
A new Russian law about “fakes” meant the entire newsroom could be jailed for their coverage. In these conditions
column2: Muchnik took the decision to close down the station.

column1: “We couldn’t convey to people what was happening in their own country
column2: and that hurts me

column2: and she said
column3: ‘Why did you have to talk so much

column1: Like many recent Russian emigres

column1: They hope they will be able to continue to have an influence on politics in Russia from outside the country

column1: “It’s very difficult to exist inside this atmosphere of militaristic hysteria. We will not go back until the collapse of the regime

column1: As Russia’s invasion of Ukraine began
column2: the director of the Museum of Local History in Melitopol in the south-east of the country
column3: Leila Ibrahimova
column4: arranged for a hoard of gold artefacts from ancient Scythia to be hidden. Just a few weeks later
column5: she was kidnapped and interrogated by Russian troops. They demanded to know where the Scythian gold was; she refused to cooperate. Subsequently the museum’s curator Galina Andriivna Kucher was taken at gunpoint to the museum and asked to show a Russian “expert” and agents where the gold was. She also refused to locate the collection. Kucher was later abducted from her home on 30 April and her whereabouts remains unknown.

column1: According to a report on the theft in the New York Times
column2: Russian troops eventually found the gold hoard
column3: which dates back to the fourth century BC
column4: boxed up in the museum’s basement. The items were taken to Donetsk
column5: in the Russian-controlled Donbas region
column6: for “safety”
column7: with the museum’s newly installed puppet director
column8: Evgeny Gorlachev
column9: stating that the gold artefacts were not just for Ukrainians but “of great cultural value for the entire former Soviet Union”. His carefully chosen words were designed to erase the collection’s Ukrainian heritage and replace it with a Soviet one
column10: one that suggested Ukraine was back within Russia’s sphere of influence and control.

column1: To date
column2: Russian forces have caused the destruction or severe damage of 250 museums and institutions in Ukraine. Twenty-five paintings by Ukrainian folk artist Maria Prymachenko were incinerated after the Museum of Local History in Ivankiv was hit by a missile. The Arkhip Kuindzhi museum in the besieged city of Mariupol was badly damaged by an airstrike that left paintings exposed to the elements
column3: hanging on walls amid piles of rubble. The Cultural Heritage Monitoring Lab
column4: run by the Virginia Museum of Natural History in association with the Smithsonian
column5: has already logged more than 110 memorials destroyed by Russian weapons. But as well as destroying museums and galleries
column6: Russian troops are accused of having stolen an estimated 2
column7: 000 artworks. In addition to the theft of the Scythian gold in Melitopol
column8: in Mariupol a handwritten Torah scroll and a valuable gospel printed in Venice in 1811 were all have been taken.

column1: Autocratic leaders seizing art as a means to rewriting a nation’s cultural history and advance their interests is nothing new: in 1937
column2: Hitler confiscated 17
column3: 000 works of art from more than 100 German museums in less than a month. Some were shown in his Degenerate Art exhibition but many were destroyed or “lost”. Napoleon had cartloads of masterpieces shipped to Paris from all over Europe: the classical sculptures Apollo Belvedere and Laocoön from Italy; Rubens’s The Descent from the Cross from Belgium. But these latest thefts are in keeping with Putin’s attempts to erase Ukraine’s independent history and promote his own expansionist model of a new Russian empire.

column1: It is clear that Putin sees the Scythian gold as particularly central to Ukraine’s cultural identity and independence. It is not the first time he has tried to claim it for Russia. In 2014
column2: examples of Scythian gold were on loan to the Allard Pierson museum in Amsterdam. Four of the Ukrainian museums that had issued the loans were in Crimea. As Putin invaded and annexed Crimea
column3: he pressed the Netherlands to send the gold back. A protracted legal battle ensued and only in October 2021 did a judge finally rule that the works categorically belonged to the State Museum Fund of Ukraine and not the Russian-controlled Crimean museums (the works remain in the Dutch museum’s stores).

column1: When the paintings that were forcibly removed from Mariupol are also considered
column2: a clear pattern emerges. These works have been chosen to undermine Ukraine’s national identity. Paintings by western European artists have not been targeted
column3: for example. Instead it is the work of Ukrainian-Russian artists that has been stolen. Take 19th-century maritime painter Ivan Aivazovsky. Born in Feodosiya
column4: a Crimean port
column5: he was a leading Romantic artist who painted heavy seas
column6: golden sunsets and storm-tossed ships. The slightly younger Arkhip Kuindzhi
column7: another whose works were taken
column8: was born in Mariupol. His paintings are the calm before Aivazovsky’s storm: landscapes of harmonious tranquillity. Both painters worked in regions that are now in modern-day Ukraine and Russia
column9: and both countries claim the artists as their own. Other works stolen are by Tetyana Yablonska (1917–2005)
column10: a politically active Ukrainian painter who was born in Smolensk
column11: Russia
column12: and Mykola Hlushchenko (1901–1977)
column13: who lived in Donetsk from an early age but was likewise born in Russia. Russia’s line of thinking seems to be that if it seizes such paintings by Ukrainian-Russian artists then the contested territory they once called home will follow.

column1: There is hope
column2: however. The resilience Ukraine is showing in the war is mirrored by the country’s response to this parallel attack on its culture. At the Venice Biennale
column3: the exhibition This Is Ukraine was crowded with artists
column4: with President Zelenskiy’s handwritten slogan “We are defending our freedom” adorning the side of the building. One of the artists involved
column5: Nikita Kadan
column6: created a work from war-damaged metal shards collected from Donbas during the war of 2014 and the current onslaught. He uses his Instagram account to record damage to Ukrainian museums but also to show how the country is protecting its cultural assets
column7: posting photographs of monuments across the country
column8: wrapped in blankets and tape or surrounded by hundreds of sandbags. All Ukrainians are aware that their heritage is under direct attack.
