Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/games/2022/may/27/from-the-invasion-of-ukraine-to-weapons-procurement-the-war-games-seeking-solutions-to-real-life-conflicts;2022-05-27;From the invasion of Ukraine to weapons procurement: the war games seeking solutions to real-life conflicts;"At King’s College London
column2: students are designing games that explore diplomacy
column3: drones and the psychological impact of battle. But can they really help?

column1: On the second floor of the stately King’s College London building on the Strand
column2: Vladimir Putin
column3: Emmanuel Macron
column4: Olaf Scholz and Joe Biden are sitting around a table studying a map of Ukraine. They are here to negotiate the future of the country
column5: but they all have ulterior objectives too. Germany wants to ensure the safe transit of refugees; the US wants Russia to cease its disinformation campaign; France wants trade; and Russia needs dozens of sanctions to be lifted. But nobody is giving anything away. It’s tense as hell and the clock is ticking.

column1: This is not real
column2: of course
column3: it’s just a game – but it’s a game with serious intentions. Today
column4: the heads of state are being played by four people attending an event organised by the university’s department of war studies. Several students who have taken an MA module entitled Designing Wargames for Education & Analysis are showing games they have created to a select crowd of wargaming professionals
column5: members of the military and representatives of a few big corporations.

column1: Wargaming is essentially the competitive simulation of conflict
column2: usually on some sort of map board with a variety of playing pieces. Chess can be understood as a heavily abstracted version
column3: but there are detailed
column4: complex games based on everything from the unification of Japan (Sekigahara) to apocalyptic sci-fi combat (Warhammer 40
column5: 000). Wargames have also been used extensively by military forces for about 200 years in order to plan real-life campaigns and role-play possible outcomes. The UK’s Defence Science and Technology Laboratory (DSTL) has a dedicated Defence Wargaming Centre near Portsmouth
column6: while the US Marine Corps is currently building a Wargaming and Analysis Center at its base in Quantico
column7: Virginia.

column1: One of those attending is an expert from the MoD who assures me the Ukraine invasion has been heavily war-gamed by both Nato and Russian military planners. Indeed
column2: a report published by the Royal United Services Institute in February claimed that Russian forces ran wargames preceding the invasion in order to plan an attack on Ukraine’s infrastructure using assets within the country.

column1: The Ukraine game here today is called War and Change and was designed by Sacha Nacouzi
column2: currently studying for an MA in international security. The main aim for the western countries is to get Russia out of Ukraine
column3: but each country also has to secure its own interests in the region. Meanwhile the player representing Russia must seek to end sanctions
column4: reopen trade routes and get back on the Swift financial system. The action is separated into a series of 10 five-minute rounds
column5: in which players negotiate
column6: swap asset cards and work out mini deals. It’s more like a fantasy role-playing game
column7: especially as Nacouzi encourages players to mimic the personalities and policies of the leaders they are portraying.

column1: When I take part
column2: I get stuck with Donald Trump
column3: who is voted back in to power early in the game. I decide this means I should seek to grab the most valuable Ukrainian territories back from Russia so that I can look like a tough guy
column4: while also reopening US airspace to Russian craft and unfreezing the assets of oligarchs so I can suck up to my pal Putin.

column1: “The game is designed to provide a holistic overview of issues considered in territorial negotiations
column2: ” says Nacouzi. “This includes the strategic placements of regions
column3: borders
column4: trade agreements
column5: agrifood exports
column6: economic sanctions
column7: gas and oil.” Her hope is that players come away with a better understanding of the assets countries have at their disposal and the kinds of liabilities they face in complex negotiations.

column1: On a table beside War and Change
column2: another group is playing Guns N’ Money
column3: a game about weapons procurement. Nearby there’s Shooting Daedalus
column4: about the tactics of modern urban combat.

column1: What is interesting about these games is that the students don’t come from the professional wargame sector
column2: so they’re unencumbered by conventional thinking and design rules. “It’s precisely because the students don’t have a professional background that they have a way of thinking of questions or ideas that you wouldn’t otherwise see
column3: ” says the event’s organiser
column4: David Banks
column5: a wargaming lecturer and academic director of the Wargaming Network at King’s College London. “One of the designers of the game about urban warfare was an architect – he’s really interested in the use of space. The diversity of life experiences on this course really helps. They don’t fall back on things they’ve learned or played.”

column1: The next game I play illustrates this pretty clearly. Called Don’t Fear the Reaper Drone
column2: it’s a simulation of drone warfare involving two players
column3: one taking part as a drone pilot
column4: the other as their commanding officer. In each round a possible target is identified on the board
column5: which represents a satellite image
column6: and the CO gives the pilot the command to strike. The pilot needs to follow that order or play an action card to question the directive. Each square on the board has a number relating to how many civilians may be killed if an attack goes ahead. Some of the actions are “signature strikes”
column7: where the drone spots someone who looks like
column8: or is behaving like
column9: a known enemy target but their identity is not confirmed. The outcome of each strike is decided by the roll of the dice and if things go wrong
column10: the pilot could be responsible for civilian casualties. When this happens
column11: the player loses moral points
column12: and they need to draw cards that show photographs of their victims. Repeated failures lead to increasing mental health difficulties and eventually incapacitating depression.

column1: It is uncommon for wargames to model psychological outcomes
column2: and I ask the game’s lead designer
column3: Edward McEvoy
column4: if there has been interest from those attending. “Yes
column5: ” he says. “Some of the experts we’ve spoken to today think that games that explore the human aspects of war and conflict could give new perspectives that may change certain policies. Perhaps they’ll even lead to less conflict.”

column1: Wargames aren’t employed only by the military. Corporations use them to explore business decisions; government policymakers use them to simulate major events
column2: including pandemics; and they have a role in disaster relief. “The UNHCR has made efforts in various cities to help with the influx of Ukrainian refugees and provide relief to civic centres and to other spaces housing many people and aid workers
column3: ” says Lily Boland
column4: co-designer of Don’t Fear the Reaper Drone. “Wargaming and/or simulating some of these crucial aspects of refugee aid work would certainly help organisations like the UN and local institutions to prepare for these scenarios in advance.”

column1: What the situation in Ukraine has shown the world is that the outcomes of military action are becoming less predictable. Russia’s command and control strategy has been found wanting
column2: while Volodymyr Zelenskiy’s innovative and playful use of social media has increased awareness and support for his country in a way that would have been tough to forecast. As Banks puts it
column3: “I’m a huge believer in using historical case studies as much as possible
column4: but a lot of the problems we’re facing in the 21st century are not ones that we have any ready guides for.”

column1: As the world becomes ever more unpredictable and prone to disruptive global events
column2: perhaps new strategies and solutions will be discovered in games like these."

column1: For the last three months
column2: 600 people have slept in the Heroiv Pratsi metro station in Kharkiv
column3: north-east Ukraine. The city lies just 40km (25 miles) from the Russian border and has been heavily shelled since the first day of the invasion. Last week
column4: the mayor of Kharkiv urged the temporary residents of Heroiv Pratsi to return to their homes. I first visited Heroiv Pratsi in mid-March
column5: and recently returned to the metro station a few days before the mayor’s announcement. I was amazed by how well-maintained people’s temporary sleeping areas had become since my previous visit. Bouquets of lilac and daffodils had been placed next to almost every mattress.

column1: Nina Maksymivna
column2: an 80-year-old woman who had been staying in Heroiv Pratsi on my last visit
column3: was still sleeping by the stairs in the same place where I had met her in March. Aside from very brief forays outside
column4: she had barely left the underground in two months. It’s still possible to hear sounds of distant explosions in the area. For her
column5: they were too close to feel safe. The Ukrainian army pushed the Russians back from Kharkiv’s outskirts in early May
column6: but local fighting continues.

column1: At 3am during my night in Kharkiv city centre
column2: I was awoken by a loud bang. Still
column3: I’m told this was nothing compared to how the city felt weeks ago. In Saltivka
column4: the most damaged neighbourhood of Kharkiv
column5: which had been inaccessible for some time
column6: all that remains are empty buildings and burnt-out blocks. Russian troops are still stationed less than a mile away. On my recent visit
column7: I met residents returning to check whether any of their belongings had survived. Men and women were cleaning the streets
column8: some obviously shocked to see what remained. A local shipping company was helping people to move fridges and TV sets. “Long live Saltivka
column9: ” one of their guys
column10: who was loading a lorry
column11: shouted to me as I passed.

column1: Almost two million people were living in Kharkiv at the start of the war. There are still more than a million left
column2: and many more are now returning. The Kyiv to Kharkiv express trains are now packed. For Ukrainians
column3: the decision to return is rational
column4: but only if two conditions are met: first
column5: if your house survived the shelling
column6: and your water and electricity supply are fixed. Second
column7: if there’s still a chance of getting a job. After three months of war
column8: people’s savings are depleted. Many working-age adults are returning home to Kharkiv
column9: leaving family members and friends to look after kids and elderly relatives in safer towns. But it’s especially hard for families where relatives have joined the army.

column1: Compared to Kharkiv
column2: my native Kyiv feels strangely normal
column3: despite the curfew
column4: the not yet fully operational public transport
column5: and the occasional air-raid siren. Yet the war still goes on. The major battles are being fought in Donbas
column6: in the south of Ukraine. In the newly occupied area around the southern city of Kherson
column7: people are being kidnapped and tortured. I covered the Russian invasion of Donbas and Crimea in 2014. My biggest fear now is that Ukrainians in Kyiv and the west of the country will get used to the distant battles unfolding hundreds of kilometres away
column8: and ignore the war. Last time
column9: the unresolved conflicts in Donbas and Crimea became a pretext for the Kremlin’s full-scale attack.

column1: Yet
column2: finding myself recently at a small party in Kyiv
column3: I know this time it’s different: there is nobody in the country untouched by the war. At the party
column4: I spoke to one of Ukraine’s most famous travel bloggers
column5: who is now making stories not from exotic far-flung locations
column6: but from liberated Ukrainian towns. He is originally from occupied Luhansk
column7: in the east. Every one of us at the party had a friend who had been killed
column8: lost a house
column9: became a refugee or is fighting on the frontline.

column1: As a conflict reporter I know that wars cause societies to disintegrate. But from what I’ve seen
column2: Ukrainians
column3: and in particular Kyiv residents (who were previously known for their briskness and focus on work)
column4: have become kinder and warmer. The discussions that prevail are about rebuilding the country for the better. Professionals who helped with the logistics during the first months of the military invasion are now figuring out how their skills might be useful in a new environment. My cousin
column5: an architect
column6: recently called to tell me how his university mates have been united in developing a plan for rebuilding the country’s demolished infrastructure.

column1: I find it hardest to interact with foreign experts and analysts. One veteran reporter from the Balkans recently told me that the longer the war lasted
column2: the less she could understand its goal. Perplexed
column3: I responded that Ukrainians saw the goal even more clearly now than before: to defend cities from invasion while ensuring the fewest possible casualties and to liberate the occupied territories
column4: where the atrocities have been greatest.

column1: Despite the many positive surprises we have seen during the war – including the strength of the Ukrainian army
column2: which has shown itself to be more efficient compared to Russia’s poorly organised troops – for Ukrainians
column3: it is going on exactly as we imagined. We knew that if we were attacked
column4: it would last a long time. I’ve head many times that Ukrainians should manage their expectations
column5: and that “compassion fatigue” is inevitable from the west. But Ukrainians aren’t asking for compassion: we’re asking for solidarity. We’re fighters
column6: not powerless victims.

column1: Yes – Ukrainians are adjusting to the war
column2: and trying to make daily life more bearable
column3: as the people who put flowers near their beds in the Kharkiv metro attest. But this doesn’t mean we have to normalise the conflict. Discussions about rebuilding the country and victory come not from naivety: they are rooted in the knowledge that we can’t afford to waste energy and time explaining why things are impossible. We need to preserve our strength to prove the opposite is true.

column1: In Kyiv
column2: I recently passed by a bookstore that was still open. It sold funny socks with infamous phrases such as “Russian ship
column3: go fuck yourself”. On the label of one pair was written: “Made of 92% cotton
column4: 8% Lycra
column5: and 100% trust in Ukraine”.

column1: Nataliya Gumenyuk is a Ukrainian journalist specialising in foreign affairs and conflict reporting
column2: and the author of Lost Island: Tales from the Occupied Crimea (2020)"

column1: An increasingly bitter diplomatic row over Germany’s unwillingness to supply heavy weaponry to Ukraine threatened to spill into a wider dispute between allies over whether they are prepared to accept a peace settlement that leaves Vladimir Putin capable of claiming victory.
One western official said western leaders are divided between those who think they can work with Vladimir Putin’s Russia once the war is over
column2: and those who think they cannot.

column1: The row is leading to disputes over the arming of Ukraine
column2: the feasibility of enforcing a Russian oil import embargo and whether Kyiv will have to accept a further loss of territory at the end of the war as the price for peace.

column1: The immediate point of conflict between Ukraine and some of its allies focusses on the supply of weaponry to Ukraine
column2: and the heavy weather Germany seems to be making in setting up an elaborate chain that would see the country supplying armaments to its Eastern neighbours – principally Poland and the Czech Republic – that would in turn send armoury on to Ukraine.

column1: Kyiv is suffering serious losses due to the absence of long-range weaponry. The commander-in-chief of Ukraine’s armed forces
column2: Valerii Zaluzhnyi
column3: said the delivery of weapons could not be delayed: “We are in great need of weapons that will make it possible to hit the enemy from a long distance.”

column1: Citing its sources in Nato
column2: the national news agency
column3: Deutsche Presse Agentur
column4: reported that alliance members have informally agreed not to supply certain weaponry to Ukraine
column5: fearing Russia could see the delivery of tanks and combat aircraft as the west entering the war and take retaliatory measures. Quite what this decision means in practical terms is disputed.

column1: There were also US-sourced reports that Israel had rejected a US request to allow Germany to send Spike anti-tank missiles to Ukraine. Spike missiles are produced in Germany with Israeli technology under an Israeli licence. Since the beginning of Russia’s large-scale invasion of Ukraine in February
column2: Israel has taken a neutral stance and refused to supply weapons to Ukraine.

column1: The disputes come as some influential US voices
column2: from veteran diplomat Henry Kissinger to the New York Times
column3: have urged Ukraine to realise it may have to lose territory to Putin.

column1: In a reference to the tensions
column2: the UK foreign secretary Liz Truss
column3: a staunch war hawk
column4: warned the West against backsliding and appeasement
column5: insisting the need to supply arms was urgent in a speech in Sarajevo: “What we cannot have is any lifting of sanctions
column6: any appeasement
column7: which will simply make Putin stronger in the longer term.” She insists private sanctions on Russia cannot be lifted until Putin has completely left Ukraine
column8: and his army is irreversibly weakened. She has strong allies in eastern Europe
column9: and the Baltics
column10: but not in Paris or Berlin.

column1: Truss has argued that any backsliding would result in a more prolonged and painful conflict.
Ukraine’s foreign minister
column2: Dmytro Kuleba
column3: adopted an ironic
column4: almost uncomprehending tone at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week about the slowness of arms deliveries: “We are pursuing this with strategic patience. I don’t understand why this is so difficult.” The president
column5: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column6: sensed German reticence stemmed from a desire to rebuild relations with Putin once the war ends. “No matter what the Russian state does
column7: there is someone who says: ‘Let’s take his interests into account’
column8: ” said Zelenskiy.

column1: Poland has also heavily criticised Germany’s slowness
column2: and within Germany the chancellor
column3: Olaf Scholz
column4: has come under attack for appearing not to want either side to emerge victorious from the war
column5: a stance Scholz denies.

column1: Marie-Agnes Strack-Zimmermann
column2: chair of the Bundestag Defense Committee and a member of the Free Democrat party
column3: said: “It must not be that at the end of the war the world sees Germany as a complete brakeman and loser just because we are unable to organise and communicate.”

column1: Early in the conflict Germany proposed quickly supplying Ukraine with heavy weaponry in a “ring system” – whereby eastern European countries such as Poland and the Czech Republic would provide Soviet-era tanks to Ukraine
column2: with these being replenished by modern German Leopard tanks. Whether the failure to achieve this yet is due to bureaucratic inertia
column3: cynical procrastination or a reflection of the depleted state of the German armed forces is hard to unravel. If you are on the frontline
column4: it probably matters little.

column1: In a speech in Davos
column2: Scholz tried to dismiss claims that he did not understand the scale of the issues at stake. He said the 24 February invasion had come like a thunderclap.

column1: He described Putin’s war as “imperialism” that is “trying to bomb us back to a time when war was a common tool. It is not only the statehood of Ukraine at stake but a world order that binds might to law”. He claimed Putin had already missed all of his strategic goals. “A capture of all of Ukraine by Russia seems further away today than it was at the beginning of the war. More than ever
column2: Ukraine is emphasising its European future.”

column1: He added that “our goal is clear. Putin must not win this war”. His remarks
column2: insisting there can be no peace dictated by Putin
column3: contrast with those of Boris Johnson
column4: who has always insisted Putin must lose the war and be seen to lose the war.

column1: Truss was one of the first European figures to echo Ukrainian claims that it cannot lose territory in the war
column2: but must regain land lost to Russian separatists since 2014. The Polish president
column3: Andrzej Duda
column4: in Kyiv this week said: “Only Ukraine has the right to decide about its future. No decisions can be taken about its future without it.” Although there are different voices within the Ukrainian diplomatic landscape
column5: Zelenskiy’s public position appears to be broadly the same. He told a meeting at Davos that he joined by video link: “When Ukraine says it is fighting to regain its territories
column6: it means that Ukraine will fight until it restores all of its territory. It doesn’t mean anything else. It’s about our sovereignty
column7: our territorial integrity and our independence.”

column1: He added: “This state of ‘hot’ hostilities
column2: of bloody war
column3: can only move into diplomatic negotiations with the authentic participation of the Russian and Ukrainian presidents
column4: supported by our strategic partners
column5: when we see that the Russian Federation shows real willingness and desire to move from bloody war to diplomacy. This will be possible only when Russia concedes at least something
column6: such as pulling back troops to the borders as they were on February 24.”

column1: At present there does not seem to be any likelihood of Russia signalling such a retreat. Quite the opposite.
But that does not mean countries are not coming forward to offer their mediation services. Italy’s prime minister
column2: Mario Draghi
column3: for instance
column4: has assembled a complex four-point plan that was formally presented to the UN secretary general
column5: António Guterres.

column1: The first step in the plan would involve a supervised ceasefire and “demilitarisation” of the frontline. This would be a multilateral negotiation at a conference on the future status of Ukraine
column2: resuscitating the proposal of future Ukrainian neutrality backed by security guarantees provided by major powers. This could give a security umbrella to Ukraine before the end of the peace process
column3: and act as a substitute for Ukraine’s one-time aspiration to Nato membership.

column1: The next stage would be a bilateral treaty between Ukraine and Russia on “border issues”. The language of the proposal points to free movement of people and economic life
column2: de facto autonomy for the occupied territories and a single economic zone
column3: as well as civil guarantees for Russian minorities
column4: including over language. This would be very close to the Minsk agreement
column5: a format that France and Germany oversaw and the Ukrainians never liked.

column1: The final stage would be a grand bargain on EU/Nato-Russia relations
column2: revival of strategic stability talks
column3: a new role for the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe and a revisiting of some of the other issues that were being discussed between the US and Russia last summer.

column1: Russia seemed to take great pleasure in ridiculing both the plan and its proponent. The former Russian president Dmitry Medvedev blasted Draghi’s proposals: “It seems that it was prepared not by diplomats
column2: but by local political scientists who have read provincial newspapers and operate only with Ukrainian fakes.” Yet other voices in Russia think there are aspects of the plan that could be adopted later
column3: when both sides have fought themselves to a standstill."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/kharkiv-hit-by-fresh-strikes-amid-fears-city-is-still-on-russian-agenda;2022-05-27;Kharkiv hit by fresh strikes amid fears city is still on Russian agenda;"Life had begun to return to normal in Ukraine’s second city after Moscow’s troops were forced to retreat
Artillery has pounded the city of Kharkiv for the first time in two weeks
column2: just as life in Ukraine’s second city was starting to return to normal after Russian troops were pushed back from its outlying towns and villages.

column1: Kharkiv’s regional governor
column2: Oleh Synehubov
column3: said at least nine people had been killed and 17 injured in the attacks on the northern part of the city.

column1: “There’s no logic to it
column2: it’s just terror against the local population
column3: to sow panic and to destroy critical infrastructure
column4: ” said Synehubov

column1: The largely Russian-speaking city near the border of the two countries was heavily attacked during the first days of the war as Russian forces tried to take control

column3: on one occasion destroying the regional administration building

column1: “For two weeks it’s been relatively quiet … I think this is them saying hello
column2: telling us they are still there
column3: trying to create panic
column4: ” Synehubov said.

column1: The booms of incoming and outgoing artillery fire were audible throughout Thursday
column2: shaking buildings and setting off car alarms in central Kharkiv.

column1: In the afternoon
column2: a deep shell crater was left on Otakara Yarosha Street in front of a block of flats from which the windows on all five floors had been blown out. Police at the scene said they did not know how many people had died there.

column1: Outside the 23 August metro station
column2: a blast had brought down large branches from several trees

column1: It was not immediately obvious whether people had died at the scene
column2: and there were few people around to ask
column3: as air raid sirens and the booms of artillery sounded.

column1: A steady flow of residents had started to return to their homes in the city. A few cafes and restaurants had opened
column2: people were strolling in city parks on Thursday morning and this week
column3: and the metro began operating again for the first time since the invasion. In recent weeks
column4: its main use has been as a bomb shelter
column5: with thousands living on its underground platforms.

column1: The city mayor
column2: Ihor Terekhov
column3: told residents: “We will not stop the metro
column4: but we will allocate special sectors where you can stay and shelter from bombing.”

column1: After Russia failed in its assaults on Kyiv and Kharkiv in the early days of the war
column2: Moscow has concentrated much of its efforts on a bloody offensive to take more territory in the Donbas region. But Thursday’s attacks raised fears that Kharkiv could still be on the agenda.

column1: “The Russian troops are engaged in a counter-offensive
column2: and are trying to reoccupy territories that were liberated by our troops just a month ago
column3: ” said Oleksandr Filchakov
column4: Kharkiv region’s chief prosecutor
column5: in an interview with the Guardian. He said he believed the ultimate aim was to launch a renewed assault on the city itself.

column1: Filchakov also noted reports that Russian troops were unloading Iskander missiles at the railway station in Belgorod
column2: just across the border.

column1: For now
column2: said Synehubov
column3: a renewed ground assault on the city was not possible. “They are firing from the positions they have held for a long time; they are constantly trying to counterattack but our forces are holding their positions.”

column1: He said there was not a significant enough buildup of new troops and equipment on the other side of the border to signal the capacity for a new assault on the city. “But that’s right now
column2: and the situation can change at any minute
column3: ” he added.

column1: However
column2: Synehubov said
column3: the main problem for the Kharkiv region
column4: unlike others
column5: was that the Russians continued to shell settlements after they had retreated.

column1: “In Kyiv
column2: Sumy
column3: Chernihiv regions
column4: the Russians fought for a certain period
column5: realised they had hit a wall and then took the decision to retreat
column6: and they retreated fully from these territories
column7: ” he said.

column1: “Here
column2: even if we liberate a place
column3: then the enemy stays in its positions and keeps hitting it
column4: and we can’t properly evacuate people
column5: we can’t bring humanitarian aid
column6: because these places are under permanent fire. We can’t bring in de-mining teams because of the shelling

column8: ” he said."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/may/26/autistic-ukrainian-boy-timothy-tymoshenko-uk-grant-visa;2022-05-26;‘No humanity whatsoever’: pleas for UK to grant visa to autistic Ukrainian boy;Timothy Tymoshenko was sent to Poland because of his distress but does not qualify for Homes for Ukraine scheme

A British man who has turned his Polish castle into a makeshift hotel for Ukrainian refugees has accused the UK government of showing “no humanity whatsoever” for not allowing a severely autistic teenager to come to live with an approved foster carer in Lancashire.
Pleas are mounting for compassion to be shown to Timothy Tymoshenko
column3: who fled the war in Ukraine without his parents. He is living with his 17-year-old brother
column4: Yurii
column5: in what was once a private palace for the prince-bishop of Wrocław in Piotrowice Nyskie
column6: a tiny Polish village near the Czech border.

column1: Jim Parton
column2: a former stockbroker and writer from London
column3: lives there with his Polish wife
column4: Anna
column5: and their six children
column6: aged seven to 17.

column1: When the Russian invasion began in February
column2: they decided to turn what is usually a guest house and wedding venue into an open house for Ukrainians seeking sanctuary abroad.

column1: They are currently hosting 17 people in the sprawling 700-year-old palace
column2: after four left for Canada on Monday. Among those remaining is Timothy
column3: who is severely autistic
column4: non-verbal and needs strong prescription medication to control his changing moods.

column1: Experienced children’s carers in Lancashire have been to visit the boys in Poland and are willing to take brothers in
column2: but are growing increasingly frustrated that the UK government hasn’t yet granted them visas to enter the country.

column1: Julie Elliot
column3: and her husband
column4: Roger
column6: already have 14 children together – four biological and 10 adopted. Both worked as nurses before becoming full-time carers to their adopted family
column7: and were made MBEs in 2016 for services to children.

column1: Their adopted children
column2: aged between nine and 40
column3: all have disabilities and eight of them still live at the couple’s home in the Ribble Valley
column4: Lancashire.

column1: They and Parton are pleading with the Home Office to let Timothy come to the UK along with his brother. They do not qualify for the Homes for Ukraine scheme as unaccompanied children under 18.
The issue is the subject of a high court challenge and dozens of UK foster carers are anxiously waiting to see if approval is granted for the children they hope to care for to be brought to the UK.

Parton is growing increasingly frustrated with the visa situation. “It’s an absolute disgrace that it is taking so long. There’s no humanity whatsoever from the government in recognising that this is a special case
column2: ” he said.

column1: “What makes me most cross is the safeguarding reason for delaying visas for these children
column2: ” said Julie Elliot
column3: who recently travelled to Poland to meet Timothy and Yurii and help look after Timothy for a week.

column1: On arrival
column2: she found him to be hungry
column3: unwashed and dehydrated. “Tim needs someone to care for him to ensure he eats and drinks regularly
column4: ” she said.

column1: The boys’ mother
column2: Anna
column3: sent the two brothers across the border because Timothy was not coping with the interruption to his routine by having to hurry into underground bomb shelters and was getting very distressed at the sound of the constant warning sirens.

column1: “Tim is in a very unsafe situation
column2: ” said Elliot. “We have been through 10 adoption assessments and they are the most frightening thing on God’s earth but they don’t compare with this process of trying to get a visa for Tim. There doesn’t seem to be a system in place. I was told we should hear something about the legal case in 14 days but that is a long time when you’re a child and nobody’s looking after you … All I’m asking for these children like Tim who are waiting to be fostered is just give them a visa
column3: they’re not going to be any trouble to anyone.”

column1: Anna is also frustrated about the delays in granting the visas: “When the generous people of Britain extended a helping hand to my family we cannot grab it because the documents will not be issued. As a mother I am under a lot of stress and want to breathe a sigh of relief that my children are not under shelling and are under supervision of responsible and kind people
column2: ” she said.

column1: A government spokesperson said: “It is tragic that children have been caught up in Putin’s war. The safety and wellbeing of children is paramount and it is vital we have robust safeguarding processes. For this reason
column2: only under-18s who are reuniting with a parent or legal guardian in the UK are currently eligible for Homes for Ukraine. We keep eligibility for all schemes under review.”"

column5: in its three-month war

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/russia-uses-orwellian-propaganda-news-vans-in-mariupol;2022-05-26;Russia uses Orwellian propaganda news vans in Mariupol;"Large TVs play Russian state news in support of invasion in war-torn city still lacking electricity and water

column2: which it called “mobile information complexes”

column1: The effort to install Russian propaganda in the ruined city is part of a larger effort at pacifying and integrating captured cities like Mariupol despite earlier assurances by Vladimir Putin that Russia did not seek to occupy new territory in Ukraine.

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/ukraine-war-government-to-allow-councils-to-sever-russian-contracts;2022-05-26;UK government to allow councils to sever Russian contracts;"Councils pushing to break ties had been prohibited from taking ‘non-commercial considerations’ into account
The UK government introduced legislation on Thursday to help councils
column2: NHS trusts and other public bodies exit contracts with Gazprom and other Russian companies

column2: and they have a statutory duty to find the cheapest deal on behalf of the taxpayer.

column1: In March
column2: the Cabinet Office asked central government to review all contracts with Russia and Belarus-linked firms and to consider terminating those contracts. This process has now been extended to local councils.

column2: but our message is clear: Putin’s barbaric regime should not benefit from taxpayers’ money.”

column1: The communities secretary

column3: will now write to all councils to make them aware of the changes.

column1: The government has said any costs incurred from exiting contracts will have to be covered by existing budgets.
The west is attempting to choke off the Russian economy to damage Putin’s war coffers and fuel anti-war sentiment among the Russian public.

Research for the Guardian and Tussell shows that councils and NHS trusts have paid nearly £5m to Russian firms including Gazprom since the invasion of Ukraine under existing contracts.
NHS trusts – including Manchester University NHS foundation trust and the Southport & Ormskirk hospital NHS trust – have paid £3.2m. Councils including Portsmouth and Buckinghamshire have paid £1.6m.
Separately
column2: a Treasury deadline to halt payments to Gazprombank and its subsidiaries for gas going from the UK to European Union countries is fast approaching. An original deadline of 21 April to halt payments was extended to 31 May last month. Many large Gazprom gas contract holders are based in the UK and help supply gas to the EU
column3: which imports about 40% of its gas from Russia.

column2: 000 sites
column3: with contracts worth approximately £4bn
column4: according to Capital Monitor estimates."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/filtration-and-forced-deportation-mariupol-survivors-on-the-lasting-terrors-of-russias-assault;2022-05-26;Filtration and forced deportation: Mariupol survivors on the lasting terrors of Russia’s assault;"Svitlana and Vitaly lost almost everything
column2: including their unborn baby
column3: during Russia’s siege
column4: their experiences a snapshot of the horrors endured by Mariupol’s remaining residents

column1: On the final day of March
column2: soldiers of the so-called Donetsk People’s Republic entered the basement in Mariupol where Svitlana and Vitaly were sheltering.

column1: “You have 15 minutes to get ready and then you’re leaving
column2: ” shouted one
column3: waving an automatic rifle.

column1: It was
column2: according to the Russian narrative of its Ukraine invasion
column3: the day that Svitlana and Vitaly were liberated. But it did not feel much like that to them.

column1: Instead
column2: it was merely the end of one ordeal and the start of another: a wearying and humiliating journey through so-called “filtration” procedures
column3: followed by forced deportation to Russia.

column1: The siege
column2: destruction and ultimate Russian conquest of Mariupol have been well-documented
column3: but Svitlana and Vitaly’s experiences provide a particularly vivid illustration of the unexpected terror that was visited on this city of half a million people over the past months.

column1: Until late February
column2: the couple lived in a compact but cosy one-room apartment on the eastern side of Mariupol
column3: with Svitlana’s two children from a previous marriage. She worked in a school
column4: he had a factory job. She was three months pregnant and the couple were looking forward to their first child together.

column1: Over the next two months
column2: they lost almost everything.

column1: They had not paid much attention to the warnings that Russia could launch a new war in Ukraine
column2: but they could see and hear the first incoming fire on 24 February from their windows.

column1: It soon became clear that it was too dangerous to stay sleeping in the apartment
column2: but their block’s cellar was not fit for habitation
column3: so instead most residents moved to the stairwell
column4: laying out makeshift mattresses on the hard concrete floors.

column1: Gradually
column2: they settled into a routine. In the first days
column3: there were lulls in the shelling and they could scurry outside to buy food. They bought two chickens from an acquaintance with a garden; with someone else
column4: they swapped a bottle of vodka for some potatoes.

column1: They cooked over open fire in the courtyard
column2: though at times even that seemed too dangerous
column3: as the artillery shells flew in with increasing frequency. Once every two days
column4: Vitaly would risk his life to venture out to a well and bring water for the family. Some days
column5: he took Svitlana’s 13-year-old son with him
column6: so they could carry more water back. In the night
column7: it was sometimes so cold in the stairwell that the bottles of water turned to ice.

column1: One day
column2: when Vitaly began to lower the bucket into the well
column3: he saw there were dead bodies floating far down below. He assumed they had jumped in to take cover during unexpected shelling
column4: but had then fallen and drowned. He set off to find another well
column5: with clean water.

column1: On one water run
column2: a shell landed so close to Vitaly that he was thrown to the ground by the blast. “He came back home with these crazy eyes
column3: he was making no sense
column4: I thought I’d lost him forever
column5: ” said Svitlana. The next day
column6: his cognitive function was better
column7: but he lost hearing in his right ear for the next two months.

column1: How many people in their building were killed? Vitaly counted
column2: slowly: “One
column3: two
column4: three
column5: four
column6: five
column7: six
column8: seven
column9: eight. Eight people we knew personally
column10: just from our section of the block. And in the neighbouring block it was much
column11: much worse
column12: ” he said.

column1: From the blown-out windows of the upper floors of their building
column2: they could see plumes of smoke rising across Mariupol. Svitlana wondered about her parents on the other side of town. She had no idea if they were still alive
column3: and no way of finding out. There was no electricity and no phone reception.

column1: On days when there were deaths
column2: a group of men from the block buried the bodies in the courtyard
column3: working as quickly as possible to minimise the time spent outside. It was the old people who died first.

column1: “I knew those old women all my life. They sat outside the apartment block on the benches
column2: chatting away
column3: passing the time. And then you have to close the eyes of those women and bury them in their own courtyard
column4: ” said Vitaly.

column1: Five times
column2: Grad missiles hit their apartment block
column3: as Russian forces haphazardly attempted to target detachments of Ukrainian forces that had based themselves nearby. Vitaly and Svitlana’s flat caught fire after one of the strikes. By the time the flames died down
column4: everything had been destroyed; even the wall between the kitchen and the living room had been incinerated.

column1: The cold nights
column2: the lack of food and the constant bombardment were hard to stand. Svitlana’s daughter had bouts of hysteria and screaming. An old man on one floor kept asking the same question: “When will it end?” On another floor
column3: a woman refused food. It would be better to end things sooner
column4: she said quietly.

column1: On 17 March
column2: after another rocket attack
column3: Svitlana lost her pregnancy. She was bleeding heavily and feverish
column4: but there was no chance to receive proper medical care. On the third day
column5: one of the neighbours managed to find an ampoule of Oxytocin; Svitlana injected it herself and blood started flowing more freely.

column1: “I’m not 15
column2: I know how these things work
column3: ” she said
column4: when asked how she knew how to inject the medicine. It may have saved her life.

column1: After the miscarriage
column2: the neighbours rallied around Svitlana with the few provisions they had left. Someone rustled up some vitamin pills. Someone else found a miraculously uneaten piece of cheese. She continued to bleed periodically
column3: but felt as if she might survive.

column1: One morning
column2: a part of the apartment block was hit by an airstrike
column3: causing the entire building to shake and debris to fall from the ceiling and walls. As they regained composure
column4: they could hear wailing from the ninth floor
column5: where a woman had remained
column6: living with her 11-year-old son throughout the bombardment.

column1: Vitaly rushed upstairs. He could see the boy’s arms and legs sticking out from under a pile of bricks and debris. He worked him free. The boy was shocked
column2: but unhurt. His mother was dead.

column1: They were not able to bury her in the courtyard like the others; she had not been a slim woman
column2: and it was too much to carry her down from the ninth floor. So they left her under the rubble.

column1: Afterwards
column2: the boy displayed few emotions. He did not cry. He politely said thank you when someone gave him food
column3: or a hug. But then
column4: in the nights
column5: he would let out terrible piercing screams amid his fitful bursts of sleep.

column1: Soon after the airstrike
column2: the family moved to the basement of a neighbouring house
column3: where another group of people were already sheltering. They took the boy with them.

column1: After a week living in the cellar
column2: with only the briefest forays above ground during which the shelling seemed to have intensified further
column3: the Russia-backed forces arrived on 31 March and ordered everyone out of the cellar.

column1: When the group emerged above ground
column2: they were ordered to walk for half an hour
column3: carrying their possessions with them and with shells flying overhead
column4: to a spot where they joined others from the district. Women and children were crammed into buses while the men continued on foot.

column1: In the village of Sartana
column2: Vitaly and some other men were put into the back of a truck that reeked of corpses. Nobody explained anything about where they were going or what would happen next.

column1: Svitlana and Vitaly were reunited in the town of Novoazovsk
column2: part of the Russian proxy Donetsk People’s Republic
column3: where they were housed in a school
column4: 20 people to a classroom. There was nothing to sleep on
column5: but they were given hot food. Soldiers confiscated their phones.

column1: They left the boy whose mother had died in Novoazovsk; his estranged Russian father would come to pick him up
column2: they hoped. His father would take him to live in Russia
column3: the country whose assault had killed his mother.

column1: After some days
column2: Svitlana
column3: Vitaly and the two children were again loaded on to buses
column4: and driven to the town of Dokuchayevsk
column5: where they joined hundreds of people waiting in the local Soviet-era House of Culture to undergo what the Russians have termed a “filtration” procedure.

column1: Svitlana was allowed into the mothers and children room; Vitaly was held in the main hall
column2: where hundreds of men tried to grab a few hours sleep slumped on chairs. The smell was disgusting.

column1: The mothers and children room was hardly any better. Many of the children had diarrhoea or dysentery; Svitlana’s daughter was vomiting frequently. She herself still felt weak. There was almost no food: breakfast was tea
column2: lunch was hot water and a biscuit.

column1: After two days
column2: it was Vitaly’s turn for filtration. He was taken to the police station
column3: where he was ordered to undress fully and examined for tattoos that might give away a Ukrainian nationalist affiliation. Then he was questioned
column4: photographed and fingerprinted. The process took five hours. After that
column5: the family were put on a bus to the border with Russia. They crossed after another round of questioning
column6: and spent the night at a camp on the other side
column7: from where the next morning yet another bus drove them to the train station in the city of Taganrog.

column1: In the filtration camps
column2: Mariupol residents had been told they would be given resources to start a new life anywhere they wanted in the Russian Federation. But when they arrived at the station in Taganrog
column3: there was one train
column4: departing to Saransk
column5: a dusty city 300 miles east of Moscow.

column1: For those who did not have their own travel plans
column2: Saransk was the only option. Exhausted
column3: weary and unwashed
column4: they boarded the train to an uncertain new life.

column1: Svitlana had found a better option. She had managed to contact a friend who had an acquaintance in Taganrog
column2: who agreed to put the family up for three days. For the first time in two months
column3: Svitlana and Vitaly slept in real beds and had hot showers.

column1: They told their host in Taganrog a little about what they had been through
column2: and the woman was incredulous. But they did not go into detail.

column1: “We didn’t want to say too much about what we had seen while we were still in Russia; we didn’t want to attract attention
column2: we wanted to be able to leave
column3: ” said Svitlana.

column1: She was still regularly bleeding from the miscarriage. Some of her skin had attained a blueish hue
column2: and her legs were swollen “like a bear”
column3: she said. On occasion
column4: she fainted. But she did not seek medical treatment. Spending time inside Russia after the weeks of misery they had been through felt like further abuse
column5: and she wanted to get out as soon as possible.

column1: From Taganrog
column2: the family took a train to Moscow
column3: then to St Petersburg. From there
column4: they crossed to Estonia without problems
column5: and made their way onwards to a western European country
column6: where they are now trying to make a new home.

column1: Soon after their arrival
column2: doctors performed an operation on Svitlana that she should have had weeks earlier. Slowly
column3: her life is getting back to normal. The children have calmed down a little. The aches and pains have dissipated and the swelling in her legs has subsided. She no longer jumps in fear every time someone opens or closes a door
column4: and she can recount the awful ordeal she went through with clarity and poise.

column1: But the nights are harder than the days. Almost every night
column2: Svitlana has visions of incoming artillery and missiles. She wakes up breathless and terrified.

column1: Many of the couple’s friends have simply disappeared. Are they still in Mariupol? Trying to start a new life after being dumped somewhere in a far-flung corner of Russia? Dead? They have no idea.
Svitlana does know that her parents survived the siege of Mariupol. She has not spoken to them since the beginning of the war
column2: and they do not currently have working phones. But twice
column3: they called Svitlana’s sister from a borrowed phone
column4: to give notice they were still alive.

column1: Svitlana has no more information than that; she does not know what horrors they went through in their part of the city
column2: though she can guess it was not easy. It was not easy for anyone in Mariupol.

column1: Svitlana and Vitaly are pseudonyms. They asked not to use their real names
column2: or give their address in Mariupol
column3: because they fear for Svitlana’s parents. She hopes that soon
column4: they too will be able to leave for Europe; she knows her father would not want to live under Russian rule
column5: she said. The fate of her parents is a constant worry that prevents her focusing fully on starting a new life in Europe.

column1: One thing Vitaly and Svitlana are both certain of is that they will never go back.
“Return to what?” asked Vitaly
column2: bitterly. “There’s nothing there. Nothing. It’s over. Mariupol is over.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/26/russia-crude-tactics-ukraine-bombardment-kyiv;2022-05-26;The cold logic behind Russia’s crude
column2: nihilistic tactics in Ukraine;"Constant bombardment threatens to produce a stalemate that would cost Kyiv dear economically and politically

column1: Russia’s offensive in the Donbas region is making slow progress. Having rushed to launch the operation to avoid giving Ukraine time to bring up new weapons from the west
column2: Russia has found that its depleted and exhausted units are unwilling and unable to assault Ukrainian positions without incurring unacceptable losses. The Russian army has
column3: therefore
column4: fallen back on the mass application of artillery
column5: destroying village after village
column6: which they occupy after Ukrainian units withdraw.

column1: For the Ukrainian military
column2: the current Russian tactics may be unsophisticated and nihilistic
column3: but they are also dangerous. To stop the Russians from advancing
column4: the Ukrainian armed forces must occupy the ground. This subjects their units to heavy bombardment
column5: and is producing a steady accumulation of Ukrainian casualties. The Ukrainians are trying to limit the weight of Russian fire by raiding and striking the logistics supporting the Russian artillery.

column1: The challenge for the Russian military is maintaining troop levels. Moscow has begun an unannounced mobilisation of citizens with former military service
column2: complementing a recruitment drive for volunteers to take up short-term service contracts. The short-term contracts are intended to keep up the strength of units until mobilised personnel are organised and equipped. But with little training
column3: low morale
column4: poor unit cohesion following significant casualties and a steady influx of new personnel
column5: Russian units continue to perform badly and suffer disproportionately in engagements.

column1: Although the short-term military trends currently favour Ukraine
column2: the country faces hard choices. So long as Russia has a significant number of artillery systems and its air defences deny Ukraine air support
column3: the Ukrainian military is forced to remain dispersed
column4: limiting its available combat power at any one point and slowing the rate at which it can liberate territory. Ukraine must also guard against the risk that Russia moves into a large and more overt mobilisation of its population that
column5: while politically risky
column6: would threaten a significant offensive late in the year
column7: requiring Ukraine to hold forces in reserve.

column1: If the Ukrainian military cannot liberate significant tracts of territory or bleed out the Russian army this summer then there is the risk of a protracted conflict. The principal security concerns for Kyiv are economic and political. Without a peace settlement
column2: Ukraine will remain economically paralysed
column3: its ports blockaded
column4: its cities heavily damaged
column5: and investment or reconstruction deterred by the ever looming prospect of missile strikes. Kyiv is expected to lose almost half of its GDP this year. Many internally displaced Ukrainians have been living off their savings. These will begin to run out.

column1: A protracted conflict also risks damaging internal cohesion. Ukraine has so far been politically unified
column2: with Russia’s sympathisers in the Ukrainian state keeping a low profile or enthusiastically supporting the war effort. It would be dangerous to do anything else. As curfews and movement controls are lifted
column3: however
column4: and the political clarity of the need to defend Kyiv dissipates
column5: there are renewed opportunities for subversion. How the government ensures it can provide heating for citizens away from the front as winter approaches
column6: for example
column7: is an issue over which criticism may be justified. But such issues can also be weaponised by Russia to degrade the country’s internal unity.

column1: In a protracted conflict
column2: Ukraine will probably depend upon financial assistance from abroad
column3: but it is also likely to need that assistance precisely when its international partners are under the greatest economic strain. Inflation in the UK is approaching 10%. There is a serious risk of recession. If job losses come in the autumn
column4: it will coincide with people’s renewed need to heat their homes. Energy prices
column5: meanwhile
column6: are expected to remain high
column7: and Russia has so far kept supplying Europe. Under these conditions European citizens may become less supportive of aiding Ukraine to fight a grinding war in Donbas when there is acute pain felt at home.

column1: Given these dark clouds on the horizon
column2: Ukraine’s partners must pursue two courses of action. First
column3: Ukraine must improve its security position as much as possible over the summer. To do this it requires long-range artillery that can challenge Russia’s fires dominance. The US provision of M777 155mm howitzers is a good start. Ukraine’s partners must also help in training new Ukrainian brigades so that the country can withdraw and reconstitute some of its units. It is also critical that the Russian army not be given the opportunity to recover the initiative. To prevent this
column4: it is important to keep the rate of Russian casualties in Donbas high
column5: so that mobilised personnel have to be immediately pushed into maintaining Russian positions rather than organised into new units able to open up new axes.

column1: The second line of effort must be a coordinated approach across Europe to build resilience for this winter and to begin working out the best means of offering economic support to Ukraine. There is also a need to inform the public early and clearly as to the direct correlation between Russia’s actions and the economic pain to come. Russian disinformation will inevitably portray the economic pain as a consequence of supporting Kyiv. Such distortions need to be preemptively undermined.
Finally
column2: there is the question of alliance unity. There are growing calls across Nato to consider negotiated solutions
column3: often premised on trading Ukrainian territory for peace. While negotiations should never be abandoned
column4: pushing for a ceasefire that would lock in Russian gains
column5: allow the Russian army to recover and prepare for a renewed offensive and leave Ukraine economically crippled
column6: is deeply naive. It is vital that the disagreements about objectives between key European partners are thrashed out and resolved as soon as possible. As Ukrainian citizens are put through filtration camps
column7: and Russia plots the annexation of more of its territory
column8: it must be understood that peace on Russia’s terms would be a very violent affair.

column1: Jack Watling is senior research fellow for land warfare at the Royal United Services Institute
Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a letter of up to 300 words to be considered for publication
column2: email it to us at guardian.letters@theguardian.com"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/putin-anarchists-join-ukraine-war-effort;2022-05-26;‘Putin’s terror affects everyone’: anarchists join Ukraine’s war effort;"Activists from Kyiv and around world join state forces in fight against totalitarianism
In an unnamed basement bar in central Kyiv
column2: Ukrainian anarchists have created a headquarters where they gather supplies to send to their peers on the frontlines and welcome anarchists from abroad who have come to fight.

column1: It is unusual to see anarchists supporting state structures
column2: but they say taking action against Russia is necessary for their survival. “We are fighting to protect the more or less free society that exists in Ukraine
column3: ” said an activist
column4: Dmytro. “Without which there would be no space for activism or underground movements.”

column1: He added: “Putin’s terror is happening [in Ukraine] and it is indiscriminate. It is happening against every part of the population
column2: but especially against the Russian-speaking parts of the population that Putin supposedly came here to liberate
column3: ” referring to the fact that the war has been heaviest in eastern and southern Ukraine.

column1: “His regime is an ultraconservative
column2: rightwing dictatorship that represses anarchists in Russia
column3: the free press
column4: LGBT networks. It scares even the most banal
column5: grassroots initiatives
column6: like animal rights activists. We see the conflict between Ukraine and Russia as a conflict between a more or less democratic state and a totalitarian one.”

column1: The activist left is relatively small in Ukraine
column2: where the memory of Soviet communism lingers
column3: and its anarchist component is even smaller. But from 1917-21 Ukraine was home to one of the world’s most famous anarchist movements
column4: which sprung out of the power vacuum created by the fall of Tsarist Russia.

column1: Led by the anarchist Nestor Makhno
column2: the movement argued for the rights of Ukraine’s peasantry and quickly grew in popularity under the slogans “Death to those who stand in the way of free working people” and “Power breeds parasites
column3: long live anarchy!”

column1: At the height of the movement
column2: self-governing communes existed across most of southern and eastern Ukraine under the protection of Makhno’s army. His base was in Huliaipole
column3: a town in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region
column4: which has been frequently fought over since February. The Bolsheviks defeated Makhno’s army and he died in exile in Paris.

column1: Those at the Kyiv anarchists’ headquarters admit that these are no longer “Makhno times”. Today
column2: the anarchist movement in Ukraine is small and a battalion acting independently would collapse on a modern-day battlefield
column3: they say.

column1: About 100 anarchists have signed up to fight in Ukraine’s army and territorial defence forces
column2: according to Serhiy Movchan
column3: the group’s spokesperson. In addition
column4: about 20 foreign anarchists have signed up
column5: including a Russian who fled his country three years ago. Others have come to Ukraine to work as volunteer paramedics.

column1: “We have a strict screening process
column2: ” said Dmytro
column3: who was eager to stress that the foreign volunteers differ from some of the others who have arrived in the country since February. “We don’t want people who just come here to kill; we want them to understand what they are fighting for.”

column1: Before the 24 February invasion
column2: the anarchists – small in number – would join forces with wider leftwing activist networks. But attracting supporters faced obstacles due to the country’s experience of the Soviet era.

column1: In the name of socialism
column2: mass murders were carried out
column3: a man-made famine was created
column4: and swathes of culture and history
column5: including the Ukrainian language
column6: were repressed. A controversial set of de-Communisation laws were passed in 2015 to deal with this legacy
column7: but many on the left feel the wider population began to associate everything on the left with the Soviet Union.

column1: Then
column2: under Putin’s Russia Kremlin spin doctors and their allies co-opted leftist rhetoric to create pro-Russian political parties across the former Soviet Union
column3: including Ukraine. These parties were used to appeal to those voters who harboured nostalgia for communist times.

column1: Leaked emails in 2016 revealed how the Kharkiv regional leader of the Communist party of Ukraine
column2: banned the previous year for promoting separatism
column3: had received emails from the office of the former Kremlin spin doctor Vladislav Surkov on how to foment separatism and campaign for federalisation. (Since 2014 the Kremlin has been pushing for federalisation in Ukraine as Russia’s way of re-gaining leverage in national politics.)

column1: Dmytro also pointed to the “leftwing” messaging used by the Kremlin when creating the self-declared people’s republics in Donetsk and Luhansk regions
column2: the Russian-backed unrecognised states in eastern Ukraine. He said that the irony is that the entities have been headed by ultra-rightists such as Igor Girkin
column3: who promoted Russian nationalism
column4: carried out extrajudicial killings
column5: and banned freedom of speech and association.

column1: The recent full-scale invasion by Russia has brought another layer of mud for activists on Ukraine’s left
column2: said Movchan.

column1: “Putin has appropriated the word anti-fascist and he exploits it to justify his war
column2: ” said Movhcan. “[Ukrainian] nationalists say if you’re anti-fascist
column3: you’re pro-Russian
column4: but that’s not the case.”

column1: Movchan said far-right nationalism has always failed to gain popular support in Ukraine
column2: but moderate nationalism – which emphasises religion
column3: language and the army – became mainstream after 2014.

column1: Many Ukrainian politicians assumed nationalist messaging in an ensuing competition to present themselves as Ukrainian patriots. This nationalism promotes conservative
column2: non-progressive ideas and therefore presents a “big problem”
column3: said Movchan.

column1: “I think both sides of the elite did a lot to create a situation whereby Ukrainians argue a lot about language and versions of history instead of how Kryvyi Rih Stal was privatised
column2: ” said Movchan
column3: referring to Ukraine’s largest steelworks that was privatised in 2004 by oligarchs close to the then-president.

column1: Movchan said that this form of nationalism has given those in power a tool to ignore Ukraine’s social issues
column2: but that people need to be clear that Ukraine’s internal problems are not to blame for the war. “The cause of the war is the Russian Federation
column3: ” said Movchan."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/26/ukraine-pleads-for-more-weapons-to-tackle-russian-onslaught-in-donbas;2022-05-26;Ukraine pleads for more weapons to tackle Russian onslaught in Donbas;"Bombardment continues in 40 towns including the key city of Sievierodonetsk as police in Lysychansk collect bodies for mass burials
Fierce battles have continued to rage in eastern Ukraine with Russian troops on the verge of encircling a key industrial city
column2: bringing a sharp rebuke of the west from Volodymyr Zelenskiy for not doing enough to help Kyiv win the war.

column1: As the Ukrainian military reported on Thursday that 40 towns in the Donbas region were under Russian bombardment
column2: Luhansk governor Sergiy Gaiday described fighting outside Sievierodonetsk
column3: a key military goal for Russia
column4: as “very difficult”
column5: saying Russian troops were shelling the city from the outskirts with mortars.

column1: “The coming week will be decisive
column2: ” Gaiday said in a video posted on Telegram
column3: adding he believes Russia’s goal is to “capture the Luhansk region no matter what cost”.

column1: “There is a colossal amount of shelling
column2: ” he added.

column1: Having failed to seize Ukraine’s capital or its second city
column2: Kharkiv
column3: after invading in February
column4: Russia is trying to take full control of the Donbas
column5: comprised of two eastern provinces Moscow claims on behalf of separatists.

column1: Russia has poured thousands of troops into the region
column2: attacking from three sides in an attempt to encircle Ukrainian forces holding out in Sievierodonetsk and its twin
column3: Lysychansk. Their fall would leave the whole of Luhansk province under Russian control
column4: a key Kremlin war aim.

column1: “The occupiers shelled more than 40 towns in Donetsk and Luhansk region
column2: destroying or damaging 47 civilian sites
column3: including 38 homes and a school. As a result of this shelling five civilians died and 12 were wounded
column4: ” the joint task force of Ukraine’s armed forces said on Facebook.

column1: The statement said 10 enemy attacks were repelled
column2: four tanks and four drones destroyed
column3: and 62 “enemy soldiers” were killed.

column1: Gaiday said police in Lysychansk were collecting bodies of people killed in order to bury them in mass graves. About 150 people have been buried in a mass grave in one Lysychansk district
column2: he added.

column1: Families of people buried in mass graves will be able to carry out a reburial after the war
column2: and police are issuing documents enabling Ukrainians to secure death certificates for loved ones
column3: Gaiday said.

column1: Zelenskiy said in his nightly address on Wednesday that Russian troops “heavily outnumber us” in some parts of the east and echoed pleas from his foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba to the World Economic Forum in Davos for more weaponry from the west.
“We need the help of our partners - above all
column2: weapons for Ukraine. Full help
column3: without exceptions
column4: without limits
column5: enough to win
column6: ” Zelenskiy said in his daily address to the nation.

column1: And he called out the international community for paying too much attention to Russia’s interests and too little to Ukraine’s.
The Ukrainian president took specific aim at former US secretary of state Henry Kissinger and the New York Times for suggesting territorial sacrifices might be necessary to end the conflict.
Kissinger
column2: the 98-year-old champion of realpolitik
column3: this week told World Economic Forum attendees in Davos that a return to the “status quo” before Russia’s February 24 invasion would be ideal. Russia had formally annexed Crimea in 2014
column4: while separatist groups aligned with Moscow have long controlled the easternmost regions of Donetsk and Luhansk.

column1: Pushing Moscow to surrender that territory threatened to turn the conflict into a new
column2: broader war
column3: Kissinger warned
column4: adding that negotiations needed to begin within two months.

column1: “It seems Mr Kissinger’s calendar is not 2022
column2: but 1938
column3: ” Zelensky responded
