column4: in a conflict situation
column5: we have a national prosecutor who is able to lead these investigations and it’s absolutely right” that Ukraine has made seeking justice for atrocities committed by Russian troops a priority and national prosecutors are risking their lives to collect evidence of war crimes even in areas still threatened by enemy forces or laced with mines.

column1: “Having said that
column2: there is a danger of the prosecutors are getting overwhelmed because it’s huge number of cases
column3: ” said Neistat
column4: who noted that instead of obstructing parallel investigations
column5: the prosecutor’s office had been open to international support and was active in coordinating parallel investigations being launched elsewhere.There has been unprecedented interest in building cases by foreign prosecutors and NGOs over the crimes committed in Ukraine. More than a dozen national prosecutors outside of Ukraine have opened cases into war crimes or crimes of aggression. The international criminal court opened its investigation just four days after the invasion. On Monday
column6: a court in Kyiv sentenced a Russian soldier to life in prison for the killing of a Ukrainian civilian
column7: in the first verdict in a trial related to war crimes carried out by the Russian army during its invasion of Ukraine."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/25/russian-assault-eastern-ukraine-sievierodonetsk-donbas;2022-05-25;Russian assault on eastern Ukraine threatens to encircle Sievierodonetsk;"Zelenskiy calls situation in Donbas ‘extremely difficult’ as Russia tries to carve up Ukrainian-held territory
Russian forces have launched fresh assaults on towns in eastern Ukraine
column2: with the city of Sievierodonetsk increasingly in danger of being totally encircled.

column1: The head of Ukraine’s military intelligence
column2: Kyrylo Budanov
column3: said delays in arrival of western arms to the frontline had left Kyiv “catastrophically short of heavy weapons”.

column1: The governor of Luhansk region
column2: Serhiy Haidai
column3: said the area was now without gas supplies and had limited water and electricity after the last gas supply station was hit.

column1: Haidai added that Russian forces were attempting to “completely destroy” the city of Sievierodonetsk in an attempt to conquer the Donbas region
column2: near Russia’s border.

column1: “They are simply erasing Sievierodonetsk from the face of the Earth
column2: ” Haidai said on his Telegram channel.

column1: “At the moment
column2: with the support of artillery
column3: the Russian occupiers are attacking Sievierodonetsk
column4: ” Haidai added.

column1: President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said the situation in Donbas was “extremely difficult”
column2: with the Russian army bringing its full force to bear. Footage from recent days from frontline areas
column3: posted on social media
column4: has depicted a constant barrage of artillery and rocket fire raining down on key roads and Ukrainian positions.

column1: Recent video footage posted by AFP photographer Aris Messinis in Donbas showed shells hitting close to a road in the country’s east and the constant sound of incoming artillery fire.
Driving at the roads of #Donbas in eastern #Ukraine️ #UkraineRussiaWar pic.twitter.com/GpcPVIzW3l
After failing to seize Kyiv or Ukraine’s second city
column2: Kharkiv
column3: Russia is trying to take the rest of the separatist-claimed Donbas’s two provinces
column4: Donetsk and Luhansk
column5: and trap Ukrainian forces in a pocket on the main eastern front.

column1: In the easternmost part of the Ukrainian-held Donbas pocket
column2: the city of Sievierodonetsk on the east bank of the Siverskyi Donets River and its twin Lysychansk
column3: on the west bank
column4: have become a pivotal battlefield as Russian forces have advanced from three directions to encircle them.

column1: Assessment of Russian operations by western analysts suggests that rather than encircle Ukrainian forces in one large and all-encompassing effort
column2: Russia is attempting to carve up Ukrainian-held territory into several small encirclements to the same effect.

column1: The US-based thinktank the Institute for the Study of War said in its 24 May update that Russian troops “are instead attempting to secure smaller encirclements and focus on Sievierodonetsk”
column2: adding that Ukrainian forces were also probably conducting a controlled withdrawal south-west of the town of Popasna to protect Ukrainian supply lines against Russian offensives.

column1: Russia appears to have deployed higher quality troops from a so-called operational manoeuvre group to spearhead the operation around Sievierdonestsk
column2: with some reports suggesting that Russian aircraft were flying several hundred sorties a day in support of the attack.

column1: Russian forces also appear to be benefiting from better supply lines in the Luhansk region with Ukrainian officials appealing for more western heavy weapons – including multiple launch rocket systems – for their outgunned defenders.
In the city of Sloviansk west of Donbas
column2: many residents took advantage of what Ukraine said was a break in the Russian assault to leave. “My house was bombed
column3: I have nothing
column4: ” said Vera Safronova
column5: seated in a train carriage among the evacuees.

column1: Along with the eastern Donbas region
column2: Moscow is also targeting southern Ukraine and has blockaded ships that would normally export Ukrainian grain and sunflower oil through the Black Sea
column3: pushing up prices globally and threatening lives.

column1: Russia
column2: which has blamed Ukraine and the west for the food crisis
column3: said it was ready to provide a humanitarian corridor for vessels carrying food to leave Ukraine but said western sanctions would need to be lifted in return.

column1: Three months into the invasion
column2: Russia still has only limited gains to show for its worst military losses in decades
column3: while much of Ukraine has suffered devastation as Moscow stepped up artillery strikes to compensate for its slow progress.

column1: Russia’s defence minister
column2: Sergei Shoigu
column3: said it was deliberately advancing slowly in what it calls its “special operation” to avoid civilian casualties
column4: comments Zelenskiy dismissed as “absolutely unreal”.

column1: “We will continue the special military operation until all the objectives have been achieved
column2: ” Shoigu told the Collective Security Treaty Organization
column3: a Russian-led military alliance of former Soviet states. The secretary of Russia’s security council
column4: Nikolai Patrushev
column5: also said Moscow’s offensive would last as long as necessary.

column1: “We are not rushing to meet deadlines
column2: ” he said."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2022/may/25/they-wont-accept-us-roma-refugees-forced-to-camp-at-prague-train-station;2022-05-25;‘They won’t accept us’: Roma refugees forced to camp at Prague train station;"Humanitarian crisis grows as Ukrainian Roma families stuck at Czech train station say they are not treated like other refugees
Prague’s central railway station seems a picture of normality amid warm spring sunshine and the return of legions of tourists
column2: who had been largely absent at the height of Covid. On the platform one weekday morning
column3: two German sightseers gaze curiously at the statue of Sir Nicholas Winton
column4: the British stockbroker who helped 669 mostly Jewish children escape from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia on the eve of the second world war.

column1: Yet just yards away
column2: hundreds of Roma people are sheltering in the only place available to them since they joined the millions of Ukrainians fleeing the Russian invasion.

column1: Unlike other Ukrainians who have been offered refugee visas
column2: these families have found they have nowhere to go and no one who wants them.

column1: On the morning the Guardian visited
column2: two small boys played unsupervised
column3: perilously close to the platform’s edge. Nearby
column4: a young mother lay asleep on a blanket as her infant toddler crawled over her.

column1: The scene was symptomatic of a festering crisis that has unfolded in recent weeks
column2: as hundreds of Roma refugees have sheltered on the station floor and in a makeshift sleeper train that berths only between 9pm and 5am
column3: in what emergency workers say are dangerously unsanitary conditions.

column1: More than 500 people are crammed each night into quarters that were originally envisaged to accommodate 260 on a one-night-only basis. Some have stayed for up to 10 nights.
Volunteer aid workers say they are overstretched and overwhelmed. “This is the most important situation in the Czech Republic
column2: ” says Geti Mubeenová
column3: crisis coordinator with the Organisation for Aid to Refugees (OPU).

column1: Along with other voluntary groups helping at the station
column2: the OPU plans to end its work there at the end of the month in an effort to pressure the government into providing more suitable accommodation.

column1: “We were set up to provide information
column2: but now we are dealing with a humanitarian crisis. It is no longer sustainable
column3: ” says Mubeenová.

column1: Out of sight of ordinary passengers in a sealed-off area of the ornate Habsburg-era station
column2: Roma families – mostly women and children
column3: some elderly and disabled – sit and lie around
column4: surrounded by bags of belongings and protected by security guards
column5: many of them also Roma.

column1: Many are waiting for Czech authorities to decide on their status and whether they qualify for permanent accommodation; others are in an even bleaker situation.
“We tried to register for refugee protection at the registration centre but they wouldn’t accept us and didn’t give us any document explaining why
column2: ” says Zanna
column3: a teenage mother of three children from Kyiv
column4: who says she had arrived in Prague with her family four days earlier.

column1: “We came here looking for a place to stay but instead we are just lying on the floor like dogs. We are exhausted and have no energy any more. I’m just feeling really hopeless.”
It is a tale typical of many Roma arrivals
column2: aid workers say.

column1: Since Vladimir Putin ordered Russian troops to invade Ukraine on 24 February
column2: the Czech Republic has issued about 350
column3: 000 temporary protection visas to refugees.

column1: Many Roma have faced a different fate
column2: driven – according to Mubeenová – by an anti-Roma prejudice that is widespread in the Czech Republic and neighbouring countries. Many Roma who left Prague for Germany later returned
column3: she says
column4: including some who reported that police in Dresden refused to allow them to disembark from their train.

column1: Czech officials say many Roma arrivals do not qualify for refugee status because they are EU citizens holding dual Ukrainian-Hungarian nationality – thanks to a policy enacted by Hungary’s prime minister
column2: Viktor Orbán
column4: of offering citizenship to ethnic Hungarians in Ukraine’s Transcarpathia region.

column1: Some of the Hungarian passport holders claim they were bribed into applying for the documents
column2: not understanding the consequences of dual citizenship. Several told the Guardian they left the Czech Republic for Budapest only to return to Prague after authorities in Hungary rejected their passports as forgeries.

column1: Holding EU citizenship protects them from deportation under Schengen rules while affording freedom of movement between member states – but it also potentially leaves them in limbo when states are not obliged to provide accommodation under protected status arrangements.
However
column2: Mubeenová says only a fifth of the current station inhabitants hold Hungarian citizenship. The fate of others
column3: who often face obstacles to submitting applications or even entering registration centres
column4: reflects hardening official attitudes that dismiss Roma arrivals as bona fide refugees.

column1: Vít Rakušan
column2: the Czech interior minister
column3: has claimed that the Roma influx is tied to organised crime and spoken of the need to combat “social tourism”.

column1: Mubeenová says: “I have sat in meetings with representatives of Prague city hall
column2: the police etc
column3: and noticed the narrative changing – people stopped talking about refugees and started referring to ‘economic migrants’ and ‘welfare tourists’.

column1: “Representatives have told me that they don’t have the necessary documents to apply for protection
column2: but they are often not even allowed to submit applications and that’s not legal.”

column1: A spokesperson for the Czech interior ministry – which is responsible for the processing of refugees – says those at the railway station who had applied for temporary protection were entitled to state-provided accommodation
column2: including at a recently established “tent city” in the Prague neighbourhood of Troja.

column1: “It happens that some people refuse this offer and return to the main station. However
column2: there are also people staying at the station who are not entitled to temporary protection or who have not applied for temporary protection at all
column3: ” he says.

column1: “When an application for temporary protection is submitted
column2: an assessment is made
column3: in accordance with the legislation in force
column4: as to whether the person concerned is eligible. If it turns out that the applicant is a citizen of another EU member state
column5: then temporary protection cannot be granted.”

column1: The increasingly dire situation at the station has led to instances of chickenpox
column2: measles
column3: hepatitis A
column4: lice
column5: scabies and tuberculosis being reported by medical students working as volunteers. Firefighters disinfect the premises three times a day.

column1: Hygiene restrictions prevent aid agencies distributing hot
column2: cooked food. In the absence of regular meals
column3: many refugees leave during daytime and go into Prague city centre
column4: where some resort to begging.

column1: Jan Vágner
column2: the station’s building manager
column3: describes the current situation as “more challenging” than early in the refugee crisis
column4: when more than 5
column5: 000 people poured off trains arriving from Ukraine.

column1: “Even though the numbers are far fewer now
column2: we need to talk to them all individually and work closely with them
column3: but we don’t have the right kind of help
column4: ” he says.

column1: Amid the chaos
column2: however
column3: one man has a relatively happy story. Stick thin and wearing a white cap
column4: Heorhii Stan
column6: originally from Odesa
column7: was preparing to travel to Vienna with his four children to collect his wife after successfully applying for protected status in the Czech Republic.

column1: His relief was sharpened by having spent four nights at the railway station
column2: an experience he described as “tough and hopeless” before being moved to an isolated refugee camp generally reserved for Roma in the Bohemian forest. “I really want to integrate here and ensure my kids go to school
column3: ” he says. “And I want to work.”

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/25/im-never-going-back-the-high-profile-russian-defectors-rejecting-war;2022-05-25;‘I’m never going back’: the high-profile Russian defectors rejecting war;"Gazprombank’s Igor Volobuyev and diplomat Boris Bondarev are among the Russian elite to oppose Putin’s invasion of Ukraine
Igor Volobuyev spent two decades working in the heart of the Russian business establishment
column2: first for Gazprom and then for its affiliate Gazprombank
column3: where until February this year he was vice-president.

column1: Then Vladimir Putin launched his war on Ukraine in late February
column2: and Volobuyev decided he could no longer stand living in Russia. He packed a small rucksack of possessions and a stack of cash
column3: and flew out of the country on 2 March
column4: pretending he was going on holiday.

column1: A few days later
column2: he crossed from Poland into Ukraine
column3: where he spent his childhood years. Now
column4: he spends his days trying to convince officials to provide him with Ukrainian documents and allow him to sign up for military service.

column1: “I want to go to the place where I can defend my homeland with a weapon
column2: I’m trying every day
column3: ” he said
column4: in an interview in the suburbs of the capital
column5: Kyiv. “I am never going back to Russia.”

column1: Hundreds of thousands of Russians are believed to have fled the country since Putin launched the war
column2: and many intellectuals
column3: journalists and activists have voiced their opposition to the conflict. However
column4: among the political and business elites
column5: defections have been extremely rare. Despite reports of widespread dismay over the invasion of Ukraine
column6: only a tiny handful of people have spoken publicly to condemn the war.

column1: On Monday
column2: Boris Bondarev
column3: a career diplomat posted to the Russian mission to the UN in Geneva
column4: became the highest-level Russian diplomat to denounce the war. When he resigned
column5: Bondarev published a scathing letter in which he wrote that he was “ashamed” of his country and called the invasion a “disaster”.

column1: Bondarev said he made his mind up to resign on the day Russia launched its invasion
column2: but it took months to gather the resolve to go public.

column1: Like many fellow diplomats
column2: Bondarev had remained in his post over the past decade
column3: despite Russia’s growing isolation due to a series of crises
column4: including its annexation of Crimea and the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in 2014.

column1: “You understand that it is wrong
column2: ” he said in a telephone interview. “That it’s not good. But it doesn’t really touch you
column3: your life. These bad things they happen somewhere far away. It’s not right but that’s how most people think.”

column1: “But now this is totally different: Russia attacked another country. This is Ukraine who we always considered to be our brothers and attacked them in the most brutal manner. Bombing cities. Claiming them to be Nazis and denazified. It’s something ridiculous. It’s something unimaginable.”
Bondarev said he believed many of his fellow diplomats were also opposed to the war
column2: but he never discussed it with them. “It isn’t something you really talked about with other people
column3: it isn’t something you can speak about openly these days
column4: ” Bondarev said. “Everyone is silent.”

column1: Volobuyev said that after 2014
column2: he had started to speak openly about his concerns over Russian politics in the workplace
column3: and while many people were scared of getting involved in a discussion
column4: he felt that most people he knew agreed at least partially.

column1: “In Gazprom there were a few passionate Putinists
column2: but the majority of people understood exactly what kind of country they lived in. A lot of people in Russia are just scared
column3: ” he said.

column1: “You have this internal censorship
column2: that it’s dangerous to say certain things
column3: and you live with this permanently. Ukrainians look at this and they don’t understand it because they are a free people
column4: ” he said.

column1: Volobuyev grew up in the Ukrainian city of Okhtyrka
column2: and left for Moscow in 1989
column3: when he was 18. After spending some time in journalism
column4: he joined Gazprom
column5: where he worked for 15 years before moving to become one of Gazprombank’s vice-presidents in 2015.

column1: As he tells it
column2: he was originally a supporter of Putin
column3: and voted for him in 2012
column4: but his “eyes were opened” by the Maidan revolution in 2014 and subsequent Russia-backed war in Donbas. He wanted to return to Ukraine then
column5: but said he could not
column6: for family reasons
column7: about which he declined to elaborate.

column1: “It was a choice between my homeland and my family
column2: and at that time I chose my family. On 24 February this year
column3: I understood I could not put it off any longer
column4: ” he said.

column1: Volobuyev was a mid-ranking cog in the Gazprom machine; among the higher business echelons few people have dared to break ranks.
Oleg Tinkov
column2: a self-made billionaire who set up one of Russia’s leading banks
column3: has so far been the most outspoken public opponent of the war among the business elite. In one of a series of critical Instagram posts
column4: Tinkov wrote: “I don’t see ANY beneficiary of this crazy war! Innocent people and soldiers are dying.”

column1: After his statements
column2: Tinkov said he was forced to sell his assets at a knockdown price to an oligarch loyal to the Kremlin. In an interview with the Russian journalist Yury Dud
column3: he said he was sure that the entire business elite backed his statements but were too scared to say the same publicly.

column1: “I have spoken to 12 of the top 20 on the Forbes list personally
column2: and they all support me
column3: there is a full consensus
column4: ” he said.

column1: He said half of those he had spoken to justified their silence by claiming to fear for their tens of thousands of employees
column2: who could be affected if they fell out of favour with the Kremlin.

column1: “The other half say
column2: ‘We’ll make a statement and then lose our business
column3: like you
column4: and then what
column5: what have you achieved?’”

column1: Putin has referred to those who oppose Moscow’s actions as “scum and traitors”
column2: whom the Russian people will “spit out like a fly”. In the current climate it is clear that public opposition to the war makes it dangerous to return to Russia.

column1: Bondarev said he was worried about the response to his statement and said he would “welcome” an offer of asylum in the west. Tinkov has said he has hired bodyguards.
As a Russian citizen of Ukrainian origin
column2: Volobuyev’s position is a little different. His arrival in Ukraine has given him a feeling that he has finally returned home
column3: he said. But he accepts that he has a lot of work to do to persuade Ukrainians of his sincerity.

column1: “All these years
column2: I said I was Ukrainian but I continued to live and work there. I understand that I have to repent
column3: and to prove for many years that I should be allowed to live here and that I can be trusted
column4: ” he said."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/25/death-to-the-enemy-ukraine-news-channels-unite-to-cover-war;2022-05-25;‘Death to the enemy’: Ukraine’s news channels unite to cover war;"State-backed broadcast has strategic and practical justifications but some see it as dangerous monopoly
In an age of social media and satellite television
column2: the singular wartime news bulletin evokes images of families tuning in to the radio during the second world war. But in Ukraine
column3: the state-backed broadcast has remerged
column4: albeit with a 21st-century spin.

column1: Shortly after Russia invaded
column2: the country’s main TV channels started broadcasting the same content 24 hours a day
column3: nicknamed the United News telemarathon. Each channel has a daily slot on the broadcast
column4: which is shown simultaneously on all the channels.

column1: United News was initially aired by five channels owned by various Ukrainian oligarchs as well as the publicly owned channels. It has since been signed into law and now includes all Ukrainian channels that used to show news.
The head of Ukraine’s parliamentary broadcasting committee said he believed the arrangement should continue until the war ends.
While some say there are critical strategic justifications for the telemarathon
column2: others argue that it amounts to a monopoly of the information space by President Volodymyr Zelenskiy’s team and could be exploited for political purposes.

column1: “The telemarathon is the information war equivalent of our anti-aircraft systems and I think it’s the most optimal option for Ukraine right now
column2: ” said Svitlana Ostapa
column3: the deputy head of Detector Media
column4: a media monitoring organisation that tracks propaganda
column5: disinformation and political interference in Ukraine. “It helps protect Ukrainians from Russian fakes and prevents panic among the population.

column2: Russian propagandists and their allies released a barrage of disinformation about the Maidan revolution
column3: Crimea and events in eastern Ukraine that experts said worked to destabilise the country.

column1: There are also more practical reasons for the channels working together. “Most of the journalists left Kyiv and the channels simply could not cope individually
column2: ” Ostapa said. “The top ministers and officials do not have the time to comment to more than half a dozen channels
column3: and this format means they are communicating with the population once a day and not being seen to favour one channel.”

column1: The language used by Ukraine’s TV presenters has changed dramatically
column2: reflecting usage among the wider population. Russian soldiers are often called “occupiers”
column3: “terrorists”
column4: “orcs” and “Rashists” – a combination of the words Russian and fascist.

column1: Guests are welcomed with the greeting “Glory to Ukraine!”
column2: to which they answer “Glory to the heroes!”. The famous words of a Ukrainian soldier tasked with defending Snake Island in the Black Sea
column3: who was recorded over the military radio saying “Russian ship go fuck yourself”
column4: are mentioned without the swearword being censored
column5: and the presenters regularly end their segments with “Death to the enemy!”
column6: a historic Ukrainian wartime slogan.

column1: The 24-hour wartime news focuses on the Ukrainian military’s victories
column2: its defence of Ukraine’s frontlines and Russia’s war crimes. The abrupt collapse of Ukraine’s economy in February means there is almost no advertising. Commercial breaks advertise hotlines for finding missing loved ones and reporting war crimes
column3: as well as videos produced by normal Ukrainians
column4: the Ukrainian army press service and the presidential office about the resistance of Ukrainian soldiers and citizens.

column1: Ostapa said the language and messaging were discussed in editorial meetings between all the channels involved
column2: the culture ministry and the national broadcasting council
column3: and there was now a move to ban slogans containing swearwords. The overarching editorial message of the telemarathon is Ukrainian resistance in the face of Russian brutality
column4: Ostapa wrote in one her analysis pieces.

column1: The TV channel heads have rejected accusations that the authorities dictate the content
column2: saying dialogue with officials includes things such as censoring information that reveals Ukrainian military positions. And since May
column3: Ukrainians looking for an alternative to news can tune in to other channels that show films and cartoons about good winning out against evil.

column1: But some see the unified TV coverage as propagandistic and point to the fact that airtime is now almost exclusively given to people close to the president
column2: including regular comedy sketches by the president’s former comic colleagues.

column1: “The telemarathon is an attempt by the presidential office to gain even greater control over the information space
column2: ” said Aksenyia Kurina
column3: a journalist and campaigner who has spent her career focusing on censorship in Ukraine. “We may soon find ourselves in a heavily censored information space.”

column1: Zelenskiy won the 2019 Ukrainian presidential election with more than 70% of the vote
column2: thanks in large part
column3: said Kurina
column4: to his innovative digital campaign. Zelenskiy’s party also controls Ukraine’s parliament.

column1: Though Ukraine’s media have celebrated a marked change in their president since the invasion
column2: Zelenskiy was on terse terms with some journalists before the war. He was known to publicly display disdain towards journalists who asked critical questions
column3: and his press service ostracised some reporters for critical coverage.

column1: “The telemarathon does not reflect reality
column2: it forms a picture that the authorities would like to see. This is dangerous
column3: because at some point the authorities may begin to believe in their own propaganda
column4: ” said Kurina. “I understand that many journalists are not able to cope with their emotions at the moment
column5: for many this is a personal traumatic experience
column6: but it is important to remember professional ethics and not to allow hate speech.”

column1: Notably
column2: three channels owned by Ukraine’s former president Petro Poroshenko and that are close to his associates have not been given slots and therefore do not contribute to the telemarathon’s content or editorial meetings. Poroshenko was charged with treason after Zelenskiy came to power
column3: a case that the former president says is politically motivated.

column1: At first
column2: Poroshenko’s channels split their coverage 50-50 between the telemarathon and their own content. But since in mid-March all channels – except for those dedicated to light entertainment – are obliged to stream the telemarathon.

column1: The head of one of Poroshenko’s channels has said that despite their appeals to be included
column2: they are still waiting to hear from the authorities."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/25/russia-ukraine-war-what-we-know-on-day-91-of-the-invasion;2022-05-25;Russia-Ukraine war: what we know on day 91 of the invasion;"Invasion in ‘most active phase’
column2: says Ukraine; Russian forces take control of three Donetsk regions; 200 bodies found in Mariupol basement

column1: Russia’s military campaign in Ukraine has entered its most active phase
column2: according to Ukraine’s defence ministry spokesperson
column3: Oleksandr Motuzyanyk. Battles being fought in eastern Ukraine could determine the country’s fate
column4: he added. “The situation on the (eastern) front is extremely difficult because the fate of this country is perhaps being decided (there) right now.”

column1: Russian forces have taken control of three Donetsk region towns including Svitlodarsk
column2: according to the regional governor
column3: Pavlo Kyrylenko. Earlier today
column4: it was reported that Russian forces had entered Svitlodarsk and hung up a Russian flag over the city administration building.

column1: The governor of Ukraine’s eastern Luhansk region said the situation there “is only getting worse” as Russian troops advance.“The situation is very difficult and unfortunately it is only getting worse. It is getting worse with every day and even with every hour
column2: ” said governor Sergiy Gaidai. “They are simply eliminating Severodonetsk from the earth.”

column1: The bodies of more than 200 people have been discovered in the rubble of a high-rise apartment building in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol
column2: according to a Ukrainian official. Petro Andryushchenko
column3: an adviser to Mariupol’s mayor Vadym Boychenko
column4: said workers found the bodies while digging through a basement underneath the collapsed building.

column1: Ukrainian soldiers captured by Russian forces after the three-month siege of the Azovstal steel plant are being held in “satisfactory” conditions
column2: according to the unit commander’s wife
column3: amid uncertainty over the fate of the prisoners. At least 1
column4: 000 Ukrainian fighters
column5: including members of the Azov battalion
column6: were transferred to Russian-held territory last week after the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol was taken by Russian forces.

column1: Ukraine’s foreign minister
column2: Dmytro Kuleba
column3: said the Russian offensive in the Donbas is “the largest one on European soil since WWII”. He urged allies to “speed up deliveries of weapons and ammunition”. The UK’s Ministry of Defence said Russia has increased the intensity of its operations in the Donbas as it seeks to encircle Severodonetsk
column4: Lyschansk
column5: and Rubizhne in order to place the whole of Luhansk oblast under Russian occupation.

column1: Ukraine is gathering the bodies of dead Russian soldiers found in formerly occupied towns in the hope of exchanging them for prisoners of war or for Ukrainian bodies. In Kharkiv
column2: 60 bodies were retrieved and stacked in a refrigerated rail carriage
column3: Reuters reports.

column1: Ukrainian prosecutors have launched a war crimes investigation in Kharkiv’s Gorky Park which was hit by about 50 shells in three months of war. “Hitting civilian targets
column2: civilian infrastructure
column3: trying to kill civilians and destroy cultural heritage
column4: are considered war crimes. An error can happen once or twice

Today China and Russia present the greatest threat to open society.”

column5: the very few people thus contributing to further isolation and degradation of my country. Russia no longer has allies
column6: and there is no one to blame but its reckless and ill-conceived policy.”

column1: Bondarev is the highest-level diplomat yet to resign publicly from the Russian foreign ministry over the war
column2: which began in February. In a telephone interview with the Guardian
column3: Bondarev confirmed that he had written the statement and submitted his letter of resignation on Monday.

column1: “The decision was very simple
column2: ” said Bondarev. “When you see that your country is doing the worst things and being a civil servant you’re somehow related to that
column3: it’s your decision just to terminate your connection with the government. We all must be responsible. And I don’t want to have any responsibility for what I don’t approve of.”

column1: Bondarev published the statement on his Facebook and LinkedIn accounts and also sent copies to diplomats and media outlets. He said he had walked into work on Monday
column2: submitted his resignation
column3: and walked out.

column1: “The decision was made on February 24. But it took some time to gather some resolve to make it
column2: ” he said.

column1: Hillel Neuer
column2: the executive director of the Geneva-based human rights organisation UN Watch
column3: called Bondarev a “hero”.

column1: “We are now calling on all other Russian diplomats at the United Nations – and worldwide – to follow his moral example and resign
column2: ” he said.

column1: Neuer also called for Bondarev to be allowed to speak at this week’s Davos forum
column2: a gathering of the world’s political and business elite at a mountain resort in Switzerland.

column1: Bondarev’s statement was also confirmed by the Russian media outlet Kommersant
column2: which said that it “also knows the names of several other diplomats who resigned from the Russian foreign ministry after the start of the ‘special military operation’ in Ukraine
column3: but almost none of them have made public statements about this”.

column1: Bondarev
column2: a counsellor on arms control at the Russian diplomatic mission in Geneva
column3: said that other Russian diplomats have similar feelings about the war but are unlikely to speak out.

column1: “There are people who think the way that I think and see the situation for what it is
column2: ” he said. “But I don’t know whether some of them will follow my example. I don’t think that there will be many.”

column1: He said he had not had any response yet from the foreign ministry after delivering his letter of resignation on Monday.
“I don’t know what the [Russian] reaction will be
column2: ” he said. “I don’t know what I am going to do either. No plans.”

column1: Asked whether he had asked for asylum outside Russia
column2: he said: “I think that if someone offers to help in this difficult situation
column3: I think it would be very gratefully accepted.”

column1: As to returning to Russia
column2: he said that “would not be a very good idea right now”.

column1: In his public statement
column2: Bondarev took aim at top officials such as Vladimir Putin and Sergei Lavrov
column3: calling the Russian foreign minister “a good illustration of the degradation of the system”.

column1: “The aggressive war unleashed by Putin against Ukraine
column2: and in fact against the entire western world
column3: is not only a crime against the Ukrainian people
column4: but also
column5: perhaps
column6: the most serious crime against the people of Russia
column7: with a bold letter Z crossing out all hopes and prospects for a prosperous free society in our country
column8: ” he wrote.

column1: “Those who conceived this war want only one thing – to remain in power forever
column2: live in pompous tasteless palaces
column3: sail on yachts comparable in tonnage and cost to the entire Russian Navy
column4: enjoying unlimited power and complete impunity
column5: ” he said. “To achieve that they are willing to sacrifice as many lives as it takes. Thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have already died just for this.”

column1: Bondarev is a career diplomat who has worked for the foreign ministry since 2002. He has served as an adviser on nuclear non-proliferation for nearly a decade
column2: first in Moscow and then at Russia’s permanent mission to the UN and other international organisations in Geneva.

column1: During that time
column2: he said
column3: he had stayed on as a diplomat even as relations deteriorated with the west because he felt there was “some room for diplomacy
column4: some room to go back to normal somehow”.

column1: “But now after February 24
column2: we just jumped into an abyss and there can be no going back to normal
column3: no going back to anywhere
column4: ” he continued. “Today of course we can see that there can be no negotiations
column5: it’s just all-out war.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/23/up-to-100-ukraine-troops-could-be-dying-donbas-each-day-zelenskiy;2022-05-23;Up to 100 Ukraine troops could be dying in Donbas each day
column2: says Zelenskiy;"President gives insight into country’s casualties
column3: as Luhansk governor says Russia using ‘scorched-earth’ tactics

column1: Ukraine’s president has given an insight into the level of losses being suffered by Ukrainian forces in the Donbas
column2: saying between 50 to 100 Ukrainians could be dying every day.

column1: While Ukraine and its allies have made much of Russian losses since the war began
column2: the issue of Ukrainian casualties has been something of a black hole.

column1: The heaviest fighting is focused around the twin cities of Severodonetsk and Lysychansk in Luhansk
column2: one of the two provinces that make up the Donbas.

column1: Watching a Russian rocket artillery salvo being unloaded on Lyman from about 10km away. We could see the explosions of the rounds hitting Ukrainian positions. pic.twitter.com/tKwhGR5y1T
“Today
column2: from 50 to 100 people could be killed here in the most complicated area
column3: in the east of our country
column4: ” Volodymyr Zelenskiy said on Sunday evening.

column1: Serhiy Haidai
column2: the governor of Luhansk
column3: said in a local television interview that Russia was using “scorched-earth” tactics in the region and that Severodonetsk had been attacked from “four separate directions”
column4: though Russian forces had not succeeded in breaking into the city.

column1: The Donbas has been the scene of recent heavy fighting involving intense shelling by both sides
column2: with Zelenskiy’s remarks appearing to be a reference to fatalities in combat. The high recent death toll on the Ukrainian side also suggests an even larger number of non-fatal casualties.

column1: Historically a ratio of one killed in action to three wounded was regarded as a rough rule of thumb for assessing casualties
column2: although better field medical treatment and evacuation
column3: not least for US forces in theatres such as Afghanistan and Iraq
column4: resulted in a far higher survival rate from injuries that would once have caused deaths.

column1: According to a policy briefing paper published by the Belfer Center in 2014: “The ratio of wounded to killed in battle has increased dramatically as a result of improvements in medical care in conflict zones. This shift is particularly relevant for technologically advanced countries such as the United States
column2: which invest significant resources in military medicine.”

column1: The new estimate came as Kyiv also revealed its worst military losses from a single attack of the Ukraine war on Monday
column2: saying 87 people had been killed last week when Russian forces struck a barracks housing troops at a training base in the north.

column1: The disclosure that scores had been killed in the attack demonstrated Russia’s ability to inflict huge losses
column2: even far from the front. Previously
column3: Kyiv had said eight people died in the 17 May strike on the barracks in the town of Desna.

column1: “Today we completed work at Desna. In Desna
column2: under the rubble
column3: there were 87 casualties. Eighty-seven corpses
column4: ” Zelenskiy said during a speech made by video link to business leaders in Davos
column5: Switzerland.

column1: Moscow had said at the time that it hit a training base with long-range missiles. The toll Zelenskiy announced on Monday was more than double the number killed in a similar attack on a Ukrainian training base in Yaraviv in the west in March.
The updated death toll from Desna emerged following recent remarks by senior Ukrainian officials
column2: including the president
column3: that warned of increasing bloodshed in the next phase of the conflict
column4: amid anticipation of a Ukrainian counteroffensive later in the summer.

column1: Zelenskiy’s acknowledgment of the increasingly heavy toll on Ukraine’s military follows claims by the UK’s Ministry of Defence that since Russia invaded Ukraine
column2: it has probably suffered a similar death toll to that experienced by the Soviet Union during its nine-year war in Afghanistan
column3: although those claims could not be independently verified.

column1: Like Ukraine
column2: western allies including the UK have tended to emphasise Russian losses while avoiding the issue of Ukrainian losses as part of the information war with Moscow that appears in part aimed at trying to shift Russian public opinion against Putin’s invasion.

column1: A combination of “poor low-level tactics
column2: limited air cover
column3: a lack of flexibility” and a command approach that is “prepared to reinforce failure and repeat mistakes” has led to the high Russian casualty rate
column4: British intelligence said in its latest report released on Monday morning.

column1: Casualties are continuing to rise in the Donbas offensive
column2: the report added. “The Russian public has
column3: in the past
column4: proven sensitive to casualties suffered during wars of choice. As casualties suffered in Ukraine continue to rise they will become more apparent
column5: and public dissatisfaction with the war and a willingness to voice it may grow.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/23/germany-to-relax-visa-rules-for-russian-workers-despite-spy-warning;2022-05-23;Germany to relax visa rules for Russian workers despite  spy warning;"Process to be eased to exempt applicants with special expertise from case-by-case assessment
Germany is to relax visa requirements for skilled workers from Russia
column2: just as the country’s domestic intelligence agency warned of a heightened risk that Russian nationals working for German firms could be recruited for industrial espionage.

column1: The chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government is streamlining the visa application process by exempting Russian workers with specialised expertise in areas such as IT and communication technology from case-by-case assessments through the federal employment department.
The so-called “global approval for access to the labour market”
column2: which applies only to Russian employees of German companies who are earning at least €43
column3: 992 a year
column4: will last until 30 September.

column1: Between the start of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the beginning of May
column2: Germany issued more than 600 visas for Russian skilled workers
column3: which allow for a longer stay in Germany than the 90-day so-called Schengen visa.

column1: The German foreign office told the news agency dpa it had issued about 350 work visas via its Moscow embassy in April
column2: in addition to a further 190 working visas issued by the general consulate in St Petersburg. Most of those in receipt of such visas were already working for German firms
column3: dpa said.

column1: Germany is already home to about 235
column2: 000 Russian passport holders
column3: more than any other country in the European Union.

column1: Only last week
column2: the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution issued a special warning that Russian nationals who were about to move to Germany
column3: and those already working in the country
column4: faced an increased risk of being blackmailed or otherwise put under pressure to collect information of use to a Russian economy increasingly cut off from global knowledge networks.

column1: “Russia is increasingly isolated through the sanctions imposed in reaction to the war in Ukraine”
column2: the report said. “Its economy is cut off from the knowhow and technologies of the west.”

column1: Recruitment attempts could take place during mandatory appointments with Russian embassies or other bureaucratic bodies
column2: Germany’s domestic intelligence agency said. “They may also try to exercise pressure via reprisals against relatives or acquaintances who have remained in Russia”
column3: the report continued. “In general
column4: Russian intelligence services do not shy away from methods like threats and blackmail.”

column1: Asked if the German government was introducing special measures to vet Russian working visa applicants
column2: a spokesperson said: “Standard security checks of applicants are being made within the visa process.”

column1: The decision to ease entry for Russian skilled workers comes as human rights NGOs said the German government was not doing enough to ease the visa application process for independent journalists facing repression in Russia.
About 70 Russian journalists and media professionals
column2: most of them employees of the independent Russian TV channel Dozhd and the news website Meduza
column3: have been put on a humanitarian visa list drawn up by the German culture ministry but do not yet qualify for the more generous visas for skilled workers.

column1: “We want to offer Russian journalists who are being persecuted in Russia protection in Germany
column2: ” a spokesperson for the interior minister
column3: Nancy Faeser
column4: said on Monday. “We want to ease entry and speed up processes.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/23/lithuania-calls-for-joint-effort-on-russia-black-sea-blockade;2022-05-23;UK backs Lithuania’s plan to lift Russian blockade of Ukraine grain;"Britain supports in principle the call for a naval coalition ‘of the willing’ to restart exports through Black Sea
Britain has backed in principle a proposal by Lithuania for a naval coalition “of the willing” to lift the Russian Black Sea blockade on Ukrainian grain exports.
The Lithuanian foreign minister
column2: Gabrielius Landsbergis
column3: proposed the plan during talks with the UK foreign secretary
column4: Liz Truss
column5: on Monday in London.

column1: “Time is very very short. We are closing in on a new harvest and there is no other practical way of exporting the grain except through the Black Sea port of Odesa
column2: ” he told the Guardian. “There is no way of storing this grain and no other adequate alternative route. It is imperative that we show vulnerable countries we are prepared to take the steps that are needed to feed the world.”

column1: Landsbergis proposed that a naval escort operation – not run by Nato – could protect the grain ships as they headed through the Black Sea and past Russian warships. He suggested that
column2: apart from Britain
column3: countries that were affected by the potential loss of grain such as Egypt could provide the necessary protection.

column1: “What we have seen now is just the beginning. The worst is yet to come in the next five to seven weeks when the first harvest arrives and there is no place to put it
column2: so that means people in northern Africa
column3: the Middle East and south-east Asia will be paying exorbitant prices for wheat
column4: corn and the other commodities they need to put food on their table”. He said Ukraine needed to export 80m tonnes of wheat alone this year and the only option was through Odesa

column1: https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2022/05/ukraine_ports/giv-6562fszkaD67mVNX/
His plan
column2: under gestation for weeks
column3: would require demining parts of the Black Sea to ensure safe passage
column4: as well as the agreement of Turkey
column5: which guards the entrance to the Black Sea.

column1: “This would be a non-military humanitarian mission and is not comparable with a no-fly zone
column2: ” he said. “In this endeavour military ships or planes or both would be used to ensure that the grain supplies can leave Odesa safely and reach the Bosphorus without Russian interference. We would need a coalition of the willing – countries with significant naval power to protect the shipping lanes
column3: and countries that are affected by this”.

column1: Nato as an alliance should not take a role
column2: he said.

column1: After meeting Landsbergis
column2: Truss said the UK would want British naval ships to join the escort if the practicalities could be sorted
column3: including demining the harbour and providing Ukraine with longer-range weapons to defend the harbour from Russian attack. The UK is in discussions with allies about the plan and it would probably need US agreement to be activated.

column1: Truss said: “What we need to do is deal with this global food security issue and the UK is working on an urgent solution to get the grain out of Ukraine”.
The UN secretary general
column2: António Guterres
column3: has warned of “a hurricane of hunger” if Ukrainian grain is not exported. The world’s 41 least-developed nations import a third of their wheat from Ukraine and Russia. Soaring food prices have already driven inflation levels in Egypt to the highest level since mid-2019.

column1: Asked how Britain had reacted to his plan
column2: Landsbergis said: “From my perspective the British government is interested in assisting Ukraine in any way it can. The UK has taken some very strong and decisive steps in this crisis and maybe there is a chance that the UK will participate. Britain was the first country to provide rockets to shield Odesa”.

column1: He said Lithuania
column2: one of Ukraine’s closest allies in the west
column3: had been looking into how Ukraine would feed the world for weeks.

column1: Landsbergis said alternative routes by rail through Belarus or by road to the Baltic Sea ports in Poland and Lithuania had severe practical drawbacks
column2: while bottlenecks and complete overload would mean it would take Ukrainian trucks five to nine weeks to reach ports by road either in Romania
column3: Poland or Lithuania.

column1: Turkey
column2: Landsbergis acknowledged
column3: had its doubts about the escalation potential inherent in his scheme. However
column4: he pointed out that as a major importer of grain
column5: Turkey had a self-interest in the naval lanes being opened up if Russia would not voluntarily lift the blockade.

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/may/23/zelenskiy-sanctions-russia-davos-speech-ukraine;2022-05-23;Zelenskiy urges ‘maximum sanctions’ against Russia in Davos speech;Ukrainian president tells business leaders they need to decide whether ‘brute force’ should rule the world
Ukraine’s president
column2: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column3: has urged the west to intensify its economic sanctions against Russia as he said business leaders in Davos needed to decide whether “brute force” should rule the world.

column1: In a keynote video address to the World Economic Forum (WEF)
column2: Zelenskiy called for a full oil embargo
column3: the severing of Russian banks from the global financial system
column4: the complete isolation of the Russian IT sector and a ban on trade with Russia.

column1: Ukraine’s president called for the implementation of “maximum sanctions” against Vladimir Putin’s regime and said there would be no point to Davos if Russian aggression was allowed to prevail.
Noting that history was at a turning point
column2: Zelenskiy said: “This is really the moment when it is decided whether brute force will rule the world.”

column1: Zelenskiy received a standing ovation and concluded his 45-minute session at the WEF by sending out a collective message to business leaders
column2: telling them they should “wake up each morning with the feeling ‘what have I done for Ukraine today?’”.

column1: Russia’s absence from this year’s Davos gathering has provided Ukraine with an opportunity to make its case for a stepping up of the west’s economic war against Russia
column2: with Zelenskiy’s team of ministers at the WEF all urging tougher action.

column1: Earlier Ukraine’s deputy prime minister
column2: Yulia Svyrydenko
column3: called for secondary sanctions against companies that continued to do business in Russia. “Now is not the time for a cost benefit analysis. We have to cut Russia off from the global economy completely
column4: ” Svyrydenko said.

column1: Citing the example of the Munich agreement in 1938
column2: Zelenskiy called for the withdrawal of all foreign companies from Russia so they were not used in the “bloody interests” of the Kremlin.

column1: He said any company quitting Russia was welcome to move to Ukraine
column2: where they could help with the massive task of repairing the colossal damage to an economy expected to shrink by at least 30% this year.

column1: “We offer the world the chance to set a precedent for what happens if you try to destroy a neighbour
column2: ” he said. “I invite you to take part in this rebuilding.”

column1: Zelenskiy said he was looking at alternative ways of getting Ukraine’s food out of the country after accusing Russia of stealing grain supplies ready for export. Talks are under way with Poland to see if food could be shipped out of ports on the Baltic Sea.
He added a corridor should be established for exports such as wheat and sunflower oil
column2: to prevent a food crisis for countries in Africa and Asia.

column1: Sir Lawrence Freedman
column2: the emeritus professor of war studies at King’s College London
column3: said he agreed about the urgent need for international agreement to secure a good corridor because the blockading of Ukraine’s food was “looming large now”.

column1: Freedman added: “The Ukraine line is there’s no time to waste. Just hit hard
column2: hit now
column3: and we need all the support we can get. And don’t nod in the direction of the Russians
column4: they’ve got nothing to give you.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/23/ukrainian-court-sentences-russian-soldier-to-life-in-prison-for-killing-civilian-vadim-shishimarin;2022-05-23;Ukrainian court sentences Russian soldier to life in prison for killing civilian;"Vadim Shishimarin shot dead Oleksandr Shelipov as he rode his bicycle in village in Sumy region during early days of invasion
A court in Kyiv has sentenced a Russian soldier to life in prison for the killing of a Ukrainian civilian
column2: in the first verdict in a trial related to war crimes carried out by the Russian army during its invasion of Ukraine.

column1: Vadim Shishimarin
column2: a 21-year-old sergeant
column3: was found guilty of killing 62-year-old Oleksandr Shelipov in the Sumy region during the first days of the invasion.

column1: The verdict was delivered on Monday by the judge Serhii Ahafonov in a packed courtroom
column2: with dozens of Ukrainian and foreign television cameras crammed into the small chamber.

column1: The judge said although Shishimarin cooperated with the investigation and expressed remorse
column2: the court could not accept his claim he did not mean to kill Shelipov when he fired at him. “The murder was committed with direct intent
column3: ” he said.

column1: Shishimarin
column2: wearing a grey and blue hoodie
column3: listened to the judge deliver his long verdict with his head bowed from inside the glass box for defendants. He was given a translation of the judge’s words from Ukrainian to Russian by a court-appointed translator.

column1: Shishimarin was commanding a tank division from the Moscow region that came under attack on 28 February
column2: prosecutors said. The attack led the Russian soldiers to disperse and Shishimarin ended up stealing a car with four other soldiers.

column1: When they saw Shelipov riding a bicycle and speaking on his mobile phone
column2: one of the other soldiers told Shishimarin to shoot him
column3: for fear he would give away their positions. Shishimarin fired three or four shots at Shelipov from his Kalashnikov.

column1: “I was ordered to shoot
column2: so I opened fire on him and he fell. We carried on driving
column3: ” he said in a video interrogation released by Ukraine’s SBU security services.

column1: Shishimarin pleaded guilty to the crime
column2: but his lawyer argued that his client was following an order and did not have intent to kill. Shishimarin also apologised to the wife of the victim.

column1: “The court cannot recognise the sincerity of his repentance
column2: ” Ahafonov said in his verdict.

column1: Shishimarin was whisked away from the court after the hearing in the back of a police van. He has 30 days to launch an appeal.
Speaking outside the courthouse
column2: Shishimarin’s lawyer
column3: Viktor Ovsyannikov said he would challenge the verdict. “This is the most severe sentence and any level-headed person would challenge it
column4: ” he said. He added that he believed “societal pressure” had influenced the court’s decision.

column1: The prosecutor Andriy Syniuk said the ruling was “lawful and justified”.
It is the first in a number of war crimes cases that Ukraine prosecutors want to try as quickly as possible. Ukraine’s prosecutor general
column2: Iryna Venediktova
column3: has said she is preparing more than 40 cases related to war crimes that could come to trial soon
column4: and Ukrainian authorities say they have registered more than 10
column5: 000 war crimes across the country.

column1: Trying cases so quickly
column2: while the conflict rages on
column3: is extremely unusual and may violate elements of the Geneva conventions
column4: legal experts say. However
column5: Ukraine has made swift justice a priority
column6: partly as a warning to Russian troops still occupying parts of the country that they may face justice for any crimes they commit.

column1: In an interview with the Russian independent news outlet Meduza
column2: Shishimarin’s mother
column3: Lyubov
column4: claimed her son was a caring and kind young man who had joined the army partly because there was a lack of opportunity in their home town
column5: and partly to help support the family after his stepfather was killed last year.

column1: She said her son called in late February and said: “Mummy
column2: I won’t have a telephone for a week
column3: I have to give it up. If someone tells you I went to Ukraine
column4: don’t believe them.” The next she heard of him was when she found out he was a prisoner in Ukraine
column5: she said.

column1: Shelipov’s widow
column2: Katerina
column3: identified Shishimarin as the man who shot her husband during a court hearing last week
column4: and told the court she hoped he would receive a life sentence. “But if he is traded for our defenders of Azovstal
column5: I would not mind
column6: ” she said.

column1: There has been some speculation that once convicted
column2: Shishmarin and others may be used as part of an exchange for Ukrainians held by Russia
column3: including the more than 2
column4: 000 defenders of the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol who recently surrendered to the Russians.

column1: Russian officials have veered between calling for harsh punishments
column2: including even the death penalty
column3: for some of the fighters
column4: and suggesting they may be open to an exchange.

column1: On Monday Denis Pushilin
column2: the leader of Russia-backed Donetsk separatists
column3: said there should be an “international tribunal” for the Azovstal defenders
column4: many of whom have been called “Nazis” by Russian authorities.

column1: “If an enemy [soldier] has laid down his arms
column2: his future fate is decided by a court
column3: if he is a Nazi criminal
column4: this will be a tribunal
column5: ” Pushilin said.

column1: The Kremlin said on Monday it was following the Shishimarin case. “Of course we are worried about the fate of our citizen. Unfortunately we have no possibilities to defend his interests there
column2: ” said Vladimir Putin’s spokesperson Dmitry Peskov on Monday. He said the Kremlin would use “other channels” to assist Shishimarin."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/23/we-must-stop-letting-russia-define-the-terms-of-the-ukraine-crisis#comments;2022-05-23;We must stop letting Russia define the terms of the Ukraine crisis;"A question like ‘Did US intelligence-sharing with Ukraine cross a line?’ forgets the fact that it was Russia that crossed the line – by invading Ukraine
In recent weeks
column2: the western public has been obsessed with the question “What goes on in Putin’s mind?” Western pundits wonder: do the people around him tell him the whole truth? Is he ill or going insane? Are we pushing him into a corner where he will see no other way out to save face than to accelerate the conflict into a total war?

column1: We should stop this obsession with the red line
column2: this endless search for the right balance between support for Ukraine and avoiding total war. The “red line” is not an objective fact: Putin himself is redrawing it all the time
column3: and we contribute to his redrawing with our reactions to Russia’s activities. A question like “Did US intelligence-sharing with Ukraine cross a line?” makes us obliterate the basic fact: it was Russia itself which crossed the line
column4: by attacking Ukraine. So instead of perceiving ourselves as a group which just reacts to Putin as an impenetrable evil genius
column5: we should turn the gaze back at ourselves: what do we – the “free west” – want in this affair?

column1: We must analyze the ambiguity of our support of Ukraine with the same cruelty we analyze Russia’s stance. We should reach beyond double standards applied today to the very foundations of European liberalism. Remember how
column2: in the western liberal tradition
column3: colonization was often justified in the terms of the rights of working people. John Locke
column4: the great Enlightenment philosopher and advocate of human rights
column5: justified white settlers grabbing land from Native Americans with a strange left-sounding argument against excessive private property. His premise was that an individual should be allowed to own only as much land as he is able to use productively
column6: not large tracts of land that he is not able to use (and then eventually rents to others). In North America
column7: as he saw it
column8: Indigenous people were using vast tracts of land mostly just for hunting
column9: and the white settlers who wanted to use it for intense agriculture had the right to seize it for the benefit of humanity.

column1: In the ongoing Ukraine crisis
column2: both sides present their acts as something they simply had to do: the west had to help Ukraine remain free and independent; Russia was compelled to intervene militarily to protect its safety. The latest example: the Russian foreign ministry claiming Russia will be “forced to take retaliatory steps” if Finland joins Nato. No
column3: it will not be “forced”
column4: in the same way that Russia was not “forced” to attack Ukraine. This decision appears “forced” only if one accepts the whole set of ideological and geopolitical assumptions that sustain Russian politics.

column1: These assumptions have to be analyzed closely
column2: without any taboos. One often hears that we should draw a strict line of separation between Putin’s politics and the great Russian culture
column3: but this line of separation is much more porous than it may appear. We should resolutely reject the idea that
column4: after years of patiently trying to resolve the Ukrainian crisis through negotiations
column5: Russia was finally forced/compelled to attack Ukraine – one is never forced to attack and annihilate a whole country. The roots are much deeper; I am ready to call them properly metaphysical.

column1: Anatoly Chubais
column2: the father of Russian oligarchs (he orchestrated Russia’s rapid privatization in 1992)
column3: said in 2004: “I’ve reread all of Dostoevsky over the past three months. And I feel nothing but almost physical hatred for the man. He is certainly a genius
column4: but his idea of Russians as special
column5: holy people
column6: his cult of suffering and the false choices he presents make me want to tear him to pieces.” As much as I dislike Chubais for his politics
column7: I think he is right about Dostoevsky
column8: who provided the “deepest” expression of the opposition between Europe and Russia: individualism versus collective spirit
column9: materialist hedonism versus the spirit of sacrifice.

column1: Russia now presents its invasion as a new step in the fight for decolonization
column2: against western globalization. In a text published earlier this month

column1: We should stop this obsession with the red line
column2: this endless search for the right balance between support for Ukraine and avoiding total war. The “red line” is not an objective fact: Putin himself is redrawing it all the time
column3: and we contribute to his redrawing with our reactions to Russia’s activities. A question like “Did US intelligence-sharing with Ukraine cross a line?” makes us obliterate the basic fact: it was Russia itself which crossed the line
column4: by attacking Ukraine. So instead of perceiving ourselves as a group which just reacts to Putin as an impenetrable evil genius
column5: we should turn the gaze back at ourselves: what do we – the “free west” – want in this affair?

column2: in the western liberal tradition
column3: colonization was often justified in the terms of the rights of working people. John Locke
column4: the great Enlightenment philosopher and advocate of human rights

column6: not large tracts of land that he is not able to use (and then eventually rents to others). In North America
column7: as he saw it
column8: Indigenous people were using vast tracts of land mostly just for hunting
column9: and the white settlers who wanted to use it for intense agriculture had the right to seize it for the benefit of humanity.

column3: it will not be “forced”

column4: after years of patiently trying to resolve the Ukrainian crisis through negotiations
column5: Russia was finally forced/compelled to attack Ukraine – one is never forced to attack and annihilate a whole country. The roots are much deeper; I am ready to call them properly metaphysical.
