column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/23/we-had-too-much-to-do-to-be-scared-the-couple-who-fled-irpin-with-19-dogs;2022-05-23;‘We had too much to do to be scared’: the couple who fled Irpin with 19 dogs;"Anastasiya Tikha and her husband
column2: Arthur Lee
column3: fought their way through bombs and gunfire to save the array of animals in their care

column1: The image of a windswept young woman holding tight to the leads of nine dogs under an ominously dark sky spread far and wide at the time of the Battle of Kyiv.
The apparent bravery of the woman
column2: who was attempting an audacious evacuation across a broken bridge targeted by Russian fire
column3: and the vulnerability of the animals
column4: some of whom were strapped into dog wheelchairs
column5: epitomised to many the cruelty of the war being waged by Vladimir Putin and the dignity of the Ukrainian response.

column1: The full story of the trials of Anastasiya Tykha
column3: a veterinary student in the final year of her degree
column4: and her husband Arthur Lee
column6: is perhaps even more striking than the photograph
column7: which the couple discovered had gone viral when Tykha saw herself on the television news and listened to the presenter report that she was dead.

column1: Speaking in Irpin
column2: the town 13 miles north of Kyiv from where the couple had fled on 9 March
column3: Tykha said they ended up making seven crossings of the bridge in total
column4: each one under fire.

column1: “We had too much to do to be worried or scared”
column2: said Tykha
column3: who has run an animal shelter in Irpin for four years
column4: and who on that first journey was seeking to escape with 19 dogs
column5: five cats
column6: a turtle
column7: a chameleon
column8: two Triton lizards
column9: an axolotl and a hamster.

column1: It was not an easy decision to flee
column2: but the Russians had wrestled control of the town
column3: there was no electricity or running water and the dogs were having to drink from the shelter’s aquarium.

column1: It was Snizhana Bugryk
column3: a friend who was involved in finding abandoned and disabled animals for Tykha and Lee’s shelter
column4: who persuaded the couple that they had no choice but to leave.

column1: “Snizhana said we had to go or we would be killed
column2: that this was our last chance for us and the animals to survive
column3: ” said Tykha. “And she was right”
column4: added Lee. “Our house was later in the heart of the heavy fighting.”

column1: It was a two-mile walk to the bridge where Ukrainian soldiers were helping people across.
Two of the dogs – Strong and Baileys
column2: mongrel border collies with broken spines – were in wheelchairs
column3: while Life
column4: a four-year-old with amputated legs
column5: had refused to be strapped in and was dragging herself on her stumps. “I did think at one point that we would not make it
column6: ” said Lee
column7: “but Snizhana called and said there would be a minibus on the other side to help”.

column1: It took three hours to get to the bridge. One dog
column2: Pandora
column3: a one-and-a-half-year-old mongrel Belgian shepherd
column4: was so terrified that he bit off part of his tongue
column5: while four of the others
column6: including the couple’s own dog
column7: Zeus
column8: a beagle
column9: became so worked up by the sounds of war they chewed through their leads and ran away.

column1: Arriving exhausted at the Ukrainian checkpoint by the bridge
column2: the couple and their animals drew the attention of press photographers
column3: who crowded around them.

column1: “That was when that photo was taken – I just wanted them to let us get through to the bridge
column2: ” said Tykha. “I was worried because there were burned out cars and lots of smashed glass and metal
column3: and I didn’t want the animals to be cut up.”

column1: A group of Ukrainian soldiers came to their aid
column2: ushering the photographers away. “There were explosions and shooting but after two weeks of Russian occupation
column3: we were used to it
column4: ” Lee said.

column1: The couple found the minivan and it took them to a south-western district of Kyiv
column2: where a sauna on the side of a house had been made available to them and their animals to stay in.

column1: It was the next day that the couple discovered that their adventures were being talked about across Ukraine
column2: and that Tykha was presumed dead.

column1: They were determined to go back to find Zeus and the other dogs who had fled in fear.
“We were in the sauna for five days
column2: but every one of those days Anastasiya went to the Ukrainian military checkpoint and demanded that she be allowed through to get the escaped dogs
column3: ” said Lee. Every day the commander at the checkpoint refused
column4: and every day she came back. He was finally browbeaten into submission.

column1: After crossing the bridge
column2: again under fire
column3: they faced a three-mile walk to a an abandoned animal shelter
column4: where they knew there were hungry dogs who needed help.

column1: “It was a hard walk because we had all this heavy food
column2: ” said Lee. They returned to their own home
column3: where they found Zeus
column4: and picked up some neighbours’ dogs
column5: including a German shepherd
column6: bringing their party of animals for the return to five.

column1: They would make two further trips
column2: and all the dogs that fled on the first escape were accounted for.

column1: Lee said their final trip back to Irpin
column2: on 29 March
column3: was the scariest. “The council had said that the Russians had gone the previous day and that it was safe – but it wasn’t
column4: ” Lee said. “The bombs were landing just 2 metres from us. We hid between the minivan and a fence
column5: but it was close.”

column1: Now they are back in Irpin in a new
column2: rented house. Because so many former residents have left
column3: their collection of sheltered animals has grown to 30 dogs and 10 cats. They are
column4: the couple say
column5: just happy to be living the life they love."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/23/first-edition-ukraine-war-russia-end;2022-05-23;Monday briefing: What would a ‘win’ look like for both sides in Ukraine?;"In today’s newsletter: nearly 100 days into the conflict
column2: Nimo Omer investigates what ‘victory’ would actually mean for Russia and Ukraine

column1: Good morning. When the war in Ukraine first began
column2: the fall of Kyiv
column3: and the Ukrainian state more broadly
column4: seemed highly likely. Almost three months on
column5: the pendulum has swung in the opposite direction. Russia has suffered a series of significant military setbacks that make any victory for them look a much more distant and difficult prospect – but a swift win for Ukraine doesn’t look likely either.

column1: As the war begins to enter a protracted phase
column2: and with decisive developments on the ground becoming rarer and harder to read
column3: I spoke to some experts about how the war in Ukraine might develop. First
column4: though
column5: the headlines – and a programming note: from today
column6: we’ll be adding the Guardian’s crosswords to the First Edition mix. You’ll find links to them at the bottom of the email.

column1: Ukraine | Ukraine’s primary negotiator in peace talks
column2: Mykhailo Podolyak
column3: has said that there will not be a ceasefire deal with Russia if it involves ceding any territory to Russia.

column1: Health | More monkeypox cases are being detected in the UK on a daily basis
column2: says a senior doctor. So far there have been 20 confirmed cases of the disease.

column1: Cost of living |The chief executive of E.ON
column2: Michael Lewis
column3: has said that consumers in the UK should expect high fuel bills for at least another year and a half
column4: with Lewis warning that costs could reach £3
column5: 000 a year after the price cap lifts in the autumn.

column1: Ireland | Seven centuries’ worth of Irish archives
column2: which were destroyed during the civil war in 1922
column3: have been meticulously recreated by academics. At the end of June
column4: there will be an immersive 3D reconstruction of the destroyed library and an extensive digital archive which will be open to the public.

column1: Australia | Labor leader
column2: Anthony Albanese
column3: has been sworn in as the country’s 31st prime minister in Canberra.

column1: Since the start of the war in Ukraine
column2: the discussion on how and when the conflict would end has been at the top of the agenda. Here are four scenarios for an end to the violence:

column1: Ukraine wins

A Ukrainian victory means different things to different people. To some it is pushing Russia back to the territories it controlled before the start of the invasion; for others it’s about pushing it back to the pre-2014 borders
column2: before Russia annexed Crimea.

column1: Orysia Lutsevych
column2: head of the Ukraine Forum and the Russia and Eurasia programme at Chatham House
column3: told me that a real victory for Ukraine is one where the country is in a more secure position than it was before the war began. This is the second Russian-Ukrainian war in the last decade
column4: she notes
column5: and a meaningful victory should stop a third war from ever happening. Practically speaking
column6: in the short term
column7: Orysia says
column8: “Ukraine will have to push Russia out of as much territory as possible
column9: including the occupation in the south and in Donbas”.

column1: But there is a larger issue. “A Ukrainian victory means that Putin’s doctrine and Russian revanchism is contained [in Russia] and
column2: eventually
column3: put an end to completely
column4: ” Orysia says. Anything else is an “interim solution” (which isn’t to be discounted if it could stop the immediate effects of war). But to claim any real long term resolution
column5: she adds
column6: the underlying problems that caused the war must be addressed and dealt with. And
column7: perhaps most importantly
column8: Orysia argues
column9: the mistakes of 2015 cannot be repeated: “Ukraine was pushed into concessions and a ceasefire agreement that
column10: in the end
column11: only gave Putin an upper hand to prepare for a bigger war.”

column1: Russia wins
A Russian victory is more difficult to imagine for a number of reasons. I spoke to senior international affairs correspondent Emma Graham-Harrison
column2: who has been covering the war on the ground
column3: about what it might look like. “First of all
column4: it’s important to differentiate between whether the whole world is saying Russia won or if Putin decides to declare victory himself – because those are potentially two quite different things
column5: ” she says. Another reason why it’s so difficult to envision what victory for Russia might look like is that the goalposts have moved so dramatically since the start of the war. “Putin’s objectives were pretty clear: to take Kyiv and install a puppet government
column6: ” Emma says. “But now that seems militarily impossible.”

column1: Another road to victory is to simply run down the clock
column2: with Russia working under the assumption that
column3: even if the west keeps supplying Ukraine with arms
column4: Kyiv’s army might run out of military personnel. Or
column5: as time wears on
column6: the war may just fall down the agenda in western countries
column7: and resources and capital may slowly stop flowing in. This could lead to a situation where Ukraine capitulates
column8: but this would take years. A victory in this scenario would look like mass loss of life
column9: much of Ukraine levelled
column10: and economic devastation for both countries.

column1: A negotiated settlement
One way the war could end
column2: is the way that many wars in history have ended – some kind of peace deal. Dr Sam Greene
column3: director of the Russia Institute at King’s College London
column4: sees such a settlement as difficult to achieve. Russia’s initial demands from Ukraine were unworkable
column5: he argues: “Demilitarisation is not likely to happen and ‘de-nazification’
column6: whatever that means in the Ukrainian context
column7: is a mythological problem
column8: so it doesn’t really have anything other than a mythological solution.” These things cannot be negotiated
column9: partly because they’re non-negotiables from the Ukrainian perspective
column10: but also because some of the problems are entirely within the heads of the Russian government
column11: Greene says.

column1: The other sticking point is that Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy is an elected representative of the Ukrainian people – any settlement has to be mandated by them too. “They would not support a negotiated solution that would cede control of Ukrainian territory on a permanent basis
column2: ” Greene adds.

column1: So a negotiated settlement would have to mean that Russia would move away from some of its stated aims and Ukraine would have to move to some kind of neutrality status (this means that

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/22/devils-advocate-russian-soldiers-ukrainian-lawyer-viktor-ovsyannikov-defends-role-on-eve-of-verdict;2022-05-22;Devil’s advocate? Russian soldier’s Ukrainian lawyer defends role on eve of verdict;"Viktor Ovsyannikov speaks out on his defence of a 21-year-old tank commander who shot and killed an unarmed civilian
Defending a Russian soldier accused of a war crime in Ukraine is no easy task
column2: which is why some people have described Viktor Ovsyannikov as “the devil’s advocate”.

column1: But the 43-year-old Ukrainian is unrepentant. “First of all
column2: I am defending a person
column3: not a crime
column4: ” Ovsyannikov said on Sunday on the eve of the verdict in the trial of the 21-year-old tank commander Vadim Shishimarin
column5: who has already pleaded guilty to killing an unarmed civilian in late February. “I’m trying to prove that my defendant’s actions were misqualified. It’s up to judges to decide. I just do my job.”

column1: “My family
column2: friends and colleagues support me
column3: ” Ovsyannikov added. “They know someone has to do it. But there are other people who ‘invited’ me to go to Moscow or Donbas [the area in eastern Ukraine claimed by Russia-backed separatists].”

column1: Prosecutors were astonished on Friday when Ovsyannikov asked judges in the courtroom in Kyiv to acquit Shishimarin despite his guilty plea
column2: on the grounds that he had executed an order. The Ukrainian prosecutor Andriy Syniuk said the instruction to open fire could not be considered a military order and therefore did not protect Shishimarin from responsibility.

column1: Ukraine has made seeking justice for atrocities committed by Russian troops a priority and national prosecutors are risking their lives to collect evidence of war crimes even in areas still threatened by enemy forces or laced with mines.
Shishimarin comes from Ust Illyinsk
column2: in the south-east Irkutsk region of Russia
column3: and was a commander of the Kantemirovskaya tank division on 28 February
column4: the day that 62-year-old Oleksandr Shelipov died in Chupakhivka village.

column1: Prosecutors say a group of Russian soldiers shot at a civilian vehicle after their convoy came under attack from Ukrainian forces
column2: then stole the car and drove it away. They later came across the unarmed victim
column3: who was talking on his phone a few dozen metres from his home. One of the men in the car told Shishimarin “to kill a civilian so he would not report them to Ukrainian defenders”
column4: according to prosecutors. He opened fire out of the car window and shot down Shelipov.

column1: This is not Ovsyannikov’s first controversial trial. In 2014 he defended the Russia-backed former president Viktor Yanukovych
column2: who was eventually found guilty of high treason and sentenced in absentia to 13 years in prison over attempts to quash a pro-western uprising.

column1: Ovsyannikov argues that ever since he accepted the task of defending Shishimarin
column2: people have asked him the same question: “How can you defend a war criminal?”

column1: “And I am so tired of explaining that
column2: in Ukraine
column3: only a court of law can recognise one as a criminal. And
column4: as far as I know
column5: there is no verdict for my defendant at the moment.”

column1: The trial is unprecedented in Ukraine
column2: where authorities are moving fast and trying to carry out justice while conflict is ongoing. Ukraine’s prosecutor general
column3: Iryna Venediktova
column4: has said she is preparing more than 40 cases for war crimes trials. Monday’s verdict is being seen as a public test of the independence of Ukraine’s judicial system.

column1: “Of course
column2: it is quite an important test and there is even stronger pressure from society on the judges to find him guilty
column3: ” said Ovsyannikov.

column1: “My first impression of Shishimarin was of an ordinary person
column2: just like you or me
column3: ” he said. “My second impression
column4: when I started to work with him
column5: is that he began to understand what had done. The only thing he desires now is to go back home. I am under this impression that he perceives this as some kind of a dream.”

column1: “Sometimes
column2: ” he added
column3: “I feel pity for him.”

column1: This article was amended on 23 May 2022 to change the spelling of Vadim Shishimarin to put into Guardian style."

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/may/22/ukrainian-man-loses-life-savings-in-stablecoin-crypto-slump;2022-05-22;Ukrainian man loses life savings in ‘stablecoin’ crypto slump;"Yuri Popovich invested in the supposedly safe cryptocurrency to protect against risks of the invasion
A Ukrainian man who converted almost all his family’s money into the crypto “stablecoin” terra in April in an effort to protect against the risks of invasion or currency collapse has lost almost $10
column3: 000) after its sudden demise.

column1: “It was impossible and unsafe to store funds in the form of banknotes
column2: ” said Yuri Popovich
column3: who lives in Kyiv. Cryptocurrencies advertised as safe and “backed with fiat currency” suggested another option.

column1: Unlike most cryptocurrency purchases
column2: buying a stablecoin isn’t intended to be a risky investment. The tokens
column3: with names such as “terra”
column4: “tether” and “USD coin”
column5: are supposed to maintain a fixed value of one token to one US dollar. “I am not a speculator; I just wanted to save money
column6: ” Popovich said.

column1: But when terra collapsed in early May
column2: as well as sparking a broader meltdown in the cryptocurrency sector
column3: it wiped out the savings of retail investors. “I stopped sleeping normally
column4: lost 4kg; I often have headaches and anxiety
column5: ” Popovich said. “My wife still doesn’t know about this loss. I don’t know how to tell her.”

column1: His savings
column2: according to a screenshot seen by the Guardian
column3: are now worth less than $500. “This is a colossal amount for us
column4: and in the current situation it is critically important for life. I fear for my wife’s health
column5: my health and our relationship. I don’t even know how it will end.”

column1: Popovich is one an unknown number of retail investors who lost money in the collapse of terra
column2: which at one point had almost $50bn invested in it and is now worth barely $1bn. As well as those looking for a safe place to keep their funds
column3: others were lured in by the promise of interest rates topping 20% a year
column4: in a currency that was theoretically pegged to the dollar.

column1: But the interest rates
column2: and ultimately the stability of the currency itself
column3: relied on the continued interest of investors. That property led many to accuse terra
column4: and other similar tokens
column5: of effectively being a Ponzi scheme."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/22/syrias-barrel-bomb-experts-in-russia-to-help-with-potential-ukraine-campaign;2022-05-22;Syria’s barrel bomb experts in Russia to help with potential Ukraine campaign;"Over 50 specialists skilled in delivering crude explosive working with Putin’s forces

Technicians linked to the Syrian military’s infamous barrel bombs that have wreaked devastation across much of the country have been deployed to Russia to help potentially prepare for a similar campaign in the Ukraine war
column2: European officials believe.

column1: Intelligence officers say more than 50 specialists
column2: all with vast experience in making and delivering the crude explosive
column3: have been in Russia for several weeks working alongside officials from Vladimir Putin’s military.

column1: Their arrival is understood to be one factor behind US and European warnings that the Russian military may have been preparing for the use of chemical weapons in the conflict
column2: which has entered its fourth month with little sign of slowing.

column1: Barrel bombs – crude explosives packed in to a drum and dropped from a helicopter – were used to devastating effect throughout the Syrian war. The regime was also regularly accused of filling canisters with chlorine and dropping them on opposition held towns and cities
column2: causing hundreds of deaths and sparking widespread alarm.

column1: With no anti-aircraft weapons
column2: the anti-Assad opposition had little to counter the Syrian military’s air supremacy
column3: which was a big factor in the regime clawing back parts of the country after 10 years of war.

column1: The situation is very different in Ukraine
column2: however
column3: where Ukrainian troops armed with lethal ground to air missiles can bring down Russian jets and helicopters
column4: stalling advances and exposing ground forces to withering artillery fire.

column1: “This is probably why we haven’t seen them cross the border
column2: ” said one European official. “We know the capacity is there
column3: but if they use it
column4: they lose; we will know who’s done it
column5: and they will likely be killed anyway.”

column1: The barrel bomb specialists were at the vanguard of the forces the Syrian government sent to Russia to support Putin
column2: whose backing had been instrumental in securing Assad regime’s grip on power.

column1: The officials believe between 800 and 1
column2: 000 Syrian troops have so far volunteered to travel to Russia
column3: where the Kremlin has promised them salaries of between $1
column5: 000 – up to 20 times the amounts they would receive in Syria
column6: where an economic collapse has ravaged the local currency’s value.

column1: The Syrian government has established four main recruiting centres for the Russian deployment
column2: in Damascus
column3: Latakia
column4: Hama and Homs. Recruits are deployed under contract with the Wagner Group
column5: the Russian private military organisation
column6: which has played a leading role in hiring mercenaries to support Russia’s foreign adventures.

column1: Wagner has been prominent in Libya and eastern Syria supporting Russia’s interests. However
column2: it has sometimes had a frayed relationship with the Kremlin. In early 2018
column3: its forces were engaged in a brutal battle with US and Kurdish forces in the Syrian province of Deir Azzour
column4: in which more than 140 mercenaries were killed
column5: mainly by US artillery. European officials say that the Russian government had given a green light for the attack.

column1: “It seems they had gotten too big for their boots
column2: ” an official said. “We know for a fact that the Kremlin cut them loose.”

column1: Ever since though
column2: Wagner has been central to Russia’s actions. Its forces were among the first deployed into Ukraine and are accused of committing atrocities in Bucha
column3: where up to 1
column4: 000 people were massacred over a few days in early April.

column1: A relative of a Syrian army lieutenant who signed up to fight in Ukraine denied his uncle was a mercenary. “They are going there as a regular army unit
column2: ” he said. “He is traveling with a full platoon. Only four of them didn’t want to go. Putin did a lot for us
column3: and we can help him now.”

column1: In late April
column2: the Ukrainian government claimed that up to 25 Libyan or Syrian fighters had been killed in the town of Popasna
column3: though this was denied by both Syrian officials and opposition members.

column1: “I asked my uncle that
column2: ” said the relative who refused to be named. “He said it’s not them
column3: but it might be Libyans. He insists that not one of them has crossed the border.”

column1: Wagner is thought to have deployed up to 500 men as reconnaissance elements in Ukraine. Many have been flown in from hotspots around north and central Africa."
Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/may/22/youtube-ukraine-invasion-russia-video-removals;2022-05-22;YouTube removes more than 9
column2: 000 channels relating to Ukraine war;"Exclusive: Platform takes ‘unprecedented action’ to address content guideline violations since invasion

column1: YouTube has taken down more than 70
column2: 000 videos and 9
column3: 000 channels related to the war in Ukraine for violating content guidelines
column4: including removal of videos that referred to the invasion as a “liberation mission”.

column1: The platform is hugely popular in Russia
column2: where
column3: unlike some of its US peers
column4: it has not been shut down despite hosting content from opposition figures such as Alexei Navalny. YouTube has also been able to operate in Russia despite cracking down on pro-Kremlin content that has broken guidelines including its major violent events policy
column5: which prohibits denying or trivialising the invasion.

column1: Since the conflict began in February
column2: YouTube has taken down channels including that of the pro-Kremlin journalist Vladimir Solovyov. Channels associated with Russia’s Ministries of Defence and Foreign Affairs have also been temporarily suspended from uploading videos in recent months for describing the war as a “liberation mission”.

column1: YouTube’s chief product officer
column2: Neal Mohan
column3: said: “We have a major violent events policy and that applies to things like denial of major violent events: everything from the Holocaust to Sandy Hook. And of course
column4: what’s happening in Ukraine is a major violent event. And so we’ve used that policy to take unprecedented action.”

column1: In an interview with the Guardian
column2: Mohan added that YouTube’s news content on the conflict had received more than 40m views in Ukraine alone.

column1: “The first and probably most paramount responsibility is making sure that people who are looking for information about this event can get accurate
column2: high-quality
column3: credible information on YouTube
column4: ” he said. “The consumption of authoritative channels on our platform has grown significantly
column5: of course in Ukraine
column6: but also in countries surrounding Ukraine
column7: Poland
column8: and also within Russia itself.”

column1: YouTube did not provide a breakdown of the taken-down content and channels but Mohan said much of it represented Kremlin narratives about the invasion. “I don’t have the specific numbers
column2: but you can imagine a lot of it being the narratives that are coming from Russian government
column3: or Russian actors on behalf of the Russian government
column4: ” he said.

column1: YouTube has an estimated 90 million users in Russia
column2: although it no longer allows advertising on the platform in the country. The decision by YouTube’s parent company
column3: Google
column4: has drawn protests from Navalny
column5: who said well-targeted ads helped counteract Kremlin propaganda.

column1: “YouTube remains the largest video-sharing site up and running in Russia itself
column2: ” said Mohan. “So YouTube is a place where Russian citizens can get uncensored information about the war
column3: including from many of the same authoritative channels that we all have access to outside of the country. We remain an important platform for Russian citizens themselves as this crisis continues to evolve.”

column1: Last week
column2: the Russian minister for digital development
column3: Maksut Shadaev
column4: said the country would not block YouTube
column5: despite disputes over content that have resulted in the platform being fined in court for not removing banned videos.

column1: Shadaev indicated that blocking Russia’s most popular social media platform would affect users. “We are not planning to close YouTube
column2: ” the minister said. “Above all
column3: when we restrict something
column4: we should clearly understand that our users won’t suffer.”

column1: YouTube has also placed a worldwide ban on channels associated with Russian state media
column2: including Russia Today and Sputnik. Facebook and Instagram are banned in Russia and access to Twitter has been restricted
column3: in response to the platforms’ own bans on Russian state-owned media."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/22/ukrainian-man-drives-3700km-to-be-reunited-with-parents-and-fiancee-who-live-just-10km-away;2022-05-22;Ukrainian man drives 3
column2: 700km to be reunited with parents and fiancee – who live just 10km away;"Only a 10-minute drive apart but cut off by war
column3: Serhi Belyaev took a perilous road trip to be with his loved ones again

column1: It is a 10-minute drive from Serhi Belyaev’s house in the village of Tsyrkuny to his fiancee’s home in Kharkiv
column2: Ukraine’s second city. A quick spin west on Soborna Street
column3: over the E40 motorway on to the Lesia Serduika highway
column4: and you are there. That was
column5: until the war came.

column1: It took just hours for Russian forces to sweep into Belyaev’s village on 24 February
column2: as they advanced on Kharkiv
column3: the closest major Ukrainian city to the Russian border.

column1: Lives across Ukraine were changed that morning. For Belyaev
column2: the frontline of the largest conflict in Europe since the second world war now lay between him and both his girlfriend
column3: Nataliy Drozd
column5: and his parents.

column1: No longer the familiar road into town
column2: Lesia Serduika was now an impassable no man’s land. Belyaev was cut off
column3: worried for his sick mother
column4: Galina
column6: and determined to be with his terrified girlfriend.

column1: Then Belyaev
column3: a professional poker player
column4: had an idea. A gamble. He mused on it
column5: initially rejected it and then settled on it. He would replace the 10km drive with a 3
column6: 700km odyssey.

column1: “To the Russian border
column2: through Russia to Latvia
column3: on to Lithuania and Poland and then back into western Ukraine to come at Kharkiv from the west
column4: ” he says. “It was a bit crazy
column5: yes.” But it was possible.

column1: What followed was an extraordinary adventure that brought Belyaev to the attention of the Kremlin’s secret police
column2: the FSB
column3: who rightly suspected him of giving away Russian positions to the Ukrainian army. He traversed cities under fire
column4: driving in against the flow of refugees
column5: and there were
column6: he admits
column7: moments of doubt. “But only briefly: I had to get to my fiancee.”

column1: In the first days of the war
column2: Belyaev and his brother Yuri
column4: fled Tsyrkuny
column5: which was in flames
column6: for Strilecha
column7: a village a short way north that was occupied but not under fire.

column1: Belyaev started talking to families who wanted to get to Poland. He decided he would join a convoy of four cars in his black Honda Accord. “The car needed repairs to the brakes and the transmission
column2: ” he recalls. “It made terrible noises
column3: but there was no other option.”

column1: Yuri
column2: who has a heart condition
column3: chose to stay behind to look after their dog. His place in the car was taken by two strangers: Emil
column5: and Emil’s fiancee
column6: Katya
column7: 22. On 4 April at 1pm they set off. It was a jittery start.

column1: “We had been told by Russian soldiers the border
column2: a kilometre away
column3: would be open. But it wasn’t
column4: ” Belyaev recalls. The only viable option was to drive 70km through occupied land to a second border crossing. “That 70km was the hardest
column5: ” says Belyaev. “There were lots of checkpoints and
column6: halfway there
column7: we came to some Russian soldiers who wouldn’t let us through.”

column1: The convoy was turned round. They were directed by the soldiers towards what they would soon discover was a filtration camp in a local administrative building. Their lives were on the line. “We were all interrogated. They were very suspicious of Emil
column2: who was from Luhansk in the east and didn’t have a passport as it had been burned at the start of the war. His phone was also broken because of the humidity in the cellar where he had hidden from the bombardments.”

column1: Emil was undressed to his underwear so they could search for tattoos that might offer evidence of a military affiliation. Then they went through Belyaev’s phone. “I had deleted everything
column2: ” he says. “If I hadn’t
column3: I would be dead. I didn’t sit with my hands in my pockets when the war began. I sent locations of Russian military convoys to friends in the territorial defence.”

column1: But the group were finally handed the documents they needed at 4pm on the first day of the journey. A 5pm Russian curfew was looming. Those breaking it were liable to be shot.
Belyaev put his foot down
column2: unsure whether he was on the right road as there was no data coverage
column3: no road signs and they were on dirt tracks. “We had to cross a bridge at the village of Rubizhne. I saw it being built when I was 10 when my brother took me fishing
column4: ” Belyaev says. Now it was in ruins. “I saw its birth and I saw its death
column5: ” he adds. There was just one lane still standing. “It wouldn’t take much weight
column6: ” Belyaev says. “I was terrified at that point. It was a 20-metre drop to the river below.”

column1: But they made it – and at the next checkpoint
column2: the convoy of cars was waved through. The mood of the group lifted. But disaster struck. One of the drivers had got overexcited. “He was driving a bit faster – and he hit a pot hole hard.” The car’s front wheels were badly damaged and there was no way it could complete the journey. They drove to the closest city
column3: Vovchansk
column4: with a heavy heart. “But again pure luck
column5: ” says Belyaev. “The first person I asked about where a garage might be said he was a mechanic. He repaired the car so quickly that we could get going immediately.”

column1: It was now 7pm and the border was due to close at 8pm. But the mechanic was confident they would get through. “We went but there was no electricity
column2: so it was pitch black
column3: ” Belyaev recalls. “I was the lead car. Then
column4: out of nowhere
column5: right in front of me
column6: was a soldier with a machine gun. We were at the border.”

column1: It took five hours to get across after a thorough questioning. “And then we decided to turn right – I don’t know why because it was the wrong way
column2: ” says Belyaev. The soldiers blinked the lights on their military vehicles. They had their machine guns out and were now suspicious and aggressive.

column1: “We explained that we didn’t know the way.” The soldiers conferred. “But they accepted it and waved us on.”
As the convoy went on its way
column2: Emil joked
column3: “What do we need to do to get shot?” But now
column4: at 3am on the second day
column5: they were in Putin’s Russia. “I sent a text to Nataliy telling her where I was
column6: just saying that it was safer there
column7: ” says Belyaev. “She was actually angry because I had left the dog behind. I didn’t tell her about my plan to come back in. I was worried my communications would be intercepted.”

column1: The convoy drove on
column2: heading to Belgorod
column3: the closest big Russian city. Almost immediately they were waved down again. It was the FSB
column4: the successor to the Soviet KGB. “Every single one of us was interrogated again
column5: ” says Belyaev. “But I knew my phone was clean. They asked me about my job. We must have spent 20 minutes talking about poker.”

column1: They reached Belgorod around 5am
column2: where they slept in their cars outside a supermarket. “But this was enemy territory. We knew we had to sleep less and drive more.” They were up again two hours later. Belyaev played music on his phone. The soundtrack
column3: Belyaev laughs
column4: was Gwen Stefani
column5: Jay-Z and Limp Bizkit.

column1: Their trip then took them through Kursk
column2: Roslavl
column3: Smolensk and Velikiye Luki
column4: where they arrived at 5am on the second day
column5: to snatch some sleep. Exhausted
column6: they finally reached the Ubylinka border crossing into Latvia at 10am the following day
column7: 6 April.

column1: It took 16 hours to get through border control. “But it was such a relief
column2: ” recalls Belyaev. “I felt I was a man with rights again. I called Nataliy and my parents and told her about my real plans. Nataliy said
column3: ‘You have a chance to stay in safety. You should stay there because men between 18 and 60 aren’t allowed to leave Ukraine. We can be together when the war ends’.”

column1: Belyaev had no time to think. It was 2am and they were facing a 1
column2: 000km journey to Poland via Latvia. At midday they stopped at Kaunas in southern Lithuania. “This was the first wifi – in McDonald’s. I called my friends and parents. ‘I am eating McDonald’s. How about you?’
column3: ” he laughs.

column1: The convoy headed off again
column2: this time to Warsaw
column3: arriving at 7pm. His fellow travellers had reached their destination: a large expo hall turned into a refugee centre. Belyaev had to make a decision. He pondered during a seven-day stay in Warsaw. The risks seemed grave. He was also sick with Covid symptoms and getting worse. But he felt he had to go on. “I told Nataliy that I wanted to come back. I said
column4: ‘Wait for me
column5: baby’.”

column1: On 14 April
column2: at 2pm
column3: Belyaev left Warsaw for the Rava-Ruska border
column4: joining a humanitarian convoy. They reached Lviv
column5: Ukraine’s most westerly city
column6: at midnight
column7: loaded up some supplies
column8: and set off. This was wartime Ukraine: every road posed a risk.

column1: “A lot of roads were closed – it added probably 100km to our 550km journey. But it is nothing when you are driving 3
column2: 700km rather than 10km to get home
column3: ” laughs Belyaev.

column1: He reached Kyiv at noon on 15 April and slept at a friend’s – in a bed for the first time in 11 days. On the morning of 18 April
column2: he left Kyiv for Poltava
column3: a city halfway to his destination
column4: where his younger brother lived. “It was the first time I had driven alone
column5: ” says Belyaev. “I found it hard.” In Poltava
column6: he picked up medicines for his parents and he was now en route to the very frontline of the war in Ukraine
column7: where his village remained cut off and the battle of Kharkiv raged. But Belyaev had no doubts. It was perhaps even time for a little surprise.

column1: “I rang my dad and told him a volunteer was near with supplies
column2: so he should come down
column3: ” Belyaev smiles. “And he found me.” The men hugged. With his mum
column4: tears flowed. Then
column5: just 50 metres from Nataliy’s house
column6: he was stopped by police. “They were suspicious of the blankets and the state of my car. They asked if I had been sleeping in it
column7: and why. It was only my passport stamps that persuaded them of my story.”

column1: Finally he was
column2: however
column3: back with the woman he loved. Had Belyaev made the right decision to head back? Nataliy smiles: “Home is home.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/may/22/britain-slashes-humanitarian-aid-by-51-despite-global-food-crisis;2022-05-22;Britain slashes humanitarian aid by 51% despite global food crisis;"Campaigners say ministers must change course as millions face famine in Africa and the Ukraine war threatens to disrupt global food supplies
Ministers have been accused of choosing the “worst moment in history” to slash the foreign aid budget
column2: as provisional figures showed that UK overseas humanitarian funding was cut by more than half last year.

column1: MPs and charity campaigners say the aid budget urgently needs to be increased to cope with the Ukraine conflict and the risk of famine in Africa. Up to 23 million people face acute hunger in Ethiopia
column2: Kenya and Somalia due to drought.

column1: The UN has warned the Ukraine crisis risks tipping 1.7 billion people – one-fifth of the global population – into poverty
column2: destitution and hunger. The government said last week it now intends to boost humanitarian aid by giving less money to international organisations and focusing on direct aid from the UK.

column1: Western officials reportedly fear that Vladimir Putin is “weaponising” global food supplies. Russia and Ukraine account for nearly a third of the world’s wheat and barley exports.
Sarah Champion MP
column2: Labour chair of the Commons international development committee
column3: said: “It would be hard to consider a worse moment in history for the government to be cutting its foreign aid budget.

column1: “We are the only member of the rich country G7 grouping to be doing so. It is having a damaging effect on our international standing – and the survival chances of some of the poorest people on the planet.”
Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a controversial reduction of aid spending from 0.7% to 0.5% of gross national income in November 2020.
UK direct humanitarian aid to foreign countries was £744m last year
column2: compared with £1.53bn in 2020
column3: a cut of 51%
column4: according to the most recent provisional UK aid figures. UK official development assistance was nearly £11.5bn last year
column5: compared with £14.48bn in 2020
column6: a fall of 21%.

column1: Separate figures published in the Foreign
column2: Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) annual report last year revealed direct UK aid and planned aid to Ethiopia fell from £241m in 2020/21 to £108m in 2021/22
column3: a cut of 55%; aid to Kenya fell from £67m to £41m
column4: a cut of 39%; and aid to Somalia fell from £121m to £71m
column5: a cut of 41%.

column1: One of the largest global humanitarian crises is in Yemen
column2: devastated by eight years of civil war. About 24 million people need help
column3: including nearly 13 million children. UK aid to Yemen fell from £221m 2020/21 to £82m in 2021/22
column4: a cut of 63%.

column1: Sam Nadel
column2: Oxfam’s head of government relations
column3: said: “The government is cutting aid at a time we have war in Ukraine
column4: the Covid pandemic and millions of people in Africa on the brink of starvation. It’s the most horrific timing. It’s also shortsighted because aid helps tackle global challenges
column5: which helps the UK in the long term.”

column1: Ministers have announced £220m in humanitarian and development aid for Ukraine
column2: putting more pressure on the reduced UK aid budget.

column1: Kate Munro
column2: head of advocacy at charity Action Against Hunger
column3: said aid funding needed to return to 0.7% of GNI and ministers should urgently announce a new aid package for the millions of people facing starvation in east Africa. “It saves money to act early in a crisis
column4: ” she said.

column1: The charity will attend an event in parliament this week to campaign for more aid for east Africa. It is calling for a funding commitment from the government of £750m
column2: similar to the amount provided in 2017 when east Africa was also hit by drought and widespread famine was averted.

column1: Liz Truss
column2: the foreign secretary
column3: last week announced a new international development strategy
column4: with aid targeted to help deliver the UK’s foreign policy objectives. More money will be spent on direct aid from the UK
column5: rather than internationally.

column1: Champion last week described the new strategy as a “rehash of existing slogans’

column1: The FCDO said: “Stepping up our life-saving humanitarian work to prevent the worst forms of human suffering around the world is one of the top priorities the foreign secretary laid out in the UK’s international development strategy this week.
“We will prioritise humanitarian funding levels at £3bn over the next three years
column2: to remain a global leader in crisis response
column3: including in Africa.”"

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/22/if-my-65m-kent-mansion-is-sold-now-it-could-help-fund-putins-war;2022-05-22;‘If my £6.5m Kent mansion is sold now it could help fund Putin’s war’;"Russian state-linked bank pursuing financier for millions over alleged fraud is not on UK sanctions list

It is one of Britain’s most controversial property sales. A former multimillionaire banker warns that proceeds from the disposal of his £6.5m Kent country estate risk being sent to help fund Vladimir Putin’s war machine.
Ilya Yurov
column3: who is originally from Moscow
column4: is being pursued with two former colleagues for $900m (£720m) from the National Bank Trust in Russia after losing a high court case.

column1: National Bank Trust is tasked with recovering billions of pounds from around the world to send back to Russia
column2: but to date has escaped the UK sanctions list. As revealed by the Observer last week
column3: it is majority owned by the Central Bank of the Russian Federation and was once promoted by the actor Bruce Willis.

column1: Yurov bought Oxney Court in Kent
column2: a 17th-century gothic-style mansion with crenellated walls and towers
column3: in 2012. The property was destroyed by a blaze during the first world war when it was commandeered as an operation headquarters and place of recuperation for soldiers returning from the front. It was meticulously rebuilt in 1998. The 14-hectare (35-acre) estate
column4: with tennis court and pool
column5: has been put on the market for £6.5m to help pay his debt.

column1: Speaking at the Grade II-listed building last week
column2: he accepted that the property needed to be sold and money recovered
column3: but said National Bank Trust should urgently be put on the sanctions list.

column1: He said: “I can’t accept that this money can go back to the Russian state. I feel sick that it could be used to support horrible atrocities. The west can’t turn a blind eye to this. It’s illogical that the bank is not sanctioned.”
Yurov
column2: a father of six
column3: said the funds returned to the Russian state could be used to support the war. He said state-controlled banks were providing loans and finance for defence contractors in the face of global sanctions.

column1: Ministers announced sanctions targeting the central bank in February
column2: but face questions over concerns that National Bank Trust may be a conduit for funds going to Putin. The Foreign Office declined to comment last week.

column1: The Observer understands lawyers in the case have said that National Bank Trust is not a sanctioned entity
column2: so funds can be transferred.

column1: Executives at National Bank Trust have said they are tasked with recovering £6bn of global assets by 2023. This includes debts such as those owed by Yurov and colleagues
column2: Nikolay Fetisov
column3: a former president of the bank
column4: and Sergey Belyaev.

column1: National Trust Bank alleges the three former shareholders fraudulently used offshore companies to conceal bad debts and extract millions of dollars. The bank had a state bailout after it collapsed in 2014.
Yurov and Fetisov said they properly used offshore companies to manage bad debts. Belyaev said he had no knowledge of the scheme.

The high court ruled in January 2020 that the three men owed the bank compensation. The judge ruled that the three former owners had evaded banking standards. He found Yurov to be a “dishonest and untruthful witness”. Yurov said he considered the judgment unfair
column2: but has exhausted all avenues of appeal. He was bankrupted by the case.

column1: Yurov’s family estate is in the name of his wife
column2: Nataliya
column3: but the court ruled that he owned half of the property. The trustees acting for Yurov’s creditors will be entitled to half of the estate when it is sold.

column1: The main creditor is National Bank Trust
column2: but trustees have said no transactions will occur with sanctioned entities
column3: or their subsidiaries
column4: without permission of the courts.

column1: Russia tried to extradite Yurov in 2018
column2: but the request was refused on the grounds that he would not get a fair trial. He was sentenced in absentia to eight years in prison for organising theft of funds from a credit institution. He denies the charge."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/22/ukrainian-women-fear-childcare-issues-will-affect-their-ability-to-work-in-uk;2022-05-22;Ukrainian women fear childcare issues will affect their ability to work in UK;"Mothers shocked by the cost as charities urge government to step in

Childcare issues and inflexible working hours are preventing Ukrainian women from getting jobs as they attempt to rebuild their lives in Britain. Ukrainian refugees told the Observer they were shocked to discover the cost and inaccessibility of childcare and after-school provision and that they were struggling to navigate the system.
For many
column2: the problem is exacerbated by language issues – meaning they cannot access better-paid jobs
column3: even if they are highly qualified.

column1: With childcare unaffordable for many
column2: Anya Abdulakh
column3: a trustee of the charity Families4Peace
column4: which is helping newly arrived Ukrainians in north London
column5: said mothers are struggling to find work that fits around school hours. Abdulakh is trying to get childcare providers to offer free or reduced-cost places for Ukrainian children. In the long term
column6: she said
column7: government help is needed for the “thousands” of women she thinks will be affected.

column1: Under the Homes for Ukraine scheme
column2: refugees are theoretically guaranteed free accommodation for six months
column3: but many are worried about not having a job and enough money saved up for when they have to rent for themselves.

column1: “So
column2: being able to be employed is security that you can offer to your child going forward when you have to pay for the rent
column3: ” said Abdulakh. If they can’t
column4: she added
column5: some may be forced to go back to Ukraine
column6: even if the war is continuing.

column1: When she tried to help a beautician get free childcare for her two-year-old son so that she could work
column2: she was told there was nothing until September. Another Ukrainian mother
column3: Victoria Shcherbyna
column5: has been living in temporary accommodation for seven weeks in a village in Ukraine near the Hungarian border with her seven-year-old daughter

column7: and a job in sales
column8: set up in London

column2: like in Ukraine before the war. But after speaking to UK-based Ukrainian mothers
column3: she realised that it would be unaffordable and finish too early in the day. “I have received many messages back like ‘This is the reality
column4: you get used to it’
column5: ” she said. She is also concerned about after-school care. While she feels fearful and powerless

column7: who she said “has seen enough”
column8: by presenting their move as an adventure.

column1: “There is not much I can do. I just need to adapt somehow and I have only one thought in my mind: that there is nothing that is impossible for me
column2: that I have to cope with everything and find solutions because otherwise it won’t work.”

column1: Through tears
column2: she said at first she didn’t want to leave her husband and Ukraine
column3: but that she must
column4: for her children’s future. Her son Danylo
column6: is at Manchester University

column9: [for] the whole day

column2: ” she said. But she is determined to work out their new life in London. “I’m trying to adapt to a new life and I understand I have to start from scratch. I’m ready because I’m a strong person and
column3: if I believe in myself

column1: Meanwhile

column3: while most men are required to stay in the country – highlight the existing systemic issues in childcare provision for all families across the UK. They also accused the government of leaning too heavily on the voluntary sector to help newly arrived Ukrainians

column3: said that the difficulties faced by Ukrainians
column4: “to a huge extent have highlighted some of the systemic issues there are for childcare and children’s activities – not only for smaller children but also for older children and teenagers”.

A government spokesperson said: “All children and young people living in the UK have a right to access education and childcare

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/bravo-reopened-kyiv-opera-drowns-out-russian-artillery;2022-05-21;Bravo! Music at reopened Kyiv opera replaces noise of Russian artillery;Three months after the invasion
column2: the capital’s grand old venue stages an emotional comeback

column1: The lights dimmed
column2: a hush came over the auditorium and the orchestra struck up the first notes of the overture. This ritual has taken place thousands of times at Kyiv’s grand opera house over the past century
column3: but the performance on Saturday afternoon was something out of the ordinary.

column1: In a city that over the past three months became used to wailing air-raid sirens and the thuds of artillery from the suburbs
column2: the audience was instead treated to the frothy melodies of Rossini’s The Barber of Seville.

column1: It marked the first performance since the missiles and shells of Vladimir Putin’s invasion rudely interrupted the opera season – and everything else in Ukraine – in the early hours of 24 February.
Now
column2: less than three months later and with fierce battles still raging in the eastern part of the country
column3: the opera is back
column4: although with some changes. Performances will only take place on weekend afternoons
column5: a maximum of 300 tickets are sold
column6: and the audience has to be ready to move quickly to the basement cloakrooms if air-raid sirens sound during a performance.

column1: Saturday’s audience was a mix of couples enjoying their first opportunity for weeks to wear their most elegant outfits
column2: and soldiers in military fatigues taking a break from their army service for some high culture.

column1: Only the stalls were full
column2: with the four tiers of gilded balconies off-limits to ensure an evacuation could take place more quickly if needed.

column1: “I can’t say opera is my usual entertainment
column2: but it is an incredible feeling to hear this music and to be in a different world for a little while
column3: before coming back to our reality
column4: ” said Volodymyr
column5: a soldier who only wanted to give his first name.

column1: Many of the opera troupe are still abroad
column2: and some in the orchestra are fighting on the frontline or serving in the territorial defence forces.

column1: Oleksii Potiomkin
column2: the principal dancer of the ballet
column3: has joined up and is serving in the army
column4: posting daily updates on Instagram.

column3: struggled to hold back tears as she spoke of her emotions before going on stage.

column1: “I had the feeling this morning that I was coming to sing a premiere

column3: which I know so well
column4: for the first time
column5: ” she said.

column1: Fomichova mostly stayed in Kyiv during the invasion but sent her son to safety in Germany. She saw him recently when she travelled there to take part in a charity gala to help Ukraine
column2: and both the family reunion and the concert were emotional
column3: she said.

column1: “When you take a Ukrainian flag on to the stage for the curtain call and you are met with a 10-minute standing ovation
column2: I don’t have words to describe the feeling
column3: ” she said.

column1: Over the past three months
column2: the soloists have kept in touch in a chat group on Viber
column3: swapping stories about how the war was going for them

column3: ” she said. On Sunday
column4: Nykolaishyn will sing the lead role in the opera  Natalka Poltavka by the Ukrainian composer Mykola Lysenko.

column1: “We wanted to open with symbolic performances: first a European classic and then a Ukrainian classic

column1: Kyiv’s opera house has seen a lot over the years
column2: on and off the stage. Opened in 1901 after a fire destroyed the previous building
column3: a decade later it was the scene of a dramatic assassination.

column1: Prime minister Pyotr Stolypin
column2: attending a Rimsky-Korsakov opera with Tsar Nicholas II
column3: was shot dead during the interval while standing in the front row of the stalls.

column1: Now
column2: with the Russian invasion

column1: “But right now

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/zelenskiy-signals-readiness-for-new-talks-if-mariupol-troops-are-not-harmed;2022-05-21;Zelenskiy signals readiness for new talks if Mariupol troops are not harmed;"Ukrainian leader tells TV station ‘there are things that can only be reached at the negotiating table’

Ukraine has suggested that it is willing to resume talks with Russia as Moscow claimed to have taken full control of the besieged city of Mariupol – its biggest prize since it invaded Ukraine in February.
Speaking to a television channel on Saturday
column2: Ukraine’s president
column3: Volodymyr Zelenskiy
column4: said that “discussions between Ukraine and Russia will undoubtedly take place”.

column1: “Under what format I don’t know – with intermediaries
column2: without them
column3: in a broader group
column4: at the presidential level
column5: ” he added. “But the war will be bloody
column6: there will be fighting and [it] will only definitively end through diplomacy.

column1: “There are things that can only be reached at the negotiating table. We want everything to return [to as it was before] but Russia does not want that.”
The Kremlin’s spokesperson
column2: Dmitry Peskov
column3: responded by blaming Ukraine for stopping the talks. The last discussions between the two sides took place on 22 April
column4: according to Russian news agencies.

column1: During the interview
column2: held with a Ukrainian broadcaster
column3: Zelenskiy spoke of creating a document enshrining security guarantees for his country. Although bilateral discussions would be held with Russia
column4: the document would be signed by “friends and partners of Ukraine
column5: without Moscow”
column6: he added.

column1: However
column2: he warned that the precondition for resuming negotiations was that Moscow did not kill Ukrainian troops who had been defending the Azovstal steelworks in Mariupol. “The most important thing for me is to save the maximum number of people and soldiers
column3: ” he said.

column1: Last week
column2: Russia announced it had taken full control of Mariupol
column3: the first major city to fall. The last group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the Azovstal steelworks surrendered on Friday
column4: bringing to an end a months-long siege of the defenders’ last stronghold.

column1: “Underground structures of Azovstal where militants were hiding are now under full control of Russian armed forces
column2: ” Russia’s defence ministry said in a statement
column3: adding that 2
column4: 439 Ukrainian fighters had surrendered.

column2: Zelenskiy said the defenders had been told by commanders that they should leave. In a live video posted on the messaging service Telegram
column3: Denys Prokopenko
column4: commander of the Azov Regiment
column5: which has led the defence of the factory
column6: said only the dead remained.

column1: “The higher military command has given the order to save the lives of the soldiers of our garrison and to stop defending the city
column2: ” he said. “I now hope that soon the families and all of Ukraine will be able to bury their fighters with honours.”

column1: Ukraine hopes to exchange the surrendering Azovstal soldiers for Russian prisoners. But in Donetsk
column2: pro-Kremlin authorities are threatening to put some of them on trial.

column1: The fall of Mariupol – the largest trading port on the Sea of Azov
column2: from which Ukraine exports grain
column3: iron
column4: steel and heavy machinery – is a breakthrough for Russia. Taking control of the city means gaining a land corridor from the Donbas to Crimea.

column1: Fierce fighting continued in the eastern Donbas
column2: where Zelenskiy said Russian troops had “completely ruined” the cities of Rubizhne and Volnovakha
column3: “just as they did Mariupol”
column4: adding that the Russians were “trying to do the same with Severodonetsk and many other cities”.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: on Saturday the Russian energy company Gazprom halted gas exports to neighbouring Finland

column4: after Helsinki angered Moscow by applying for Nato membership last week.

The majority of gas used in Finland comes from Russia

column2: Sauli Niinistö
column3: said he and the Turkish president
column4: Recep Tayyip Erdoğan

column6: after Erdoğan openly questioned whether Finland and Sweden
column7: which has also applied
column8: should be permitted to join."

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/food/2022/may/21/olia-hercules-when-russia-invaded-ukraine-i-couldnt-cook-for-the-first-month#comments;2022-05-21;Olia Hercules: ‘When Russia invaded Ukraine

column1: When Russia invaded Ukraine
column2: I couldn’t eat. And I definitely couldn’t cook for the first month and a half. It was the feeling of guilt. I just felt
column3: “How can I even cook anything when there’s such horror happening everywhere else in Ukraine?” Then

column5: this woman I’d never met before came up to me and said

column1: When I was writing Mamushka

column3: “Oh

column5: but hopefully I’ve been able to break some of them. Even when I spoke of Ukraine back then

column10: everything.

column1: I only really realised the scope of my mum and my dad’s skills after I trained to be a chef. Watching Mum make filo pastry

column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/may/21/canada-announces-sanctions-on-alexander-lebedev-russia-ukraine-report;2022-05-21;UK under pressure over Alexander Lebedev sanctions after Canada move;"Labour says the case for the British government to follow Ottawa’s lead is ‘extremely strong’
The British government is under pressure to impose sanctions on Alexander Lebedev after Canada targeted the former KGB agent in a fresh wave of restrictions against Vladimir Putin’s regime.
The billionaire Russian businessman
column2: who little more than a decade ago bought the UK’s Evening Standard and Independent newspapers
column3: was named in Ottawa’s latest sanctions announced on Friday.

column1: James Emmanuel Wanki
column2: a spokesperson for Global Affairs Canada
column3: confirmed to the Guardian on Saturday that Alexander Yevgenievich Lebedev
column4: born in 1959
column5: is on Canada’s sanctions list against Russia.

column1: The restrictions also included a ban on the import of Russian vodka
column2: diamonds and caviar
column3: according to the Globe and Mail.

column1: A UK government spokesperson said: “This government has been resolute in standing up to Russian aggression. We keep all sanctions under review and they are determined after careful consideration.”
But Labour accused the government of dragging its feet in imposing sanctions on those with links to the Russian president.
The party’s deputy leader
column2: Angela Rayner
column3: said: “Labour has been clear that anyone with links to the KGB must face sanctions. The Conservatives have been so slow and too soft in issuing sanctions to those with links to Putin.

column1: “There is now an extremely strong case for Alexander Lebedev to face sanctions from the UK and the government must now urgently look at the evidence.”
She accused Boris Johnson of having “form when it comes to protecting the Lebedevs”.
“He failed to release critical information relating to the appointment of Alexander Lebedev’s son to the House of Lords
column2: despite concerns from the security services. This is another case of the prime minister bending the rules to protect his friends
column3: ” she said.

column1: Lebedev’s links to Johnson are well documented.
He is also a minority shareholder in the Russian opposition newspaper Novaya Gazeta. His son Evgeny
column2: who owns the Evening Standard and is a minority shareholder in The Independent
column3: was appointed to the House of Lords in 2020 despite concerns raised by MI5.

column1: The government was accused of a cover-up last week after it declined a Commons instruction to release information about the decision to make him a peer
column2: claiming it would undermine the confidentiality of those nominated and could degenerate into political point-scoring.

column1: He published a statement in the Standard in February in which he pleaded with Putin to end the war.
The Canadian government said the ban on trade in luxury goods and the addition of 14 oligarchs and Putin associates was aligned with similar measures imposed by allies such as the US and the EU
column2: and would “help to mitigate the potential for Russian oligarchs to circumvent restrictions in other luxury goods markets”.

column1: The sanctions package
column2: announced by Canada’s foreign minister
column3: Mélanie Joly
column4: covers goods that were worth $75.7m (£47m) in 2021. It also bans the export of jewellery
column5: art and kitchenware to Russia and restricts the export of “goods that could be used in the production and manufacture of weapons”.

column1: “The Putin regime must
column2: and will
column3: answer for their unjustifiable acts
column4: ” Joly said. “Canada
column5: together with our allies
column6: will be relentless in our efforts to maintain pressure on the Russian regime until it is no longer able to wage war. We are unwavering in our support for Ukraine and its people.”

column1: According to the Globe and Mail
column2: other figures Canada has newly subjected to sanctions include Gleb Frank
column3: a leading Russian fishery company owner; his father
column4: Sergei Frank
column5: the former minister of transport and former chief executive of Russian shipping firm Sovcomflot; and Sergei Frank’s wife
column6: Ksenia Frank
column7: the daughter of Gennady Timchenko
column8: an oligarch and an associate of Putin.

column1: David Davidovich
column2: a close associate of Roman Abramovich
column3: who has been forced to sell Chelsea football club after being placed under sanctions in the UK
column4: was also sanctioned.

column1: The fresh wave of sanctions came as talks between G7 countries and Ukraine’s prime minister
column2: Denys Shmyhal
