column1: Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/apocalypse-now-the-alarming-effects-of-the-global-food-crisis;2022-05-21;Apocalypse now? The alarming effects of the global food crisis;"The Bank of England governor warned last week of ‘apocalyptic’ food price rises. Yet war in Ukraine
column2: climate change and inflation are already taking their toll all over the world

column1: Apocalypse is an alarming idea
column2: commonly taken to denote catastrophic destruction foreshadowing the end of the world. But in the original Greek
column3: apokálypsis means a revelation or an uncovering. One vernacular definition is “to take the lid off something”.

column1: That latter feat is exactly what Andrew Bailey
column2: governor of the Bank of England
column3: achieved last week
column4: possibly inadvertently
column5: when he suggested Britain was facing “apocalyptic” levels of food price inflation. Tory ministers fumed over what they saw as implied criticism of the government’s masterly economic management.

column1: In fact
column2: Bailey was talking as much about the drastic impact of Ukraine-war-related rises in food costs and food shortages on people in poorer countries. “There’s a major worry for the developing world as well ... Sorry for being apocalyptic for a moment
column3: but that is a major concern
column4: ” he said.

column1: With most political and media attention narrowly focused on the emerging UK “cost of living crisis”
column2: Bailey’s high-profile comments were timely – and revelatory. Months of warnings about a global tidal wave of hunger
column3: rendered more urgent by Ukraine
column4: have been largely ignored
column5: not least by Boris Johnson’s aid-cutting government.

column1: The cost of living is a problem in Britain. For UN agencies and humanitarian relief workers around the world
column2: the bigger worry is the cost of dying.

column1: Sounding the alarm again last week
column2: António Guterres
column3: the UN secretary general
column4: said Ukraine-related shortages could help “tip tens of millions of people over the edge into food insecurity”. The result could be “malnutrition
column5: mass hunger and famine in a crisis that could last for years” – and increase the chances of a global recession.

column1: The World Food Programme estimates about 49 million people face emergency levels of hunger. About 811 million go to bed hungry each night. The number of people on the brink of starvation across Africa’s Sahel region
column2: for example
column3: is at least 10 times higher than in pre-Covid 2019.

column1: The adverse impact of Russia’s invasion on the availability and price of staples such as wheat
column2: maize
column3: barley and sunflower oil – Ukraine and Russia normally produce about 30% of global wheat exports – has been huge.

column1: Ukraine’s wheat production this year is likely to be 35% down
column2: and exporting much of it may be impossible due to Russia’s Black Sea blockade. In March
column3: global commodity prices
column4: recorded by the UN’s Food and Agriculture Organisation
column5: hit an all-time high. They remain at record-breaking levels.

column1: Russia’s war has compounded or accelerated pre-existing food deficits and inflationary trends arising from a host of linked factors: the negative economic impact of the pandemic; resulting supply-chain
column2: employment and transport problems; extreme weather and climate-crisis-related falls in output; spiralling energy costs; and numerous other ongoing conflicts worldwide.

column1: Middle-income countries
column2: such as Egypt and Brazil
column3: are exceptionally poorly placed to cope with increased food insecurity
column4: international risk consultants Verisk Maplecroft said in a report last week. Many governments had exhausted their financial and material reserves fighting Covid and incurred large debts.

column1: Now the cupboard is bare. “Unlike low-income countries
column2: they were rich enough to offer social protection during the pandemic
column3: but now struggle to maintain high social spending that is vital to the living standards of large sections of their populations
column4: ” the report said.

column1: Argentina
column2: Tunisia
column3: Pakistan and the Philippines
column4: highly dependent on food and energy imports
column5: were among many other middle- or lower-middle-income countries facing an elevated risk of civil unrest by the end of 2022
column6: it suggested.

column1: As the food “apocalypse” approaches
column2: the poorest peoples will suffer
column3: as they always do
column4: while the wealthiest may be insulated
column5: up to a point. But it is feared that the pain will rapidly move up the global food chain. With it is likely to come a surge in political turbulence
column6: humanitarian crises
column7: instability and geo-strategic rivalries across a hungry world.

column1: Scarce food
column2: combined with price increases
column3: electricity blackouts and shortages of petrol
column4: cooking gas and medicines
column5: provoked a political crisis in Sri Lanka this spring that serves as a discomfiting template for countries facing similar problems.

column1: Months of protests culminated in the resignation of the prime minister
column2: Mahinda Rajapaksa
column3: but even his scalp did not prevent unrest turning violent. Desperate
column4: Sri Lanka has been seeking a bridging loan from the World Bank to help pay for essential imports. On Thursday
column5: it defaulted on its debt for the first time ever.

column1: Double-digit inflation that left many Pakistanis unable to afford basic foodstuffs was also a major contributory factor in the fall from power earlier this year of the prime minister
column2: Imran Khan. His attempt to cling to office created a crisis of democracy with which Pakistan is still grappling.

column1: Longer-term factors – repressive governance
column2: corruption
column3: incompetence
column4: polarisation – fuelled unrest in both countries. But dire food shortages and inflation were the catalyst that rendered the objectionable intolerable. That’s a prospect now facing insecure and unpopular regimes from Peru
column5: the Philippines and Cuba to Lebanon and Tunisia.

column1: Analysts compare what is happening today in the Middle East with the Arab spring revolts. Egypt
column2: whose government was overthrown in 2011
column3: is the world’s largest wheat importer. About 70 million people rely on state-subsidised bread. Russia and Ukraine accounted for 80% of Egypt’s grain imports last year.

column1: Today’s high prices and supply shortfalls
column2: especially if they worsen
column3: could do for Abdel Fatah al-Sisi’s regime what similar grievances did for his deposed presidential predecessor
column4: Hosni Mubarak.

column1: Another country to watch closely is Iran. Violent protests erupted last week in Khuzestan after the government raised the price of bread
column2: cooking oil and dairy products. Iranians’ situation is made worse by tough US sanctions and a tyrannical
column3: corrupt clerical regime. If living standards continue to fall
column4: there could be an explosion similar to the thwarted nationwide uprising of 2017-18.

column1: In many parts of the world
column2: especially Africa
column3: food insecurity is anything but a new phenomenon. Hunger is the norm and the risk of famine is ever-present
column4: often exacerbated by conflict and climate change. That said
column5: the situation
column6: broadly speaking
column7: is deteriorating.

column1: The total number of people facing acute food insecurity and requiring urgent food assistance has nearly doubled since 2016
column2: according to the Global Network Against Food Crises
column3: a joint UN and EU project. And the scale of the challenge is expanding
column4: up by 40 million people
column5: or 20%
column6: last year. The network’s latest report pinpointed countries of particular concern: Ethiopia
column7: South Sudan
column8: southern Madagascar and Yemen
column9: where it said 570
column10: 000 people – up 571% on six years ago – were in the most severe or “catastrophe” phase of food insecurity
column11: threatened by the collapse of livelihoods
column12: starvation and death.

column1: Guterres
column2: the UN chief
column3: warned that Vladimir Putin’s war was seriously affecting efforts to fight hunger in Africa. It was imperative
column4: he said
column5: to “bring back the agriculture production of Ukraine and the food and fertiliser production of Russia and Belarus into world markets”. As Russian state media often note
column6: western sanctions have added to global price volatility.

column1: The UN is calling for Ukraine’s blockaded Black Sea and Azov Sea ports to be reopened so that grain exports can resume
column2: not least to African countries. Especially badly affected is the drought-hit Sahel region. “An absolute crisis is unfolding before our eyes
column3: ” the World Food Programme’s director
column4: David Beasley
column5: said following visits to Benin
column6: Niger and Chad. “We’re running out of money
column7: and these people are running out of hope.”

column1: That’s partly because aid now costs more. The UN and international agencies are obliged to pay inflated prices
column2: up about 30% from pre-Covid norms
column3: to secure vital food aid. And it is partly because food is more expensive relative to income. An average UK household spends 10% of its income on food. In Kenya or Pakistan
column4: it is over 40%.

column1: Conflict is the biggest driver of hunger
column2: whether it is the depredations of Islamist jihadists in Mali
column3: Nigeria and the southern Philippines
column4: the crass rivalries of regional powers in Yemen and Libya
column5: or an unpardonable full-scale war
column6: as in Ukraine.

column1: The UN estimates that 60% of the world’s hungry live in conflict zones. Ukraine has shown again how war
column2: by causing shortages of essentials and rendering normal life insupportable
column3: leads to internal displacement
column4: aid dependency
column5: refugee emergencies and mass migration.

column1: Syria’s civil war provides a cautionary example – although there are many others. A relatively prosperous country has been reduced by over a decade of conflict to something approaching a basket case. About 12.4 million people – 60% of the population – suffer food insecurity
column2: a figure that has more than doubled since 2019.

column1: Ethiopia’s disastrous war of choice in Tigray
column2: which was invaded by government troops in 2019
column3: is another case of famine following folly. The UN estimated in January that 2 million people were suffering from an extreme lack of food
column4: and were dependent on aid in a province that was previously mostly self-sufficient.

column1: In contrast
column2: South Sudan has never been fully able to feed itself since independence in 2011. Ethnically rooted rivalries have often combined with competition for land and food resources with catastrophic effects. Cattle rustling is a key source of violence
column3: while drought is another big factor.

column1: Even when a struggling country is in the international spotlight – rarely the case with South Sudan – and the war is supposedly over
column2: its fortunes do not necessarily improve. The plight of many Afghans appears to have gone from bad to worse after the 20-year occupation by US and Nato forces ended last year and the Taliban took charge.

column1: The billions of dollars of aid ploughed into the country since 2001 now count for naught. Save the Children said this month that 9.6 million Afghan children are going hungry due to deepening economic woes
column2: Ukraine
column3: and ongoing drought. It is the country’s worst hunger crisis on record
column4: the charity said.

column1: It is no longer controversial to assert that destroyed crops
column2: lost livelihoods and impoverished communities – key micro-ingredients of mass hunger emergencies – are intimately connected to
column3: and affected by
column4: climate change and extreme weather events. But it is still hard to find concerted
column5: effective international action or public pressure to shift the dynamic.

column1: Horn of Africa countries such as Somalia
column2: for example
column3: are experiencing the worst drought in 40 years amid unprecedentedly high temperatures. As Foreign Policy magazine reported recently
column4: when the rains did come
column5: they were extreme and short-lived
column6: causing flooding and breeding swarms of locusts.

column1: It is claimed that about 3 million livestock have perished in southern Ethiopia and semi-arid parts of Kenya since last year. Pointing to climate change
column2: the UN says 20 million people across the region could go hungry this year. Their plight
column3: too
column4: has been exacerbated by Ukraine.

column1: But when the charity Christian Aid commissioned polling on the Horn of Africa region to find out what the British public thought should be done
column2: only 23% of those questioned were aware there was a problem. In contrast
column3: 91% were aware of Putin’s war.

column1: India recently demonstrated the lack of joined-up international thinking on climate
column2: hunger and war. A record-breaking heatwave in north-west India has damaged this year’s crops. That led the government to suspend wheat exports this month. Global markets had been relying on India
column3: the world’s second-largest producer
column4: to make up the Ukraine shortfall. Instead of helping
column5: Narendra Modi’s government did the opposite.

column1: Critical links between the twin crises of climate and hunger are broadly recognised by governments and analysts
column2: but acting to effect real change is proving harder
column3: as the less-than-stellar outcomes of last year’s Cop26 summit in Glasgow suggest.

column1: In the meantime
column2: the World Bank is throwing money at the problem – at the latest count
column3: $30bn to help low-income countries embroiled in climate and food crises.

column1: When the history of the Ukraine war is written
column2: Russia’s reckless action in weaponising food and deliberately disrupting global supplies
column3: thereby risking the lives of countless millions
column4: may be counted a bigger crime than even its unprovoked attack on its neighbour.

column1: Russia’s role as a key grain and energy exporter is likely to outlive the current regime in Moscow. But its global standing and influence is diminished
column2: probably permanently.

column1: That is largely due to Putin’s personal failure to recognise
column2: or accept
column3: that the era of Soviet exceptionalism is over – and that Russia
column4: like other countries
column5: inhabits a newly interconnected
column6: interdependent
column7: mutually responsible world of rules
column8: rights and laws.

column1: The UN general assembly vote in March
column2: overwhelmingly condemning as illegal Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
column3: brought together many once Moscow-friendly developing countries shocked by Putin’s disregard for national sovereignty and borders – and his apparent indifference to the wellbeing of poorer nations dependent on food and fuel imports. It was a watershed moment.

column1: China’s refusal to condemn the invasion
column2: and its failure to show international leadership in addressing the resulting global hunger and supply crises
column3: may also significantly damage its reputation and
column4: with that
column5: its hopes of hegemony. The contrast presented by the US is striking.

column1: Addressing the UN last week
column2: Antony Blinken
column3: the US secretary of state
column4: said the world faced “the greatest global food security crisis of our time”. Blinken announced an additional $215m in global emergency food assistance on top of $2.3bn already donated by the US since the Ukraine invasion began on 24 February.

column1: If the looming global “apocalypse” revealed to parliament by Andrew Bailey does indeed materialise this winter
column2: it will be to the US
column3: the UK
column4: their allies and the much-battered UN system – not China
column5: the 21st century’s self-designated superpower – that the world must look for earthly salvation. The challenge ahead is truly biblical.

column1: This article was amended on 25 May 2022. An earlier version referred to Sri Lanka having recently obtained a bridging loan from the World Bank; this followed news reports that the country’s prime minister had said on 18 May that a loan had been secured. The bank later issued a statement saying new financing had not been agreed."
Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/only-diplomacy-can-end-ukraine-war-volodymyr-zelenskiy;2022-05-21;Only diplomacy can end Ukraine war
column2: says Volodymyr Zelenskiy;"Country’s president emphasises need for talks to resume with Russia after previous negotiations stalled

column1: Ukraine’s president has said the war can only be resolved through diplomacy
column2: despite the current suspension of negotiations.

column1: “Discussions between Ukraine and Russia will undoubtedly take place
column2: ” Volodymyr Zelenskiy said in an interview with a Ukrainian television channel.

column1: “Under what format I don’t know – with intermediaries
column2: without them
column3: in a broader group
column4: at the presidential level. But the war will be bloody
column5: there will be fighting and will only definitively end through diplomacy.”

column1: He added: “There are things that can only be reached at the negotiating table. We want everything to return [to as it was before] but Russia does not want that
column2: ” he said.

column1: The last talks between the two sides took place on 22 April
column2: according to Russian news agencies.

column1: The Kremlin spokesperson
column2: Dmitry Peskov
column3: accused Ukraine of not wanting to continue talks to end the fighting.

column1: During the interview
column2: Zelenskiy spoke of a document about security guarantees for his country. Although a bilateral discussion would be held with Russia at the same time
column3: the document would be signed by “friends and partners of Ukraine
column4: without Moscow”

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/may/21/psychologist-ukrainians-trauma-war-survivors;2022-05-21;As a psychologist helping Ukrainians
column2: I am a witness to the terrible traumas of war;"We can support those trapped in shelters or struggling with survivor’s guilt. But some emotional damage is irreparable

column1: All four of my grandparents survived the second world war
column2: and all four were scarcely willing to talk about it
column3: having either survived the siege of Leningrad or come back from the frontline wounded. On the rare occasions they did
column4: their memories would leave them devastated.

column1: The lifelong PTSD they experienced was quite possibly one of the reasons I became a psychologist. I wanted to do something to end the vicious circle of trauma
column2: abuse
column3: self-neglect and fear. But during my training
column4: I could never have predicted the way I would be applying my skills a decade later.

column1: On 25 February
column2: the day after the Russian invasion of Ukraine
column3: I volunteered to join several crisis hotlines where psychologists were working to support those affected by the war. I couldn’t stop the war
column4: but at least I might try to lessen the damage. My colleagues come from many different countries – some of the Ukrainian psychologists kept working between bombings
column5: while others had evacuated to a safer place. Quite a few of us
column6: myself included
column7: are living abroad in safety — a privilege too often taken for granted.

column1: During the first weeks of the war
column2: most of the Ukrainian people who texted or called us had either just been evacuated or were still in areas of heavy shelling. Those who managed to escape were suffering from survivor’s guilt
column3: along with shock from the war in general. Those who stayed were experiencing shock in a different way
column4: trying to navigate through their daily spikes of anxiety.

column1: My first client was a person besieged in Ukraine. Their whole family had been hiding in a bomb shelter for days and they were experiencing panic attacks
column2: partly from the sudden responsibility of having to care for elderly relatives and beloved pets. They had to make the kind of decisions no one should have to face.

column1: As the war developed
column2: everyone’s stress tolerance was wearing thinner and thinner. Those who fled Ukraine reported apathy and a loss of the will to live. Old traumas have resurfaced
column3: tightening their grip and making it harder to breathe. Those who were still besieged were getting weaker mentally and physically
column4: and they were finding it harder to cope with the sleep deprivation and constant levels of tension and alertness. In such situations
column5: the main way we can offer support is by validating the person’s feelings; helping them find things they can control; and finding self-regulatory techniques that work
column6: such as body relaxation or breathing techniques.

column1: It became the eerie norm to receive text messages from people who had managed to come online in pauses between hiding in the shelter from bombs. However
column2: none of us could get used to having to guess whether a delay in response meant the person had no network connection
column3: or that they were no longer alive. Messages such as “I feel drained”
column4: “I need an urgent vent call” and “I need to talk to someone
column5: I feel it’s taken a toll on me” started to appear in our internal specialists’ support chats more often.

column1: As a response to this
column2: psychologists who specialise in supervision support started to organise webinars and video conferences in order to help each other work through the tension generated by the sessions. A group of dance movement therapists has recently launched a series of virtual meetups where they show how dance and movement can be used to cope with stress. I find such initiatives very important: if we burn out now
column3: we won’t be able to help.

column1: Messages such as this keep us going: “Thank you for helping me find the strength to let my husband go to war”; “Thank you for this talk
column2: I needed to be heard. I found the courage to try and evacuate
column3: and I’m in a safe place now.”

column1: My grandma – the only grandparent still living – struggles to relive her wartime memories without tears. But she emphasises the importance of truth
column2: especially during the times we’re living in
column3: and of preserving these memories. Lately
column4: my family and I have been spending hours on video calls with her as she shares them with us.

column1: To honour my colleagues’ work I recently started a documentary project
column2: taking their portraits via video calls. It feels important to make a record of this almost invisible part of war. When I publish the project later this year
column3: I hope the war will be over. But a huge volume of trauma repair work is still to be done.

Guardian;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/may/21/children-back-in-school-after-cleanup-in-traumatised-ukrainian-village;2022-05-21;Children back in school after cleanup in traumatised Ukrainian village;"No windows or textbooks but enthusiasm among pupils as classes resume in Novyi Bykiv
A class of children in Novyi Bykiv sat listening to their teacher
column2: his voice competing with the sound of plastic sheets flapping in the window frames. Asked if they were happy to be back in school
column3: the class of fifth-grade students chorused “Yes!” with genuine enthusiasm.

column1: They may not have windows

column1: Novyi Bykiv was one of a series of settlements occupied by the Russian army for a month as part of Vladimir Putin’s failed drive towards the capital from three directions. For a month the residents lived in terror
column2: with summary executions and widespread looting part of life.

column1: The school was the main Russian base in the village
column2: and when the Guardian visited just after the Russian departure there were clothes
column3: food and broken glass strewn across the floors
column4: graffiti sprayed on the walls and messages left by the Russians on the blackboards.

column1: The Russians launched BUK missiles from just outside the school
column2: drawing Ukrainian artillery fire that blew out the school’s windows
column3: destroyed much of the Russian hardware and eventually led to their retreat in the last days of March.

column1: “It was an unbearable time; you walked along the street and saw people you knew to be well dressed and elegant and they were wearing rags
column2: with red eyes and looking dazed
column3: ” said the headteacher
column4: Natalia Vovk. “Back then I thought that was it
column5: that we’d never been able to work here again
column6: we’d never be able to bring life back to this place
column7: ” she said.

column1: For the children
column2: too
column3: the occupation was a traumatic time
column4: as they saw the adults helpless to protect their homes and loved ones from the Russian onslaught.

column1: The cleanup process was long
column2: tiring and unpleasant. One of the downstairs rooms at the school had been used as a hybrid toilet and barbers
column3: and was littered with clumps of hair and piles of faeces. Everywhere there was shattered glass and other debris. Someone found a hand grenade in the basement.

column1: By the beginning of May
column2: enough had been repaired for lessons to resume. In some parts of Ukraine
column3: schools are using distance learning
column4: but the Russian army looted most of the houses in Novyi Bykiv
column5: meaning neither teachers nor students have computers or tablets.

column1: About 100 of the school’s 188 pupils now attend regularly for short school days. Many of the others are still abroad or in western Ukraine
column2: having fled with their families.

column1: A number of small charitable organisations and individuals contacted the school after reading the Guardian article in April detailing the destruction there
column2: Vovk said. Someone sent six computers
column3: which arrived recently by post and are being stored elsewhere until the school building has windows again to ensure they remain safe. Another donor has offered to pay for replacement textbooks
column4: after the entire stock was destroyed in a fire during the occupation.

column1: Locals have also pitched in. Someone donated a lawnmower to mow the grass in front of the building
column2: as the Russians had looted the school’s mower. The school bus driver and the building manager were working on Thursday afternoon to rig up plastic coverings on more of the windows
column3: until the money comes in for permanent replacements.

column1: The war has disrupted schooling across Ukraine
column2: even in the relatively safe western part of the country. More than 200 schools have been fully destroyed and hundreds more damaged

column4: in schools with no bomb shelter the lessons have had to go online.

column3: nightmares
column4: anxiety and panic attacks.

column2: and it’s really important to give them proper support
column3: ” said Yulia Serdyuk
column4: a 35-year-old teacher and psychologist from Novyi Bykiv.

column2: ” she said.

column2: before deciding to leave with her daughter on 19 March

column1: “We have an enormous amount of testimony from the occupied areas about teachers being forced to change curriculums

column4: less qualified people who are willing to collaborate

column1: In Novyi Bykiv the teachers have done everything to remove signs of the Russian occupation

column1: “Do not bring shame on the memories of your fathers and grandfathers

column1: Vovk

column2: and welcome to the weekly L.A. Times soccer newsletter. I’m Kevin Baxter

column1: Fairy tales don’t always end the way we want them to
column2: but for Ukraine the result was heartbreaking for several reasons. The loss was Ukraine’s first in World Cup qualifying and came in what might have been the team’s best game. Ukraine had the ball for more than an hour of the 90 minutes
column3: outshot Wales 22-9
column4: put nine of those shots on goal and completed 300 more passes.

column1: But the only score came on Gareth Bale’s free kick in the 34th minute that appeared headed into the waiting gloves of Ukrainian goalkeeper Georgiy Bushchan when captain Andriy Yarmolenko tried to head the ball out of danger and instead redirected it past Bushchan and into the net.
Wales
column2: gifted an own goal
column3: spent much of the rest of the rainy evening bunkering in
column4: keeping as many as nine men behind the ball and absorbing the relentless Ukrainian attack but never conceding.

“I don’t think we deserved to lose

column1: The game was much bigger than a soccer match because the Ukrainians were playing for people back home who continue to suffer more than 100 days after Russia’s unprovoked invasion. Days earlier
column2: Ukraine had beaten Scotland to advance to the playoff final against Wales. The winner would head to Qatar this fall to open the World Cup against the United States.

column1: For the Ukrainians
column2: playing on the road for the second time in four days against a well-rested team
column3: a victory would have provided a monumental morale boost — one that just eluded them.

column1: “There is a dead silence in the locker room
column2: ” Ukrainian coach Oleksandr Petrakov said afterward.

column1: Petrakov is a perfect example of the pluck
column2: spirit and determination of the Ukrainians
column3: who have risen to the occasion in both war and soccer.

column1: In the early hours of the invasion
column2: Petrakov asked to join the territorial defense force
column3: but
column4: at age 64 and with no combat experience
column5: he was turned away. So he fought for his country’s sovereignty on the soccer field instead.

column1: His own playing career was undistinguished and consisted mostly of stints with lower-division clubs — and even a few games with a Soviet military team. After taking over the Ukrainian national team last August
column2: he showed few signs of the kind of graceful leadership he soon would be forced to exhibit.

column1: He got his players to focus as much as possible on the game and not the war while winning friendlies against clubs from Germany and Italy and playing to a draw with a Croatian team before the win over Scotland left them a win away from the country’s second World Cup berth and first in 16 years.
That only ratcheted up the pressure.
“Everyone knows the situation in Ukraine ... and we need to show the performances of our lives
column2: ” Zinchenko said before the match against Wales. “We dream as a team to be in the World Cup.”

column1: None of that was lost on the Welsh
column2: who repeatedly stressed their solidarity with Ukraine — with the exception of a 90-minute period Sunday.

column3: the third-oldest national team in the world
column4: had its own dream too. It hasn’t been to a World Cup since 1958.

column1: “Opportunities like this don’t come around every day
column2: ” Page said. “If we could click our fingers and take away the pain the Ukraine are going through
column3: we’d do it in a heartbeat. But when it comes to football and the whistle goes
column4: we’ll want to win that game.

column1: “Business is business.”

column3: and the gamble paid off handsomely when the aging Wayne Hennessey
column4: who started just seven games in goal for his club teams the last three years
column5: played superbly

column1: “That’s the best game I’ve had in a Welsh shirt

column5: propaganda

column1: First
column2: why did Russia invade? Every answer to “why we fight”’ is an example of a society or its leaders ignoring the terrible price that will be paid. Putin
column3: isolated and insulated

column1: Here are three possible paths forward in the struggle for Ukraine:

column3: including its annexation of Crimea that year. Russia has a long history of using Potemkin villages — elaborate facades to hide uncomfortable truths — that could serve as a foundation for a new lie: victory in Ukraine.

column5: for a future military operation. This pattern reflects a sad truth from international relations: The most likely source of conflict is past conflict. Many wars never end: They hibernate only to perpetually return

column2: Ukraine and the persistence of evil - Los Angeles Times;"

column1: In the New Testament accounts of the resurrection of Jesus
column2: no passage is more poignant than Mary Magdalene’s breathless declaration to the apostles Peter and John: “They have taken the Lord out of the tomb
column3: and we do not know where they have laid him.” We can well imagine that far too many families in Ukraine in this moment of darkness are saying much the same thing as they search for loved ones amid the carnage of war: “We do not know where they have laid him.”

column1: Mass graves are being unearthed. Executed civilians
column2: hands tied behind their backs
column3: have been left by the side of the road. Entire cities have been essentially wiped off the map. Rescuers seek the living and the dead
column4: sheltered or homeless or buried beneath the rubble.

column1: The story that Christians call the Passion narrative reminds us of the presence of evil in the world — as if we needed such a reminder.
You don’t have to share the Christian belief that Jesus was the son of God to acknowledge that he was a decent and gentle man
column2: someone who heralded the meek and told his followers to turn the other cheek
column3: someone who lauded peacemakers and insisted that anyone who aspired to follow him must visit prisoners
column4: welcome the foreigner
column5: care for orphans and widows and take notice of those he called “the least of these.”

column1: Yet
column2: despite his gentleness and compassion
column3: despite his renunciation of temporal power
column4: Jesus died the slow
column5: excruciating death of an insurrectionist at the hands of Roman authorities. Yes
column6: there is evil in the world.

column1: The people of Ukraine understand that too well. Without provocation
column2: a neighboring autocrat has decided to feed his insatiable ego by invading a sovereign nation
column3: exacting a fearsome toll of casualties and destruction. This madman
column4: who professes to be a follower of Jesus
column5: has prosecuted his war against Ukraine with no regard to “just war” theory.

column1: What is worse
column2: Vladimir Putin has perpetrated this evil with the apparent blessing of the Russian Orthodox Church.  A new Orthodox cathedral
column3: dedicated to the armed forces and located on the outskirts of Moscow
column4: featured a massive mosaic depicting Putin and his  advisors triumphantly celebrating the Russian conquest of Crimea in 2014. High above the scene
column5: the Blessed Virgin Mary cast her protective veil
column6: suggesting that the annexation was divinely sanctioned.

column1: The backlash was swift
column2: and the image was removed before the cathedral’s consecration. When apprised of the matter
column3: Putin reportedly remarked
column4: “Someday our grateful descendants will appreciate our accomplishments. But for now
column5: it is still too early for that.”

column1: Far too often
column2: evil and ego walk hand in hand. And far too often those who purport to be followers of Jesus have perpetrated such evil.

column1: From the Crusades and the Wars of Religion to Manifest Destiny
column2: from the Inquisition and the scourge of slavery to “enhanced interrogation” at Abu Ghraib and children separated from parents at the border
column3: those who claim to be Christians have been complicit in violence and evil. Putin’s gratuitous invasion of Ukraine is merely the most recent example.

column1: What do we make of the persistence of evil more than 2
column2: 000 years after Mary Magdalene frantically searched for the body of Jesus? Phalanxes of theologians through the centuries have tried to explain it
column3: blaming everything from social circumstances to human nature itself.

column1: But the fact remains that we have not eradicated evil from the world
column2: and the deterrents we have devised — shaming
column3: incarceration
column4: sanctions
column5: war crimes tribunals — may have stanched some of the violence
column6: but they certainly haven’t eliminated the incidence of evil.

column1: Where does this leave us
column2: especially those who identify as followers of Jesus
column3: during this season of Easter? It’s unrealistic to expect that we can undo the evil of decades and centuries past
column4: although we bear responsibility for reconciliation and reparations.

column1: Our best strategy is to address the evil at hand
column2: before it metastasizes into a greater peril. In the case of Ukraine
column3: many nations have united in opposition to Putin
column4: and for now at least
column5: their calculation is that violence should not be met with violence.

column1: In the face of such titanic forces
column2: it may seem that there’s little individuals can do to eliminate or redress the war’s overwhelming evil. But we can act in small ways — with contributions to humanitarian organizations
column3: with forthright condemnations of Russian Orthodox complicity and yes
column4: prayer. As the Bible says
column5: we weep with those who weep. And no
column6: Putin does not deserve to be  heroized in an Orthodox cathedral for his monstrous invasion of neighboring nations.

column1: The resurrection narrative in the New Testament attests to the presence of evil. But Easter is also a story of hope. Mary Magdalene did find Jesus
column2: and the Christian gloss on that discovery is that evil and death do not have the final word.

column12: as the title suggests

column1: Does the principal really see what he thinks he sees? “Bad Roads
column2: ” which was Ukraine’s 2021 Oscar submission for international feature

column4: it speaks to the long-term trauma of an ongoing military presence and the malevolence that can seep
column5: without warning
column6: into everyday encounters. This first story
column7: which takes place under a hot sun and centers on three men
column8: is both a prologue and a bit of an anomaly: It establishes a theme — the plight of women in wartime — that will be given more unflinching attention in the remaining three vignettes
column9: each of which focuses on a woman’s experience and unfolds under cover of darkness.

column1: Those stories are all self-enclosed
column2: with conversant themes and beats but no overlapping characters. It’s a structural choice that underscores each character’s sense of isolation
column3: but it also highlights the weird
column4: sometimes terrible intimacy that can take root between strangers. The second story focuses on a trio of teenage girls waiting at a bus stop for their boyfriends
column5: who turn out to be enemy soldiers. We never meet those men but their presence is felt in scraps of gossip that reveal the desperate
column6: transactional nature of relationships in a place where everything — a cigarette
column7: a bag of seeds
column8: a woman’s body — has a price. As nighttime shadows descend
column9: the camera lingers on one of the girls (Anna Zhurakovskaya) as she has a lonely nighttime meeting with her grandmother (Yuliya Matrosova)
column10: who begs her to come home with her

column12: less fraught times.

column1: The understated
column2: open-air melancholy of the second story devolves into horrific
column3: claustrophobic violence in the third
column4: which follows a female journalist (Maryna Klimova) as she’s imprisoned and verbally and physically abused by a soldier (Yuri Kulinich) in an underground bunker. The actors’ commitment to this brutal spectacle is remarkable
column5: especially Klimova’s as her character tries
column6: with as much sober determination as she can muster
column7: to appeal to her captor’s long-abandoned sense of decency. But Vorozhbit’s technical virtuosity — the starkness of the production design
column8: the intricate pools of light and shadow at play in her carefully composed frames and the soundtrack’s relentless “Stalker”-esque drip-drip of water — serves only to emphasize the artificiality of this longest and most punishing episode. (It runs about 40 minutes and seems to go on for hours
column9: which is surely by design.)

column1: The two middle stories in particular are marked by a certain staginess
column2: a sense of visual abstraction
column3: that points to the movie’s origins in Vorozhbit’s 2017 play
column4: also titled “Bad Roads.” More convincingly inhabited is the film’s fourth and finest segment
column5: in which a young woman (Zoya Baranovskaya) accidentally runs over a chicken with her car and tries to compensate its owners
column6: a poor older couple (Oksana Voronina and Sergei Solovyov). What begins as an admirable
column7: if naive
column8: act of atonement gradually spirals
column9: in quietly terrifying and mordantly funny fashion
column10: into a waking nightmare as a lifetime of class resentment and economic woe comes writhing to the surface. Impressively restrained in its flirtation with full-bore horror
column11: it’s a reminder that when inhumanity is the everyday norm
column12: there may be few things more futile — or dangerous — than the stirrings of individual conscience.

LA Times;https://www.latimes.com/opinion/story/2022-04-29/russia-ukraine-invasion-military-history-russo-japanese-war;2022-04-29;Op-Ed: Russia didn't learn from the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-05. But Ukraine can - Los Angeles Times;"On television and online
column2: commentators reach furiously for comparisons to past conflicts for insights into the Ukrainian-Russian war. How will it ever end?

column1: At the same time
column2: military analysts watch closely to see how lethal new technologies lead to ghastly carnage like in Donbas and Irpin. What can we learn about how to fight future wars?

column1: Surprising answers arise from comparisons to an often-overlooked conflict more than a century ago
column2: between a small nation just elbowing its way onto the world stage and a huge but faltering Western power that just happened to be Russia.

column1: Opinion
It may sound like a neat way to avoid ‘boots on the ground’ for Americans
column2: but the bloodshed would be immense.

column1: The Russo-Japanese War of 1904-05 was a big deal at the time
column2: and it is generally considered the first modern war. The world watched with rapt attention. In the story of this conflict
column3: we can find clues to what is happening
column4: and what may still happen
column5: in Vladimir Putin’s misbegotten and bloody invasion of  Ukraine.

column1: Repeating rifles
column2: machine guns and fast-firing artillery were as new in 1904 as Javelin anti-tank missiles and Turkish drones are today. They all played roles
column3: as did swiftly maneuvering steel warships. The Japanese navy’s destruction of the Russian Baltic Fleet
column4: which had sailed halfway around the planet
column5: shocked the world in 1905 as much as Ukrainian missiles’ sinking of the Russian cruiser Moskva did this month.

column1: But it shouldn’t have. And nor would the struggles of the Russian military today surprise anyone who studied the Russo-Japanese War. Rivers of similarities run through these two conflicts.
Naturally
column2: there were differences
column3: the biggest being that Japan
column4: angered by diplomatic betrayals and Russian expansion in Asia
column5: started the war. It began with a surprise nighttime torpedo boat attack against the Russian fleet in Port Arthur (now the Lüshunkou District of China).

column1: Opinion
KGB agents are apparently not taught history
column2: or so it would seem from Vladimir Putin’s recent statement that only “God knows” how a portion of southeastern Ukraine ever became part of that country.

column1: Japan’s navy was modern
column2: its traditions based on Britain’s Royal Navy; Japanese sailors even ate curry on Fridays like their English counterparts. (They still do.) Its warships were state-of-the-art and built in England. Thus
column3: a major Western power supplied modern technologies to the smaller of the warring nations
column4: like in the current conflict.

column1: The Japanese soldiers and sailors
column2: swept up in their nation’s extraordinary shift to modernity
column3: were motivated to fight. They were also trained and fed well. And they saw Russia as a greedy
column4: overreaching bully.

column1: Russian soldiers
column2: meanwhile
column3: quickly found themselves under siege in the barren winter hellscape of Port Arthur
column4: thousands of miles from Russia’s major urban centers — and with no real rationale in their heads as to why they were fighting. Supply lines
column5: already extraordinarily long
column6: were easily cut. Russian soldiers’ equipment
column7: training and basic supplies were lacking.

column1: Sound familiar?
Opinion
War is on everybody’s mind in Germany. But not always the immediate war in Ukraine — sometimes it’s the wars of the past we promised never to have again.
The world was sure Russia would win. It had a vaunted military in the grand European tradition. How could little upstart Japan possibly emerge victorious?
Like the conflict in Ukraine that has been livestreamed to and from smartphones

column2: which will require the penetration of Ukraine’s major cities. Urban warfare requires nimbleness
column3: agility
column4: sophisticated intelligence-gathering operations
column5: doctrine to overcome the inherent challenges of the urban terrain
column6: formations of artillery
column7: tanks
column8: infantry
column9: engineers working in concert
column10: disciplined rank-and-file
column11: strict command and control with authority devolved down to junior officers in the field
column12: and knowledge of local terrain. Russia has none of this.

column1: Yet even the best-trained military in the world would struggle to conquer and control a country as large as Ukraine. And urban warfare reduces all the strengths of the attacker
column2: even if it is a superior military force.  The attackers lack situational awareness to see into dense terrain with full  clarity. They are confined to narrow streets and alleys
column3: and are prevented from spreading out to support each other.

column1: Concrete obstacles and buildings provide the defense with  protection and concealment. The attacking military must crisscross open areas and exposed streets to attack a defender behind walls of concrete. The attackers will have no clue where the enemy is amid the thousands of potential hiding spots. History is full of examples of small
column2: prepared urban defenders striking  potent blows to a superior attacking military —  including Mogadishu
column3: Somalia
column4: in 1993;  Grozny
column5: the Chechen capital
column6: in 1994;   and Suez City
column7: Egypt

column1: Nor does Russia have sufficient forces — even if reinforced by Chechen or Syrian mercenaries — to control Ukraine’s cities. U.S. Army doctrine says that to hold urban terrain
column2: a military needs three to five times the troops required in any other environment.

column1: If defended well
column2: a city can force a military to send five or more soldiers to attack just one urban defender. Yet Russia commands an estimated 280
column3: 000 soldiers in its active army in the war
column4: while Ukraine fields an active force of around 126
column6: though it has tens of thousands more in its volunteer militias called the territorial defense force. It’s simple arithmetic.

column1: World & Nation
Photojournalist Carolyn Cole documents Ukrainian life amid Russia’s invasion.
But doctrine matters too. Russia discovered what many armies have learned from history: Bombing cities does not force their inhabitants to give up. It did not do so in the 1942 battle of Stalingrad
column2: the 1945 battle of Berlin
column3: or the 2003 U.S. invasion of Baghdad — ground forces must go in to clear and hold the city if it is to be taken.

column1: The paradox of urban warfare is that the more you bomb a city
column2: the harder it is to take. Bombed buildings are easier to defend if a defender survives the initial bombing because rubble  of concrete and steel makes for nifty bomb-proof bunkers to fight from and  perfect locations to hide improvised explosive devices.

column1: Russia’s failure to quickly penetrate Kyiv and the other major Ukrainian cities allowed the Ukrainians to use the urban terrain to defend their cities. Ukrainian forces blew up bridges
column2: blocked roads
column3: attacked convoys from hidden ambushes and prepared the streets to be “meat grinders” that the Russians feared. No wonder desertions are high
column4: troop morale is flagging and so many Russian commanding officers have reportedly been killed.

column1: Make no mistake
column2: Russia will regroup and retool its military strategy. It will rely less on precision and more on collective punishment. Expect more war crimes and horrific images from the front lines. Sun Tzu famously noted in “The Art of War” that the best warfare strategy is to attack the enemy’s plans
column3: next is to attack alliances
column4: next is to attack the army
column5: and the worst is to attack a walled city. Even though cities like Mariupol may look like post-apocalyptic hellscapes
column6: they are the worst places for an invading army to target.

column1: That is the only piece of good news going for Ukraine.

column2: senior fellow at New America and co-author of the forthcoming book “Understanding Urban Warfare.”"

column1: A lot of people who fancy themselves foreign policy realists roll their eyes at talk about “good guys” versus “bad guys.” The world is made up of nation-states with interests and those states act rationally on their interests. Good and bad ain’t got nothing to do with it.

column1: There’s equal clarity for the United States. I think the realist case for doing everything possible to assure a Russian defeat is obvious. It is Russian policy to undermine our interests and the interests of our allies around the world.

Wells felt the need to call World War I “the war to end all wars.”

column2: which included genocide and scores of civilian casualties.

column1: History has proven Wells wrong time and time again. Yet his statement should not be read empirically
column2: as if acknowledging the scale of the death and destruction of World War I would prevent all future armed conflict. Instead
column3: his lesson from WWI is that no matter how many wars take place

column1: Fast forward about 100 years
column2: and we see Russia committing atrocities in Ukraine such as those that shocked Wells.

column1: Opinion
Being in the inner circle is not restraining the Kremlin. It should be deprived of its standing in the international community.
Our international institutions are supposed to rein in such violence. Specifically
column2: the United Nations’ mission includes securing peace and suppressing aggression.

column1: Yet we are running up against a critical issue in the U.N.: the veto power of Security Council members. If one of the permanent members — France
column2: Great Britain
column3: Russia
column4: China or the United States — finds some initiative that calls for coordinated international action to be contrary to their national interests
column5: that country has the prerogative to cancel it. That is what has blocked international action in Ukraine: Although 11 of the 15 members of the Security Council voted in February to support a resolution to denounce the war
column6: the resolution went nowhere because Russia vetoed it (China
column7: India and the United Arab Emirates abstained).

column1: A successful vote would not only have denounced the conflict but laid out concrete next steps to reestablish peace
column2: including negotiations or launching a peacekeeping operation with soldiers and civilian personnel.

column1: This failure doesn’t let the U.N. off the hook. Articles 39
column2: 41 and 42 of its charter call upon Security Council members to decide when peace is threatened or has been breached and then address the situation — as it did with some success in Liberia
column3: where
column4: in the aftermath of the civil war
column5: U.N. personnel from various countries worked on reforming the military and police
column6: reducing HIV/AIDS transmission and creating programs for the country’s youth.

column1: The promise of the U.N. endures in this mandate to facilitate on peace. What needs to change is the Security Council. And change to the U.N. is possible. We have seen it in the past.
Less than 20 years after the U.N. was created
column2: the organization increased the number of non-permanent members of the Security Council from six to 10. Although non-permanent members lack veto powers and serve for only two years without the chance to be reelected
column3: the change successfully widened participation by including more countries from different regions.

column1: Another reform took place in 2005
column2: when the General Assembly voted to give the 54-member Economic and Social Council more responsibilities
column3: including assessing international development and the power to convene ad hoc meetings on humanitarian issues. The council has since used this power to support reconstruction efforts in Haiti following the earthquake that devastated that country in 2021.

column1: Still
column2: the most significant change in international institutions was the unlikely creation of the U.N. itself out of the failure of its predecessor
column3: the League of Nations.

column1: Opinion
Ukraine
column2: with international help
column3: needs to begin data gathering on Russian atrocities before evidence gets lost and victims scatter or disappear.

column1: The shock Wells experienced after World War I was shared by leaders such as U.S. President  Wilson
column2: who helped found the league — the first sincere attempt to bring countries together formally to resolve problems through diplomacy. But Wilson’s hope fell apart when the U.S. Senate refused to ratify the league charter
column3: removing the emerging superpower from the organization during its vulnerable origins.

column1: Participating countries ultimately failed to find common ground. For one thing
column2: they initially excluded the Soviet Union
column3: later allowed it as a member and then expelled it for invading Finland.

column1: The league’s failure to cooperate made it incapable of stopping aggression by the Axis powers in the 1930s. It took the Second World War for some leaders to see the error of their ways.

column2: Great Britain and the United States met to create the Atlantic Charter
column3: proclaiming that states should not increase their territory at the expense of others and that governments were instead tasked to develop economically
column4: cooperate and disarm.

column1: Particularly relevant to the U.N.‘s current challenges
column2: as the U.S. and Britain moved to expand their charter globally
column3: Russia had to be won over. Stalin feared that Soviet interests would not be represented in the new institution. So the founding countries developed the Security Council veto partly to reassure the Soviets. (Roosevelt also told Stalin to wait until after the 1944 election to take Poland
column4: a compromise meant to entice Stalin.)

column1: Opinion
Globalization interwove economies of very different nations
column2: now coming apart as autocracies ally with the Kremlin and democracies stand with Ukraine.

column1: When the U.N. charter was signed in San Francisco
column3: 50 countries — including the Soviet Union — agreed. It is this spirit of maneuvering for peace that should drive Security Council reform. There needs to be a way to overturn the veto — for instance
column4: by allowing an override if two-thirds of the General Assembly decides to
column5: and/or if four out of five Security Council members agree.

column1: Such a change requires approval from not only two-thirds of the General Assembly — which has already voted against Russia’s invasion — but every member of the Security Council. To bring Russia along
column2: other countries need to issue a credible threat where it matters most: natural gas. Europe
column3: with the U.S. and perhaps major gas exporters such as Qatar
column4: should completely cut off natural gas exports from Russia to any part of the world if it continues to block Security Council actions
column5: including support for a veto override.

column1: Other countries
column2: including the U.S.
column3: will have to accept that their future interests would be served by having to cooperate instead of acting unilaterally via veto. Perhaps the rising cost of gas and grain
column4: just one consequence of the U.N.'s impotence on Russia
column5: will make the U.S. rethink the value of unchecked veto power.

column1: H.G. Wells was right — no matter how challenging
column2: peace is essential. The Security Council is tasked to uphold it. With the Ukraine-Russia conflict again showing the horrors of war
column3: the U.N.'s future now depends on whether it can reform its own structure.

column1: Anthony Pahnke is associate professor of international relations at San Francisco State University."

column1: LA Times;https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2022-04-02/explainer-whats-next-for-europes-natural-gas-during-war;2022-04-02;News Analysis: What's next for Europe's natural gas during war in Ukraine? - Los Angeles Times;"Russian President Vladimir Putin is demanding payment in rubles for natural gas — or else. column2: generate electricity and power industry are through the roof.

column1: There’s a lot of discussion around natural gas in Europe against the background of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
column2: to say the least.

column1: Here are key things to know:
What is Putin proposing?
Putin has said importers of Russian gas must now pay in rubles. European leaders said no dice — their contracts say euros or dollars and one side can’t abruptly change that.
Changing currency would normally follow extended negotiations
column2: analysts say
column3: with customers demanding something in return for being exposed to fluctuations that would come with paying in the less-stable ruble.

column1: The open questions about what the change could mean have sent shudders through energy markets
column2: raising uncertainty about whether Europe’s natural gas could be cut off and cause a major hit to the economy. But Russia also relies on oil and gas sales to fund its government as sanctions have squeezed its financial system.

column1: The Kremlin offered what could be seen as a loophole. Importers would simply have to establish an account in dollars or euros at a designated bank
column2: then a second account in rubles. The importer would pay the gas bill in euros or dollars and direct the bank to exchange the money for rubles.

column1: In any case
column2: Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Friday that the change won’t happen immediately: “Payments on shipments in progress right now must be made not this very day
column3: but somewhere in late April
column4: or even early May.”

column1: European leaders have rejected the proposal as “blackmail” and say payments will continue in dollars and euros.

German officials wouldn’t discuss the impact of Putin’s decree other than to say they were examining it. Economy Ministry spokeswoman Beate Baron noted that Russia’s Gazprombank has been given 10 days to explain the procedure
column2: “and of course we will in turn look carefully at that.”

column1: A top European Commission energy official tweeted that the European Union was coordinating “to establish a common approach.”
What is Putin after?
The Kremlin says the change is necessary because Western sanctions have frozen its reserves of foreign currency. Because the measure targets importers in “unfriendly countries
column2: ” it can be seen as retaliation for the sanctions that have cut many Russian banks off from international financial networks  and led some Western companies to abandon their businesses in Russia.

column1: The economic advantages for Russia aren’t clear. In theory
column2: payment in rubles would increase demand for the currency and help the Kremlin prop up its exchange rate
column3: which has regained ground from its initial plunge after the invasion. But gas exporter Gazprom already has to sell 80% of its foreign earnings for rubles
column4: so the boost to the currency from converting the remaining 20% could be minimal.

column1: The Kremlin indicates it also wants to extend ruble payments to other commodities
column2: such as metals.

column1: One motive may be political
column2: said Stefan Meister
column3: head of the program on international order and democracy at the German Council on Foreign Relations.

column1: “Russia is not interested in stopping gas
column2: but it wants a kind of political victory
column3: ” Meister said. “It wants to show that Putin dictates the conditions under which it exports gas.”

column1: The move is partly aimed at Russia’s domestic audience
column2: Meister said
column3: with Putin telling his people: “Look
column4: these are enemy states and now they have to pay under a different scheme.”

column1: “So I think that this is also about getting support inside the country
column2: defining who are the enemies
column3: ” Meister said.

column1: Another motive could be to protect the designated bank
column2: Gazprombank
column3: from being hit by sanctions because it would be the conduit for the payments that keep gas flowing
column4: Meister said. It is the third-largest bank in Russia
column5: and like Sberbank
column6: the largest
column7: it has not been cut off from the international SWIFT payment system.

column1: What’s the state of the gas supply for Europe?

column2: which provides 40% of Europe’s gas and 25% of its oil.

column2: according to pipeline operators’ websites.

column1: Many aren’t happy  that European utilities are still buying energy from Russia
column2: which on average got 43% of its annual government revenue from oil and gas sales between 2011 and 2020
column3: according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

column1: That helped pay for the tanks and missiles used in the invasion. But it also means Russia has strong reasons not to cut off natural gas.

column2: although the impact would vary based on how much countries use.

column2: the continent’s largest economy
column3: “is heavily dependent on Russian energy supplies
column4: ” said Monika Schnitzer

column2: ” she said.

column3: with Europe facing an energy crunch even before the war broke out.

column1: The crisis has left governments and companies scrambling to round up supplies from other sources

column1: The Bruegel think tank estimated that Europe would be 10% to 15% short of normal demand to get through the next winter heating season

column1: European leaders have said they can’t afford the consequences of an immediate boycott. Instead
column2: they plan to reduce the use of Russian gas as fast as possible. They’re ordering more liquefied natural gas
column3: which comes by ship; seeking more gas from pipelines from Norway and Azerbaijan; accelerating deployment of wind and solar energy; and pushing conservation measures.

column1: The aim is to cut use of Russian gas by two-thirds by the end of the year and completely by 2027.
The situation is serious enough that Germany has declared an early warning of an energy emergency

column1: In a full-blown emergency
column2: government regulators must decide which companies would have their gas shut off  to spare homes and hospitals. Makers of chemicals
column3: glass
column4: ceramics and galvanized metals use lots of gas.

column1: Rationing would hit a European economy already suffering from the fallout from the war and high energy prices that have boosted inflation to a record 7.5%."

column3: their days-old infant
column4: was warm enough and still breathing. At the time
column5: the couple constantly questioned whether they made the right decision.

column1: The outbound trip became a 27-hour ordeal. The story explains how the escape was difficult due to the scores of Ukrainian refugees and foreigners who had similar plans to flee. “It was chaos. There wasn’t a line

column3: ” Carcamo writes. “Vivian started to cry. She was hungry. But the bag with the baby formula and water bottles were with Jacob

column1: This city has proved to be remarkably resilient.
Water is a precious resource - supplies were cut off after Russia seized the neighbouring city of Kherson. Queues to fill bottles are often long and June temperatures are hitting around 30C.
And yet people here have managed to find a way to make it work. They fill up their containers from local stations set up in neighbourhoods.

The daily thud of incoming shells barely registers. Most hardly look up from their coffee as they sit on benches in the park. There is even a horse and Cinderella-like carriage with courting couples merrily trundling up and down the High Street.
This may be a Kremlin target
column2: but it is also home.

column1: The wail of the air raid siren is a prelude to a thud to our right as our car makes its way through the suburbs of this major port.

We are following a Ukrainian Red Cross van as they try to rescue some of those coming under regular shelling: yet another busload to add to the already historic human exodus from this country.
These farewells have become a familiar sight across Ukraine over the last 100 days
column2: but they are no less heartbreaking to watch.

column1: Liudmyla has decided it is time for her youngest children to leave. She can't let them play outside as the bombardment continues and she wants them to be somewhere safe.
She holds on to them as long as she can
column2: one under each arm

column1: Mykolaiv was one of the first cities attacked when the invasion began. Russian forces came close to the city limits but were pushed back.

column1: This week's American and German promises to supply advanced multiple rocket artillery and air defence and radar systems will certainly have gone some way towards meeting the urgent demands of hard-pressed Ukrainian commanders.

But allegations of German foot-dragging over previous commitments and Joe Biden's insistence that US weapons only be used to hit Russian targets inside Ukraine cause some to wonder why the West seeks to place limits on Ukraine's war effort while Russia observes no limits at all.
There's a kind of calibration going on
column2: says Ian Bond. ""As though we're saying 'we want the Ukrainians to win but not to win too much'"".

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61666358;2022-06-01;Ukraine war: Your questions on the conflict answered;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
It's been 98 days since Russia launched its invasion of Ukraine and events on the ground remain complex and fast-moving.
Moscow's forces have been pushed back from the capital city of Kyiv
column2: and the troops dispatched by Vladimir Putin towards the second city of Kharkiv have been forced across the border back into Russia - but intense fighting continues.

column1: Our correspondents on the ground have been answering your questions about how the war is progressing and whether Ukraine can survive the Russian onslaught. They are:
David Perdue
column2: in Washington DC
column3: asks: Has Russia's ground offensive practically stalled? What further Ukrainian territory will Russia look to occupy
column4: if any?

column1: After initial setbacks
column2: Russian troops seem to be making gains in eastern Ukraine. But what's Moscow's objective? If Russia occupies the whole of Donetsk and Luhansk regions
column3: will the Kremlin stop or push on for more territory?

column1: Even if Russia does call a halt
column2: there's no guarantee it would be a permanent cessation of hostilities. They say a leopard doesn't change its spots… neither
column3: I suspect
column4: would Russia's president.

column1: In speeches and articles Vladimir Putin has made it clear that he does not see Ukraine as a sovereign nation; instead he views it as a territory that belongs historically in Moscow's orbit.
After launching his ""special military operation""
column2: the Kremlin leader seems to have expected the government in Kyiv to fall quickly. He even called on the Ukrainian military to rise up and overthrow the Ukrainian leadership. That didn't happen.

column1: But that doesn't mean Vladimir Putin has given up on the idea of forcing Ukraine back into Moscow's sphere of influence - even in the face of Western sanctions.
This question comes from SC Bhargava: Why is it that Ukraine has been mostly defensive? Why has it not attacked military and civilian targets inside Russia?
This is a war Ukraine did not choose and did not start. It's defensive in its very nature: the country is fighting for its right to exist against an all-out Russian attack.
I don't think you can underestimate what it has cost Ukraine to stop Russia taking Kyiv
column2: and now to try and halt the advance of Russian troops across the Donbas.

column1: Openly and deliberately targeting Russia itself would be a major escalation at a time when Ukraine is battling to hold the line.

The pleas from Kyiv for more weapons from the West are constant. But the US recently made very clear that the longer-range missiles it will provide are not for hitting Russian territory: it fears an escalation.
Remember
column2: the West judged it too risky to impose a no-fly zone over Ukraine when Kyiv was begging for that at the start. As for Ukraine targeting Russian civilians? That would be a war crime.

column1: Isobel McRae-Morris asks about reports that some Russian soldiers have been refusing to fight in Ukraine
column2: with some conscripts deserting their positions. Is this really happening?

column1: Yes
column2: although it's hard to know the scale. The thing is
column3: Russia hasn't officially declared war: Vladimir Putin insists on calling his invasion a ""special operation"" and that means professional soldiers can refuse to take part. They can be fired
column4: but they can't - or shouldn't - be prosecuted.

column1: Still
column2: it takes some guts to actually do it. From my own reporting in Ukraine
column3: I know that many of the Russian soldiers deployed at the start of this invasion were young and inexperienced; some didn't know they were going to war
column4: others thought they'd take Kyiv in days
column5: without resistance.

column1: But the proof of heavy battles and heavy losses is everywhere
column2: including in the refrigerated train carriages I've seen piled up with dead Russian soldiers. So it doesn't surprise me that some would refuse to fight
column3: especially now they've seen for themselves that Ukraine doesn't want ""liberating"". But we're not seeing reports of mass desertion.

column1: Philip Withers asks: Why has Nato not moved to protect the Black Sea port of Odesa
column2: given that the Black Sea is international waters?

column1: There are lots of complicated reasons for this.
Firstly
column2: Nato is not directly involved in the conflict and wants to keep it that way.

column1: Second
column2: the Montreux Convention
column3: which regulates maritime access to the Black Sea
column4: gives Turkey a say over which non-Black Sea states are allowed to pass in and out through the Bosphorus.

column1: Turkey has much closer relations with Moscow than almost all other Nato members (with the exception of Hungary) and wants to be seen as a mediator between Russia and Ukraine. Any move to forcibly break Russia's blockade of Odesa would inevitably be seen by Moscow as a hostile move.
Britain and Lithuania recently indicated that they wanted to see a ""coalition of the willing"" to protect commercial shipping in and out of Odesa
column2: in an effort to allow Ukraine to export its badly needed agricultural products
column3: especially grain
column4: around the world. But plans have yet to take shape.

column1: In the meantime
column2: a Danish decision to supply Ukraine with American-made Harpoon missiles
column3: combined with Ukraine's own Neptune system (which was responsible for sinking the Moskva
column4: the flagship of Russia's Black Sea fleet) mean that
column5: for now
column6: Odesa is not likely to be attacked from the sea.

column1: The next question comes from reader Jayesh who asks whether Russia and Ukraine are holding any peace talks at the moment on establishing a ceasefire.
Talks between Russia and Ukraine started up soon after the Russian invasion. There were several rounds of negotiations
column2: but they didn't produce any agreement.

column1: For now
column2: the talking's over. Both sides blame each other for that. But remember: if Russian forces hadn't attacked Ukraine in the first place
column3: there'd be no need for a ceasefire!

column1: It's likely that developments on the battlefield will dictate when
column2: how and in what format negotiations resume.

column1: This week
column2: President Erdogan of Turkey talked by phone with his Ukrainian and Russian counterparts and offered to mediate in the conflict.

column1: Russia's current military aim appears to be to seize and occupy (or ""liberate"" as the Russians put it) the whole of the Donbas region. Moscow may not be ready for a ceasefire until it manages that.
One reader
column2: Johnny
column3: writes: When are countries going to stop acting scared of Russia and stand up to them?

column1: Are Ukraine's Western backers scared or merely acting cautiously?
Some
column2: like the Baltic republics
column3: have voiced frustration over what they see as the West's reluctance to give Ukraine everything it needs.

column1: But for all Russia's military deficiencies - which have been cruelly exposed over more than three months of a frequently bungled campaign - it is still armed with a vast arsenal of nuclear weapons which it has hinted it could use.
Western officials continue to believe that Moscow is unlikely to resort to such doomsday options
column2: but they cannot simply act as if such dangers didn't exist.

column1: And while some
column2: including the British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss
column3: seem happy to talk about expelling Russian forces from the whole of Ukraine
column4: others see a return to the situation that existed on the morning of 24 February as a more likely and feasible scenario.

column1: This would leave Russia in control of the Crimean peninsula
column2: which it annexed in 2014
column3: as well as significant chunks of the eastern Donbas.

column1: Lois Barakat Ichelson says: In light of new EU oil embargoes
column2: which will be tougher by the end of the year
column3: are the oligarchs organised
column4: powerful and motivated enough to oust President Putin?

column1: He goes on to ask whether there are any other groups or forces in the country that could remove him.
Considering the highly secretive nature of Kremlin politics
column2: it's only natural that there's lots of rumour and speculation about the man at the top; after all
column3: it's Putin who takes all key decisions in the country.

column1: So… is Vladimir Putin seriously ill? Are the knives being sharpened ahead of a ""palace coup""? Are the oligarchs plotting to overthrow the president?
Much of this
column2: I suspect
column3: is wishful thinking on the part of President Putin's detractors. Of course
column4: not everyone in the corridors of Kremlin power will be happy with what Russia's doing in Ukraine and the international sanctions Moscow has brought upon itself.

column1: But
column2: right now
column3: there's no hint of an anti-Putin coup - and that includes amongst the oligarchs
column4: whose wings the Kremlin clipped long ago.

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-61681045;2022-06-03;Wales-Ukraine: 100 tickets for refugees for World Cup play-off;"Ukrainian refugees will be given 100 tickets for Sunday's World Cup play-off final in Wales.
The Football Association of Wales (FAW) and the Welsh government confirmed 100 of those fleeing the war will be given a chance to see the game.
It comes as Ukrainians who were living in Wales before the conflict called on the FAW to give tickets to those displaced by Russia's invasion.
Home tickets at the Cardiff City Stadium have sold out.
The Ukrainian ambassador has also been invited
column2: while a welcome message will be waiting for the Ukrainian team when they arrive at Cardiff Airport.

column1: First Minister Mark Drakeford said: ""I would like to give a warm Welsh welcome to the Ukrainian football team and their supporters to Cardiff.
This will be an opportunity for us to reaffirm our support for Ukraine as it fights Russia's unprovoked and brutal act of war.
I am sure that the game will be a very competitive fixture between two skilful and passionate teams - there is a big prize to be won.""
Ukraine qualified for the play-off final on Wednesday by beating Scotland 3-1 in Glasgow
column2: and now face Wales for a place at the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.

column1: Wales are hoping to qualify for the tournament for the first time since 1958
column2: while Ukraine qualified for their first and only World Cup in 2006.Ukrainian refugees will be given 100 tickets for Sunday's World Cup play-off final in Wales.

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-61680382;2022-06-03;Ukraine lifts interest rate to highest in Europe;"Ukraine's central bank has more than doubled its interest rate to 25% to the highest level for any European country.
The move is intended to slow soaring inflation and prevent a further collapse of its currency following Russia's invasion in February.
Businesses have been forced to close and key supply chains have been cut off since the war began.
The World Bank predicts that Ukraine's economy could shrink by as much as 45% this year.

Wars ebb and flow. Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine is no exception.
Early fears of a swift conquest were succeeded by Russian retreat and Ukrainian resistance. That has now been met by a more focused Russian offensive in the east.

column2: where might this war go next?

column1: Here are five potential scenarios - they are not mutually exclusive
column2: but all are within the bounds of plausibility.

column1: The war might continue for months - if not years - as Russian and Ukrainian forces grind each other down.
Momentum shifts to and fro as both sides make gains and losses. Neither side is willing to give up. Russia's President Putin judges he can gain by demonstrating strategic patience
column2: gambling that Western countries will suffer from ""Ukraine fatigue"" and focus more on their economic crises and the threat from China.

column1: The West
column2: however
column3: shows resolve and continues to supply Ukraine with weapons. Semi-permanent front lines are established. Steadily the war becomes a frozen conflict
column4: a ""forever war"".
