column2: a retired Australian general and military scholar
column3: says: ""There is little prospect of a crushing operational or strategic victory by either side in the short term. Neither belligerent has demonstrated the capacity to land a strategically decisive blow.""

column2: running short of manpower and munitions. The price in blood and treasure no longer justifies further fighting. Russia's military and economic losses are not sustainable. The Ukrainian people tire of war

column1: Sergey says he was completely shocked.
My first thoughts were 'Is this really happening to me?'""
They were continually shelled
column2: he says
column3: both when moving and when parked overnight. In his unit of 50 people
column4: 10 were killed and 10 others wounded. Almost all his comrades were under the age of 25.

column1: He heard of Russian servicemen so inexperienced that they ""did not know how to shoot and couldn't tell one end of a mortar from another"".
He says his convoy - travelling through northern Ukraine - broke up after just four days when a bridge they were about to cross exploded
column2: killing comrades ahead of them.

column1: In another incident
column2: Sergey says he had to overtake comrades trapped inside a burning vehicle in front of him.

column1: It was blown up from a grenade launcher or something else. It caught fire and there were [Russian] soldiers inside. We drove around it and on
column2: firing as we went. I didn't look back.""

column1: His unit moved on through the Ukrainian countryside
column2: but there was a clear lack of strategy
column3: he says. Reinforcements failed to arrive and soldiers were poorly equipped for the task of taking a large city.

column1: We went without helicopters - just in a column
column2: as though we were heading to a parade.""

column1: He believes his commanders had planned to capture strongholds and key cities very quickly - and had calculated that the Ukrainians would simply surrender.
We rushed forward with short overnight stays
column2: without trenches
column3: without reconnaissance. We didn't leave anyone in the rear
column4: so if someone decided to come in from behind and hit us there was no protection.

column1: I think that [so many of] our guys died largely because of this. If we had moved gradually
column2: if we had checked the roads for mines many losses could have been avoided.""

column1: Sergey's complaints about lack of equipment have also emerged in phone conversations alleged to be between Russian soldiers and their families
column2: intercepted and posted online by the Ukrainian security services.

column1: At the beginning of April
column2: Sergey was sent back over the border to a camp on the Russian side. Troops had been withdrawn from northern Ukraine and appeared to be regrouping for an assault in the east. Later that month he received an order to return to Ukraine - but told his commander that he was not prepared to go.

column1: He said it was my choice. They didn't even [try to] dissuade us
column2: because we weren't the first
column3: Sergey told the BBC. But
column4: he had been sufficiently worried about his unit's reaction to his refusal that he decided to seek legal advice.

column1: A lawyer told Sergey and two like-minded colleagues to return their arms and go back to their unit's headquarters - where they should file a letter explaining that they were ""morally and psychologically exhausted"" and could not continue fighting in Ukraine.
Sergey was told that returning to the unit was important because simply leaving could be interpreted as desertion
column2: which can result in a two-year sentence in a disciplinary battalion.

column1: Army commanders try to intimidate contract soldiers into staying with their units
column2: according to Russian human rights lawyer Alexei Tabalov. But he stresses that Russian military law does include clauses which allow soldiers to refuse to fight if they don't want to.

column1: Human rights activist Sergei Krivenko says he is not aware of any prosecutions of those refusing to return to the front.
That is not to say that prosecutions are not being attempted.
One commander in northern Russia requested a criminal case be brought against his subordinate who would not return to Ukraine
column2: but a military prosecutor refused to proceed
column3: according to documents seen by the BBC. Such an action would be ""premature"" without having assessed the harm to the military service he was involved in
column4: the prosecutor said.

column1: And there is no guarantee that more prosecutions might not emerge in the future.
Soldiers like Sergey - reluctant to return to the front line - are not unusual
column2: according to Ruslan Leviev
column3: the editor of Conflict Intelligence Team
column4: a media project investigating the experiences of the Russian military in Ukraine through confidential interviews and open source material.

column1: Leviev says his team estimates a sizeable minority of the Russian contract soldiers sent to Ukraine to fight in the initial invasion refused to go back again.
Independent Russian media have also been reporting hundreds of cases of soldiers refusing repeat deployments to Ukraine since the beginning of April.

Several lawyers and human rights activists the BBC spoke to said they had been regularly offering advice to men trying to avoid returning to Ukraine. Each of our interviewees had dealt with dozens of cases and believed those soldiers were also sharing advice with their colleagues.
Although Sergey does not want to return to the front line
column2: he does want to complete his outstanding military service in Russia to avoid any unforeseen consequences. But that means that - while his letter of refusal to fight was accepted - there are no guarantees he won't be sent back to Ukraine during his service period.

column1: I can see that the war continues
column2: it is not going away
column3: he told the BBC. ""In these months [of compulsory military service] that I have left
column4: anything - including the worst - could happen."""

A lorry used to help evacuate civilians and deliver aid from Gloucester to Ukraine has been hit in an attack that killed a French journalist.
The 11-year-old silver Mercedes truck was attacked by Russian forces while evacuating civilians; despite being labelled a humanitarian aid vehicle.
A Ukrainian foreign ministry official said it was hit on Monday near the city of Severodonetsk in eastern Ukraine.
The truck had also been delivering baby food and medical equipment out there.
Gloucester City Councillor Alastair Chambers
column2: one of the volunteers who helped organise the relief effort
column3: told the Local Democracy Reporting service (LDRS) he was shocked to see pictures of the attack.

column1: He said: ""The lorry was picked up from Preston Fleet Services and then we drove it to Gloucester to fill it up with humanitarian aid.
Baby stuff
column2: things for elderly people
column3: food and equipment.

column1: We drove it into the Ukraine.
I handed the keys over to Ukrainians there who told me the lorry was going to be used for evacuations.
It's been evacuating people for the last three weeks from when we dropped it off.
At the same time
column2: we dropped off a lot of medical equipment for Mykolaiv hospital which included anaesthesia machines
column3: C-arm X-ray machines and other equipment.

column1: It's really devastating.
We've dropped off six vehicles
column2: so this is the first one we know of that has been attacked.

column1: Apparently
column2: my contacts think it was hit by shrapnel from a Russian missile. But I've also heard another story from a local who said it was hit by fire from a Russian BMPT Terminator vehicle.

column1: The vehicle is clearly marked out as humanitarian aid.

In its latest attempt to punish Russia for it invasion of Ukraine
column2: the European Union is to ban all imports of oil from Russia that are brought in by sea.

column1: It says this could cut the amount of oil that EU countries import from Russia by up to 90%
column2: reducing the amount of money the Russian government makes from oil sales.

column1: The EU
column2: along with countries such as the UK and the US
column3: have introduced a series of measures to weaken key areas of the Russian economy

column1: Sanctions are penalties imposed by one country on another
column2: to stop it acting aggressively
column3: or breaking international law.

column1: They are among the toughest actions nations can take

column1: Up until now
column2: EU states have been importing 2.2 million barrels per day (bpd) of crude oil from Russia and 1.2 million bpd of oil products.

column1: Given the soaring price of oil
column2: this has been earning Russia over $1m (£800
column3: 000) a day.

column1: They will continue
column2: on a temporary basis

column1: However

Flyers containing a phonetic version of the national song were handed out before the match and members of the Tartan Army sang along in solidarity.
It was Ukraine's first competitive game since the Russian invasion in February.
Amid remarkable scenes they defeated Scotland 3-1 and will now face Wales in Cardiff on Sunday for a place in Qatar.
The Ukraine players walked on to the pitch with the national flag draped round their shoulders before an emotionally charged rendition of the national anthem.
It was followed by a rousing chorus of Flower of Scotland before the match kicked off at 19:45.

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61618902;2022-05-29;Russia won't use tactical nuclear weapons in Ukraine
column2: says ambassador to UK;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.

column1: Russia's ambassador to Britain has told the BBC he does not believe his country will use tactical nuclear weapons in the war against Ukraine.
Andrei Kelin said that according to Russian military rules
column2: such weapons are not used in conflicts like this.

column1: He also described allegations of war crimes in the town of Bucha as ""a fabrication"".
And he called UK Foreign Secretary Liz Truss ""very belligerent"" and inexperienced.
On the use of nuclear weapons
column2: Mr Kelin said Russia has very strict rules for their use
column3: mainly when the state's existence is threatened.

column1: It has nothing to do with the current operation
column2: he told BBC One's Sunday Morning.

column1: When Vladimir Putin put his nuclear forces on high alert in late February
column2: soon after the invasion
column3: it was widely perceived as a warning.

column1: Mr Putin blamed the development on aggression by the West and Nato. But the UK's Defence Secretary Ben Wallace branded it an attempt to distract people from ""what's going wrong in Ukraine""
column2: saying Russia was behind schedule on its invasion after just a few days
column3: and trying to ""remind the world"" it had a deterrent.

column1: Tactical nuclear weapons are those which can be used at relatively short distances
column2: as opposed to ""strategic"" nuclear weapons which can be launched over much longer distances and raise the spectre of all-out nuclear war.

column1: But the term still includes many types of weapon
column2: including smaller bombs and missiles used on a battlefield. Russia is thought to have about 2
column3: 000 tactical nuclear weapons.

column1: The BBC's Clive Myrie asked the ambassador about comments made by UK Foreign Minister Liz Truss
column2: who said the war will only end once Russian President Vladimir Putin removes his troops entirely.

column1: Mr Kelin said Ms Truss was ""very belligerent"".
He said she was ""neither a professional military man"" nor experienced as foreign secretary. ""If she would like to continue the war she will prolongate the conflict
column2: he added.

column1: In a sometimes terse exchange
column2: the ambassador denied Russian forces were shelling civilians and said allegations of war crimes in the town of Bucha were a ""fabrication"".

column1: Asked the question
column2: ""Why is Russia conducting this war in this way
column3: committing war crimes?"" Mr Kelin replied: ""The mayor of Bucha in his initial statement has confirmed that Russian troops has left
column4: everything is clean and calm
column5: the town in a normal state.

column1: Nothing is happening
column2: no bodies are on the street. But next
column3: after it has been done - but anyway...""

column1: Myrie then pressed him: ""So this is all made up
column2: Sir? This is all a fabrication? All this evidence is a fabrication?""

column1: In our view it is a fabrication. It is used just to interrupt negotiations
column2: the ambassador replied.

column1: Russia has made such allegations before
column2: with Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov earlier claiming that footage of bodies in Bucha was ""staged"" after the Russians withdrew.

column1: This was contradicted by numerous eyewitness accounts from residents
column2: who told the BBC that Russian troops had summarily executed their loved ones.

column1: He was just a peaceful man
column2: a family man
column3: a welder
column4: who struggled with a spine fracture and was disabled all his life
column5: one man said of his murdered son-in-law.

column1: Satellite imagery also appears to directly contradict Moscow's position
column2: showing bodies lying in the street nearly two weeks before the Russians left the town.

column1: The ambassador was also asked about CCTV footage of Russian soldiers killing unarmed civilians in Ukraine.
Mr Kelin said the footage was ""probably a piece of a film or a piece of a game or a joke or whatever
column2: it's a computer games set"".

column1: What we heard from Russia's UK ambassador Andrei Kelin is what we've been hearing for years from Russian officials whenever their county is accused of anything.
All accusations are rebuffed
column2: all evidence of Russian complicity is dismissed.

column1: What you end up with is this parallel reality in which CCTV footage of Russian soldiers shooting dead unarmed Ukrainian civilians is dismissed as a joke or a computer game.
The horrors of Bucha are dismissed as a fabrication
column2: and the levelling of residential areas of Mariupol is brushed aside as either collateral damage or blamed on Ukrainian soldiers.

column1: In other words
column2: none of this is ever Russia's fault
column3: everyone is against Russia
column4: everyone is blaming Russia
column5: everyone is accusing Russia and it claims it is the innocent party.

column1: This is the Kremlin narrative which we've heard many times before.
We heard it after the Salisbury poisonings
column2: we heard it after the attempted assassination of the Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny and we're hearing it again now.

BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61441192;2022-05-28;War in Ukraine: The making of a new Russian propaganda machine;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
The port city of Berdyansk had been occupied by Russian troops for less than a week
column2: but a new pro-Kremlin online media outlet had already moved in.

column1: The company
column2: whose name translates as Southern Front
column3: makes and distributes pro-Vladimir Putin propaganda across YouTube
column4: social media app Telegram
column5: and through a website that targets areas newly under Russian control.

column1: The Southern Front news site posted its first message on day one of the Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: and now has several correspondents filing stories on a daily basis.

column1: The BBC has found evidence that the site's reporting contains falsehoods and misleading claims.
In early March
column2: Southern Front's correspondent was at the scene in Berdyansk. They reported that Russian soldiers had apparently thwarted an attack
column3: and killed two Moroccan men involved. The reporter alleged the men were working as mercenaries for Ukraine.  But it appears elements of the video were staged.

column1: The two Moroccan men identified in the attack were allegedly found with their Ukrainian residency permits still on them.
The BBC tracked down one of the men implicated. According to the report he was dead
column2: but we spoke to him on social media. He requested anonymity but says he was not aware of the Russian report and that he left Ukraine before the invasion and returned to Morocco.

column1: Southern Front regularly posts videos containing unsubstantiated claims.
The majority of the reports claim to show ""peaceful life"" has been established in occupied areas. The channel often runs stories that justify Russia's invasion.
In one video package
column2: a correspondent reports from a library where she says she found numerous examples of books containing ""Nazi symbols"". No evidence is seen on screen. The books that do appear on camera include works by contemporary Ukrainian writers about genuine historical events
column3: such as the battle of Ilovaisk.

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61627316;2022-05-30;Ukraine may soon get US long-range MLRS rocket system;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
The US government appears close to sending a long-range multiple-rocket system (MLRS) to Ukraine.
Russia sees such deliveries of heavy weapons as a provocative escalation.
President Volodymyr Zelensky and other Ukrainian officials have urged delivery of the MLRS to counter Russia's heavy bombardments in the eastern Donbas region.
But President Joe Biden said the US would not send Ukraine rocket systems ""that can strike into Russia"".
There are concerns that such action would risk drawing the US and its Nato allies into direct conflict with Moscow.
Moscow has welcomed President Biden's decision not to send weapons to Ukraine that could reach deep inside Russia.
Russia continues to pound Severodonetsk and other parts of Donbas with rockets
column2: tanks and air strikes.

column1: Kyiv's forces are already using US-delivered M777 howitzers
column2: which have a range of about 25km (16 miles). But the MLRS would allow Ukraine to reach targets much further away than that.

column1: An M270 MLRS battery can fire a range of munitions
column2: with the most advanced able to hit targets up to 300km (186 miles) away. However
column3: it can also fire shorter-range rockets with a range of around 70km (43 miles).

column1: Limiting Ukraine to the smaller rockets could be a way for the US to avoid escalating the conflict
column2: while still significantly improving Ukraine's arsenal.

column1: A senior US official quoted by the Washington Post said the White House was comfortable with giving Ukraine the MLRS
column2: but would withhold the longest range weapons compatible with the system.

column1: The UK also has the MLRS. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said Ukraine should get the rockets ""to defend themselves against this very brutal Russian artillery""
column2: but he did not say the UK would supply them.

column1: The US used the MLRS to destroy major Iraqi targets in the 1990-91 Gulf War and in 2003.
Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has accused the West of ""pumping up the Ukrainian nationalists with weapons"".
He said the West was ""waging a proxy war"" against Russia which
column2: he warned
column3: would mean ""inevitable escalation"".

column1: Last week
column2: a presenter on Russian state TV said the US would be crossing a ""red line"" by supplying the MLRS to Ukraine
column3: and it would be seen as an attempt to ""provoke a very harsh response from Russia"".

column1: In an extra move to defend Ukraine's key Black Sea port - Odesa - Denmark has supplied Harpoon anti-ship cruise missiles
column2: with a range of about 130km (70 nautical miles).

column1: Ukraine can deploy them alongside its own Neptune missiles
column2: credited with having sunk Russia's flagship cruiser Moskva last month.

column1: Russian long-range missiles have struck railway facilities
column2: oil depots and other infrastructure in western Ukraine - seen partly as an effort to thwart Western arms deliveries.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Russia is reported to have fired its latest multiple-rocket system against Ukrainian targets in the Kharkiv area - a weapon described as a giant flamethrower. Its use was reported by Tass news agency
column3: quoting a Russian security official.

Extra train services have been laid on for football fans travelling home from Scotland's semi-final play-off match against Ukraine on Wednesday.
ScotRail made the announcement hours after warning supporters travelling further than Glasgow city centre they were unlikely to get home by train.
Critics described the move as a ""U-turn... after a day of chaos"".

column1: Russia's military is pushing forward in Luhansk and Donetsk and digging in in areas of the south
column2: having taken control of the region of Kherson
column3: to the north and west of Crimea
column4: as well as part of Zaporizhzhia. Russia has already secured a land corridor from Crimea to the Russian border with the capture of Mariupol
column5: and it has control of the water supply to Crimea as well as Europe's biggest power plant.

column1: So would victory in Donbas be sufficient for Vladimir Putin?
It is impossible to know what he is thinking and what his relationship is with his military command
column2: says Sam Cranny-Evans of the Royal United Services Institute. But if Russia is successful in Luhansk and Donetsk
column3: then he believes Russia will assess the state of the Ukrainian forces: ""If the Russians feel that they are able to gain more of their stated goals
column4: I suspect they will go for them.""

column1: Leading Russian figures including Security Council Secretary Nikolai Patrushev have made clear they are not chasing deadlines but are prepared for a protracted war.
If they are successful in Donbas
column2: they may have designs on extending gains in the south. Russian troops have fired missiles at the big city of Zaporizhzhia and President Putin has signed a decree making it easier for citizens in Russian-occupied areas of the south to get Russian passports.

column1: One Russian general has suggested the aim is to conquer Ukraine's Black Sea coast to the west beyond Odesa
column2: but for now that seems little more than an aspiration.

column1: For weeks Russian forces have bombarded Severodonetsk and Lysychansk and Ukrainian forces have retreated from Lyman. They have also broken through at Popasna and are threatening key Ukrainian arterial routes and supply lines
column2: particularly the roads from Lysychansk to Bakhmut and the major M03 motorway from Slovyansk to Bakhmut.

column1: The battle for Luhansk has entered a decisive phase
column2: says regional military administration head Serhiy Haidai.

column1: Many of these towns have already experienced years of war since Russia's proxies first seized large parts of Donbas. Severodonetsk is normally a city of 100
column2: 000 people - 15
column3: 000 were still there
column4: mainly in bomb shelters
column5: as Russian troops advanced in late May.

column1: Maryna Agafonova
column3: fled her family's home in Lysychansk weeks before: ""They attacked hospitals and residential buildings
column4: she said.

column1: Another big target down the M03 road is Slovyansk
column2: a city of 125
column3: 000 people that was seized by Russian-backed forces in 2014 before being recaptured. Capturing Kramatorsk
column4: just to the south
column5: is also a big objective.

column1: But Russian progress has been slow and Ukrainian defence officials believe they are running low on high-precision weapons.
This is a big territory to control
column2: and I think we shouldn't underestimate the geographical complexities of this
column3: says Tracey German
column4: professor in conflict and security at King's College London.

column1: The Russians have already succeeded in blocking most rail traffic to the east. That was the fastest route for fleeing civilians but also the most effective transport for Ukrainian troops and heavy weaponry. Train lines in and out of Donbas have been cut and the only services remaining are going to Pokrovsk.
Serhiy Haidai believes Russia's leader is now determined to capture the Luhansk region
column2: no matter what the cost - in money
column3: soldiers' lives or military equipment.

column1: At the start of the war
column2: the 10 brigades that made up Ukraine's Joint Forces Operation (JFO) in the east were regarded as the best-equipped and best-trained soldiers that Ukraine has.

column1: President Zelensky revealed on 22 May that between 50 to 100 soldiers may be dying every day in their defence of eastern Ukraine. That would indicate an even larger number of wounded and Sam Cranny-Evans believes it is likely that some brigades are no longer combat effective.
It is hard to assess whether or not they are in a good place right now. If the above attrition rates are accurate
column2: it could be very problematic.""

column1: US officials have estimated that some 93 Russian battalion tactical groups were operating in the east
column2: each numbering 700 to 900 men. But they too have suffered from high losses and low morale. Their units are made up of men enlisted from the local separatist areas
column3: many under duress
column4: as well as the broader Russian army.

column1: Russia studies analyst Michael Kofman says the military balance in the war overall weighs in Ukraine's favour
column2: because of manpower availability and access to Western military support
column3: but in Donbas it is too early to say how the war will go: ""Ukraine may lose territory in the short term
column4: but Russia faces major problems with sustaining its military effort in the long term
column5: or holding on to gains"".

column1: That is why Ukraine is calling on its Western allies to speed up deliveries of heavy weapons including long-range artillery.
Life in the Russian proxy-held areas of Ukraine is far quieter than elsewhere in the east
column2: although the so-called people's republics have accused Ukrainian forces of shelling residential buildings and killing civilians. Officials in the Donetsk statelet say dozens of civilians have died since mid-February. Far more have been killed in Russian attacks on Ukrainian-controlled territory.

column1: One woman in Luhansk told the BBC on condition of anonymity that men of military age were required to join the local Russian proxy militia
column2: so anyone who wanted to avoid mobilisation was in hiding. People called it ""mogilisation"" after the Russian word mogila which means grave
column3: she said.

column1: There are many dead and many funerals. Wives often do not know anything about the fate of their mobilised husbands.""
Asked about the prospect of a vote on joining Russia
column2: she said people understood they had no real say in the matter: ""It's like a train you can't get off."""

column2: her job and her friends behind due to the war.

column1: Her grandparents had told her stories of starvation from the past
column2: and when supermarket shelves began to empty
column3: she became ""very scared"".

column1: She is dependent on medication and began her journey to Wales in early March
column2: spending nights on train station floors
column3: camping and sleeping on people's sofas.

column1: Oksana wants to work and rent her own home
column2: but while waiting for a bank account and job responses
column3: she said she had no choice but to live in the accommodation provided for her.

column1: Originally from Donetsk

column1: However
column2: she said she was asked to leave abruptly after discussions about veganism and animal by-products
column3: such as leather.

column1: Since then she has been trying to find a home that caters to her needs but said it had been a challenge.
With like 6% of Wales vegan and then those willing to take me on
column2: my chances are probably under 1%
column3: she said.

column1: Oksana said she feels ""traumatised"" watching people eat meat.

column2: but cannot share a fridge with non-vegans or be in the room when they are cooking or eating animal products.

column1: I will have my own fridge I will keep in my room and I going to pay them for electricity

column2: so finding somewhere they can feel safe and respected in an otherwise unfamiliar community

column2: and urged him to launch ""direct

column1: A couple trying to sponsor a refugee boy stuck in Holland say Boris Johnson's open letter to Ukrainian children is ""galling and hypocritical"".
Seventeen-year-old Andrii has been ""in limbo"" in the Netherlands for two months with his sponsor Joseph Kleijnen due to visa processing delays.
He said he felt ""forgotten"" after Mr Johnson told the children of Ukraine ""we in the UK will never forget you"".
The government said it was ""doing all we can to support new arrivals"".
I don't see any deeds that are actually approving what he said in that letter
column2: said the teenager
column3: whose parents are both military doctors in Ukraine.

column1: I haven't heard anything from the United Kingdom in the past two months.""
Mr Kleijnen
column3: who lives in Sunk Island
column4: East Yorkshire
column5: with his wife Jeanette
column7: added: ""[They are] very empty words.

column1: It would be much more helpful if Andrii and the many
column2: many other children who are in his position would actually get their visa and be in a safe and secure place.""

column1: Andrii fled Ukraine alone hours after bombs landed near his hometown of Volodymyr-Volynskyi
column2: the same day the couple applied to sponsor him under the Homes4Ukraine scheme.

column1: Mr Kleijnen flew to Amsterdam on 22 March to collect him after submitting a visa application and the pair have since been stuck in the Dutch country.
All three said they were ""fed up
column2: frustrated and just really disillusioned with this whole process""
column3: with Mrs Kleijnen describing it as being ""an abyss"".

column1: She said Wednesday was the first time they had received any communication from the Home Office
column2: which informed them Andrii's application had ""now been passed to the decision-making centre"".

column1: What that means and what the next step is
column2: we have no idea
column3: she said. ""I don't know what the end is.""

column1: In a letter tweeted on Monday
column2: the prime minister told the children of Ukraine ""you are not alone"".

column1: It was galling to read the letter that Boris Johnson penned
column2: said Mrs Kleijnen.

column1: What does that mean if we can't help somebody who's got a valid application and he's trying to get into this country with valid sponsors who've been checked and our home has been checked.
We have everything in place and nothing is happening.
It's frustrating
column2: it's hypocritical and it's irritating and I'm trying not to get angry.""

column1: The couple
column2: who were appointed as Andrii's guardians
column3: said they thought the visa application would be processed quicker in the Netherlands than in Ukraine's neighbouring country
column4: Poland.

column1: The Home Office said: ""115
column2: 000 visas have now been issued showing the work we've done to speed up the process is working and improving daily.""

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61583492;2022-05-25;How can Ukraine export its harvest to the world?;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
Ukrainian farmers have 20 million tonnes of grain they cannot get to international markets
column2: and a new harvest is about to begin. What can be done to get the food to people who desperately need it
column3: as prices soar around the world?

column1: In early February
column2: Nadiya Stetsiuk was looking forward to a profitable year. The weather had been good in 2021 and she saw bumper harvests of corn
column3: wheat and sunflower seeds on her small farm in Ukraine's central Cherkasy region.

column1: Prices on the international market were high and rising every day so she held on to some of her stock
column2: to sell later. Then Russia attacked.

column1: Her region hasn't seen the worst of the fighting - like 80% of the country's farmland
column2: it's still under Ukrainian control - but the impact on her farm has been profound.

column1: Since the invasion

column2: as it battles Russian forces in the east of the country.

column1: The prime minister said Russian troops are ""continuing to chew through ground"" in the Donbas region
column2: making ""slow

column1: Thousands of frontline Ukrainian troops are now using weapons and other equipment supplied by the UK.

column1: The UK has sent more than 5
column2: 000 next generation light anti-tank weapons
column3: or Nlaw
column4: to Ukraine.

column1: Nlaws are designed to destroy tanks at short range with a single shot.
Crucially for Ukraine's armed forces who need weapons immediately
column2: the missiles are easy to transport and simple to use. A soldier can be trained to use them in less than a day.

column1: Many analysts believe they have already had a major impact on the course of the conflict.
Nlaw was absolutely critical to the defeat of Russian ground thrusts in the early stages of the war
column2: says Justin Bronk
column3: of the Royal United Services Institute.

column1: The weapons have been ""particularly effective"" when used in combination with artillery
column2: he says.

column1: He points to successful strikes on tank columns
column2: where Nlaws have destroyed the front vehicles
column3: trapping those to the rear for targeting with artillery.

column1: Defence Minister James Heappey confirmed that ""hundreds"" of Brimstone missiles would be sent to Ukraine on 28 April.
Brimstones can be used against tanks
column2: artillery and some smaller vessels such as landing craft

column1: The missiles are normally fired from aircraft
column2: but in Ukraine they are being modified to be fired from trucks.

column1: Launching them from the ground reduces their effective range
column2: says Capt Carlson.

column1: If used as anti-ship missiles
column2: Brimstones are far too small to sink larger vessels
column3: but could cause substantial damage.

column1: It all depends where you hit

column1: Britain has donated 120 armoured vehicles to Ukraine

column2: Mastiffs are likely to be very useful.

column1: It is understood that both sides in the conflict have used landmines extensively

column1: The Ministry of Defence says it is supplying ""dozens"" of heavy lift unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) systems to provide logistical support to isolated forces.

column1: Britain says it has donated five air defence systems
column2: including Starstreak missiles.

From a pilot's point of view
column2: Starstreak is a very unpleasant thing
column3: says Mr Bronk. ""There's very little you can do about it.""

column1: He says Russian forces may deem some operations too risky if they are aware that a weapon as deadly as Starstreak is on the ground.

column5: for longer-range air defence systems.

column1: Britain is also supplying a ""small number"" of tracked Stormer vehicles to act as a mobile platform for Starstreak missiles.

column2: weapons and ammunition will be extremely important to the Ukrainians in the longer term

column4: of the International Institute of Strategic Studies.

column1: He says that although Ukraine has some weapons manufacturing capacity of its own
column2: it will be difficult for its troops to take significant territory back from Russian forces without substantial outside support.

column1: Military professionals point out that Ukraine's need is largely for equipment which its troops already know how to use
column2: or can be trained on very quickly.

column1: Much of Ukraine's weaponry was designed and manufactured in former Warsaw Pact eastern European countries.
For this reason
column2: the UK has offered to send British Challenger 2 tanks to Poland to backfill its donations of T-72 tanks to Ukraine.

column1: Ukraine's armed forces have been using T-72s for decades and have maintenance and spare parts capabilities
column2: in addition to trained crew.

A court in Ukraine has jailed a Russian tank commander for life for killing a civilian at the first war crimes trial since the conflict began.
Ukraine says it has identified more than 10
column2: 000 possible war crimes
column3: However
column4: the Russian government denies it has been targeting civilians.

column1: The International Criminal Court has also sent a team of investigators and forensics experts to the country.
It may not seem like it
column2: but ""even war has rules""
column3: as the International Committee of the Red Cross puts it.

column1: These are contained in treaties called the Geneva Conventions and a string of other international laws and agreements.
Civilians cannot be deliberately attacked - nor can the infrastructure that is vital to their survival.
Some weapons are banned because of the indiscriminate or appalling suffering they cause - such as anti-personnel landmines and chemical or biological weapons.
The sick and wounded must be cared for - including injured soldiers
column2: who have rights as prisoners of war.

column1: Serious offences such as murder
column2: rape or mass persecution of a group are known as ""crimes against humanity"" or
column3: in some circumstances
column4: ""genocide"".

column1: The 21-year-old Russian tank commander Vadim Shishimarin admitted shooting 62-year-old Oleksandr Shelipov in the head
column2: a few days after the invasion began.

column1: Sentencing Shishimarin
column2: the judge said he had committed ""a crime against peace
column3: security
column4: humanity and the international legal order"" and that only a life sentence was appropriate.

column1: Ukraine is preparing cases against 41 Russian soldiers for offences including killing civilians
column2: rape
column3: bombing civilian infrastructure and looting.

column1: US President Joe Biden and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson have both accused Russia of carrying out war crimes in Ukraine.
Investigators and journalists found what appeared to be evidence of the deliberate killing of civilians in Bucha
column2: a town on the outskirts of Kyiv
column3: and other nearby areas.

column1: Ukrainian forces said they found mass graves and evidence that civilians had been killed after their feet and hands were bound.
In March
column2: a Russian strike on a theatre in Mariupol appeared to be the first confirmed location of a mass killing. The word ""children"" was written in giant letters outside the building.

column1: Ukraine previously called Russia's air strike on Mariupol's hospital a war crime.
Many experts argue the invasion itself is a crime under the concept of ""aggressive warfare"".
There have been a series of one-off courts since World War Two - including the tribunal investigating war crimes during the 1990s break-up of Yugoslavia.
A body was also set up to prosecute those responsible for the 1994 Rwanda genocide.
Today
column2: the International Criminal Court (ICC) and the International Court of Justice (ICJ) both have roles upholding the rules of war.

column1: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) rules on disputes between states
column2: but cannot prosecute individuals. Ukraine has begun a case against Russia.

column1: If the ICJ ruled against Russia
column2: the UN Security Council (UNSC) would be responsible for enforcing that.

column1: But Russia - one of council's five permanent members - could veto any proposal to sanction it.
The International Criminal Court (ICC) investigates and prosecutes individual war criminals who are not before the courts of individual states.
It's the permanent modern successor to Nuremberg
column2: which prosecuted key Nazi leaders in 1945.

column1: Nuremberg cemented the principle that nations could set up special courts to uphold international law.
The ICC's chief prosecutor
column2: British lawyer Karim Khan QC
column3: believes there is a reasonable basis to believe war crimes have been carried out in Ukraine.

column1: Investigators will look at past and present allegations - going back as far as 2013
column2: before Russia's annexation of Crimea from Ukraine.

column1: If there's evidence
column2: the prosecutor will ask ICC judges to issue arrest warrants to bring individuals to trial in The Hague.

column1: However the court doesn't have its own police force so relies on individual states to arrest suspects - and since Russia is not a member of the court it is unlikely to extradite any suspects.
It's far easier to pin a war crime on the soldier who commits it
column2: than the leader who ordered it.

column1: Hugh Williamson of Human Rights Watch - an organisation with expertise in gathering evidence of war crimes in conflicts - agrees there is evidence of summary executions and other grave abuses by Russian forces.
He says establishing the ""chain of command"" is very important for any future trials - including whether a leader authorised an atrocity - or turned a blind eye to it.
The ICC can also prosecute the offence of ""waging aggressive war"". This is the crime of an unjustified invasion or conflict
column2: beyond justifiable military action in self-defence.

column1: It originated at Nuremberg
column2: after the judge sent by Moscow convinced the Allies that Nazi leaders should face justice for ""crimes against peace"".

column4: says the ICC couldn't prosecute Russia's leaders for this because the country isn't a signatory to the court.

A British man who fled Kyiv with his family says his Ukrainian wife is in distress because her therapy dog has been stuck in quarantine for weeks.
Mike Haley
column3: fled the war-torn country with his wife Alla
column5: and her 81-year-old mother Valentyna.

column1: They travelled more than 2
column2: 000 miles with Pomeranian Archie

column1: But the couple
column2: now in Newcastle

column1: Mr Haley
column2: originally from Jarrow
column3: had been working as an English teacher and translator when the war started in February.

column1: The family sheltered in the corridor of their apartment for eight days - during which time Mr Haley was kicked down a flight of a stairs and his friend was shot - before they got a train out of Kyiv.
After travelling via Poland to Amsterdam they sailed to North Shields with Archie
column2: who they said helped keep their spirits up by giving them ""something else to focus on"".

column1: But on arriving in the UK
column2: the dog was held by the Animal and Plant Health Agency
column3: they said.

column1: Officials said although he had been microchipped and vaccinated there was a technical problem with his rabies inoculation
column2: which happened before he was chipped
column3: the couple said.

column1: The body
column2: overseen by Defra
column3: ensures animals coming in to the UK are rabies-free and Archie was given a second inoculation after he arrived.

column1: The Haleys said they were worried about whether having two doses close together would be safe because Archie is a small dog.

Mr Haley said the uncertainty was ""like torture"" for his wife and was making her sick.
We came 2
column2: 000 miles with him
column3: he said.

column1: He was given a clean bill of health in Holland and checked over - we'd made sure he'd had all his vaccinations.

A Defra spokesman said they could not discuss individual cases but said: ""We have increased resources and streamlined processes to ensure those fleeing Ukraine and entering the UK are not delayed by bringing their pets.

column1: They travelled more than 2
column2: 000 miles with Pomeranian Archie
column3: who helps Mrs Haley manage panic attacks.

column1: But the couple
column2: now in Newcastle
column3: said red tape over vaccination issues meant the dog could not join them.

column1: Mr Haley
column2: originally from Jarrow
column3: had been working as an English teacher and translator when the war started in February.

column1: The family sheltered in the corridor of their apartment for eight days - during which time Mr Haley was kicked down a flight of a stairs and his friend was shot - before they got a train out of Kyiv.
After travelling via Poland to Amsterdam they sailed to North Shields with Archie
column2: who they said helped keep their spirits up by giving them ""something else to focus on"".

column1: But on arriving in the UK
column2: the dog was held by the Animal and Plant Health Agency
column3: they said.

column1: Officials said although he had been microchipped and vaccinated there was a technical problem with his rabies inoculation
column2: which happened before he was chipped
column3: the couple said.

column1: The body
column2: overseen by Defra
column3: ensures animals coming in to the UK are rabies-free and Archie was given a second inoculation after he arrived.

column1: The Haleys said they were worried about whether having two doses close together would be safe because Archie is a small dog.
They said he had so far been held - 240 miles away in Aberdeen - for seven weeks and they were having difficulty finding out what is going on.
Mr Haley said the uncertainty was ""like torture"" for his wife and was making her sick.
We came 2
column2: 000 miles with him
column3: he said.

column1: He was given a clean bill of health in Holland and checked over - we'd made sure he'd had all his vaccinations.
This little dog gave positive emotions to everybody
column2: and then he was just taken away when we arrived.

column1: This is torment.""

A Defra spokesman said they could not discuss individual cases but said: ""We have increased resources and streamlined processes to ensure those fleeing Ukraine and entering the UK are not delayed by bringing their pets.
We have introduced a new rapid rabies blood test to cut quarantine times and lower-risk animals are being moved into isolation.""

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-61575387;2022-05-26;Ukraine war: World Bank boss warns over global recession;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
The head of the World Bank has warned that Russia's invasion of Ukraine could cause a global recession as the price of food
column2: energy and fertiliser jump.

column1: David Malpass told a US business event on Wednesday that it is difficult to ""see how we avoid a recession"".
He also said that a series of coronavirus lockdowns in China is adding to concerns about a slowdown.
His comments are the latest warning over the rising risk that the world economy may be set to contract.
As we look at the global GDP... it's hard right now to see how we avoid a recession
column2: Mr Malpass said
column3: without giving a specific forecast.

column1: The idea of energy prices doubling is enough to trigger a recession by itself
column2: he added.

column1: Last month
column2: the World Bank cut its global economic growth forecast for this year by almost a full percentage point

column1: GDP
column2: or Gross Domestic Product
column3: is a measure of economic growth. It is one of the most important ways of measuring how well
column4: or badly
column5: an economy is performing and is closely watched by economists and central banks.

column1: It helps businesses to judge when to expand and recruit more workers or invest less and cut their workforces.
Governments also use it to guide decisions on everything from tax to spending. It is a key gauge
column2: along with inflation
column3: for central banks when considering whether or not to raise or lower interest rates.

column1: Mr Malpass also said that many European countries were still too dependent on Russia for oil and gas.
That's even as Western nations push ahead with plans to reduce their dependence on Russian energy.
He also told a virtual event organised by the US Chamber of Commerce that moves by Russia to cut gas supplies could cause a ""substantial slowdown"" in the region.
He said higher energy prices were already weighing on Germany
column2: which is the biggest economy in Europe and the fourth largest in the world.

column1: Developing countries are also being affected by shortages of fertiliser
column2: food and energy
column3: Mr Malpass said.

column1: Mr Malpass also raised concerns about lockdowns in some of China's major cities - including the financial
column2: manufacturing and shipping hub of Shanghai - which he said are ""still having ramifications or slowdown impacts on the world"".

column1: China was already going through some contraction of real estate
column2: so the forecast of China's growth before Russia's invasion had already softened substantially for 2022
column3: he said.

column1: Then the waves of Covid caused lockdowns which further reduced growth expectations for China
column2: he added.

column1: Also on Wednesday
column2: China's premier Li Keqiang said the world's second largest economy had been hit harder by the latest round of lockdowns than it had been at the start of the pandemic in 2020.

column1: He also called for more action by officials to restart factories after lockdowns.
Progress is not satisfactory
column2: Mr Li said. ""Some provinces are reporting that only 30% of businesses have reopened… the ratio must be raised to 80% within a short period of time.""

column1: Full or partial lockdowns were imposed in dozens of Chinese cities in March and April
column2: including a long shutdown of Shanghai.

column1: The measures have led to a sharp slowdown in economic activity across the country.
In recent weeks
column2: official figures have shown that large parts of economy have been impacted
column3: from manufacturers to retailers.

BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-61528087;2022-05-25;Prince Charles arrives in Romania to meet Ukraine refugees;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
The Prince of Wales has arrived in Romania to show his support for Ukrainian refugees and to see first-hand the assistance being provided.
It's the first visit from a senior royal to the region since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
The latest figures show almost a million Ukrainians have already crossed the border into Romania.
Prince Charles visited a centre near Bucharest
column2: which supports a rising number of refugees.

column1: It's a nightmare situation
column2: the prince said to Ukrainian families who were collecting supplies of food and clothing.

column1: He said to ""keep praying"" and told them he was ""full of admiration for the Ukrainian people - their extraordinary courage and resilience"".
Aid workers explained the scale of the pressures.
More than six million people have left Ukraine in the three months of the war. In the past week alone
column2: a further 40
column3: 000 people are estimated to have crossed into Romania.

column1: Prince Charles has been strongly outspoken about the war
column2: attacking the ""brutal aggression"" inflicted on Ukraine. Having travelled to Bucharest
column3: about 150 miles from the Ukraine border - this is also the closest a senior British royal has come to the conflict.

column1: The prince also has a long-standing connection with Romania
column2: having set up a charitable foundation in the country and restored a traditional farmhouse.

column1: The visit comes as figures from the UNHCR show 966
column2: 000 Ukrainians have entered Romania since the start of the war
column3: with only Poland taking in more refugees.

column1: I've not seen anything so big and so fast. By any measure it's a major movement of people
column2: says Mike Weickert
column3: global rapid response director for World Vision
column4: a charity supporting Ukrainian refugees in Romania.

column1: It's going to be increasingly difficult for refugees and for the hosting countries
column2: said Mr Weickert
column3: whose aid agency is working in the Romexpo centre
column4: visited by Prince Charles and Margareta
column5: head of Romania's royal family.

column1: The conference centre site is helping more than 1
column2: 000 people a day
column3: with Romanian authorities and international agencies providing food
column4: clothing and advice services.

column1: Among those helping with the international effort at the centre is Stephen Noble of the Salvation Army.
He spent the pandemic helping with a food bank in Scarborough
column2: and there are some similarities to the services being offered here
column3: with food parcels available and racks of second-hand clothing.

column1: There are soft toys for children and pet food for the dogs and cats that some families brought with them.
Mr Noble has been struck by the dignity of those arriving
column2: who had to leave everything behind - and says that for those in the UK who have made donations it is ""absolutely worthwhile"".

column1: He says one of the most practical ways of supporting refugees has been to give them vouchers
column2: worth about £10
column3: to use in local supermarkets
column4: which allows them to buy for their individual needs.

column1: One of the translators is herself a refugee. Lisa has gone from being a sales manager in Odessa to helping disorientated new arrivals.
At first it's a shock. You don't believe it. Then you realise you have to stay."" So many people have left Ukraine that in some villages there is only one person left
column2: she says.

column1: For those refugees continuing to stream across the border into Romania
column2: by car
column3: bus or train
column4: there is still a generous reception.

column1: At Bucharest's Gara de Nord train station there are volunteers and support workers waiting to help families escaping the war.
Romania has given Ukrainian refugees free travel on its railways
column2: with women and children the great majority of new arrivals. On the station concourse there are tents ready to provide immediate shelter and first aid.

column1: This is a refugee crisis in a highly-mobile
column2: urban setting.

column1: Many are moving on to other countries
column2: some will try to return to Ukraine
column3: and those that stay in Romania are mostly in the bigger cities
column4: with spaces having to be found in hostels
column5: private houses
column6: public buildings or hotel rooms.

column1: As well as emergency needs
column2: such as food and shelter
column3: aid workers say they will need to provide longer-term support for refugees.

column1: Children will need schools
column2: adults will need jobs to have an income
column3: older people with health problems will need access to medical support and there will be mental health problems from such a traumatic uprooting.

column1: The longer refugees are out of their homes the more they risk ""running out money
column2: running out of options""

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61571895;2022-05-25;Ukraine: The fallen Russian soldiers left behind;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
Weeks after Russian forces were pushed back from their attempt to take the Ukrainian capital
column2: Kyiv
column3: the bodies of many dead Russian soldiers still lie abandoned.

column1: Some were buried by Ukrainian villagers in shallow graves; others have been exhumed and are now stacking up in refrigerated train carriages. Ukraine says Russia shows no interest in getting its bodies back."

BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61571855;2022-05-25;Ukraine war: Bodies of dead Russian soldiers abandoned near Kyiv;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
When their dogs started digging insistently at a spot in the woods
column2: villagers in Zavalivka called in the authorities.

column1: A Ukrainian military team were soon at the scene in white protective suits
column2: carefully removing the topsoil.

column1: They uncovered a man's body
column2: face down with his legs oddly twisted beneath him. It was clear from his uniform that he was a Russian soldier.

column1: Weeks after they failed to seize Ukraine's capital
column2: the remains of Russian troops are still being discovered in and around the villages they passed through or occupied near the capital
column3: Kyiv. But Ukraine says Russia shows little interest in getting them back.

column1: From the grave in the woods
column2: the body was removed to a refrigerated train on the outskirts of Kyiv that now operates as a mobile morgue for the Russian dead.

column1: The white plastic sacks are marked with numbers rather than names and there were at least 137 stacked inside two carriages on the day we visited.
The Ukrainians attempt to identify the dead: on the body just brought in
column2: the forensics team turned up two bank cards
column3: as well as badges for a Russian motorised rifle brigade.

column1: At least this one has a chance of getting home
column2: the man in charge announced
column3: displaying the finds
column4: including a soiled fragment of T-shirt printed with the Army of Russia logo.

column1: Moments later
column2: I confirmed that the man I had just seen exhumed had been a young
column3: married soldier from Siberia. Next to his body bag
column4: a carefully posed black-and-white photograph from his social media profile stared out from my phone.

column1: Russia has a proud slogan: ""We don't abandon our own."" It's a big part of President Vladimir Putin's supposed justification for invading Ukraine
column2: where he falsely claimed Russian-speakers needed protection.

column1: That pledge appears not to apply so much to Russia's own soldiers.
The bodies we've found show they treat people as rubbish
column2: as cannon fodder
column3: Col Volodymyr Liamzin told the BBC. ""They don't need their soldiers. They throw them here
column4: retreat - and leave the bodies.""

column1: We don't actually know how the young soldier in the woods came to be abandoned. The villagers in Zavalivka say they were mostly hiding in their cellars from shelling at the time - they assume he was injured and got lost as his unit was forced to retreat.
From what we've learned of the Russian troops fighting around Kyiv
column2: many were young and inexperienced. It's likely they were fleeing under fire.

column1: We did do one swap
column2: Col Liamzin says
column3: explaining that the Russian side provided a shortlist of the dead soldiers it wanted returned.

column1: We're ready to give them all back
column2: we want our own dead returned too. We knock on every door there is
column3: but there is no response
column4: no dialogue
column5: the colonel says.

column1: The delay in collecting bodies isn't unique to Russia.

Neither side in this war is open about the number of casualties suffered. We've spoken to several Ukrainian families who say their own government has been less than helpful in recovering the remains of Ukrainian soldiers from the battlefield.
One woman
column2: who was told of her husband's death by the men in his unit
column3: said she had been trying to recover his body for almost three months.

column1: But the Russian dead are being discovered here all the time.
Just up the road from Zavalivka in Sytnyaky
column2: the village elder told us at least 10 Russian soldiers were killed and left behind in March
column3: probably more.

column1: Their column was ambushed after they lost their way: the locals had removed and switched the traffic signs.
The battle was fierce. What was once a roadside restaurant at the spot is now a heap of rubble
column2: a bit of wall and a giant aquarium that somehow survived the assault.

column1: Leaflets in the ruins call on Russian soldiers to surrender and save their lives
column2: and spare the blood of Ukrainian children.

column1: The village elder says he and others buried the Russians after the battle ""for sanitary reasons"". When I look quizzical
column2: he says most were blown to pieces.

column1: He wasn't allowed to show us the graves: they constitute a crime scene until Col Liamzin's team can get round to visiting and exhuming the site. But his dig-list is already long.
A local man planting beetroot confirms that the Russians were killed along the main road.
It's not humane to abandon a soldier
column2: not to bury them
column3: Mikola says
column4: leaning on his spade. His own son is in Ukraine's army.

column1: My wife felt sorry for the Russians at first
column2: but then we found out what they did here
column3: he adds
column4: referring to the shooting of unarmed civilians in places like Bucha and Irpin.

column1: No-one feels sorry for the Russians after that.""
The burned wrecks of Russian tanks still line all the main roads into Kyiv. Every few seconds
column2: cars stop and families spill out to take photographs
column3: children clambering over the top.

column1: It seems somehow cathartic. The other day
column2: I watched a man working out by lifting a tank barrel up and down
column3: over his head
column4: as though he was doing weights.

column1: But that same day
column2: just a few steps across the road
column3: we spotted human remains on a scorched patch of verge - a charred piece of spine and a fragment of foot - and a sweet
column4: deathly smell when the wind dropped. It was most likely one of the men killed in one of the nearby tanks.

column1: So the refrigerated train in Kyiv is still filling up
column2: and there are more in other cities close to the fighting. For the Ukrainian military who recover and store the bodies
column3: there is little sympathy: the dead are enemy soldiers - invaders.

column1: But in Russia
column2: someone
column3: somewhere must be looking for each one of them.

column2: suitable and dignified"".

column2: some of whom may arrive with complex needs given the horrors they may have experienced.

column2: to ensure visas can be granted to Ukrainian beneficiaries.""

column1: People who put themselves forward as sponsors will be contacted

column2: and people flooded the streets waving Ukrainian flags.

column1: When the Russians started cracking down on the protesters

column1: Melitopol

column2: two Russian soldiers were found dead in the street. Last month a bridge near Melitopol - used to deliver supplies to the Russian army - was blown up.

column1: Ivan Fedorov
column2: the mayor of Melitopol
column3: says these attacks were organised by partisan groups. ""It's the job of our partisans
column4: our secret services and our soldiers. They do this job together

column2: residents say
column3: often at random.

column1: On 29 April
column2: armed men in military uniform with white armbands - the marking used by Russian soldiers - abducted Boris Kleshev
column3: the head of a local fire brigade in Melitopol.

column1: For two weeks his relatives heard nothing about his whereabouts. A few days ago

column1: Mr Kleshev was speaking with a low voice

column3: those who made the video were unlikely to have cared - their aim is to break the resistance spreading through Melitopol.

column1: These resistance groups

column3: chanting: ""Melitopol is Ukraine.""

column1: Russian forces were truly shocked to see that the local population was not happy to see them. Those soldiers really believed that they were liberators

column3: who lives in Melitopol.

column1: A few weeks after the invasion
column2: police from Rosgvardia - Russia's national guard - arrived to crack down on the protests. They started dispersing crowds and detaining activists.

column2: the military in Melitopol have been trying to win people's hearts and minds. ""We have the brand of 'polite people'""
column3: Iryna jokes
column4: referring to the term used to describe Russian soldiers when Moscow annexed Crimea in 2014.

column1: These are ordinary guys who look like us and try to be nice
column2: she explains. ""They help elderly women and show that they care about people. But they can't realise that it was them who created all these troubles and that our people didn't beg for help before.""

column1: In order to create a perception of normality
column2: the Russian forces try to silence anyone who openly opposes them.

column2: First Deputy Prime Minister of Ukraine

column2: who is also Ukraine's Minister of the Economy

column1: And to make it

A same-sex couple who fled Ukraine have been welcomed into a home in Derbyshire after a woman and her wife offered to host LGBT refugees.

One of the refugees
column2: Tetiana
column3: said living in the town of Belper was like being ""inside some English TV show"".

column1: The BBC is not using photos of the couple as they were not openly in a relationship in Ukraine.
Sarah Barley-McMullen
column2: who is hosting them with her wife Helen
column3: said LGBT couples face more discrimination in Ukraine than they do in the UK.

column1: You are going against the family tradition and the Russian Orthodox Church
column2: said Mrs Barley-McMullen
column3: who is chair of Pride in Belper.

column1: You will then be accused of trying to destroy the culture and the identity of the country.
It's so important that LGBT people from Ukraine are able to come to the UK and feel safe
column2: often for the first time in their lives.""

column1: Tetiana said she and her partner Yulia were struck by how beautiful their new home is.

column3: maybe Murder She Wrote
column4: maybe Agatha Christie
column5: she said.

To Ukrainians it was clear from the very start of Russia's invasion that this was no ""special operation"" to liberate the Donbas region
column2: as Vladimir Putin had declared. It was all-out war.

column1: But in Russia it's a crime to call it that.
Dozens of people have already been prosecuted under the ""fake news"" law
column2: as it's known. They face up to 15 years behind bars for challenging the official line on Russia's invasion or criticising the military.

column1: It's a dramatic increase in censorship in Russia
column2: where Vladimir Putin has spent his two decades in power removing opponents
column3: stifling free speech and silencing the independent media: a dismantling of democracy that is having devastating consequences here in Ukraine.

column1: Vladimir Kara-Murza tried to warn of the danger.
In a speech in the US in March
column2: the Russian opposition activist lambasted Western leaders for seeking constant ""resets"" in relations with Mr Putin
column3: allowing their countries to act as havens for tainted money and looking the other way even as Russia became ever less free.

column1: The whole world now sees what the Putin regime is doing to Ukraine
column2: Mr Kara-Murza told the Arizona House of Representatives
column3: a fortnight into the war. ""The bombing of maternity wards and hospitals and schools. The war crimes. These are war crimes.""

column1: But in Russia uttering such words is also a crime now.
A month after his speech
column2: Mr Kara-Murza was picked up by police in Moscow and later charged with ""spreading false information"" about Russia's military. He's still in custody. The law he is accused of breaking was passed in March
column3: soon after the invasion.

column1: And yet Ukrainian prosecutors have already registered more than 11
column2: 000 alleged war crimes. A Russian soldier has admitted in court to shooting a civilian. And the BBC has gathered its own evidence
column3: including CCTV footage of the shooting of two civilians by Russian forces.

column2: powerful testimony.

column1: When Russia invaded Ukraine
column2: many families fled Kyiv for nearby villages like this
column3: thinking they would be safer away from the capital. Instead they spent weeks cowering in cold cellars as occupying soldiers drove tanks into their yards and dug trenches in their vegetable plots.

column1: After the Russians withdrew
column2: in April
column3: the village elder says the bodies of 13 residents were found here.

column1: They had their hands tied behind their backs and had been shot in the head
column2: says Anatoliy Kibukevych. He then names every one of the victims.

column1: The main road - the route taken by Russian tanks ordered to seize Kyiv - is lined with the rubble of homes: heaps of singed bricks with metal bedframes or pots and pans oddly marooned in the middle of them. Painted pleas that read ""Children!"" or ""People!"" on garden gates have been pierced by shrapnel.

column4: from Washington DC

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-61530935;2022-05-23;Ukraine War: Families want pet quarantine rule change;"Ukrainian families in Wales have said settling has been harder because their pets cannot be with them.
Under Welsh rules
column2: many animals brought over have to be in quarantine centres for up to four months.

column1: Elsewhere in the UK they can quarantine in homes after health checks.
The Welsh government said it wants to reduce the risk of rabies and has ""concerns about how the current home isolation process can be monitored and enforced effectively"".
Marianna Koniushenko
column3: who fled to Cardiff with her family
column4: said her two dogs would help the trauma and anxiety she suffers after escaping Bucha in Ukraine.

column1: Along with brother Roman
column3: and mother Larysa Martseva
column4: she managed to escape
column5: despite people in cars in front and behind them being killed by Russian troops.

column1: But they had to leave their Rhodesian Ridgebacks Trisha and Vinchi in Dover when they arrived the UK on 26 April.
They are now in kennels in Poulton-le-Fylde
column2: south of Blackpool and they do not know when they will be reunited.

column1: Ms Koniushenko said she is suffering from trauma following their experiences
column2: adding: ""I think the dogs could help me. I can hug them and tell them all about my problems.

column1: I feel really upset. It's like a part of me. The dogs are a part of our family.""
Her mum said: ""My children have lost a huge part of their emotional support. Their lives - their happy lives in their country - changed just like that.
They had a nice life and it's very important for all of us to be all together.""
The family has been sent photos of the dogs by staff at the kennels
column2: but Ms Martseva added: ""I was crying when I saw the photos because it's like giving children to an orphanage.

column1: We love Wales and our host family but half of our family isn't here.""
The family pleaded ""please let the dogs be with us""
column2: with Ms Martseva saying: ""They are a five hour drive away. At least it would be great if the kennels were in Wales we're ready to drive to see them every day but we can't.""

column1: In Montgomery
column2: Powys
column3: on the border with England
column4: three generations of the Komrokova family now live with a host family.

column1: Their three cats Senia
column2: Charly and Flora are in a cattery
column3: and they are trying to secure a temporary home for them nearby
column4: in England
column5: so they can visit them.

column1: Rita
column2: eight
column3: who has additional learning needs
column4: finds comfort from spending time with the cats.

column1: Mark Michaels
column2: who is hosting the family
column3: said: ""We're a stone's throw from England here. You look out of the window and England is there it just seems desperately unfair. They would have chosen to be in England if they'd known they couldn't be with their animals.""

column1: Vladyslav Sdarikov
column3: who lives in Conwy
column4: said he and his girlfriend
column5: Darya Holodiak would have thought of different options if they had known their one-year-old pug Taylor had to quarantine in a kennel.

column1: Mr Sdarikov said: ""We cannot have him because of this invisible border for animals.""
Rural Affairs Minister Lesley Griffiths said she worked closely with the chief veterinary officer when considering the rules.
We haven't had rabies in this country for 100 years
column2: she said.

column1: This is about protecting the animal that arrives from Ukraine. It's about protecting animals here in Wales and of course it's about public health as well.
England and Scotland have chosen home confinement as a form of quarantine - how do you enforce that? How do you ensure that it absolutely takes place? It's impossible in my view.""

A Welsh government spokesman said: ""We understand how important people's pets are to them and we want to do everything we can to ensure people seeking refuge in Wales are reunited with their pets safely and as quickly as possible.
We also need to take steps to protect the health and welfare of all animals in Wales by reducing the risk of exposing them to diseases such as rabies.
We have concerns about how the current home isolation process can be monitored and enforced effectively.""
He said this is why the decision was taken
column2: adding: ""We fully recognise the distress this can cause pet owners
column3: particularly those who have come to Wales after fleeing the atrocities in Ukraine.

column1: We will continue to assess different options to keep the time their pets are in quarantine to a minimum.""
The spokesman added there are quarantine places in Wales currently in use and efforts are being made to create more spaces.
The UK government's Department for Environment
column2: Food and Rural Affairs said it had increased resources and streamlined processes to make sure those fleeing Ukraine with pets are not delayed.

column1: We have introduced a new rapid rabies blood test to cut quarantine times
column2: and lower risk animals are being moved into isolation
column3: he added.

column1: We are continuing to review processes and increase quarantine capacity - whilst maintaining our biosecurity standards.""  Ukrainian families in Wales have said settling has been harder because their pets cannot be with them.

The Ukrainian government says it will not agree a ceasefire deal with Russia that involves giving up territory.
The apparent hardening of Ukraine's position comes a day after President Volodymyr Zelensky said the war could be resolved only through diplomacy.
Presidential adviser Mykhaylo Podolyak said concessions would lead to an even larger and bloodier Russian offensive.
His comments come as Russia continues attempts to encircle Ukrainian forces defending Severodonetsk in the east.
In another development
column2: Polish President Andrzej Duda has become the first foreign leader to address the parliament in Kyiv in person.

column1: He received a standing ovation as he declared that only Ukrainians themselves could decide their future.
He added that Poland would do everything it could to help Ukraine join the EU.

column3: Clément Beaune
column4: said in a radio interview on Sunday that it would probably take ""15 or 20 years"" for Ukraine to be accepted as an EU member.

column2: who played for Bournemouth and Portsmouth

column1: They are hoping to complete the challenge in 10 back-to-back days after months of preparation.

column2: one of the team members
column3: the ride is more than just a physical challenge - it's about overcoming an accident that changed her life.
