BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-61535188;2022-05-21;Ukraine war: Mother and six sons get keys to Chepstow home;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
A Ukrainian mother and her six children who fled Russian bombing have been handed the keys to their new home.
Lilia Onopa
column3: and her children received an official welcome in Chepstow
column4: Monmouthshire
column5: on Friday.

column1: She tearfully described seeing her hometown destroyed
column2: people killed
column3: and wanting to save her sons.

column1: Having fled their home north of Dnipro
column2: where military strikes began in early March
column3: Ms Onopa and her boys travelled to Bucharest
column4: Romania.

column1: This was after attacks on the port city of Odesa made other methods of travel impossible.
They arrived in the Monmouthshire town last week after waiting five weeks for the British Embassy to approve their online application.
At the gathering
column2: they were given the keys to a bungalow
column3: a former caretaker's property which has been refurbished by volunteers from St Mary's RC Primary School and church with donations from across the area.

column1: Speaking of the horrors she and her children had encountered after the war began
column2: Ms Onopa thanked everyone who had helped them get to a place of safety
column3: including the UK government who she said came to her aid when there were issues with their applications.

column1: Ms Onopa said: ""The horrible situation happening to our country is because one person
column2: one regime decided my country should not exist
column3: that my nation should not exist.

column1: Imagine living next to a neighbour
column2: he might have completely different opinions but you do live together.

column1: And one day your neighbour decides to invade your house
column2: destroy your house
column3: kill your kids
column4: just because they think you're going to invade them.""

column1: She said every mother would probably be able to understand how she was not scared for her own life
column2: but those of her children.

column1: We saw our cities being destroyed
column2: rockets falling on our houses and people dying
column3: and the worst thing was we could do nothing to stop it
column4: she added.

column1: All we could think about is what are we going to do next.""
Ms Onopa said she posted an appeal for help on social media and a group in the UK said they would help her.
She said travelling to the border she had seen thousands of displaced families
column2: desperate for a route out of the war-torn areas.

column1: I was terrified I would lose my children so I wrote the addresses and contact details of my family in their rucksacks and clothes in the hope that should I die someone would  know where to take them to safety
column2: she said.

column1: Since arriving in the UK
column2: Ms Onopa said she has felt ""overwhelmed"" with support.

column1: I don't have enough words to describe how grateful I am to everyone who helped
column2: she said.

column1: I'm overwhelmed with the feeling that my kids can finally feel safe.""
Ms Onopa said she was keen to learn English and has already enrolled in classes.
Having been a keen cook and baker in Ukraine
column2: she said she would like to start her own pastry business
column3: and wants to volunteer to help other Ukrainian refugees settle.

column1: She said her sons
column2: aged between five and 15
column3: were looking forward to beginning school.

column1: But the devastation continuing in her own country where many of her family members and friends are still remains a source of fear and turmoil
column2: she said.

column1: As a nation we haven't stopped fighting but its very difficult
column2: she said.

column1: Just a couple of days ago I saw a 23-year-old boy from my village had been buried after being killed by the invaders.""
Presenting Ms Onopa with the keys
column2: Archbishop of Cardiff George Stack said: ""This is an opportunity to say to our new family croesi i Gymru
column3: welcome to Wales. The land of sanctuary.

column1: And we hope and pray that you will be happy and fulfilled and content as you begin to understand what wonderful people live and work in Wales.""
Chair of governors
column2: Phil Cotterell said: ""Lilia and her family will not be alone
column3: there is an incredible network of support here in Chepstow.""A Ukrainian mother and her six children who fled Russian bombing have been handed the keys to their new home.

Russia's invasion of Ukraine is now nearly into its fourth month.

column2: including perhaps Russian President Vladimir Putin
column3: did not expect it to last this long.

column1: But instead of swiftly taking the capital Kyiv
column2: Russia faced strong resistance and last month switched focus to trying to capture the eastern region known as the Donbas.

column2: Derek Chollet
column3: says Russia has already suffered a ""strategic defeat"". ""Ukraine is stronger today and closer to the West
column4: Mr Chollet says. ""And Nato is stronger as well.""

column1: Despite this

BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61524175;2022-05-20;Ukraine war: What might tip the balance?;"Russia's war in Ukraine has become an increasingly grinding and bloody affair
column2: with each side wearing the other down. Both claim to have made recent gains. But they've also suffered setbacks.

column1: Overall
column2: Russia is still the dominant force and has significant military might - but there has been no swift victory as planned. Here
column3: we take a closer look at some of the things which could tilt the outcome in favour of either party.

column1: In the north
column2: a Ukrainian counter-offensive has successfully pushed back Russian forces from the city of Kharkiv. In the south
column3: Russia has all but cleared out the final pockets of resistance in the port city of Mariupol. Both have been costly in terms of military and civilian casualties
column4: but neither is likely to prove decisive.

column1: What's happened in Mariupol and Kharkiv highlights the ebb and flow of this conflict. That pattern of costly gains and losses is now being repeated in the east of the country.

Russia has been making small but steady advances in the Donbas - the renewed focus of its offensive. But it's also suffered setbacks - as highlighted by the destruction earlier this month of dozens of Russian armoured vehicles trying to cross the Siversky Donets river.
In the east
column2: each side is exchanging heavy
column3: grinding blows using artillery. Ben Barry
column4: a former British Army brigadier who is now with the International Institute for Strategic Studies
column5: says that will continue to be the case in the battle of the Donbas.

column1: He predicts artillery will be the main cause of casualties on both sides for weeks and months to come. Western officials have highlighted significant Russian losses
column2: but they have been less willing to give estimates of Ukrainian casualties.

column1: Ukraine is now receiving Western-supplied heavy weapons - including US M777 howitzers. It has also been sent counter-artillery radar systems - to help find and target Russia's artillery lines. But Ukraine is still outgunned.

Russia has been using its artillery and rocket launchers to tie down Ukrainian forces who are dug in - along well prepared defensive lines. Russia has been pressing from two main directions - from Izyum in the north and from the west around the city of Severedonetsk. They have made limited advances in both directions.
Brig Barry says it appears that Russia is ""trying to bleed Ukraine dry"" by forcing it to concentrate its forces at key points
column2: which can then be targeted by its artillery. Military analysts believe Ukraine is likely to have suffered significant casualties as a result.

column1: However
column2: he says Ukraine will still be able to use urban areas in the Donbas to slow down Russia's advances. Fighting in town and cities
column3: as has been shown throughout this war
column4: favours the defender.

column1: Once again
column2: as in Mariupol
column3: Russia is likely to try to grind resistance down - with the now familiar pattern of using mass artillery strikes until there remains little to defend. Ukraine's President Zelensky has already said Ukraine's eastern Donbas region has been ""completely destroyed"" and has described life there as ""hell"". It's going to get worse.

column1: Military experts though still believe that Russia lacks the number of troops it needs to make significant advances in the east. Redeploying forces from the fight in  Kharkiv and Mariupol is unlikely to make a difference.
Jack Watling
column2: of the Royal United Services Institute
column3: says Russia is still short of manpower and in particular infantry. Russia has tried to reconstruct and combine some of its already battered units - dubbed ""Frankenstein's Forces"".

column1: Unit cohesion and morale of tired and depleted units is likely to be poor. A recent UK Ministry of Defence intelligence assessment concluded that Russian commanders were facing pressure to achieve results quickly and as a result were likely to redistribute forces without adequate preparation.

The ministry said that risked ""further attrition"". It is already claimed that Russia has already lost around a third of its original invasion force - an estimate that includes killed and wounded troops as well as equipment destroyed or damaged.

Mr Watling says Russia is trying to address these shortages - including mobilising reserves who are over 40 years old and offering short-term contracts to fill its ranks. But training and rebuilding an army takes time.
Russia has also proved vulnerable to Ukrainian attacks on its supply lines. But Ukraine's capacity to do this is likely to be limited with the bulk of its forces tied down in defensive positions.
No one thinks this war will be over quickly. It's not yet a stalemate. Russia is making advances - but very slowly. But the outcome of this war is unlikely to depend on military might alone.
Mr Watling says Russia is also pursuing economic and political levers to inflict as much damage on Ukraine as possible. While Russia's economy is taking a hit from Western sanctions
column2: Ukraine's is likely to suffer even more.

column1: Russia's GDP is expected to shrink by 12% over the next year
column2: but Ukraine's GDP could fall by 50%. Russia's blockade of the Black Sea is causing significant damage.

column1: Mr Watling says continuing Western economic
column2: as well as military
column3: support could prove crucial. Will the public's interest in the war wane the longer it goes on - just as it did after 2014 when Russia annexed Crimea and Russian-backed separatists first seized parts of the Donbas?

column1: Western governments now also have to worry about their own domestic challenges
column2: including rising inflation
column3: gas and oil prices and a cost of living crisis - caused in part by the war.

column2: suitable and dignified"" sponsorship arrangement.

column2: who have appropriate accommodation available
column3: with Ukrainian beneficiaries.""

column1: The policy aims to create a ""positive relationship"" between the sponsor and Ukrainian
column2: and to ensure they have access to appropriate community and public service support.

Knuckles white
column2: he holds the steering wheel tightly as the van jolts down mud tracks and through undergrowth. These paths were once used by tractors or for scenic bike trips. Now any inch of them or the open fields could be mined
column3: hit by shells or surrounded by military.

column1: Alexander is just one of the volunteer drivers crossing the front line to evacuate civilians from Kherson and other Russian-controlled areas in eastern Ukraine.

column2: in his early twenties
column3: he used to work in advocacy before the war.

column1: We can go along one road on the way in
column2: but by the time we go back there's a crater from an explosion
column3: he tells me. ""Then we know that the enemy shells have arrived. Then we pray
column4: you can shell a little to the left
column5: a little to the right. Just leave us a corridor in the middle so we can get people out.""

column1: In the last few weeks the volunteers say they have seen more demand from people wanting to leave Kherson as Russia tightens its grip on occupied territory. Arrivals tell stories of intimidation by Russian police
column2: soaring food prices and fear of kidnap by the authorities. Despite the risks
column3: they say
column4: many still want to make the journey out.

column1: Evacuating the city has been difficult. The UN and the Red Cross told us they have not run any evacuation routes as they've been unable to get safety guarantees from both sides.
Instead
column2: volunteer drivers like Alexander negotiate the checkpoints and routes without any formal agreements. We are using false names for both drivers travelling into Kherson to protect their identities.

column1: You must have a cold mind and a firm heart
column2: says Oleg. ""Otherwise
column3: you won't get to the final destination.""

column1: Oleg used to be a builder. He greets us with a broad smile and a piece of salted fish
column2: a gift from Kherson that he carried in the glove compartment. He returned last night. It was a tough journey.

column1: Every new ride gets harder and harder. The old routes are closed and we must look for new ones.""
Oleg explains the process he follows
column2: checking all the passengers' passports and documents
column3: carrying a first aid kit. But following a plan is nearly impossible. For the last two days they arrived at the checkpoint at 05:00
column4: only to wait until evening along with what he estimates to be around 2
column5: 000 other vehicles. No one
column6: he says
column7: was let through.

column1: We decided to go the way that is not yet open
column2: because there are active battles there. It's a very fast route and because the women and children were so exhausted
column3: we had to take risks. It was agreed by all passengers.""

column1: The team was lucky.

column2: trying to make the journey out. One is driven by Alexander. They haven't been heard from since last night.

We have to do it. As we speak now we have about 5

column3: not even counting from the surrounding villages.""

A man who spent more than two months helping refugees at the Ukrainian border and completing aid trips said there was still ""so much to be done"".
Kev Draper
column3: from Keynsham
column4: Somerset
column5: has returned from his third trip transporting medical supplies
column6: food
column7: petrol and support to refugees and military teams.

column1: Mr Draper said watching the conflict on the news ""brought a tear to his eye"" and he felt fortunate to help.
There is so much more I can do.""
Mr Draper said while providing aid to refugees he had seen ""so many people with this blank look on their face"".
I've never experienced anything like it
column2: he said.

column1: I have four grandsons so I know how noisy they [children] can be but I've never seen so many quiet children in one place ever.""
He said the first time he travelled into Ukraine to supply aid ""was quite scary"".
I was carrying 200 air beds to deliver to a school which was taking in refugees on a stopover.
My Satnav went down and I arrived into a military camp by mistake. I was 31km (19.8 miles) from the Russian border.""
Another time he said: ""It was curfew time and I had no where to sleep
column2: so some nuns put me up for the night in their monastery.

column1: The next morning I was having breakfast with 26 nuns
column2: which was interesting.""

column1: Some of the kit he transported included boxes with bone saws
column2: breathing equipment and penicillin.

column1: I was thinking this is probably going to the front line or an emergency hospital
column2: he added.

column1: Mr Draper said talking about his experience helps people understand how much assistance is still needed in Ukraine and for refugees.
He added: ""I was determined not to just sit in Keynsham watching it on the news and it makes me happy to be able to help... it brings a tear to my eye.""
He said he will return as soon as he can and continue helping.
Mr Draper
column2: his wife Mae and their daughter are hosting a Ukrainian mother and her teenage child.

column1: Mrs Draper said she was looking forward to the moment they arrive
column2: adding: ""We hope they like the house and the UK and hope we can be a friend
column3: a friend for life.""

column1: Nato's secretary general says Russia's war in Ukraine is not going to plan and that its attempt to capture the eastern Donbas region has ""stalled"".

Britain's Ministry of Defence (MoD) estimates Russia has lost about a third of its ground combat force since the war began in February.
The Russian invasion has been hampered by stiff Ukrainian resistance and logistical issues.
Its initial goal appeared to be to sweep across the country and topple the Ukrainian government. Instead
column2: Russia has withdrawn from areas around the capital Kyiv after failing to capture it and since mid-April has been focusing its efforts on two eastern provinces.

column1: In Ukraine's second city of Kharkiv

column1: BBC;https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-61442387;2022-05-15;Ukraine: The children's camp that became an execution ground;"We use cookies to give you the best online experience. Please let us know if you agree to all of these cookies.
Since Russian forces were pushed back from Kyiv at the end of March
column2: the bodies of more than 1
column3: 000 civilians have been discovered in the Bucha region - many hastily buried in shallow graves. The BBC has learned that around 650 people were shot in what a senior police official has described as executions. Sarah Rainsford has been investigating what happened at a children's summer camp - now being treated as a crime scene.

column1: *This report contains material some readers will find disturbing*
It is easy to miss the killing spot at first in the gloom. But in a cold
column2: damp basement on the edge of the woods that made Bucha a popular get-away spot before the war
column3: five Ukrainian men were forced to their knees and shot in the head.

column1: To the right of the entrance
column2: there are stones coated in blood that has turned dark red. Lying among that is a blue woollen hat with an exit hole in one side and its rim soaked in blood. In the wall
column3: I counted at least a dozen bullet holes.

column1: A couple of steps away are the remains of a Russian military ration pack - an open can of rice porridge with beef and an empty packet of crackers. A name daubed in graffiti on a wall is a reminder that the scene is a children's camp. But when Russian troops moved into Bucha
column2: just outside the capital
column3: in early March
column4: Camp Radiant became an execution ground.

column1: The story of the summer camp killings is chilling but so is this detail: more than 1
column2: 000 civilians were killed in the Bucha region during a month under Russian occupation
column3: but most did not die from shrapnel or shelling. More than 650 were shot dead by Russian soldiers
column4: according to a senior police official.

column1: Now Ukraine is searching for their killers.
Volodymyr Boichenko lived in Hostomel
column2: just up the road from Bucha and near the airfield where the first Russian forces landed to try to overthrow Ukraine's government. When his sister Aliona Mykytiuk decided to flee before the fighting reached her
column3: she pleaded with Volodymyr to join her. He was a civilian
column4: not a soldier
column5: but he wanted to stay and help. So he spent the days searching Hostomel for food and water to bring to neighbours
column6: including children
column7: who were trapped in their cellars by the constant shelling and Russian airstrikes.

column1: A chatty 34-year-old
column2: who had travelled the world in the merchant navy
column3: Volodymyr phoned his family from Hostomel most days to reassure them he was safe. Aliona would wait nervously for his brief calls: she knew he had to move to higher ground to get a connection and if the shelling was heavy it was impossible to leave the bomb shelter. As supplies ran low
column4: she urged her brother to try to escape but by then the roads were blocked.

column1: The last time Aliona heard from him was on 8 March. Volodymyr wasn't the demonstrative type
column2: but that day he told his sister not to worry about him. ""He said 'I really love you
column3: ' and that was so painful to hear
column4: Aliona sobs
column5: rubbing her eyes hard but unable to stop the tears. ""There was fear in his voice.""

column1: Four days later
column2: Volodymyr was spotted by neighbours close to Promenystyi
column3: as it's known here
column4: or Camp Radiant. Then he disappeared.

column1: In March
column2: the fighting around Kyiv was intense and the small town of Bucha was at the epicentre. The withdrawal of Russian troops in early April revealed scenes that shocked the world: the bodies of residents slumped in the streets where they'd been shot.

column1: Moscow tells anyone who will listen that the killings were staged
column2: an idea that is as twisted as it is patently false. Determined to hold those responsible to account
column3: Ukrainian investigators are busy collecting the hard evidence on territory now back under their control.

column1: We don't know what Putin's plans are
column2: so we are working as quickly as possible in case he drops a bomb and destroys all the proof
column3: says Kyiv regional police chief
column4: Andrii Niebytov.

column1: That evidence includes a field full of civilian cars pierced with multiple bullet holes
column2: now piled up on the edge of Bucha. They are vehicles that were shot at when families tried to flee. One still has a length of white cloth at the window
column3: hung to show the soldiers that its occupants were no threat. Step too close
column4: and you catch the sickly smell of death.

column1: When the bodies beneath Camp Radiant were discovered on 4 April
column2: Volodymyr Boichenko was among them. Aliona had spent weeks frantically calling hospitals and morgues. That day she was sent a photograph to identify. She knew it was her brother before it had even downloaded.

column1: I hate them with every cell of my being
column2: Aliona cries
column3: about Volodymyr's killers. ""I know that's wrong to say about people
column4: but they are not human. There was not one patch on those men's bodies that was not beaten.""

column1: The five men had been found crouching on their knees
column2: heads down and hands bound behind their backs.

column1: We know they had been tortured
column2: the police chief told the BBC. ""The Russian army has crossed the line of how war is conducted. They were not fighting the military in Ukraine
column3: they were kidnapping and torturing the civilian population.""

column1: Neither the Prosecutor's Office nor the SBU security service will disclose details of ongoing investigations
column2: but some Russian military were so careless at covering their tracks that there are likely to be considerable clues to work with. Ukrainian territorial defence units have even discovered lists of soldiers at some abandoned positions. One appears to be part of a rota for litter duty
column3: another includes passport details and mobile phone numbers.

column1: With such a vast volume of work - more than 11
column2: 000 potential war crimes cases registered so far - Ukraine's security services have called on more digitally savvy civilians for help.

column1: I feel some call of duty
column2: said Dmytro Replianchuk
column3: a journalist at slidstvo.info who worked to expose corruption within Ukraine's law enforcement bodies before the war. Now he's joined forces with prosecutors
column4: scouring the internet for extra data to help catch suspected war criminals.

column1: I understand it will be so hard and a lot of cases won't be solved. But in these weeks
column2: it's important to find as much information as possible
column3: Dmytro explained.

column1: We found one potential clue among the litter at Camp Radiant - the wrapping from a parcel sent by a woman named Ksyukha to a Russian soldier whose own name and military unit are clearly marked. Unit 6720 is based in Rubtsovsk
column2: in the Altai region of Siberia. It has been linked to Bucha before when soldiers from the town were caught on CCTV sending giant packages to relatives full of goods that they had looted from Ukrainian homes.

column1: We can't be sure yet whether soldiers from Rubtsovsk were based at the children's camp
column2: or were there when the men were killed. The police first need to establish a more precise time of death.

column1: We are working on it
column2: but it's not a quick thing
column3: Mr Niebytov  explains. ""But that camp was a headquarters so there would have been a commander. The soldiers could not have executed anyone without the commander's knowledge. So we will first find the organisers and then look for the implementers.""

column1: Across the road from Camp Radiant
column2: behind a church spattered with shrapnel damage
column3: a corner of Bucha is slowly showing renewed signs of life. Young boys run around the yard
column4: while a man fixes sheets of wood to windows shattered when the town was being shelled
column5: constantly. And a little shop has just reopened to serve others now trickling back to begin their own repairs.

column1: As neighbours cross paths
column2: they discuss the days when Russian tanks rolled into their town
column3: the soldiers who would shoot wildly and those who roamed the streets drunk
column4: breaking into homes and stealing from them. And they remember the local man who escaped to their block of flats from the summer camp opposite
column5: and who they had sheltered despite the risk.

column1: Viktor Sytnytskyi didn't know Camp Radiant before
column2: but all the details he gives match up. He's now in western Ukraine and told me his story over the phone
column3: calling from his car so he wouldn't upset his mother.

column1: It was early March when Viktor was grabbed by Russian soldiers on the street. They tied his hands and pulled his hat down over his eyes
column2: then dragged him to a cellar that he's sure was on the grounds of the children's camp.

column1: There
column2: the Russians poured water over his legs so he would freeze
column3: and they held a gun to his head.

column1: They kept saying
column2: 'Where's the fascists? Where's the troops? Where's Zelensky? One of them mentioned Putin so I said something rude and he hit me
column3: Viktor recalls.

column1: He remembers being angry at his captors as well as terrified. He had worked in Moscow in the past with men from Siberia and was horrified that Russians could now treat him with such brutality. Even more so
column2: when one of the soldiers revealed that he
column3: too
column4: was from Siberia.

column1: Viktor told him he was sad things had come to this.
The sad thing is that our grandfathers fought together against the Nazis and now you're the fascists
column2: was the Russian's angry reply.

column1: He told me: 'You have until the morning to remember what you've seen
column2: and if not
column3: you'll be shot.'""

column1: That night
column2: Viktor got lucky. There was heavy shelling and when he realised his captors were no longer guarding him
column3: he ran for his life.

column1: I calculated that I had more chance of surviving under shelling than if I stayed in that cellar. They'd already put the gun to my head. What would it cost them to pull the trigger?""
From a common grave beneath the children's camp
column2: Volodymyr Boichenko has now been given a proper burial beneath the cherry blossom in the old cemetery of Bucha.

column1: After his funeral
column2: Aliona says she finally saw her brother's face in her dreams again
column3: as if he were comforting her.

column1: But she still has many questions. The cross on Volodymyr's grave is marked only with his birthday
column2: not the date of his death
column3: because the family have no idea when he was shot.

column1: They may never know
column2: unless the Russian commander who took over Camp Radiant can be found.

column1: Like everyone in Bucha
column2: though
column3: they do know that civilians are not only caught up in this war. They are being targeted - by Russian soldiers who either don't know the rules of war
column4: or don't care.

column1: The last time Aliona heard from him was on 8 March. Volodymyr wasn't the demonstrative type
column2: but that day he told his sister not to worry about him. ""He said 'I really love you
column3: ' and that was so painful to hear
column4: Aliona sobs
column5: rubbing her eyes hard but unable to stop the tears. ""There was fear in his voice.""

column1: Four days later
column2: Volodymyr was spotted by neighbours close to Promenystyi
column3: as it's known here
column4: or Camp Radiant. Then he disappeared.

column1: In March
column2: the fighting around Kyiv was intense and the small town of Bucha was at the epicentre. The withdrawal of Russian troops in early April revealed scenes that shocked the world: the bodies of residents slumped in the streets where they'd been shot.

column1: Moscow tells anyone who will listen that the killings were staged
column2: an idea that is as twisted as it is patently false. Determined to hold those responsible to account
column3: Ukrainian investigators are busy collecting the hard evidence on territory now back under their control.

column1: We don't know what Putin's plans are
column2: so we are working as quickly as possible in case he drops a bomb and destroys all the proof
column3: says Kyiv regional police chief
column4: Andrii Niebytov.

column1: That evidence includes a field full of civilian cars pierced with multiple bullet holes
column2: now piled up on the edge of Bucha. They are vehicles that were shot at when families tried to flee. One still has a length of white cloth at the window
column3: hung to show the soldiers that its occupants were no threat. Step too close
column4: and you catch the sickly smell of death.

column1: When the bodies beneath Camp Radiant were discovered on 4 April
column2: Volodymyr Boichenko was among them. Aliona had spent weeks frantically calling hospitals and morgues. That day she was sent a photograph to identify. She knew it was her brother before it had even downloaded.

column1: I hate them with every cell of my being
column2: Aliona cries
column3: about Volodymyr's killers. ""I know that's wrong to say about people
column4: but they are not human. There was not one patch on those men's bodies that was not beaten.""

column1: The five men had been found crouching on their knees
column2: heads down and hands bound behind their backs.

column1: We know they had been tortured
column2: the police chief told the BBC. ""The Russian army has crossed the line of how war is conducted. They were not fighting the military in Ukraine
column3: they were kidnapping and torturing the civilian population.""

column1: Neither the Prosecutor's Office nor the SBU security service will disclose details of ongoing investigations
column2: but some Russian military were so careless at covering their tracks that there are likely to be considerable clues to work with. Ukrainian territorial defence units have even discovered lists of soldiers at some abandoned positions. One appears to be part of a rota for litter duty
column3: another includes passport details and mobile phone numbers.

column1: With such a vast volume of work - more than 11
column2: 000 potential war crimes cases registered so far - Ukraine's security services have called on more digitally savvy civilians for help.

column1: I feel some call of duty
column2: said Dmytro Replianchuk
column3: a journalist at slidstvo.info who worked to expose corruption within Ukraine's law enforcement bodies before the war. Now he's joined forces with prosecutors
column4: scouring the internet for extra data to help catch suspected war criminals.

column1: I understand it will be so hard and a lot of cases won't be solved. But in these weeks
column2: it's important to find as much information as possible
column3: Dmytro explained.

column1: We found one potential clue among the litter at Camp Radiant - the wrapping from a parcel sent by a woman named Ksyukha to a Russian soldier whose own name and military unit are clearly marked. Unit 6720 is based in Rubtsovsk
column2: in the Altai region of Siberia. It has been linked to Bucha before when soldiers from the town were caught on CCTV sending giant packages to relatives full of goods that they had looted from Ukrainian homes.

column1: We can't be sure yet whether soldiers from Rubtsovsk were based at the children's camp
column2: or were there when the men were killed. The police first need to establish a more precise time of death.

column1: We are working on it
column2: but it's not a quick thing
column3: Mr Niebytov  explains. ""But that camp was a headquarters so there would have been a commander. The soldiers could not have executed anyone without the commander's knowledge. So we will first find the organisers and then look for the implementers.""

column1: Across the road from Camp Radiant
column2: behind a church spattered with shrapnel damage
column3: a corner of Bucha is slowly showing renewed signs of life. Young boys run around the yard
column4: while a man fixes sheets of wood to windows shattered when the town was being shelled
column5: constantly. And a little shop has just reopened to serve others now trickling back to begin their own repairs.

column1: As neighbours cross paths
column2: they discuss the days when Russian tanks rolled into their town
column3: the soldiers who would shoot wildly and those who roamed the streets drunk
column4: breaking into homes and stealing from them. And they remember the local man who escaped to their block of flats from the summer camp opposite
column5: and who they had sheltered despite the risk.

column1: Viktor Sytnytskyi didn't know Camp Radiant before
column2: but all the details he gives match up. He's now in western Ukraine and told me his story over the phone
column3: calling from his car so he wouldn't upset his mother.

column1: It was early March when Viktor was grabbed by Russian soldiers on the street. They tied his hands and pulled his hat down over his eyes
column2: then dragged him to a cellar that he's sure was on the grounds of the children's camp.

column1: There
column2: the Russians poured water over his legs so he would freeze
column3: and they held a gun to his head.

column1: They kept saying
column2: 'Where's the fascists? Where's the troops? Where's Zelensky? One of them mentioned Putin so I said something rude and he hit me
column3: Viktor recalls.

column1: He remembers being angry at his captors as well as terrified. He had worked in Moscow in the past with men from Siberia and was horrified that Russians could now treat him with such brutality. Even more so
column2: when one of the soldiers revealed that he
column3: too
column4: was from Siberia.

column1: Viktor told him he was sad things had come to this.
The sad thing is that our grandfathers fought together against the Nazis and now you're the fascists
column2: was the Russian's angry reply.

column1: He told me: 'You have until the morning to remember what you've seen
column2: and if not
column3: you'll be shot.'""

column1: That night
column2: Viktor got lucky. There was heavy shelling and when he realised his captors were no longer guarding him
column3: he ran for his life.

column1: I calculated that I had more chance of surviving under shelling than if I stayed in that cellar. They'd already put the gun to my head. What would it cost them to pull the trigger?""
From a common grave beneath the children's camp
column2: Volodymyr Boichenko has now been given a proper burial beneath the cherry blossom in the old cemetery of Bucha.

column1: After his funeral
column2: Aliona says she finally saw her brother's face in her dreams again
column3: as if he were comforting her.

column1: But she still has many questions. The cross on Volodymyr's grave is marked only with his birthday
column2: not the date of his death
column3: because the family have no idea when he was shot.

column1: They may never know
column2: unless the Russian commander who took over Camp Radiant can be found.

column1: Like everyone in Bucha
column2: though
column3: they do know that civilians are not only caught up in this war. They are being targeted - by Russian soldiers who either don't know the rules of war
column4: or don't care.

Ukraine's foreign minister has hit out at French President Emmanuel Macron after he said it was vital that Russia was not humiliated over its invasion.
Mr Macron said it was crucial President Vladimir Putin had a way out of what he called a ""fundamental error"".
But Dmytro Kuleba said allies should ""better focus on how to put Russia in its place"" as it ""humiliates itself"".
Mr Macron has repeatedly spoken to Mr Putin by phone in an effort to broker a ceasefire and negotiations.
The French attempts to maintain a dialogue with the Kremlin leader contrast with the US and UK positions.
Foreign minister Kuleba said in a tweet that ""calls to avoid humiliation of Russia can only humiliate France and every other country that would call for it"".
Kyiv says Russia must not get territorial concessions from Ukraine

As the 100th day of Russia's invasion of Ukraine draws to a close
column2: President Volodymyr Zelensky has hailed the efforts of his military
column3: who he said have rebuffed Moscow's attack.

column1: Mr Zelensky was speaking outside the presidential palace in Kyiv
column2: where he was flanked by key advisors
column3: echoing a video message he posted at the onset of the war.

column1: He said Ukrainian troops have ""done what seemed impossible"" and stopped ""the second army of the world"".
Later
column2: the Ukrainian leader wrote on Telegram that Russia has been ""unable to achieve any strategic goal"" and has instead tried to ""shift its powerlessness to civilian infrastructure and people"".

column1: Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov hit back
column2: insisting ""certain results have been achieved"" and claiming the ""liberation"" of some regions from what he called the ""pro-Nazi armed forces of Ukraine"".

column1: Several world leaders used the 100-day mark to praise Ukraine's resistance
column2: including EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen
column3: who said the ""bravery of Ukrainians commands our respect and our admiration"".

column3: the BBC's James Waterhouse reports. .

column1: It's all a bluff"" and ""we're at war already"" were the most common responses when people were asked whether they were worried about what seemed to be the unthinkable at the time.
Of course
column2: within five weeks that all changed. Some in the West predicted Kyiv would fall within 72 hours.

column1: Over a period of 100 days the city has gone from stubborn normality
column2: through complete darkness
column3: and is now emerging into some sort of calm. It's still far from what it was before the war
column4: but it's nevertheless a picture of defiance.

column1: Some Russian troops are refusing to return to fight in Ukraine because of their experiences on the front line at the start of the invasion
column2: according to Russian human rights lawyers and activists.

column1: One soldier spent five weeks fighting in Ukraine earlier this year. He told the BBC he didn't want to return to Ukraine to ""kill and be killed"".
He is now home in Russia
column2: having taken legal advice to avoid being sent back to the front line. He is just one of hundreds of Russian soldiers understood to have been seeking such advice.

column1: I had thought that we were the Russian army

column1: Wars ebb and flow and in enormous mechanised conflicts like Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine it can often be difficult to determine who has gained the upper hand.
Despite early fears of a Ukrainian collapse
column2: Russia's offensive in much of Ukraine stalled and its forces were pushed back from Kyiv. That has now been met by a more focused Russian offensive in the east.

Wales' men's football team knows ""most of the world will be against them"" on Sunday as they host Ukraine for a place in the World Cup in Qatar.
Wales manager Robert Page said ""most of the world want Ukraine to get through""
column2: in solidarity after Russia's invasion of Ukraine that has killed thousands.

The Football Association of Wales has invited the UK's Ukrainian ambassador to the match
column2: while the Welsh government has given the visiting team and their delegates an official ""warm Welsh welcome"" in support to the people of Ukraine in the war with Russia.

column1: Wales' First Minister Mark Drakeford has sent a message of support to the Welsh team
column2: but added this game was an ""opportunity for us to reaffirm our support for Ukraine as it fights Russia's unprovoked and brutal act of war"".

column1: Wales haven't played at football's World Cup finals for 64 years - the longest drought of any team in Europe.
In fact
column2: only Cuba and Indonesia - who played at the 1938 finals in France - have gone longer than Wales without qualifying for another World Cup.

column1: Football's first world superstar Pele was the player to break Welsh hearts in Wales' only previous World Cup appearance in 1958.
The then 17-year-old scored the only goal - and his first on the international stage - as eventual tournament winners Brazil beat Wales 1-0 in their quarter final.
The Welsh have got agonisingly close to qualifying on numerous occasions since 1958 - most notably missing out after controversial penalties in 1977 and 1985
column2: both times against Scotland
column3: before Wales themselves squandered a penalty against Romania in 1993.

column1: Wales broke their major finals hoodoo by qualifying for football's European Championships in 2016 where the Welsh reached the semi-final - before reaching the last 16 of Euro 2020.
Sunday's play-off kicks off at 17:00 BST and is for a place in the 2022 Fifa World Cup later this year where the winners will share Group B with England and Iran in Qatar.

column1: When Vladimir Putin denies the reality of the Ukrainian state

column13: a Muscovite explorer reached the Pacific Ocean.

column1: The war in Ukraine allowed Muscovy to turn its attention to Europe. In 1654
column2: the Cossacks signed an agreement with representatives of the tsar. The Muscovite armies invaded Poland-Lithuania from the east; soon after
column3: Sweden invaded from the north
column4: setting off the crisis that Polish history remembers as “the Deluge.” Peace was eventually made between Poland-Lithuania and Muscovy
column6: and Ukraine was divided more or less down the middle
column7: along the Dnipro. After a thousand years of existence
column8: Kyiv was politically connected to Moscow for the first time.

column1: The Cossacks were something like an early national movement. The problem was that their struggle against one colonial power enabled another. In 1721
column2: Muscovy was renamed the Russian Empire
column3: in reference to old Rus. Poland-Lithuania never really recovered from the Deluge
column4: and was partitioned out of existence between 1772 and 1795. Russia thereby claimed the rest of Ukraine—everything but a western district known as Galicia
column5: which went to the Habsburgs. Around the same time
column7: the Cossacks lost their status. They did not gain the political rights they had wanted
column8: nor did the peasants who supported them gain control of the black earth. Polish landowners remained in Ukraine
column9: even as state power became Russian.

column1: Whereas Putin’s story of Ukraine is about destiny
column2: the Ukrainian recollection of the Cossacks is about unfulfilled aspirations. The country’s national anthem
column3: written in 1862
column4: speaks of a young people upon whom fate has yet to smile
column5: but who will one day prove worthy of the “Cossack nation.”

column1: The nineteenth century was the age of national revivals. When the Ukrainian movement began in imperial Russian Kharkov—today Kharkiv
column2: and largely in ruins—the focus was on the Cossack legacy. The next move was to locate history in the people
column3: as an account of continuous culture. At first
column4: such efforts did not seem threatening to imperial rule. But
column5: after the Russian defeat in the Crimean War
column7: and the insult of the Polish uprising of 1863 and 1864
column8: Ukrainian culture was declared not to exist. It was often deemed an invention of Polish élites—an idea that Putin endorsed in his essay on “historical unity.” Leading Ukrainian thinkers emigrated to Galicia
column9: where they could speak freely.

column1: The First World War brought the principle of self-determination
column2: which promised a release from imperial rule. In practice
column3: it was often used to rescue old empires
column4: or to build new ones. A Ukrainian National Republic was established in 1917
column5: as the Russian Empire collapsed into revolution. In 1918
column6: in return for a promise of foodstuffs
column7: the country was recognized by Austria and Germany. Woodrow Wilson championed self-determination
column8: but his victorious entente ignored Ukraine
column9: recognizing Polish claims instead. Vladimir Lenin invoked the principle as well
column10: though he meant only that the exploitation of national questions could advance class revolution. Ukraine soon found itself at the center of the Russian civil war
column11: in which the Red Army
column12: led by the Bolsheviks
column13: and the White Army
column14: fighting for the defunct empire
column15: both denied Ukraine’s right to sovereignty. In this dreadful conflict
column16: which followed four years of war
column18: among them tens of thousands of Jews.

column1: Though the Red Army ultimately prevailed
column2: Bolshevik leaders knew that the Ukrainian question had to be addressed. Putin claims that the Bolsheviks created Ukraine
column3: but the truth is close to the opposite. The Bolsheviks destroyed the Ukrainian National Republic. Aware that Ukrainian identity was real and widespread
column4: they designed their new state to account for it. It was largely thanks to Ukraine that the Soviet Union took the form it did
column5: as a federation of units with national names.

column1: The failure of self-determination in Ukraine was hardly unique. Almost all of the new states created after the First World War were destroyed
column2: within about two decades
column3: by Nazi Germany
column4: the Soviet Union
column5: or both. In the political imaginations of both regimes
column6: Ukraine was the territory whose possession would allow them to break the postwar order
column7: and to transform the world in their own image. As in the sixteenth century
column8: it was as if all the forces of world history were concentrated on a single country.

column1: Stalin spoke of an internal colonization
column2: in which peasants would be exploited so that the Soviet economy could imitate—and then overtake—capitalism. His policy of collective agriculture
column3: in which land was seized from farmers
column4: was particularly unwelcome in Ukraine
column5: where the revolution had finally got rid of the (still largely Polish) landholders. Yet the black earth of Ukraine was central to Stalin’s plans
column6: and he moved to subdue it. In 1932 and 1933
column7: he enforced a series of policies that led to around four million people dying of hunger or related disease. Soviet propaganda blamed the Ukrainians
column8: claiming that they were killing themselves to discredit Soviet rule—a tactic echoed
column9: today
column10: by Putin. Europeans who tried to organize famine relief were dismissed as Nazis.

column1: The actual Nazis saw Stalin’s famine as a sign that Ukrainian agriculture could be exploited for another imperial project: their own. Hitler wanted Soviet power overthrown
column2: Soviet cities depopulated
column3: and the whole western part of the country colonized. His vision of Ukrainians was intensely colonial: he imagined that he could deport and starve them by the millions
column4: and exploit the labor of whoever remained. It was Hitler’s desire for Ukrainian land that brought millions of Jews under German control. In this sense
column5: colonial logic about Ukraine was a necessary condition for the Holocaust.

column1: Between 1933 and 1945
column2: Soviet and Nazi colonialism made Ukraine the most dangerous place in the world. More civilians were killed in Ukraine
column3: in acts of atrocity
column4: than anywhere else. That reckoning doesn’t even include soldiers: more Ukrainians died fighting the Germans
column5: in the Second World War
column6: than French
column7: American
column8: and British troops combined.

column1: The major conflict of the war in Europe was the German-Soviet struggle for Ukraine
column2: which took place between 1941 and 1945. But
column3: when the war began
column5: the Soviet Union and Germany were de-facto allies
column6: and jointly invaded Poland. At the time
column7: what is now western Ukraine was southeastern Poland. A small group of Ukrainian nationalists there joined the Germans
column8: understanding that they would seek to destroy the U.S.S.R. When it became clear that the Germans would fail
column9: the nationalists left their service
column10: ethnically cleansed Poles in 1943 and 1944
column11: and then resisted the Soviets. In Putin’s texts
column12: they figure as timeless villains
column13: responsible for Ukrainian difference generally. The irony
column14: of course
column15: is that they emerged thanks to Stalin’s much grander collaboration with Hitler. They were crushed by Soviet power
column16: in a brutal counter-insurgency
column17: and today Ukraine’s far right polls at one to two per cent. Meanwhile
column18: the Poles
column19: whose ancestors were the chief victims of Ukrainian nationalism
column20: have admitted nearly three million Ukrainian refugees
column21: reminding us that there are other ways to handle history than stories of eternal victimhood.

column1: After the war
column2: western Ukraine was added to Soviet Ukraine
column3: and the republic was placed under suspicion precisely because it had been under German occupation. New restrictions on Ukrainian culture were justified by a manufactured allocation of guilt. This circular logic—we punish you
column4: therefore you must be guilty—informs Kremlin propaganda today. Russia’s foreign minister
column5: Sergey Lavrov
column6: has argued that Russia had to invade Ukraine because Ukraine might have started a war. Putin
column7: who has said the same
column8: is clearly drawing on Stalin’s rhetoric. We are to understand that the Soviet victory in the Second World War left Russians forever pure and Ukrainians eternally guilty. At the funerals of Russian soldiers
column9: grieving parents are told that their sons were fighting Nazis.

column1: The history of the colonization of Ukraine
column2: like the history of troubling and divisive subjects in general
column3: can help us get free of myths. The past delivers to Putin several strands of colonial rhetoric
column4: which he has combined and intensified. It also leaves us vulnerable to a language of exploitation: whenever we speak of “the Ukraine” instead of “Ukraine
column5: ” or pronounce the capital city in the Russian style
column6: or act as if Americans can tell Ukrainians when and how to make peace
column7: we are continuing imperial rhetoric by partaking in it.

column1: Ukrainian national rhetoric is less coherent than Putin’s imperialism
column2: and
column3: therefore
column4: more credible
column5: and more human. Independence arrived in 1991
column6: when the U.S.S.R was dissolved. Since then
column7: the country’s politics have been marked by corruption and inequality
column8: but also by a democratic spirit that has grown in tandem with national self-awareness. In 2004
column9: an attempt to rig an election was defeated by a mass movement. In 2014
column10: millions of Ukrainians protested a President who retreated from the E.U. The protesters were massacred
column11: the President fled
column12: and Russia invaded Ukraine for the first time. Again and again
column13: Ukrainians have elected Presidents who seek reconciliation with Russia; again and again
column14: this has failed. Zelensky is an extreme case: he ran on a platform of peace
column15: only to be greeted with an invasion.

column1: Ukraine is a post-colonial country
column2: one that does not define itself against exploitation so much as accept
column3: and sometimes even celebrate
column4: the complications of emerging from it. Its people are bilingual
column5: and its soldiers speak the language of the invader as well as their own. The war is fought in a decentralized way
column6: dependent on the solidarity of local communities. These communities are diverse
column7: but together they defend the notion of Ukraine as a political nation. There is something heartening in this. The model of the nation as a mini-empire
column8: replicating inequalities on a smaller scale
column9: and aiming for a homogeneity that is confused with identity
column10: has worn itself out. If we are going to have democratic states in the twenty-first century
column11: they will have to accept some of the complexity that is taken for granted in Ukraine.

column1: The contrast between an aging empire and a new kind of nation is captured by Zelensky
column2: whose simple presence makes Kremlin ideology seem senseless. Born in 1978
column3: he is a child of the U.S.S.R.
column4: and speaks Russian with his family. A Jew
column5: he reminds us that democracy can be multicultural. He does not so much answer Russian imperialism as exist alongside it
column6: as though hailing from some wiser dimension. He does not need to mirror Putin; he just needs to show up. Every day
column7: he affirms his nation by what he says and what he does.

column1: Ukrainians assert their nation’s existence through simple acts of solidarity. They are not resisting Russia because of some absence or some difference
column2: because they are not Russians or opposed to Russians. What is to be resisted is elemental: the threat of national extinction represented by Russian colonialism
column3: a war of destruction expressly designed to resolve “the Ukrainian question.” Ukrainians know that there is not a question to be answered
column4: only a life to be lived and
column5: if need be
column6: to be risked. They resist because they know who they are. In one of his very first videos after the invasion
column7: when Russian propaganda claimed that he had fled Kyiv
column8: Zelensky pointed the camera at himself and said
column9: “The President is here.” That is it. Ukraine is here."

column1: Over the weekend

column3: including social-media companies
column4: to police hate speech and disinformation more effectively. Under the E.U.’s Digital Services Act
column5: European governments now have the power to ask Web platforms like Twitter
column6: Facebook
column7: and YouTube to remove any content that promotes terrorism
column8: hate speech
column9: child sexual abuse
column10: or commercial scams. The platforms will also be obliged to prevent the “manipulation of services having an impact on democratic processes and public security.”“The time of big online platforms behaving like they are ‘too big to care’ is coming to an end
column11: ” Thierry Breton
column12: the E.U.’s commissioner for the internal market
column13: declared. If the European authorities see a surge of online disinformation during a crisis

Although the new E.U. agreement stops short of treating online platforms the same as traditional publishers (which may be legally liable for intentionally false content about specific individuals and companies)
column16: it will force them to provide users with “an easy and effective way” to flag harmful content
column17: so that it can be removed. The platforms will also be subject to annual audits by European regulators on their efforts to counter disinformation and other abuses. Platforms that violate the new law can be fined billions of dollars
column18: and repeat offenders may even be banned from doing business in the E.U.
