column1: New Yorker;https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/how-congress-can-prevent-elon-musk-from-turning-twitter-back-into-an-unfettered-disinformation-machine;2022-04-26;How Congress Can Prevent Elon Musk from Turning Twitter Back Into an Unfettered Disinformation Machine;"A new European Union law is a road map for how to put the onus on social-media companies to monitor and remove harmful content
column2: and hit them with big fines if they don’t.

column1: “The time of big online platforms behaving like they are ‘too big to care’ is coming to an end
column2: ” Thierry Breton
column3: the E.U.’s commissioner for the internal market
column4: declared. If the European authorities see a surge of online disinformation during a crisis
column5: such as the ongoing war in Ukraine
column6: they will be able to order social-media companies to take “proportionate and effective measures” to counter the threat. Although the new E.U. agreement stops short of treating online platforms the same as traditional publishers (which may be legally liable for intentionally false content about specific individuals and companies)
column7: it will force them to provide users with “an easy and effective way” to flag harmful content
column8: so that it can be removed. The platforms will also be subject to annual audits by European regulators on their efforts to counter disinformation and other abuses. Platforms that violate the new law can be fined billions of dollars
column9: and repeat offenders may even be banned from doing business in the E.U.

column1: Ironically
column2: the E.U. members adopted the new measures only days before the board of directors of Twitter entered into an agreement to sell the company to Elon Musk
column3: a self-styled defender of free speech and a vigorous opponent of government regulation
column4: for about forty-four billion dollars. “The proposed transaction will deliver a substantial cash premium
column5: and we believe it is the best path forward for Twitter’s stockholders
column6: ” Bret Taylor
column7: Twitter’s chairman
column8: who is also the co-C.E.O. of the software company Salesforce
column9: said in a statement.

column1: Evidently
column2: financial considerations overrode any reservations that the members of Twitter’s board may have had about selling the company to Musk
column3: who has frequently criticized its management and demanded changes in how the site operates. Musk’s bid of fifty-four dollars and twenty cents a share represents a premium of close to forty per cent over the firm’s stock price on April 1st
column4: immediately before he disclosed that he had acquired a nine-per-cent stake in the company. But
column5: even though the financial logic of the deal is straightforward
column6: the implications of Musk taking control of Twitter are
column7: from a broader perspective
column8: potentially highly problematic
column9: especially since he still hasn’t answered some pressing questions about his intentions for the site
column10: including whether he plans to allow Donald Trump back onto it.

column1: [Support The New Yorker’s award-winning journalism. Subscribe today »]
In a statement on Monday
column2: Musk said that he wanted “to make Twitter better than ever by enhancing the product with new features
column3: making the algorithms open source to increase trust
column4: defeating the spam bots
column5: and authenticating all humans.” These aren’t necessarily bad ideas. Allowing users to edit tweets  and authenticating their identities could conceivably improve Twitter. The idea of opening up Twitter’s algorithm also sounds benign
column6: although it could  clash with the goal of defeating the bots
column7: because once the spammers know Twitter’s formula for serving up tweets they may be better able to game it.

column1: But none of Musk’s suggestions addressed the fundamental issue of which approach Twitter will now take toward content moderation. Will the company maintain the heavy investments in artificial intelligence and human monitors that it has made in recent years? Will it expand these monitoring efforts as demanded by the new European law? Or will it move in the other direction
column2: dismantling them and allowing the return of former users it had suspended or banned
column3: particularly Trump?

column1: Based on the signs so far
column2: the answer to the last question is yes
column3: Trump and others who have been banned will return. Even though Trump currently insists that he won’t return even if he is invited—he has his own social-media app to promote—many of his supporters are openly celebrating the news of Musk’s takeover. During a staff meeting on Monday
column4: a Twitter employee asked Parag Agrawal
column5: the firm’s chief executive
column6: whether Trump would be allowed back. “We constantly evolve our policies
column7: ” Agrawal replied. “Once the deal closes
column8: we don’t know what direction this company will go in.”

column1: Based on some of his public statements
column2: Musk seems intent on taking Twitter back to the not at all distant era when social media was a free-for-all. “I do think that we want to be just very reluctant to delete things
column3: ” he said
column4: in an interview earlier this month.  If Twitter does go in this direction
column5: it could encounter pushback from corporate advertisers that don’t like being associated with disinformation
column6: incitement
column7: and controversy. Musk has suggested that Twitter should grow its subscriptions base to become less dependent on advertisers
column8: but it’s not clear how many people would pay to use the site
column9: especially if its contents are largely unfiltered.

column1: Musk has also said that his pursuit of Twitter is driven by the desire to protect free speech and “help freedomn in the world” rather than to make money. These are fine-sounding words
column2: but it sometimes seems as if Musk’s notion of free speech amounts to attacking and lampooning anybody who challenges him
column3: including the financial regulators who charged him with securities fraud and fined him twenty million dollars for tweeting  misleading information in 2018 about a possible buyout of Tesla. “Even as Twitter’s board on Monday was debating his offer . . . Mr. Musk was setting the tone for his leadership by tweeting that Securities and Exchange Commission officials were ‘shameless puppets
column4: ’ ” Greg Bensinger
column5: a member of the Times’ editorial board
column6: noted. Last week
column7: Musk used his Twitter account
column8: which has about eighty-five million followers
column9: to try fat-shaming Bill Gates
column10: whom he also accused of speculating against Tesla’s stock.

column1: In a column for the Guardian
column2: Robert Reich
column3: a former U.S. Secretary of Labor
column4: argued that Musk’s real goal in purchasing Twitter is to create a position for himself where he is unaccountable to anything
column5: from laws to market competition. Whether that’s entirely accurate or not
column6: the pending takeover provides yet another confirmation that Congress needs to treat the big online platforms like the social utilities they are
column7: and regulate them. A first step would be to pass the American Innovation and Choice Online Act
column8: which cleared the Senate Judiciary Committee
column9: on a bipartisan basis
column10: in January. This legislation would prohibit dominant platforms
column11: such as Amazon and Google
column12: from exploiting their market power to boost their own products by discriminating against their competitors.

column1: Regulating content in a manner consistent with protecting free speech may be a trickier proposition
column2: but the E.U. has just provided a road map for how it could be done: by putting the onus on social-media companies to monitor and remove harmful content
column3: and hit them with big fines if they don’t. The Digital Services Act is “nothing short of a paradigm shift in tech regulation
column4: ” Ben Scott
column5: the executive director of the advocacy group Reset
column6: told the Associated Press. “It’s the first major attempt to set rules and standards for algorithmic systems in digital media markets.”

column1: Musk would surely object to the U.S. adopting a regulatory system like the one that the Europeans are drawing up
column2: but that’s too bad. The health of the Internet—and
column3: most important
column4: democracy—is too significant to leave to one man
column5: no matter how rich he is."

column1: New Yorker;https://www.newyorker.com/culture/the-new-yorker-interview/werner-herzog-has-never-liked-introspection;2022-04-26;Werner Herzog Has Never Liked Introspection;"A conversation with the filmmaker about the place of literature
column2: the toll of war
column3: and the conviction that his writing will outlast his movies.

column1: He also wrote two books. The first of these
column2: “The Twilight World
column3: ” will be published in English in June
column4: translated from the German by Michael Hofmann. Part adventure narrative
column5: part memoir
column6: and part unclassifiable lyric
column7: “The Twilight World” tells the story of Hiroo Onoda
column8: an actual Japanese soldier who manned his post on the island of Lubang
column9: in the Philippines
column10: for three decades after the Second World War had ended
column11: having convinced himself that it had not. During his thirty-year war—which Onoda described in a memoir of his own
column12: “No Surrender”—he survived more than a hundred ambushes
column13: all while protecting himself against the degradations of the jungle. (As Daniel Zalewski wrote in a Profile of Herzog
column14: from 2006
column15: the “canonical Herzogian tale . . . portrays a man immersed in a situation of almost surreal extremity.”) Onoda was also bombarded with an onslaught of well-meaning attempts to coax him from his post. Yet his delusion persisted. In “The Twilight World
column16: ” Herzog writes
column17: “Onoda’s war is formed from the union of an imaginary nothing and a dream.”

column1: I met Herzog in person
column2: in April
column3: at an apartment he maintains in Manhattan. He and his wife
column4: the photographer Lena Herzog
column5: were soon headed to Venice
column6: where she would be showing “Last Whispers
column7: ” an immersive exhibit about the vanishing of languages. Her husband and I sat on opposite sides of a glass-topped coffee table that bore books about Bruegel and Goya. For four hours
column8: we discussed Onoda’s dream
column9: Herzog’s literary bugbears
column10: and the genius of Buster Keaton. Up against a nearby wall were heavy-duty cases of virtual-reality equipment. When the interview was over
column11: Lena allowed me to be the guinea pig for the V.R. version of her exhibit. Sitting in the living room
column12: I travelled to outer space and through sinister forests. When I returned to the reality of the apartment
column13: Herzog was seated on the couch beside me
column14: quietly working on a piece of writing.

column1: Our conversation has been edited for length and clarity.
What was your experience of lockdown?
There were a few months when I hardly ever left my house in Los Angeles. I couldn’t venture out with a crew and actors and make films
column2: and so that’s when I wrote “The Twilight World.” I had the story in me for twenty years. Sometimes you have something that is completely ready: you don’t have to think
column3: you don’t have to lay out a plot—it is instantly there.

column1: Once that book was finished
column2: I immediately wrote the next book
column3: which is three times the length. It will be published in German in a few months and then translated by Michael Hofmann into English. It’s some sort of memoir
column4: but not in terms of an autobiography. Only part of it is about my life. It’s really about the origins of ideas. At age seventeen
column5: for example
column6: I stumbled across a valley filled with ten thousand windmills on the island of Crete. I had hired a donkey and was travelling in the mountains of the interior. When I saw this valley of windmills
column7: I thought
column8: This cannot be—I’m either fooled by an illusion or I’m stark mad. I knew my grandfather when he was stark mad
column9: but he was an older man
column10: and
column11: I thought
column12: It’s too early. It shouldn’t happen now.

column1: I put myself together and walked down into the valley and there were indeed windmills. They were there to pump water for the irrigation of this entire valley. There was not a single building
column2: just ten thousand windmills—it was completely insane. The book is about how an image like that lingers
column3: and then
column4: all of a sudden
column5: connects with a story
column6: and holds an entire feature film together—in this case
column7: “Signs of Life.”

column1: You met Hiroo Onoda
column2: the main character of “The Twilight World
column3: ” in the late nineties.

column1: I was in Japan to stage the opera “Chushingura
column2: ” composed by Shigeaki Saegusa
column3: which is based on the famous story of forty-seven loyal ronin whose lord is wronged and has to commit seppuku
column4: ritual suicide. The ronin avenge him
column5: knowing that
column6: for their deed
column7: they will have to kill themselves in ritual suicide
column8: as well. It’s the most Japanese of Japanese stories—every schoolchild knows about it. While in Japan
column9: I received word that the office of the Emperor had stretched out feelers to see whether I would like to meet the Emperor in a private audience
column10: but I had the feeling that I could speak only in formulas and polite
column11: prefabricated dialogue
column12: so I refused. To this day
column13: I wish the ground had opened into a chasm and swallowed me up. There are benign silences
column14: but there are also shocked silences and hostile silences
column15: and there was a long silence among those with whom I had worked.  Somebody then asked whom else I would like to meet in Japan
column16: and
column18: I said
column19: “Onoda.”

column1: For many years
column2: he had declined to participate in a film about his life. But
column3: he said
column4: “If there’s anyone who should do it
column5: it should be you
column6: Herzog-san.” I was very moved by that
column7: and
column8: for a while
column9: I thought his story could be a film. But something stopped me from doing it. I knew the story had to do with elements that are outside of movies—such as how a belief system originates from the observation of the tiniest details
column10: which
column11: all together
column12: form a coherent world view with an almost religious intensity. For example
column13: leaflets were thrown from small planes
column14: trying to inform Onoda that the war was over and he ought to surrender. He would study these leaflets like papyrus fragments of the Bible
column15: and find they contained a small error in one of the Japanese characters
column16: or that they called his battalion by its former name
column17: when shortly before the end of the war his battalion was renamed. For him
column18: this was proof that the leaflets were the work of the enemy.

column1: But I had the feeling that the tragedy of settling into a fictitious life may not have been such a tragedy after all. I have the suspicion that he lived a fulfilled life. And
column2: of course
column3: what fascinates me is not only how Onoda settles into a fictitious life but how basically all of us do
column4: within our cultural norms. In his story
column5: the deeper structure of what makes a human being becomes more visible.

column1: Did Onoda prefer not to know the war was over?
I think he was reluctant
column2: after thirty years of waging a solitary war
column3: to acknowledge that there was no war. This is why he insisted that the young man who found him
column5: should return to Japan and mobilize a former major of his unit
column6: who would then come back to the island and issue competent military orders for him to desist hostile activities. The end needed to be formalized and ritualized—only then would the war be over. But the astonishing thing is that he still hoped that the major would tell him
column7: “This was all made up
column8: we just wanted to test your perseverance.” He hoped that the end was an illusion.

column1: The main characters of your films seem to be externalizations of forces within you. What in Onoda were you trying to explore about yourself?
It’s not easy to make any comments
column2: because I don’t like
column3: and I’ve never liked
column4: introspection. But it may have to do with certain things that I’ve striven for: responsibility
column5: a sense of duty
column6: courage
column7: many things that make a good soldier. Sometimes I’ve said I’d like to be a good soldier of cinema—which may be misleading
column8: because people immediately think in military terms
column9: when I’m not thinking in military terms.

column1: What came to mind recently is that
column2: when I look at my films and I look at my writing
column3: I have the feeling that my films are like my voyage out in the world
column4: and my writing is home. That’s where I’m home. I do believe my writing will have a longer life than my films
column5: though I may be wrong. I have misjudged quite often.

column1: Do you consider this your first novel?
It doesn’t have a real category. It probably comes closest to a novel. It’s something that borders poetry
column2: or pure fantasies and pure language—language for itself.

column1: It bears some traces of the screenplay form. It’s very efficient; when it’s nighttime
column2: you just say
column3: “Night.”

column1: Strangely
column2: my first screenplays were prose. I had no idea what a screenplay looked like
column3: but I would write down something that you
column4: as a reader or an actor or a financier
column5: could immediately imagine as a movie on the screen. I would have trouble with actors who would say
column6: “Where is the dialogue? What do I have to learn? What do I have to rehearse?” And I would keep saying
column7: “Don’t rehearse.”

column1: You’ve always had a fascination with people who stand outside of what the majority of us see as history. I think of someone like Fini Straubinger
column2: who is blind and deaf and has no knowledge of the destruction of the Second World War. Or Kaspar Hauser
column3: who spends his early years locked in a cellar with no knowledge of humanity. History as we conceive of it has missed them somehow. Do you see this as a precious quality?

column1: There is something quite important in what you’re asking
column2: and I can make only a very tiny step toward an answer. In my case
column3: I have tried to live outside of the fashionable trends. This has got me into trouble all the time. I make my own observations
column4: and
column5: like Onoda
column6: I create my own world view out of the knowledge that I derive from the world itself. When you travel on foot
column7: for example—and I don’t mean backpacking or hiking
column8: I mean
column9: for example
column10: travelling on foot from Munich to Paris—you are given a world view
column11: an insight that is different or outside of the average knowledge. I have a dictum: “The world reveals itself to those who travel on foot.” I do not want to explain it any further.

column1: Your work is distinctly unromantic in its view of the natural world. Do you perceive a new romanticism emerging in reaction to ecological collapse?
The vanishing of nature is also romanticized: the lonely polar bear on an ice shelf. Romanticism has trickled down through Walt Disney
column2: and now we have the Disneyfication of landscapes
column3: of human existence
column4: of storytelling
column5: of our relationship with wild nature. The bears are cuddly and you have to hug them and you have to sing to them. That’s the tragedy of Timothy Treadwell
column6: in “Grizzly Man
column7: ” a tragedy of misguided philosophy. When somebody espouses New Age ideas
column8: I always lower my head and charge.

column1: In your films
column2: you seldom have closeups of characters. You prefer to situate them in the landscape. And it seems as though
column3: in the book
column4: you are going for the same effect. The jungle is always pressing in on the men.

column1: I think you’re right.
But the jungle is resistant to a vista—you can’t really create a vista in the jungle unless you’re above the canopy.
You don’t even see the sky most of the time.
Is that what you mean by “the twilight world”?
Yes
column2: but it’s also metaphorical. In German
column3: the title is “Dammerung
column4: ” which means “twilight” but also “dawn
column5: ” like Wagner’s “Götterdämmerung.” What is it in English
column6: “The Twilight of the Gods”? We decided we should translate it like Richard Wagner would translate it.

column1: It seems to me that one of the challenges of this story would be narrating the passage of time. The story ranges over decades
column2: and there aren’t many events in a conventional sense. “The jungle does not recognize time
column3: ” you write.

column1: The passage of time is one of the reasons why the story became a book and not a film. I spoke about time at great length with Onoda. He was fascinated by the notion that present time cannot exist. You take a million steps in the jungle. Lifting the foot out of the mud is already past
column2: and setting it down in front of you is the future. There is no present time. We live in a convention
column3: in a fiction of present time
column4: but only by dint of declaration. Technically
column5: it does not exist. We walk on crutches when it comes to time.

column1: You have said
column2: in the past
column3: that
column4: with filmmaking
column5: you don’t care about beautiful images in themselves
column6: only what a shot is about and how it fits into the story. Is content more important than form?

column1: Yes
column2: the substance. Stylizations and formalisms are not as important. If they were
column3: then everything that is kitsch
column4: everything that has perfect form
column5: perfect harmony
column6: would be the greatest of all literature and painting. But no
column7: it is not.

column1: Did the prolonging of the Second World War in Onoda’s mind resonate with your experience of the war’s legacy in Germany—the sense that the war continued somehow
column2: and exceeded the boundaries of 1945?

column1: No
column2: I don’t think so. There was a very
column3: very strong feeling among the German population of “This must never happen again.” Because the deepest of catastrophes was the First World War
column4: and then only twenty years later or so you have the Second World War
column5: and the complete destruction of Germany. Almost every single major city in Germany looked like the World Trade Center after its attack. And that sank in—and it’s in me. My first memory is of my mother ripping my brother and me out of bed in the middle of the winter night
column6: wrapping us in blankets
column7: and taking us up on a slope. In the distance
column8: at the end of the valley
column9: the entire night sky was red and orange and very slowly pulsing. She said the city of Rosenheim was burning. I was only two and a half. Normally
column10: memories do not go back that far
column11: but I know this was my very first memory
column12: and it’s embedded in my soul.

column1: Our conversation is taking place against the backdrop of the war in Ukraine.
War is always catastrophic. I made a film with Gorbachev
column2: “Meeting Gorbachev
column3: ” and what still resonates in me are things that he kept saying about how many opportunities were missed between the West and Russia to come to “normal terms.” I have seen footage of him in Canada
column4: where he was received like a rock star—that’s a different side of what could have been possible. It pains me. I worked in Kyiv many years ago
column5: as an actor
column6: and I worked in Russia
column7: making films. That’s how I sense the depth of the catastrophe.

column1: You said once that you felt as though we were entering an era of isolation. I couldn’t help but think of you when the pandemic was unfolding
column2: and whether or not you felt as though things were getting worse in that regard.

column1: I would like to see it from its quasi-opposite side: the enormous spread of social media. You can reach out to Nigeria and to New Zealand and to Uruguay with a single tweet
column2: and it may be read by millions. So we are not isolated. You break through isolation. However
column3: at the same time
column4: I do believe that
column5: on a deeper
column6: existential level
column7: our solitudes are increasing
column8: in reverse magnitude.

column1: You never use social media
column2: I assume.

column1: No
column2: I don’t. You may find me
column3: but they are complete forgeries. On the Internet
column4: you find people giving advice for the burning questions of your life with my imitated voice.

column1: How do you feel about all these tech billionaires going to space?
It’s a testosterone-laden competition. One person who sticks out is Elon Musk
column2: because he builds reusable rockets
column3: which I find a very fine and noble thing to do. But
column4: at the same time
column5: his idea to colonize Mars with a million people is an obscenity. We should look after the well-being of our planet
column6: rather than make an inhospitable place livable. You don’t have to be a scientist to know a colony on Mars is not going to happen. As for this race with Bezos and the other billionaires
column7: I think it’s a marketing design. It gives him the label of being—and I say it in quotes
column8: several times quotes around it—a “visionary
column9: ” meaning that if you want to buy an electric car
column10: don’t buy it from the Germans
column11: don’t buy it from the Chinese
column12: buy it from the “visionary.”

column1: Do you remember the first time you came to New York?
Yes
column2: I came to New York on a boat
column3: on the Bremen
column4: the same ship that brought Siegfried and Roy the year before. But they stayed and became magicians and moved to Las Vegas. I moved to Pittsburgh and had a scholarship there
column5: which was not very well thought through. I had a vague notion that I would like to go not to one of the Ivy League universities but to a city where there were still steelworkers. I had worked the night shift in a steel factory
column6: and I felt that was the place where I should go. But it was already the beginning of the Rust Belt. I left the scholarship very quickly and was basically homeless
column7: and was picked up by a wonderful family who incorporated me within minutes into their family. I have seen the very best of America
column8: so I’m very fond of my first experience here. Of course
column9: there are certain things for which I have ambivalent feelings
column10: but that’s O.K. My ambivalence toward Germany is even deeper
column11: and you probably have a certain ambivalence toward your own country
column12: Canada. Everyone has it
column13: in a way. But I had such a crazy
column14: wonderful
column15: deep
column16: and priceless time in America

column1: You’ve said that film allows us to delve into the least understood truths of man
column2: our dreams and nightmares. If that’s the level on which film operates
column3: on what level does literature operate?

column1: It somehow touches on a deep level that lives in all of us
column2: in most cases
column3: hidden away—a sense of poetry. People who do not read at all
column4: and do not read poetry or never have had contact with books
column5: still have that inside of them. I’m totally convinced. There’s something embedded in language that we can touch
column6: that we can make vibrate
column7: with literature
column8: with poetry.

column1: I still believe that literature is of very deep importance not only for our singular existence but for our collective experience. In the nineteen-seventies
column2: while making a toast
column3: I quoted a few sentences of Turgenev
column4: and my host toasted back by continuing the Turgenev story for the next five pages by heart. Through language
column5: you establish a togetherness of souls. I miss that. However
column6: not long ago
column7: I was in front of a room of thirty or forty people
column8: and quoted a verse of Hölderlin. Suddenly
column9: somebody was illuminated
column10: and that person came forward
column11: very close to me
column12: and started speaking with me as if nobody else were in the room. So perhaps you still do have that
column13: in a way.

column1: What is the place of literature now
column2: in your view?

column1: Certain things we have to accept. Fifty years ago
column2: prime-time American television showed Gore Vidal and Norman Mailer debating
column3: almost coming to blows. That’s gone
column4: and we have to acknowledge it. We can also observe something much more widespread: people read less. You even see it in academia. Students in the humanities
column5: and not just freshmen
column6: do not read
column7: or do not read enough. They have barely any knowledge of literature and deeper reading. That’s more alarming. Things have shifted very much into forms like tweets or Facebook entries or short messages.

column1: Does it bother you that people are now watching movies on tiny devices and laptop screens?
There is something big coming at us. Just as the movies shifted from silent movies to talkies
column2: so the location of having a collective experience in the movie theatre is dwindling away in favor of streaming platforms. I’m not insisting on movie theatres—although
column3: for me
column4: a movie theatre is still the mother of all battles. But there are things I have to come to terms with. Very young people not only watch a movie on their cellular phone
column5: they also speed it up to twice the speed if it’s too slow for them.

column1: Charlie Chaplin always looks like he’s moving at twice the speed of a normal person.
Eighteen frames per second. But
column2: of course
column3: there was a certain beauty. My favorite character in movies has been and still is Buster Keaton.

column1: There’s no illusion there—he’s really doing it.
Exactly. And it looks highly stylized
column2: but it is not.

column1: The moment when he’s standing there and the frame of the house collapses on him
column2: and he goes perfectly through the window.

column1: I rejoice for having seen that. It’s one of the all-time best moments in a movie ever.
Do contemporary novels interest you?
I read everything. I just read an autobiography
column2: “Forget Me Not
column3: ” by a woman who lives in Montana and was married to one of the great mountain climbers of his time. He perished in an avalanche
column4: some thirty years ago
column5: and the best friend of this mountain climber survived
column6: and
column7: returning home
column8: he immediately took care of the three boys of his best friend and took responsibility
column9: and he ended up falling head over heels in love with his friend’s wife and marrying her. It’s not that it’s great literature
column10: but I read it with fascination. Next thing
column11: I reach for Hölderlin. And next I reach for Diodorus Siculus
column12: an ancient Greek historian who is not very intelligent—he’s a dumb encyclopedist. But he becomes completely exuberant
column13: and a phenomenal writer
column14: when it comes to the father of Alexander the Great
column15: Philip II of Macedon
column16: and it’s like the most intense soap opera you’ve ever witnessed in your life
column17: outdoing all the Brazilian soap operas. So I’m very fond of Diodorus Siculus for that.

column1: Probably my favorite novelist is Thomas Bernhard. I know you’re a fan as well. Do you have any favorite books of his?
Almost everything that he has written. I never connected so deeply to his stage plays
column2: but I was at the world première of “Heldenplatz
column3: ” named after the square where Hitler first arrived in Austria
column4: after the Anschluss. The right wing threatened to invade the première of this play and incite fights in the theatre
column5: so I got myself a mouth guard and went. At the end
column6: they brought Bernhard out on stage. The actors took a bow
column7: and then they walked backward and came forward again and bowed again
column8: collectively. But Bernhard turned his back to the audience and walked with his face to the depths of the stage
column9: and then turned around and came toward the audience again
column10: in the opposite pattern of the actors.

column1: He didn’t often go to the theatre himself. He spent much of his time in his big farmhouse going in circles on his bicycle. Peter Handke told me about him. That’s how I got into him—Handke gave me “Das Kalkwerk” and he said
column2: “Read this
column3: read this. We have a great
column4: great writer emerging.”

column1: His project has resonance with your projects sometimes. His characters are always toiling on these great works that will never get finished—
Or they end up in vicious circles
column2: circles that could go on into infinity
column3: inescapable circles.

column1: I remember reading about your father
column2: and that he was always working on a futile book that never got written. He seemed a very Bernhardian character in a way.

column1: I never made that connection
column2: but you are right. On a superficial level
column3: the book was his pretext for not working and earning money; the woman had to raise the children and earn the money. But I’m absolutely convinced that he talked himself so deep into it that he believed in the existence of this fictitious great study—I think he really believed he was writing an important book
column4: and he never wrote a line. He actually lived his fiction
column5: and in a way you could see him in a context with Onoda.

column1: You once said that you believe that English literature was brought to a sort of dead end by “Finnegans Wake.”
Yes
column2: but I would say literature per se. I perceive a hard core of what constitutes storytelling
column3: and I have the feeling that sometimes literature has gone into a cul-de-sac. “Finnegans Wake” was clearly a cul-de-sac. Joyce worked toward it
column4: convinced that he would explore new terrain for literature
column5: but I do not think he discovered it—because nobody followed up
column6: number one
column7: and it is in disregard of what I see as the central quality of storytelling
column8: which you find in Joseph Conrad
column9: Hölderlin
column10: Virgil’s Georgics
column11: or even the Warren Commission’s report on the Kennedy assassination.

column1: Are you a fan of Joyce’s other works?
No
column2: I’ve never been a fan. I see the poet at work when it comes to “Ulysses
column3: ” the different forms of speech
column4: of language. The tools of the craft are being exposed
column5: and he is trying to show you how new his form of writing is. I have the same problem with actors. I do not like actors—and some of them are considered great actors—when I can see how they are acting. Bruno S. is the quintessential opposite of this. I’ve never seen an actor of his depth. There is something in him that deeply resonates with us
column6: something completely untechnical
column7: unstylized
column8: and unformalized.

column1: How did your great collaborator Klaus Kinski feel about your thinking that Bruno S. was the greatest actor you’d ever worked with?
I think he understood it. Kinski himself was furious when somebody would call him an actor
column2: because in a way much of what he does is stark-naked him—with a layer of training on top of it.

column1: Does art need to be more direct?
I don’t know exactly—it’s so primitive to label it like that
column2: but you immediately can tell when you read
column3: for example
column4: Emily Dickinson. You know it instantly: yes
column5: there’s a great poet.

column1: Your notion of “ecstatic truth” seems to have foreshadowed many trends of the twenty-first century: fake news
column2: virtual reality. In a way
column3: your theory has been vindicated by people’s attraction to these forms.

column1: Yes
column2: but I’m speaking of truth
column3: not news. I’m speaking about something that you cannot easily grasp. None of us knows what truth is
column4: so I touch it only with a pair of pliers when I use this word. But
column5: of course
column6: it has been caught up in many of the trends of today
column7: fake news and virtual realities. For example
column8: I read that Bruce Willis
column9: who retired from acting
column10: has sold the rights to his virtual persona for a commercial
column11: which re-creates his facial expressions and his voice. That’s something new and fascinating and stunning.

column1: It’s easy to see as well how ecstatic truth can be misinterpreted and run rampant.
Sure. And when I start to invent certain things—like quoting Blaise Pascal at the beginning of “Lessons of Darkness”—I declare myself. In interviews
column2: I have said this Pascal aphorism was invented by me to give a cosmic feeling
column3: the sense of a cosmic event taking place.

column1: Or the mountain range surrounded by mist that is
column2: in fact
column3: a tire track.

column1: A few inches tall. I do not conceal that I am inventing—but sometimes it’s good that you do not need to know that I’m inventive here or inventive there.
But let me say one thing about ecstatic truth. The simplest way to explain it is by looking at Michelangelo’s Pietà
column2: the statue. Jesus in the arms of Mary is a thirty-three-year-old man
column3: tormented on a cross and taken down
column4: but his mother is only seventeen. It’s one of the most beautiful sculptures that was ever created. And my question now is did Michelangelo try to cheat us
column5: did he try to give us fake news
column6: defraud us
column7: lie to us? The answer
column8: of course
column9: is no. He shows us a deeper truth of both figures.

column1: Inevitably
column2: you’re going to have a biographer.

column1: I hope it’s not going to happen. One of the reasons I’ve written my quote-unquote memoirs is to prevent that. There shouldn’t be a biography—there should be somebody pointing out this film and that film
column2: and how these films somehow make a person behind it visible. You don’t need to describe the person.

column1: I always had the feeling that it would be so wonderful to be anonymous. You can do it in literature
column2: like Ferrante
column3: and it is possible in painting
column4: like with Banksy. But I think both have been identified by now. Some miserable human critter published their real identities. Shame on them.

column1: Are there moments in your films that you would take back?
There are
column2: but I cannot. I threw away all my outtakes because a carpenter doesn’t sit on his shavings. But I’ve learned to live with all the mistakes. Every one of my films has certain mistakes
column3: and basically I’m cringing at the première. Sitting and seeing the film with an audience
column4: I wish I was not alive anymore. But within a week I come to terms with it. Yes
column5: it was me
column6: and nobody saw the mistakes anyway
column7: or hardly anyone. I don’t want to go back and reëdit my films or do some reshooting. You can pay me as much money as you want—I won’t do it.

column1: On the last page of Onoda’s memoir
column2: he’s travelling away from the island by helicopter
column3: and he looks down on his battlefield and asks himself a series of questions: “Why had I fought here for thirty years? Who had I been fighting for? What was the cause?” Do you have any answers for him?

column1: No. No. But it’s beautiful that his book ends like that.
My new book
column2: after this one
column3: ends in the middle of a sentence. I thought of Onoda
column4: who told me he could see a bullet coming at him from a distance
column5: in a strange glow
column6: and he would turn his body away
column7: and it wouldn’t hit the solar plexus for which it was aimed. It would whirr by. And I looked up
column8: because outside of the window I saw something shooting at me
column9: shining in orange and green
column10: and it was a hummingbird. Sometimes they shoot very straight. The moment where I was
column11: in the middle of writing
column12: I looked up and that’s it. The book ends all of a sudden
column13: literally in the middle of a sentence.

column1: So maybe you appreciate “Finnegans Wake” after all?
No
column2: because in my book the moment is derived from solid narrative. It’s embedded in storytelling.

column1: Do you find that the images exist in your mind already and you’re searching for the words to communicate them
column2: or do the images emerge in the act of writing itself?

column1: Quite often
column2: I stumble onto images
column3: like the ten thousand windmills
column4: but very often also the image starts to glow in the distance. I see this
column5: and I turn myself toward it. Where does this light come from? Where is this glimmer? Where does this glow emerge? I never have a plan. I never have any sort of board with yellow Post-its and the line of the story
column6: neither in writing nor in films. The story somehow has evolved in me
column7: or suddenly comes at me
column8: and I can write very fast. When I don’t know how to continue writing
column9: I just continue anyway. I walk once around the house for thirty seconds
column10: and then I continue writing
column11: and something emerges that was completely unknown thirty seconds before. It’s always worked.

column1: Do you listen to music while you write?
Yes
column2: most of the time. I blare it
column3: mostly Beethoven piano concertos. Somehow it has a certain level of excitement and dynamic and push. But sometimes I would listen to choral music from the Republic of Georgia.

column1: Do you prefer a room with a view
column2: or without?

column1: Mostly without. I see something outside the window
column2: like the hummingbird
column3: but it’s very narrow. When I wrote “Fitzcarraldo
column4: ” I was in San Francisco
column5: and Francis Ford Coppola offered me the use of his mansion on Broadway. There was a little turret with almost three-hundred-and-sixty-degree windows
column6: and I immediately decided to sit there and write. I gave myself ten days to compose the whole screenplay. From Coppola’s turret
column7: I could see the entire bay and the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz Island. I was completely mesmerized by what I saw out there
column8: and
column9: after two hours
column10: I noticed I had only half a page. So I turned my chair around. There was one segment with no window
column11: and with a ruler and a very sharp pencil
column12: I made a cross on this segment
column13: like the crosshairs in your binoculars. When I looked up from writing
column14: I would stare into the crosshairs and then continue."

column1: New Yorker;https://www.newyorker.com/news/us-journal/the-ordinary-americans-resettling-migrants-fleeing-war;2022-04-25;The Ordinary Americans Resettling Migrants Fleeing War;"After Trump eviscerated the refugee-resettlement system
column2: the government was unprepared for the large numbers of Afghans displaced by their country’s collapse. A new program lets civilians step up to help.

column1: Halima was an aspiring artist
column2: but her father had decided that she should become a civil engineer. She had received a full scholarship at the leading military academy in Afghanistan
column3: where
column4: in her third year
column5: she was first in her class of some five hundred students. “There were a few other girls in my engineering class at first
column6: ” she told me. “But
column7: by my third year
column8: I was the only one left.” As Taliban fighters approached the university
column9: Halima left her textbook open on her desk and rushed to escape
column10: grabbing only her passport. Her name and photograph were still posted on her dormitory door
column11: which could tip the Taliban off to her identity.

column1: Halima had nowhere to go; her family lived hours away. “The road was too dangerous
column2: ” she told me. “And if the Taliban found out who I was
column3: they would target my family.” She hid in the home of a kindly classmate whose father was out of the country. Soon afterward
column4: another classmate put her in touch with “Mr. Sam” and “Miss Tory
column5: ” handlers working with the U.S. military. The handlers directed her to the basement of a house
column6: where she hid with dozens of other women. (Halima requested that I use only her first name
column7: to protect her family.) For the next three months
column8: she was shuttled through a series of windowless safe houses with about eighty other female military personnel
column9: journalists
column10: and activists. Safe-house operators allowed them outside only to be hustled between hiding locations. “When you don’t see the sun for that long
column11: your bones begin to hurt
column12: ” she told me
column13: recently. Sometimes the women were crammed into spaces too small to lie down in
column14: so they curled up their knees and leaned against one another to sleep.

column1: Sadiqa Khalili
column2: who was twenty-seven
column3: had passed the entrance exam to become a pilot in the Afghan Air Force and was about to start training. “I sat in the dark
column4: just waiting for the Taliban to come
column5: ” she told me. “Everything I’d worked for my whole life had just vanished.” Amena Haidari
column6: twenty-eight
column7: and Halima Akbari
column8: twenty-five
column9: had both worked with Afghan commando units. “We whispered to one another about whether or not we should wipe our phones and destroy our passports
column10: ” Akbari told me. For the women’s security
column11: they were instructed not to talk to one another. Taliban fighters were raiding houses
column12: attempting to find unchaperoned girls. The less the women knew about one another
column13: the safer they would be if one were caught. “The Taliban tortures military girls like me
column14: ” Halima told me.

column1: [Support The New Yorker’s award-winning journalism. Subscribe today »]
In the darkness
column2: Halima’s phone buzzed with threatening messages from men claiming to be the Taliban fighters who’d raided her dormitory. One sent photos of burning textbooks. “You will never read these again
column3: ” he wrote. “We will find you
column4: you shameless girl who joined the military.” She wrote in her diary
column5: “Why is it a crime to be a girl in my country? I’m a poor girl in a land of terror with 1000s of hopes and dreams.” She drew in a sketchpad
column6: and
column7: when the other women saw her talent
column8: several asked Halima to draw their portraits. At night
column9: some women whispered into their phones
column10: letting their families know that they were alive. But Halima’s father had destroyed all photographs of her and deleted her number from his phone. He was frightened that
column11: if she called
column12: one of her younger siblings might overhear and tell other children in the village.

column1: The women soon learned that
column2: of the roughly eighty in hiding
column3: only the few with passports—including Halima
column4: Khalili
column5: Haidari
column6: and Akbari—would be able to leave the country. On November 10th
column7: at a safe house in Kabul
column8: Halima received an encrypted message that instructed her to hand her passport over to the safe-house manager. The manager left for several hours and returned with airplane tickets for the next day. “We’d been told we were leaving so many times that I didn’t know if it was really going to happen
column9: ” she said. On November 11th
column10: the four women boarded a flight to a U.S. base in Qatar. A month later
column11: they arrived at a military base called Fort Dix
column12: in New Jersey. At the base
column13: they spent their days learning English
column14: which no one but Halima had studied before. “At night
column15: we listened to music and relaxed
column16: which was really a new level of freedom for us
column17: ” Halima said. Some soldiers brought Halima canvases
column18: and she painted portraits of the women who had been left behind.

column1: Fort Dix was slated to close to Afghans in the following weeks. Military bases
column2: part of an emergency solution
column3: were never intended to house tens of thousands of new arrivals for lengthy periods; at other bases
column4: Afghans slept in tents in freezing temperatures. There was a push to get people off the bases as quickly as possible
column5: and the women were determined to find a new home together. “We know one another in a way that no one else can
column6: ” Akbari told me. But resettlement agencies had been gutted during the Trump years
column7: and no agency had enough capacity to take all four of them.

column1: Soon
column2: the women learned about a new kind of program
column3: called a Sponsor Circle
column4: through which civilian volunteers could sign up to resettle Afghans themselves. A group in Duluth
column5: Minnesota
column6: was willing to take the women in
column7: and to help them find jobs and attend a local university. “We Googled Duluth and saw how much snow there was
column8: ” Halima told me. “But their letter also said that they could help us continue our education
column9: and that was most important.” On the morning of Valentine’s Day
column10: they left for Duluth.

column1: This past winter
column2: American military veterans
column3: retired professors
column4: pastors
column5: and hundreds of others took a leading role in resettling displaced Afghans. They’ve met planes from U.S. bases
column6: found apartments
column7: co-signed leases
column8: puzzled through public-assistance paperwork
column9: and located halal meat. (One trick: head to Costco.) The Sponsor Circle program began last fall as an emergency response to the arrival of Afghans. But Lucretia Keenan
column10: a strategist for the program
column11: told me that it was also the culmination of efforts by organizers across the U.S. to ease conditions for newcomers in the wake of the global migration crisis. “This is part of a global movement
column12: ” she told me. The Sponsor Circle program is modelled on a successful
column13: decades-long citizen-led resettlement effort in Canada
column14: and a dozen other countries have recently started such programs. In the U.K.
column15: two hundred thousand people and organizations have expressed interest in housing Ukrainians displaced by the Russian invasion. Gregory Maniatis
column16: who works at the Open Society Foundations
column18: “It isn’t abstract. People are volunteering to host Ukrainians in their own homes for six months.”

column1: In some ways
column2: Sponsor Circles recall the best of earlier ad-hoc methods of refugee resettlement. In the eighteen-hundreds and early nineteen-hundreds
column3: religious organizations and their grassroots networks were the primary institutions working to resettle immigrants in America; many saw it as part of a theological calling. But in 1980
column4: after Congress passed the Refugee Act
column5: which outlined the basic tenets of asylum and established the Office of Refugee Resettlement
column6: the process of welcoming refugees became professionalized; since then
column7: almost all refugees have been resettled through the federal bureaucracy. The Refugee Act also granted the President authority over the number of refugees allowed to enter the country. When Trump came to power
column8: he used the Refugee Act
column9: as well as a series of executive orders collectively known as the Muslim ban to block refugees from entering the country. According to the National Immigration Forum
column10: in the fiscal year of 2016
column11: eighty-five thousand refugees entered the U.S.; in the 2020 fiscal year
column12: that number was less than twelve thousand. Federal funding of resettlement agencies is tied to how many refugees arrive in the U.S.
column13: and dwindling numbers meant slashed budgets. “Something like one-third of resettlement offices lost their funding
column14: ” Maniatis said.

column1: When the Taliban captured Kabul last August and hundreds of thousands of Afghans headed for the exits
column2: their pathway to the U.S. was in shambles. Closed offices and a dearth of caseworkers made it impossible to resettle so many displaced people so quickly. In response
column3: Sarah Krause
column4: the executive director of a nonprofit called Community Sponsorship Hub
column5: and others scrambled to create a program that would allow ordinary citizens to help out. During the past seven months
column6: some fifteen hundred volunteers in more than twenty-five states have formed about a hundred and seventy-five Sponsor Circles to help welcome several thousand Afghans. “Groups have come forward as far away as Alaska
column7: ” Krause told me.

column1: In Duluth
column2: Charlotte Frantz
column3: a semi-retired pastor’s assistant at Peace Church
column4: asked her congregation if they wanted to participate in the program. “We were wondering what we could do
column5: ” she told me. Peace Church
column6: a place decorated with rainbow bowls and worry stones
column7: has a history of activism. In the eighties
column8: some of its members belonged to the Overground Railroad
column9: a network that smuggled undocumented migrants over the border to Canada. After Trump ramped up deportations in Minnesota
column10: Frantz remodelled part of the Peace Church basement as a sanctuary for people fearing deportation. Duluth is more than a hundred and fifty miles from the nearest resettlement agency—which
column11: in the past
column12: would have ruled the community approach out
column13: but the new program made it an option. Terrie Shannon
column14: a seventy-eight-year-old retired education professor
column15: agreed to lead the circle. “I said yes partly in defiance of the people in this county who supported Trump’s executive order to ban immigrants
column16: ” she told me. None had any experience with resettling immigrants or with Afghanistan. “Duluth isn’t really very international

column1: On February 14th
column2: Halima
column3: Haidari
column4: Khalili
column5: and Akbari landed at Duluth’s tiny airport. “We were terrified
column6: ” Halima said. “We didn’t know who would be waiting.” Eight older people stood holding neon signs that read “Welcome to Duluth.” They smiled but held back
column7: afraid that Afghan custom might bar them from touching the women. But Akbari rushed forward to hug Shannon. “We could tell by their faces that these were kind people
column8: ” Akbari told me. A group of Benedictine sisters had agreed to house the women temporarily in a retreat center. Frantz and a colleague
column9: along with the sisters
column10: had scoured the bedrooms
column11: removing crosses and icons of saints so the newcomers would feel welcome. Late the first evening
column12: the women arrived at the center and found four deer outside in the snow. The volunteers pointed them out in hushed tones
column13: but Halima and the others grew concerned and asked if the deer were dangerous. “We didn’t know if they might attack us
column14: ” Akbari said.

column1: The women weren’t allowed to work until their paperwork was sorted out
column2: so they spent their days padding around the retreat center in slippers crocheted by the sisters. The women began calling Shannon “Grandmother.” One afternoon
column3: Halima invited her over to speak with her mother on FaceTime
column4: and both older women started to cry. “I swore a sacred promise to her that I would take care of her daughter
column5: ” Shannon told me. The young women were polite and quick to smile
column6: but any mention of life at home made them grow grim. They worried about the women they had left behind. “We want so badly for them to find a way out
column7: too
column8: ” Akbari said. They wanted to send the pocket money they received from the Sponsor Circle—fifteen dollars a week—home to their relatives
column9: some of whom were near starvation owing to an ongoing famine. But the volunteers worried that too much financial support would muddy the scope of their commitment to the women. Frantz
column10: who had adopted a son from Guatemala and had experience with the complexity of distant entanglements
column11: said
column12: “We could set up a dependency we really can’t sustain.” In the end
column13: though
column14: the volunteers helped Haidari wire money home to her father
column15: who was sick.

column1: Frustrations mounted. For Halima
column2: Haidari
column3: Khalili
column4: and Akbari
column5: life as a high-ranking student or professional was over. “We really don’t fit in here yet
column6: and we don’t know the language
column7: ” Akbari said. The women had been given donated computers that were nearly useless. They needed to apply for public assistance
column8: but the system was byzantine. They had entered the country on “humanitarian parole
column9: ” which
column10: unlike refugee status
column11: did not guarantee that
column12: among other things
column13: they could stay indefinitely
column14: and meant that they still needed to apply for asylum. But many private immigration lawyers were overwhelmed and increasingly expensive. “They are charging exorbitant rates to the most vulnerable people
column15: ” Frantz said.

column1: Still
column2: the women found fun where they could. They went clothes shopping
column3: and
column4: after months of washing their hair with dish soap in the safe houses
column5: they each chose their own shampoo. They went to a potluck dinner at the only mosque in northeastern Minnesota. They baked bread and sang songs with the sisters. They played volleyball in the driveway and tried out snowshoeing. One weekend
column6: members of the Sponsor Circle offered to take the four women on a church snow-tubing trip. The night before
column7: however
column8: when a volunteer read them the waivers that they’d need to sign
column9: the women decided not to go. Why
column10: after risking their lives to escape Afghanistan
column11: would they volunteer to do something that might break their legs? “We thought it must be something very dangerous
column12: ” Khalili told me.

column1: Earlier this year
column2: I worked with several friends to set up a Sponsor Circle to help resettle five Afghan siblings and their families—all relatives of a journalist I had worked with while reporting in Afghanistan. The siblings were stuck at Fort McCoy
column3: in Wisconsin
column4: and were told that no resettlement agency could take all of them. To insure that they wouldn’t be separated
column5: my friends—including Maria Aini
column6: an Afghan American doctor who had come to Pennsylvania as a refugee when she was eight—agreed to help. The siblings’ aging mother speaks only Pashto
column7: so it was important that they be within walking distance of a community of Pashto speakers. We found them temporary housing at the Virginia Theological Seminary
column8: in a professor’s empty home
column9: which was large and sunny. One of our volunteers
column10: an attorney
column11: helped them with the process of seeking asylum. Three of the siblings now have jobs in customer service
column12: and one of them recently had a baby. But every victory is tinged with a larger sadness for their relatives who remain in Afghanistan. “I feel like a bird whose nest has been snatched away
column13: ” the siblings’ mother told me. “I’ve been made to fly far away and leave two of my children behind.”

column1: One of the most critical factors in the successful integration of immigrants is their ability to find a community
column2: and Sponsor Circles help to create local bonds. “It’s proven to make a difference in whether or not refugees succeed
column3: ” David Miliband
column4: the president and C.E.O. of the International Rescue Committee
column5: told me. Maniatis
column6: from the Open Society Foundations
column7: told me that he hopes that involving Americans directly in resettlement efforts will help to combat anti-immigrant sentiment: “This is infrastructure that engages a community in social issues and places people at the center of the solution.” Following the success of the Sponsor Circle program
column8: the Biden Administration has decided to launch a larger sponsorship program
column9: which will be implemented later this year. The Administration recently committed to welcoming a hundred thousand refugees from Ukraine
column10: and some of them will be resettled through the new sponsorship program. “The Sponsor Circle Program for Afghans has shown that everyday Americans and community groups across the country are willing and able to step up in extraordinary ways
column11: ” a State Department spokesperson told me. “The experience to date demonstrates the powerful and impactful role that Americans from all walks of life can play as they seek to welcome Afghans and now Ukrainians arriving in their communities.”

column1: But Sponsor Circles also face challenges. The program requires that volunteers raise at least two thousand two hundred and seventy-five dollars per newcomer
column2: and pledge to help out for a minimum of three months. “It’s nowhere near enough
column3: ” Embry Howell
column4: a health-policy expert and a member of a Sponsor Circle in the D.C. area
column5: told me. Sponsor Circles also lack the experience of government agencies
column6: including knowledge about how to access social workers and how to navigate the labyrinthine systems that govern Social Security and other benefits. Howell told me that one woman she works with experiences severe anxiety when using the elevator in their building—which makes it difficult for her to leave the house. “She doesn’t speak English
column7: all of her family is in Afghanistan
column8: and mental health is really the missing piece.”

column1: In Duluth
column2: Halima and the others soon found work in the kitchen of an assisted-living and health-care center associated with the Benedictine sisters. The jobs paid only thirteen dollars and thirty-three cents an hour
column3: but they came with a signing bonus of five hundred dollars. “As soon as I get that
column4: I’m sending the money home
column5: ” Halima told me. Within three weeks
column6: the Sponsor Circle had found them a place to live
column7: at a house that was formerly a rental property
column8: and sent over a team of volunteer builders to renovate it. The night before they moved in
column9: the Sponsor Circle held a last pizza party at the retreat center. (Some of the volunteers were surprised to find that the women
column10: cosmopolitan Kabulis
column11: had had pizza many times before.) The room was warm and cozy. Shannon had sewn the girls cloth bags as presents
column12: and drew numbers to determine a fair order in which each could pick a bag. “We’re just thrilled that you chose Duluth
column13: ” Shannon said. Halima replied
column14: “We are really happy that you are friendly people.”

column1: It was eight degrees below zero the next morning
column2: as the women packed the last of their duffels and drove several miles to their new home. All four set to work making their beds
column3: unpacking newly acquired knickknacks
column4: including Christmas ornaments
column5: pieces of costumes
column6: and a sparkly magic wand that Halima had collected at a church rummage sale. Akbari hung the Christmas ornaments from a light pull in her room. Halima unpacked her sketches. Flipping through them
column7: she stopped at the faces of women she’d left behind in the safe house. “They’ve moved now
column8: ” she told me. “We text with them on Facebook
column9: and every time they text with us asking our sponsors to help them.” She pulled out one painting she’d done at Fort Dix
column10: a portrait of her father
column11: and propped it on her bedside table
column12: behind her magic wand."

column1: New Yorker;https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/the-new-nuclear-reality;2022-04-23;The New Nuclear Reality;"Russia’s war in Ukraine has reawakened fears about the bomb—and endangered the principle of deterrence.
Vladimir Putin’s war in Ukraine has jolted the world back into an uncomfortable consciousness of the nuclear threat. In the past month
column2: official warnings have emerged at a striking pace. “Given the potential desperation of President Putin and the Russian leadership
column3: given the setbacks that they’ve faced so far militarily
column4: none of us can take lightly the threat posed by a potential resort to tactical nuclear weapons or low-yield nuclear weapons
column5: ” William Burns
column6: the C.I.A. director and a former ambassador to Russia
column7: warned on April 14th. The U.S. assessment of when and why Moscow might use such weaponry has changed
column8: Lieutenant General Scott D. Berrier
column9: the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency
column10: conceded in testimony to a House Armed Services subcommittee. A prolonged war in Ukraine will sap Russia’s manpower and matériel
column11: while sanctions will throw the nation into an economic depression and undermine its ability to produce more precision-guided munitions and conventional arms
column12: he said. “As this war and its consequences slowly weaken Russian conventional strength
column13: Russia likely will increasingly rely on its nuclear deterrent to signal the West and project strength to its internal and external audiences.” Putin’s aggression is “reviving fears” of a more “militaristic Russia.”

column1: The Kremlin’s successful test
column2: on April 20th
column3: of a missile capable of flying at hypersonic speeds and carrying up to ten nuclear warheads anywhere in the world—and of outsmarting defense systems—contributed to the ominous optics. “This truly unique weapon will force all who are trying to threaten our country in the heat of frenzied
column4: aggressive rhetoric to think twice
column5: ” Putin boasted on state television. Last month
column6: Washington cancelled its own test of an intercontinental missile to “manage escalation
column7: ” the Secretary of Defense
column8: Lloyd Austin
column9: testified.

column1: Russia has not yet repositioned its nuclear forces
column2: Burns said
column3: despite sabre-rattling about a heightened state of readiness. Nor is its new missile ready for deployment. But Putin’s reckless war now has a “distinct nuclear dimension”—with lessons that extend far beyond Ukraine and that will endure after the war is over
column4: the Arms Control Association in Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: concluded this month. Putin’s invasion “underscores the reality that nuclear weapons don’t prevent major wars
column7: ” Daryl Kimball
column8: the organization’s executive director
column9: told me. “U.S. and NATO nuclear weapons have proven to be useless in preventing Russian aggression against Ukraine.” The war has imperilled a long-standing premise of deterrence—having a bomb to avoid being bombed. Kimball reflected
column10: “When nuclear deterrence fails
column11: it fails catastrophically.”

column1: [Support The New Yorker’s award-winning journalism. Subscribe today »]
The war in Ukraine underscores an even bigger problem. The infrastructure of global security—like the bridges
column2: railways
column3: and power grids that make up our physical infrastructure—is decaying. The challenge ahead is to devise a new or more stable security architecture—with treaties
column4: verification tools
column5: oversight
column6: and enforcement—to replace the eroding models established after the last major war in Europe ended
column7: seventy-seven years ago.

column1: Putin’s invasion has also exposed changes to the global balance of nuclear power. Shortly before his retirement last month
column2: I sat down with Kenneth (Frank) McKenzie
column3: Jr.
column4: a four-star general who once wore a key around his neck that unlocked sensitive material necessary for the President to respond to a nuclear crisis. In what feels like a throwback to the Cold War and his early days as a young marine officer
column5: he said
column6: the U.S. is again focussed on nuclear threats from Moscow.  Only the capabilities have reversed. During the Cold War
column7: between 1945 and 1989
column8: Washington advanced its nuclear arsenal to counter Moscow’s growing might in conventional arms. In 1954
column9: it tested a weapon a thousand times more powerful than Little Boy
column10: the devastating bomb dropped on Hiroshima. America even produced nuclear land mines. After the Soviets got the bomb
column11: the U.S. still had an eight-to-one advantage in nuclear capabilities during the Cuban missile crisis
column12: in 1962. By the Cold War’s end
column13: the U.S. had developed a “capability and capacity edge
column14: really
column15: over the rest of the world that appeared insurmountable
column16: ” McKenzie said.

column1: After the Soviet Union’s collapse
column2: the Pentagon “took a holiday” from studying high-end warfare
column3: the general told me. “We looked away
column4: ” he said. The U.S. was drawn into a war in Afghanistan after the 9/11 attacks
column6: and then opted to invade Iraq
column7: in 2003. McKenzie was deployed in both wars. The U.S. focussed on conventional conflicts and insurgencies
column8: while  Russia
column9: under Putin
column10: built up its nuclear arsenal. Today
column11: U.S. and Russian capabilities have “completely inverted
column12: ” McKenzie said. The U.S. has superiority in conventional arms
column13: while Moscow has more nuclear weapons—and more options to deliver them.

column1: The type of nuclear weapons most at issue has also changed. There’s more than one. The U.S. dropped two strategic nuclear bombs on Japan. Strategic weapons are long-range—they travel some three thousand miles—and produce high-yield explosions. They can destroy vast swaths of land and any human within range. Russia currently has just over six thousand strategic warheads; the U.S. has fifty-five hundred. Beginning in the nineteen-seventies
column2: the two countries negotiated several treaties to limit strategic weapons
column3: though all but one have since been scrapped. The New START treaty is the only surviving bilateral pact; it was extended for five years shortly after Biden’s Inauguration
column4: but it seems more tenuous now.

column1: The other type of nuclear weapons are tactical
column2: or nonstrategic
column3: which the U.S. is more worried about today. They are shorter-range—they travel up to three hundred miles—and often have lower-yield warheads. (Some
column4: though
column5: carry more kilotons than the Hiroshima bomb.) They are designed to take out tank or troop formations on a battlefield—not wipe out a city. In the history of nuclear weapons
column6: there has never been a treaty—bilateral or international—that limits developing or deploying tactical nukes anywhere. During the Cold War
column7: the U.S. and the Soviet Union produced thousands each
column8: with Moscow controlling up to twenty-five thousand. Afterward
column9: the U.S. dismantled most of its tactical arsenal and withdrew most of those weapons from Europe. Russia kept more of its stockpile. There is now a vast disparity in tactical arsenals. Last month
column10: the Congressional Research Service reported that Russia has up to two thousand tactical nukes
column11: while the U.S. has around two hundred.

column1: Today
column2: Russia also has many more delivery systems for tactical nuclear weapons—submarine torpedoes
column3: ballistic missiles on land or sea
column4: artillery shells
column5: and aircraft—while the U.S. has only gravity bombs that can be dropped from warplanes. “They have more diverse capabilities than we do
column6: ” McKenzie concluded. More than a hundred U.S. tactical nukes are again situated in Europe
column7: at bases in five NATO countries: Belgium
column8: Germany
column9: the Netherlands
column10: Italy
column11: and Turkey. Most of Russia’s are on its western front
column12: near the borders of NATO members.

column1: Four scenarios may lead Russia to use a nuclear weapon
column2: according to Kimball of the Arms Control Association. To coerce Kyiv or its NATO allies to back down
column3: Putin could carry out a “demonstration” bombing in the atmosphere above the Arctic Ocean or the Baltic Sea—not for killing
column4: but “to remind everyone that Russia has nuclear weapons.” Russia could also use tactical weapons to change the military balance on the ground with Ukraine. If the war expands
column5: and NATO gets drawn into the fight
column6: Russia could further escalate the conflict with the use of short-range nuclear weapons. “Both U.S. and Russian policy leave open the possibility of using nuclear weapons in response to an extreme non-nuclear threat
column7: ” Kimball said. Finally
column8: if Putin believes that the Russian state (or leadership) is at risk
column9: he might use a tactical nuclear weapon to “save Russia from a major military defeat.” Russia has lost some twenty-five per cent of its combat power in the last two months
column10: a Pentagon official estimated this week. Moscow’s military doctrine reserves the right to use nuclear weapons “in response to the use of nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction” against Russia or its allies
column11: and also in response to aggression via conventional weapons “when the very existence of the state is threatened.” In military jargon
column12: the country’s policy is “to escalate to de-escalate
column13: ” Richard Burt
column14: the lead negotiator on the original START accord
column15: which was signed by Gorbachev and George H. W. Bush in 1991
column16: told me. “The idea is to so shock the adversary that a nuclear weapon has been used
column17: to demonstrate your resolve that you’re willing to use a nuclear weapon
column18: that you paralyze your adversary.”

column1: The new nuclear reality poses another challenge: how to limit nuclear weapons beyond Russia and the United States. Nine nations now have nuclear capabilities. Putin’s war undermines the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons
column2: the cornerstone of international arms control since 1968. It is the only binding commitment—now signed by almost two hundred states—that seeks to disarm those nations which have the bomb and to prevent others from getting it. The treaty is based on the U.N. Charter
column3: which stipulates that all nations must refrain “from the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state.”

column1: Since the nineteen-sixties
column2: experts have debated whether Washington and Moscow would use a limited number of tactical nuclear weapons on a conventional battlefield—for example
column3: to destroy a military position or gain a chunk of territory. “The answer is no
column4: ” Kimball said. “There is nothing like a limited nuclear war.” At the end of his military career
column5: McKenzie
column6: who spent more than four decades preparing for wars of all kinds
column7: reflected on the nuclear stakes. “We should be rattled right now
column8: ” he said. “I am rattled. I’m concerned about where we are.” Three decades after Gorbachev’s speech
column9: the respite now seems illusory."

column1: In our collective memory
column2: America immediately rose to the challenge of Hitler. But
column3: of course
column4: that’s not really true—after Hitler had attacked the Sudetenland and Poland and even France
column5: America was content to let Europe fight its own wars. In the winter of 1940
column6: Gallup found that just twelve per cent of Americans wanted to declare war on Germany. Later in the fall

column8: for instance—opposed even President Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s lend-lease plan to send matériel to defend Europe. Meanwhile
column9: the America First movement attracted a wide following
column10: which included a young John Kennedy and Gerald Ford
column11: not to mention Walt Disney—and
column12: notoriously

column14: Jr.
column15: who later became the U.S. Ambassador to the United Kingdom and the president of Yale; in those years
column16: though
column18: he organized across America to keep the country from being “entrapped” in foreign wars."

column1: New Yorker;https://www.newyorker.com/news/letter-from-europe/the-french-far-right-comes-on-little-cat-feet;2022-04-22;The French Far Right Comes on Little Cat Feet;"After years of seeing Marine Le Pen as a dangerous extreme
column2: many voters now see her as a politician like any other.

column1: Jean-Marie’s daughter
column2: Marine
column3: was running in the French Presidential election for the second time that year
column4: and I was there to profile him for the Washington Post. On April 24th
column5: she will again face off against Emmanuel Macron
column6: in the final round of the vote. The two sparred in a lengthy debate on April 20th
column7: during which Macron hammered Marine for her admiration of Vladimir Putin and reliance on a Russian bank
column8: and she attacked him for ignoring the plight of ordinary citizens. The far right has not been this close to power in France since 1944. Marine has styled herself as a candidate of almost grandmotherly compassion
column9: focussing on the rising cost of living and posing for photos with her cats. Although she is likely to lose

column12: who say that she has listened to their economic concerns while Macron
column13: preoccupied by the war in Ukraine
column14: has barely bothered to campaign."

New Yorker;https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/the-long-holy-war-behind-putins-political-war-in-ukraine;2022-04-21;The Long Holy War Behind Putin’s Political War in Ukraine;"Eastern Orthodox and Catholic leaders in the U.S. weigh in on the Russian invasion—and the Russian Orthodox Church.
Since March 6th
column2: when Kirill

New Yorker;https://www.newyorker.com/news/dispatch/the-siege-of-chernihiv;2022-04-15;The Siege of Chernihiv;For more than a month
column2: the Russian military pummelled residents with bombing raids and missile fire
column3: turning a locked-in Ukrainian city into an urban death trap.

column1: In the middle of March
column2: bulldozers dug trenches in an unused field at the edge of the Yalovshchina cemetery
column3: in the city of Chernihiv
column4: in northern Ukraine. By that point
column5: Chernihiv had been under effective blockade for more than two weeks
column6: with most buildings left without electricity
column7: heat
column8: or water. Roads and bridges leading out of town had either been bombed or were now the site of active battles between Russian and Ukrainian forces. All the while
column9: the Russian military pummelled Chernihiv with bombing raids and missile fire
column10: turning a locked-in city into an urban death trap. As many as fifty people were killed each day
column11: struck down while in line for food or huddling in their apartments.

column1: Where to bury them? The city’s main cemetery
column2: on the northern outskirts of town
column3: was under constant bombardment. Supply routes were blocked
column4: and no factories or workshops were open
column5: which meant it wasn’t possible to produce enough caskets to keep up with the bodies piling up at the morgue. Finally a solution was reached: during episodic lulls in bombardment
column6: city workers would pick up a dozen or so bodies at a time
column7: put them in caskets cobbled together from spare wood
column8: and lower them into the ground beneath a muddy field at the Yalovshchina cemetery."

column6: the war in Ukraine

column8: ” and dark forces that he believed would use atomic weapons to “streamline

column2: a Ukraine Tragedy Foretold;"But what can Biden really do to stop Putin?

column1: President Biden said the right things. The expected things. His words were blunt and unequivocal. On Thursday

column3: the American President stepped into the East Room of the White House and condemned Putin for his “sinister vision
column4: ” his “naked aggression
column5: ” and his evil
column6: unprovoked war of choice. He called him a bully and a liar and a tyrant. He vowed to make Putin and his outlaw Russian regime a “pariah on the international stage.” He announced sanctions that he claimed “exceed anything that’s ever been done.” But what words
column7: really
column8: could be equal to this moment
column9: to this day when Europe faces what may be the most dangerous and consequential war on the continent since the Second World War?

column1: As Biden spoke
column2: Ukraine was fighting—alone—against overwhelming military odds. There was a pitched battle in the nuclear hellscape that the Soviet Union left behind in Chernobyl. In Kyiv
column3: air-raid sirens sounded for what must have been the first time since the Second World War

column5: there were thousands of men
column6: women
column7: and children cowering in subway stations and makeshift shelters
column8: clutching their iPhones and wondering how their twenty-first-century lives had turned overnight into a replay of twentieth-century horrors."
